Parsing [sent. 23 len. 16]: Michaelmas term lately over , and the Lord Chancellor sitting in Lincoln 's Inn Hall .

Parsing [sent. 28 len. 11]: Horses , scarcely better ; splashed to their very blinkers .

Parsing [sent. 35 len. 37]: Chance people on the bridges peeping over the parapets into a nether sky of fog , with fog all round them , as if they were up in a balloon and hanging in the misty clouds .

Parsing [sent. 37 len. 27]: Most of the shops lighted two hours before their time -- as the gas seems to know , for it has a haggard and unwilling look .
Parsing [sent. 38 len. 39]: The raw afternoon is rawest , and the dense fog is densest , and the muddy streets are muddiest near that leaden-headed old obstruction , appropriate ornament for the threshold of a leaden-headed old corporation , Temple Bar .
Parsing [sent. 39 len. 32]: And hard by Temple Bar , in Lincoln 's Inn Hall , at the very heart of the fog , sits the Lord High Chancellor in his High Court of Chancery .
Parsing [sent. 40 len. 50]: Never can there come fog too thick , never can there come mud and mire too deep , to assort with the groping and floundering condition which this High Court of Chancery , most pestilent of hoary sinners , holds this day in the sight of heaven and earth .
Parsing [sent. 41 len. 78]: On such an afternoon , if ever , the Lord High Chancellor ought to be sitting her -- as here he is -- with a foggy glory round his head , softly fenced in with crimson cloth and curtains , addressed by a large advocate with great whiskers , a little voice , and an interminable brief , and outwardly directing his contemplation to the lantern in the roof , where he can see nothing but fog .
Parsing [sent. 42 len. 76]: On such an afternoon some score of members of the High Court of Chancery bar ought to be -- as here they are -- mistily engaged in one of the ten thousand stages of an endless cause , tripping one another up on slippery precedents , groping knee-deep in technicalities , running their goat-hair and horsehair warded heads against walls of words and making a pretence of equity with serious faces , as players might .
Parsing [sent. 43 len. 40]: On such an afternoon the various solicitors in the cause , some two or three of whom have inherited it from their fathers , who made a fortune by it , ought to be -- as are they not ?
Parsing [sent. 44 len. 69]: -- ranged in a line , in a long matted well -LRB- but you might look in vain for truth at the bottom of it -RRB- between the registrar 's red table and the silk gowns , with bills , cross-bills , answers , rejoinders , injunctions , affidavits , issues , references to masters , masters ' reports , mountains of costly nonsense , piled before them .
Parsing [sent. 45 len. 117]: Well may the court be dim , with wasting candles here and there ; well may the fog hang heavy in it , as if it would never get out ; well may the stained-glass windows lose their colour and admit no light of day into the place ; well may the uninitiated from the streets , who peep in through the glass panes in the door , be deterred from entrance by its owlish aspect and by the drawl , languidly echoing to the roof from the padded dais where the Lord High Chancellor looks into the lantern that has no light in it and where the attendant wigs are all stuck in a fog-bank !
Parsing [sent. 46 len. 132]: This is the Court of Chancery , which has its decaying houses and its blighted lands in every shire , which has its worn-out lunatic in every madhouse and its dead in every churchyard , which has its ruined suitor with his slipshod heels and threadbare dress borrowing and begging through the round of every man 's acquaintance , which gives to monied might the means abundantly of wearying out the right , which so exhausts finances , patience , courage , hope , so overthrows the brain and breaks the heart , that there is not an honourable man among its practitioners who would not give -- who does not often give -- the warning , `` Suffer any wrong that can be done you rather than come here ! ''
Parsing [sent. 47 len. 43]: Who happen to be in the Lord Chancellor 's court this murky afternoon besides the Lord Chancellor , the counsel in the cause , two or three counsel who are never in any cause , and the well of solicitors before mentioned ?
Parsing [sent. 48 len. 39]: There is the registrar below the judge , in wig and gown ; and there are two or three maces , or petty-bags , or privy purses , or whatever they may be , in legal court suits .

Parsing [sent. 51 len. 6]: Their places are a blank .
Parsing [sent. 52 len. 56]: Standing on a seat at the side of the hall , the better to peer into the curtained sanctuary , is a little mad old woman in a squeezed bonnet who is always in court , from its sitting to its rising , and always expecting some incomprehensible judgment to be given in her favour .
Parsing [sent. 53 len. 26]: Some say she really is , or was , a party to a suit , but no one knows for certain because no one cares .
Parsing [sent. 54 len. 23]: She carries some small litter in a reticule which she calls her documents , principally consisting of paper matches and dry lavender .
Parsing [sent. 55 len. 68]: A sallow prisoner has come up , in custody , for the half-dozenth time to make a personal application `` to purge himself of his contempt , '' which , being a solitary surviving executor who has fallen into a state of conglomeration about accounts of which it is not pretended that he had ever any knowledge , he is not at all likely ever to do .
Parsing [sent. 56 len. 10]: In the meantime his prospects in life are ended .

Parsing [sent. 58 len. 13]: in a voice of sonorous complaint on the instant of his rising .

Parsing [sent. 60 len. 6]: Jarndyce and Jarndyce drones on .
Parsing [sent. 61 len. 24]: This scarecrow of a suit has , in course of time , become so complicated that no man alive knows what it means .
Parsing [sent. 62 len. 37]: The parties to it understand it least , but it has been observed that no two Chancery lawyers can talk about it for five minutes without coming to a total disagreement as to all the premises .
Parsing [sent. 63 len. 26]: Innumerable children have been born into the cause ; innumerable young people have married into it ; innumerable old people have died out of it .
Parsing [sent. 64 len. 29]: Scores of persons have deliriously found themselves made parties in Jarndyce and Jarndyce without knowing how or why ; whole families have inherited legendary hatreds with the suit .
Parsing [sent. 65 len. 37]: The little plaintiff or defendant who was promised a new rocking-horse when Jarndyce and Jarndyce should be settled has grown up , possessed himself of a real horse , and trotted away into the other world .
Parsing [sent. 66 len. 82]: Fair wards of court have faded into mothers and grandmothers ; a long procession of Chancellors has come in and gone out ; the legion of bills in the suit have been transformed into mere bills of mortality ; there are not three Jarndyces left upon the earth perhaps since old Tom Jarndyce in despair blew his brains out at a coffee-house in Chancery Lane ; but Jarndyce and Jarndyce still drags its dreary length before the court , perennially hopeless .
Parsing [sent. 67 len. 9]: Jarndyce and Jarndyce has passed into a joke .
Parsing [sent. 68 len. 12]: That is the only good that has ever come of it .
Parsing [sent. 69 len. 16]: It has been death to many , but it is a joke in the profession .
Parsing [sent. 70 len. 12]: Every master in Chancery has had a reference out of it .
Parsing [sent. 71 len. 21]: Every Chancellor was `` in it , '' for somebody or other , when he was counsel at the bar .

Parsing [sent. 73 len. 15]: Articled clerks have been in the habit of fleshing their legal wit upon it .
Parsing [sent. 74 len. 62]: The last Lord Chancellor handled it neatly , when , correcting Mr. Blowers , the eminent silk gown who said that such a thing might happen when the sky rained potatoes , he observed , `` or when we get through Jarndyce and Jarndyce , Mr. Blowers '' -- a pleasantry that particularly tickled the maces , bags , and purses .
Parsing [sent. 75 len. 27]: How many people out of the suit Jarndyce and Jarndyce has stretched forth its unwholesome hand to spoil and corrupt would be a very wide question .
Parsing [sent. 76 len. 58]: From the master upon whose impaling files reams of dusty warrants in Jarndyce and Jarndyce have grimly writhed into many shapes , down to the copying-clerk in the Six Clerks ' Office who has copied his tens of thousands of Chancery folio-pages under that eternal heading , no man 's nature has been made better by it .

Parsing [sent. 81 len. 74]: Shirking and sharking in all their many varieties have been sown broadcast by the ill-fated cause ; and even those who have contemplated its history from the outermost circle of such evil have been insensibly tempted into a loose way of letting bad things alone to take their own bad course , and a loose belief that if the world go wrong it was in some off-hand manner never meant to go right .

Parsing [sent. 118 len. 24]: Chapter II -- In Fashion It is but a glimpse of the world of fashion that we want on this same miry afternoon .
Parsing [sent. 119 len. 27]: It is not so unlike the Court of Chancery but that we may pass from the one scene to the other , as the crow flies .
Parsing [sent. 120 len. 58]: Both the world of fashion and the Court of Chancery are things of precedent and usage : oversleeping Rip Van Winkles who have played at strange games through a deal of thundery weather ; sleeping beauties whom the knight will wake one day , when all the stopped spits in the kitchen shall begin to turn prodigiously !
Parsing [sent. 121 len. 7]: It is not a large world .
Parsing [sent. 122 len. 46]: Relatively even to this world of ours , which has its limits too -LRB- as your Highness shall find when you have made the tour of it and are come to the brink of the void beyond -RRB- , it is a very little speck .
Parsing [sent. 123 len. 23]: There is much good in it ; there are many good and true people in it ; it has its appointed place .
Parsing [sent. 124 len. 46]: But the evil of it is that it is a world wrapped up in too much jeweller 's cotton and fine wool , and can not hear the rushing of the larger worlds , and can not see them as they circle round the sun .
Parsing [sent. 125 len. 17]: It is a deadened world , and its growth is sometimes unhealthy for want of air .
Parsing [sent. 126 len. 37]: My Lady Dedlock has returned to her house in town for a few days previous to her departure for Paris , where her ladyship intends to stay some weeks , after which her movements are uncertain .
Parsing [sent. 127 len. 19]: The fashionable intelligence says so for the comfort of the Parisians , and it knows all fashionable things .
Parsing [sent. 128 len. 9]: To know things otherwise were to be unfashionable .
Parsing [sent. 129 len. 22]: My Lady Dedlock has been down at what she calls , in familiar conversation , her `` place '' in Lincolnshire .
Parsing [sent. 130 len. 7]: The waters are out in Lincolnshire .
Parsing [sent. 131 len. 15]: An arch of the bridge in the park has been sapped and sopped away .
Parsing [sent. 132 len. 36]: The adjacent low-lying ground for half a mile in breadth is a stagnant river with melancholy trees for islands in it and a surface punctured all over , all day long , with falling rain .
Parsing [sent. 133 len. 10]: My Lady Dedlock 's place has been extremely dreary .
Parsing [sent. 134 len. 40]: The weather for many a day and night has been so wet that the trees seem wet through , and the soft loppings and prunings of the woodman 's axe can make no crash or crackle as they fall .
Parsing [sent. 135 len. 12]: The deer , looking soaked , leave quagmires where they pass .
Parsing [sent. 136 len. 38]: The shot of a rifle loses its sharpness in the moist air , and its smoke moves in a tardy little cloud towards the green rise , coppice-topped , that makes a background for the falling rain .
Parsing [sent. 137 len. 21]: The view from my Lady Dedlock 's own windows is alternately a lead-coloured view and a view in Indian ink .
Parsing [sent. 138 len. 45]: The vases on the stone terrace in the foreground catch the rain all day ; and the heavy drops fall -- drip , drip , drip -- upon the broad flagged pavement , called from old time the Ghost 's Walk , all night .
Parsing [sent. 139 len. 38]: On Sundays the little church in the park is mouldy ; the oaken pulpit breaks out into a cold sweat ; and there is a general smell and taste as of the ancient Dedlocks in their graves .
Parsing [sent. 140 len. 78]: My Lady Dedlock -LRB- who is childless -RRB- , looking out in the early twilight from her boudoir at a keeper 's lodge and seeing the light of a fire upon the latticed panes , and smoke rising from the chimney , and a child , chased by a woman , running out into the rain to meet the shining figure of a wrapped-up man coming through the gate , has been put quite out of temper .
Parsing [sent. 141 len. 13]: My Lady Dedlock says she has been `` bored to death . ''
Parsing [sent. 142 len. 38]: Therefore my Lady Dedlock has come away from the place in Lincolnshire and has left it to the rain , and the crows , and the rabbits , and the deer , and the partridges and pheasants .
Parsing [sent. 143 len. 36]: The pictures of the Dedlocks past and gone have seemed to vanish into the damp walls in mere lowness of spirits , as the housekeeper has passed along the old rooms shutting up the shutters .
Parsing [sent. 144 len. 39]: And when they will next come forth again , the fashionable intelligence -- which , like the fiend , is omniscient of the past and present , but not the future -- can not yet undertake to say .
Parsing [sent. 145 len. 17]: Sir Leicester Dedlock is only a baronet , but there is no mightier baronet than he .
Parsing [sent. 146 len. 14]: His family is as old as the hills , and infinitely more respectable .
Parsing [sent. 147 len. 21]: He has a general opinion that the world might get on without hills but would be done up without Dedlocks .
Parsing [sent. 148 len. 40]: He would on the whole admit nature to be a good idea -LRB- a little low , perhaps , when not enclosed with a park-fence -RRB- , but an idea dependent for its execution on your great county families .
Parsing [sent. 149 len. 41]: He is a gentleman of strict conscience , disdainful of all littleness and meanness and ready on the shortest notice to die any death you may please to mention rather than give occasion for the least impeachment of his integrity .
Parsing [sent. 150 len. 18]: He is an honourable , obstinate , truthful , high-spirited , intensely prejudiced , perfectly unreasonable man .
Parsing [sent. 151 len. 14]: Sir Leicester is twenty years , full measure , older than my Lady .
Parsing [sent. 152 len. 15]: He will never see sixty-five again , nor perhaps sixty-six , nor yet sixty-seven .
Parsing [sent. 153 len. 16]: He has a twist of the gout now and then and walks a little stiffly .
Parsing [sent. 154 len. 32]: He is of a worthy presence , with his light-grey hair and whiskers , his fine shirt-frill , his pure-white waistcoat , and his blue coat with bright buttons always buttoned .
Parsing [sent. 155 len. 25]: He is ceremonious , stately , most polite on every occasion to my Lady , and holds her personal attractions in the highest estimation .
Parsing [sent. 156 len. 26]: His gallantry to my Lady , which has never changed since he courted her , is the one little touch of romantic fancy in him .
Parsing [sent. 157 len. 8]: Indeed , he married her for love .
Parsing [sent. 158 len. 32]: A whisper still goes about that she had not even family ; howbeit , Sir Leicester had so much family that perhaps he had enough and could dispense with any more .
Parsing [sent. 159 len. 24]: But she had beauty , pride , ambition , insolent resolve , and sense enough to portion out a legion of fine ladies .
Parsing [sent. 160 len. 38]: Wealth and station , added to these , soon floated her upward , and for years now my Lady Dedlock has been at the centre of the fashionable intelligence and at the top of the fashionable tree .
Parsing [sent. 161 len. 33]: How Alexander wept when he had no more worlds to conquer , everybody knows -- or has some reason to know by this time , the matter having been rather frequently mentioned .
Parsing [sent. 162 len. 23]: My Lady Dedlock , having conquered HER world , fell not into the melting , but rather into the freezing , mood .
Parsing [sent. 163 len. 28]: An exhausted composure , a worn-out placidity , an equanimity of fatigue not to be ruffled by interest or satisfaction , are the trophies of her victory .
Parsing [sent. 164 len. 5]: She is perfectly well-bred .
Parsing [sent. 165 len. 19]: If she could be translated to heaven to-morrow , she might be expected to ascend without any rapture .
Parsing [sent. 166 len. 22]: She has beauty still , and if it be not in its heyday , it is not yet in its autumn .
Parsing [sent. 167 len. 33]: She has a fine face -- originally of a character that would be rather called very pretty than handsome , but improved into classicality by the acquired expression of her fashionable state .
Parsing [sent. 168 len. 12]: Her figure is elegant and has the effect of being tall .
Parsing [sent. 169 len. 33]: Not that she is so , but that `` the most is made , '' as the Honourable Bob Stables has frequently asserted upon oath , `` of all her points . ''
Parsing [sent. 170 len. 29]: The same authority observes that she is perfectly got up and remarks in commendation of her hair especially that she is the best-groomed woman in the whole stud .
Parsing [sent. 171 len. 60]: With all her perfections on her head , my Lady Dedlock has come up from her place in Lincolnshire -LRB- hotly pursued by the fashionable intelligence -RRB- to pass a few days at her house in town previous to her departure for Paris , where her ladyship intends to stay some weeks , after which her movements are uncertain .
Parsing [sent. 172 len. 80]: And at her house in town , upon this muddy , murky afternoon , presents himself an old-fashioned old gentleman , attorney-at-law and eke solicitor of the High Court of Chancery , who has the honour of acting as legal adviser of the Dedlocks and has as many cast-iron boxes in his office with that name outside as if the present baronet were the coin of the conjuror 's trick and were constantly being juggled through the whole set .
Parsing [sent. 173 len. 60]: Across the hall , and up the stairs , and along the passages , and through the rooms , which are very brilliant in the season and very dismal out of it -- fairy-land to visit , but a desert to live in -- the old gentleman is conducted by a Mercury in powder to my Lady 's presence .
Parsing [sent. 174 len. 32]: The old gentleman is rusty to look at , but is reputed to have made good thrift out of aristocratic marriage settlements and aristocratic wills , and to be very rich .
Parsing [sent. 175 len. 22]: He is surrounded by a mysterious halo of family confidences , of which he is known to be the silent depository .
Parsing [sent. 176 len. 41]: There are noble mausoleums rooted for centuries in retired glades of parks among the growing timber and the fern , which perhaps hold fewer noble secrets than walk abroad among men , shut up in the breast of Mr. Tulkinghorn .
Parsing [sent. 177 len. 36]: He is of what is called the old school -- a phrase generally meaning any school that seems never to have been young -- and wears knee-breeches tied with ribbons , and gaiters or stockings .
Parsing [sent. 178 len. 24]: One peculiarity of his black clothes and of his black stockings , be they silk or worsted , is that they never shine .
Parsing [sent. 179 len. 16]: Mute , close , irresponsive to any glancing light , his dress is like himself .
Parsing [sent. 180 len. 8]: He never converses when not professionaly consulted .
Parsing [sent. 181 len. 55]: He is found sometimes , speechless but quite at home , at corners of dinner-tables in great country houses and near doors of drawing-rooms , concerning which the fashionable intelligence is eloquent , where everybody knows him and where half the Peerage stops to say `` How do you do , Mr. Tulkinghorn ? ''
Parsing [sent. 182 len. 17]: He receives these salutations with gravity and buries them along with the rest of his knowledge .
Parsing [sent. 183 len. 15]: Sir Leicester Dedlock is with my Lady and is happy to see Mr. Tulkinghorn .
Parsing [sent. 184 len. 25]: There is an air of prescription about him which is always agreeable to Sir Leicester ; he receives it as a kind of tribute .
Parsing [sent. 185 len. 17]: He likes Mr. Tulkinghorn 's dress ; there is a kind of tribute in that too .
Parsing [sent. 186 len. 15]: It is eminently respectable , and likewise , in a general way , retainer-like .
Parsing [sent. 187 len. 25]: It expresses , as it were , the steward of the legal mysteries , the butler of the legal cellar , of the Dedlocks .
Parsing [sent. 188 len. 9]: Has Mr. Tulkinghorn any idea of this himself ?
Parsing [sent. 189 len. 44]: It may be so , or it may not , but there is this remarkable circumstance to be noted in everything associated with my Lady Dedlock as one of a class -- as one of the leaders and representatives of her little world .
Parsing [sent. 190 len. 32]: She supposes herself to be an inscrutable Being , quite out of the reach and ken of ordinary mortals -- seeing herself in her glass , where indeed she looks so .
Parsing [sent. 191 len. 57]: Yet every dim little star revolving about her , from her maid to the manager of the Italian Opera , knows her weaknesses , prejudices , follies , haughtinesses , and caprices and lives upon as accurate a calculation and as nice a measure of her moral nature as her dressmaker takes of her physical proportions .
Parsing [sent. 192 len. 42]: Is a new dress , a new custom , a new singer , a new dancer , a new form of jewellery , a new dwarf or giant , a new chapel , a new anything , to be set up ?
Parsing [sent. 193 len. 89]: There are deferential people in a dozen callings whom my Lady Dedlock suspects of nothing but prostration before her , who can tell you how to manage her as if she were a baby , who do nothing but nurse her all their lives , who , humbly affecting to follow with profound subservience , lead her and her whole troop after them ; who , in hooking one , hook all and bear them off as Lemuel Gulliver bore away the stately fleet of the majestic Lilliput .
Parsing [sent. 194 len. 64]: `` If you want to address our people , sir , '' say Blaze and Sparkle , the jewellers -- meaning by our people Lady Dedlock and the rest -- `` you must remember that you are not dealing with the general public ; you must hit our people in their weakest place , and their weakest place is such a place . ''
Parsing [sent. 195 len. 50]: `` To make this article go down , gentlemen , '' say Sheen and Gloss , the mercers , to their friends the manufacturers , `` you must come to us , because we know where to have the fashionable people , and we can make it fashionable . ''
Parsing [sent. 196 len. 127]: `` If you want to get this print upon the tables of my high connexion , sir , '' says Mr. Sladdery , the librarian , `` or if you want to get this dwarf or giant into the houses of my high connexion , sir , or if you want to secure to this entertainment the patronage of my high connexion , sir , you must leave it , if you please , to me , for I have been accustomed to study the leaders of my high connexion , sir , and I may tell you without vanity that I can turn them round my finger '' -- in which Mr. Sladdery , who is an honest man , does not exaggerate at all .
Parsing [sent. 197 len. 26]: Therefore , while Mr. Tulkinghorn may not know what is passing in the Dedlock mind at present , it is very possible that he may .
Parsing [sent. 198 len. 19]: `` My Lady 's cause has been again before the Chancellor , has it , Mr. Tulkinghorn ? ''
Parsing [sent. 199 len. 9]: says Sir Leicester , giving him his hand .
Parsing [sent. 200 len. 3]: `` Yes .
Parsing [sent. 201 len. 38]: It has been on again to-day , '' Mr. Tulkinghorn replies , making one of his quiet bows to my Lady , who is on a sofa near the fire , shading her face with a hand-screen .
Parsing [sent. 202 len. 32]: `` It would be useless to ask , '' says my Lady with the dreariness of the place in Lincolnshire still upon her , `` whether anything has been done . ''
Parsing [sent. 203 len. 17]: `` Nothing that YOU would call anything has been done to-day , '' replies Mr. Tulkinghorn .
Parsing [sent. 204 len. 11]: `` Nor ever will be , '' says my Lady .
Parsing [sent. 205 len. 11]: Sir Leicester has no objection to an interminable Chancery suit .
Parsing [sent. 206 len. 14]: It is a slow , expensive , British , constitutional kind of thing .
Parsing [sent. 207 len. 66]: To be sure , he has not a vital interest in the suit in question , her part in which was the only property my Lady brought him ; and he has a shadowy impression that for his name -- the name of Dedlock -- to be in a cause , and not in the title of that cause , is a most ridiculous accident .
Parsing [sent. 208 len. 54]: But he regards the Court of Chancery , even if it should involve an occasional delay of justice and a trifling amount of confusion , as a something devised in conjunction with a variety of other somethings by the perfection of human wisdom for the eternal settlement -LRB- humanly speaking -RRB- of everything .
Parsing [sent. 209 len. 42]: And he is upon the whole of a fixed opinion that to give the sanction of his countenance to any complaints respecting it would be to encourage some person in the lower classes to rise up somewhere -- like Wat Tyler .
Parsing [sent. 210 len. 83]: `` As a few fresh affidavits have been put upon the file , '' says Mr. Tulkinghorn , `` and as they are short , and as I proceed upon the troublesome principle of begging leave to possess my clients with any new proceedings in a cause '' -- cautious man Mr. Tulkinghorn , taking no more responsibility than necessary -- `` and further , as I see you are going to Paris , I have brought them in my pocket . ''
Parsing [sent. 211 len. 26]: -LRB- Sir Leicester was going to Paris too , by the by , but the delight of the fashionable intelligence was in his Lady . -RRB-
Parsing [sent. 212 len. 43]: Mr. Tulkinghorn takes out his papers , asks permission to place them on a golden talisman of a table at my Lady 's elbow , puts on his spectacles , and begins to read by the light of a shaded lamp . ''
Parsing [sent. 213 len. 4]: ` In Chancery .
Parsing [sent. 214 len. 24]: Between John Jarndyce -- ' '' My Lady interrupts , requesting him to miss as many of the formal horrors as he can .
Parsing [sent. 215 len. 12]: Mr. Tulkinghorn glances over his spectacles and begins again lower down .
Parsing [sent. 216 len. 9]: My Lady carelessly and scornfully abstracts her attention .
Parsing [sent. 217 len. 30]: Sir Leicester in a great chair looks at the file and appears to have a stately liking for the legal repetitions and prolixities as ranging among the national bulwarks .
Parsing [sent. 218 len. 26]: It happens that the fire is hot where my Lady sits and that the hand-screen is more beautiful than useful , being priceless but small .
Parsing [sent. 219 len. 34]: My Lady , changing her position , sees the papers on the table -- looks at them nearer -- looks at them nearer still -- asks impulsively , `` Who copied that ? ''
Parsing [sent. 220 len. 16]: Mr. Tulkinghorn stops short , surprised by my Lady 's animation and her unusual tone .
Parsing [sent. 221 len. 10]: `` Is it what you people call law-hand ? ''
Parsing [sent. 222 len. 18]: she asks , looking full at him in her careless way again and toying with her screen .
Parsing [sent. 223 len. 4]: `` Not quite .
Parsing [sent. 224 len. 27]: Probably '' -- Mr. Tulkinghorn examines it as he speaks -- `` the legal character which it has was acquired after the original hand was formed .
Parsing [sent. 225 len. 6]: Why do you ask ? ''
Parsing [sent. 226 len. 8]: `` Anything to vary this detestable monotony .
Parsing [sent. 227 len. 8]: Oh , go on , do ! ''
Parsing [sent. 228 len. 5]: Mr. Tulkinghorn reads again .
Parsing [sent. 229 len. 11]: The heat is greater ; my Lady screens her face .
Parsing [sent. 230 len. 14]: Sir Leicester dozes , starts up suddenly , and cries , `` Eh ?

Parsing [sent. 234 len. 6]: Do n't speak to me .

Parsing [sent. 239 len. 7]: `` I have been quite alarmed .
Parsing [sent. 240 len. 8]: I never knew my Lady swoon before .
Parsing [sent. 241 len. 23]: But the weather is extremely trying , and she really has been bored to death down at our place in Lincolnshire . ''
Parsing [sent. 242 len. 30]: Chapter III -- A Progress I have a great deal of difficulty in beginning to write my portion of these pages , for I know I am not clever .
Parsing [sent. 243 len. 5]: I always knew that .
Parsing [sent. 244 len. 54]: I can remember , when I was a very little girl indeed , I used to say to my doll when we were alone together , `` Now , Dolly , I am not clever , you know very well , and you must be patient with me , like a dear ! ''
Parsing [sent. 245 len. 53]: And so she used to sit propped up in a great arm-chair , with her beautiful complexion and rosy lips , staring at me -- or not so much at me , I think , as at nothing -- while I busily stitched away and told her every one of my secrets .
Parsing [sent. 246 len. 5]: My dear old doll !
Parsing [sent. 247 len. 28]: I was such a shy little thing that I seldom dared to open my lips , and never dared to open my heart , to anybody else .
Parsing [sent. 248 len. 51]: It almost makes me cry to think what a relief it used to be to me when I came home from school of a day to run upstairs to my room and say , `` Oh , you dear faithful Dolly , I knew you would be expecting me ! ''
Parsing [sent. 249 len. 29]: and then to sit down on the floor , leaning on the elbow of her great chair , and tell her all I had noticed since we parted .
Parsing [sent. 250 len. 17]: I had always rather a noticing way -- not a quick way , oh , no !
Parsing [sent. 251 len. 20]: -- a silent way of noticing what passed before me and thinking I should like to understand it better .
Parsing [sent. 252 len. 10]: I have not by any means a quick understanding .
Parsing [sent. 253 len. 14]: When I love a person very tenderly indeed , it seems to brighten .
Parsing [sent. 254 len. 8]: But even that may be my vanity .
Parsing [sent. 255 len. 30]: I was brought up , from my earliest remembrance -- like some of the princesses in the fairy stories , only I was not charming -- by my godmother .
Parsing [sent. 256 len. 10]: At least , I only knew her as such .
Parsing [sent. 257 len. 8]: She was a good , good woman !
Parsing [sent. 258 len. 30]: She went to church three times every Sunday , and to morning prayers on Wednesdays and Fridays , and to lectures whenever there were lectures ; and never missed .
Parsing [sent. 259 len. 29]: She was handsome ; and if she had ever smiled , would have been -LRB- I used to think -RRB- like an angel -- but she never smiled .
Parsing [sent. 260 len. 7]: She was always grave and strict .
Parsing [sent. 261 len. 23]: She was so very good herself , I thought , that the badness of other people made her frown all her life .
Parsing [sent. 262 len. 53]: I felt so different from her , even making every allowance for the differences between a child and a woman ; I felt so poor , so trifling , and so far off that I never could be unrestrained with her -- no , could never even love her as I wished .
Parsing [sent. 263 len. 76]: It made me very sorry to consider how good she was and how unworthy of her I was , and I used ardently to hope that I might have a better heart ; and I talked it over very often with the dear old doll , but I never loved my godmother as I ought to have loved her and as I felt I must have loved her if I had been a better girl .
Parsing [sent. 264 len. 32]: This made me , I dare say , more timid and retiring than I naturally was and cast me upon Dolly as the only friend with whom I felt at ease .
Parsing [sent. 265 len. 17]: But something happened when I was still quite a little thing that helped it very much .
Parsing [sent. 266 len. 9]: I had never heard my mama spoken of .
Parsing [sent. 267 len. 18]: I had never heard of my papa either , but I felt more interested about my mama .
Parsing [sent. 268 len. 13]: I had never worn a black frock , that I could recollect .
Parsing [sent. 269 len. 10]: I had never been shown my mama 's grave .
Parsing [sent. 270 len. 9]: I had never been told where it was .
Parsing [sent. 271 len. 15]: Yet I had never been taught to pray for any relation but my godmother .
Parsing [sent. 272 len. 54]: I had more than once approached this subject of my thoughts with Mrs. Rachael , our only servant , who took my light away when I was in bed -LRB- another very good woman , but austere to me -RRB- , and she had only said , `` Esther , good night ! ''
Parsing [sent. 273 len. 7]: and gone away and left me .
Parsing [sent. 274 len. 33]: Although there were seven girls at the neighbouring school where I was a day boarder , and although they called me little Esther Summerson , I knew none of them at home .
Parsing [sent. 275 len. 54]: All of them were older than I , to be sure -LRB- I was the youngest there by a good deal -RRB- , but there seemed to be some other separation between us besides that , and besides their being far more clever than I was and knowing much more than I did .
Parsing [sent. 276 len. 33]: One of them in the first week of my going to the school -LRB- I remember it very well -RRB- invited me home to a little party , to my great joy .
Parsing [sent. 277 len. 16]: But my godmother wrote a stiff letter declining for me , and I never went .
Parsing [sent. 278 len. 7]: I never went out at all .
Parsing [sent. 279 len. 5]: It was my birthday .
Parsing [sent. 280 len. 13]: There were holidays at school on other birthdays -- none on mine .
Parsing [sent. 281 len. 29]: There were rejoicings at home on other birthdays , as I knew from what I heard the girls relate to one another -- there were none on mine .
Parsing [sent. 282 len. 14]: My birthday was the most melancholy day at home in the whole year .
Parsing [sent. 283 len. 43]: I have mentioned that unless my vanity should deceive me -LRB- as I know it may , for I may be very vain without suspecting it , though indeed I do n't -RRB- , my comprehension is quickened when my affection is .
Parsing [sent. 284 len. 32]: My disposition is very affectionate , and perhaps I might still feel such a wound if such a wound could be received more than once with the quickness of that birthday .
Parsing [sent. 285 len. 18]: Dinner was over , and my godmother and I were sitting at the table before the fire .
Parsing [sent. 286 len. 29]: The clock ticked , the fire clicked ; not another sound had been heard in the room or in the house for I do n't know how long .
Parsing [sent. 287 len. 55]: I happened to look timidly up from my stitching , across the table at my godmother , and I saw in her face , looking gloomily at me , `` It would have been far better , little Esther , that you had had no birthday , that you had never been born ! ''
Parsing [sent. 288 len. 33]: I broke out crying and sobbing , and I said , `` Oh , dear godmother , tell me , pray do tell me , did Mama die on my birthday ? ''
Parsing [sent. 289 len. 7]: `` No , '' she returned .
Parsing [sent. 290 len. 9]: `` Ask me no more , child ! ''
Parsing [sent. 291 len. 11]: `` Oh , do pray tell me something of her .
Parsing [sent. 292 len. 13]: Do now , at last , dear godmother , if you please !
Parsing [sent. 293 len. 7]: What did I do to her ?
Parsing [sent. 294 len. 6]: How did I lose her ?
Parsing [sent. 295 len. 19]: Why am I so different from other children , and why is it my fault , dear godmother ?
Parsing [sent. 296 len. 11]: No , no , no , do n't go away .
Parsing [sent. 297 len. 7]: Oh , speak to me ! ''
Parsing [sent. 298 len. 24]: I was in a kind of fright beyond my grief , and I caught hold of her dress and was kneeling to her .
Parsing [sent. 299 len. 14]: She had been saying all the while , `` Let me go ! ''
Parsing [sent. 300 len. 6]: But now she stood still .
Parsing [sent. 301 len. 19]: Her darkened face had such power over me that it stopped me in the midst of my vehemence .
Parsing [sent. 302 len. 38]: I put up my trembling little hand to clasp hers or to beg her pardon with what earnestness I might , but withdrew it as she looked at me , and laid it on my fluttering heart .
Parsing [sent. 303 len. 48]: She raised me , sat in her chair , and standing me before her , said slowly in a cold , low voice -- I see her knitted brow and pointed finger -- `` Your mother , Esther , is your disgrace , and you were hers .
Parsing [sent. 304 len. 29]: The time will come -- and soon enough -- when you will understand this better and will feel it too , as no one save a woman can .
Parsing [sent. 305 len. 51]: I have forgiven her '' -- but her face did not relent -- `` the wrong she did to me , and I say no more of it , though it was greater than you will ever know -- than any one will ever know but I , the sufferer .
Parsing [sent. 306 len. 37]: For yourself , unfortunate girl , orphaned and degraded from the first of these evil anniversaries , pray daily that the sins of others be not visited upon your head , according to what is written .
Parsing [sent. 307 len. 21]: Forget your mother and leave all other people to forget her who will do her unhappy child that greatest kindness .
Parsing [sent. 308 len. 5]: Now , go ! ''
Parsing [sent. 309 len. 21]: She checked me , however , as I was about to depart from her -- so frozen as I was !
Parsing [sent. 310 len. 27]: -- and added this , `` Submission , self-denial , diligent work , are the preparations for a life begun with such a shadow on it .
Parsing [sent. 311 len. 24]: You are different from other children , Esther , because you were not born , like them , in common sinfulness and wrath .
Parsing [sent. 312 len. 6]: You are set apart . ''
Parsing [sent. 313 len. 38]: I went up to my room , and crept to bed , and laid my doll 's cheek against mine wet with tears , and holding that solitary friend upon my bosom , cried myself to sleep .
Parsing [sent. 314 len. 39]: Imperfect as my understanding of my sorrow was , I knew that I had brought no joy at any time to anybody 's heart and that I was to no one upon earth what Dolly was to me .
Parsing [sent. 315 len. 96]: Dear , dear , to think how much time we passed alone together afterwards , and how often I repeated to the doll the story of my birthday and confided to her that I would try as hard as ever I could to repair the fault I had been born with -LRB- of which I confessedly felt guilty and yet innocent -RRB- and would strive as I grew up to be industrious , contented , and kind-hearted and to do some good to some one , and win some love to myself if I could .
Parsing [sent. 316 len. 16]: I hope it is not self-indulgent to shed these tears as I think of it .
Parsing [sent. 317 len. 22]: I am very thankful , I am very cheerful , but I can not quite help their coming to my eyes .
Parsing [sent. 318 len. 2]: There !
Parsing [sent. 319 len. 13]: I have wiped them away now and can go on again properly .
Parsing [sent. 320 len. 57]: I felt the distance between my godmother and myself so much more after the birthday , and felt so sensible of filling a place in her house which ought to have been empty , that I found her more difficult of approach , though I was fervently grateful to her in my heart , than ever .
Parsing [sent. 321 len. 48]: I felt in the same way towards my school companions ; I felt in the same way towards Mrs. Rachael , who was a widow ; and oh , towards her daughter , of whom she was proud , who came to see her once a fortnight !
Parsing [sent. 322 len. 14]: I was very retired and quiet , and tried to be very diligent .
Parsing [sent. 323 len. 48]: One sunny afternoon when I had come home from school with my books and portfolio , watching my long shadow at my side , and as I was gliding upstairs to my room as usual , my godmother looked out of the parlour-door and called me back .
Parsing [sent. 324 len. 16]: Sitting with her , I found -- which was very unusual indeed -- a stranger .
Parsing [sent. 325 len. 36]: A portly , important-looking gentleman , dressed all in black , with a white cravat , large gold watch seals , a pair of gold eye-glasses , and a large seal-ring upon his little finger .
Parsing [sent. 326 len. 17]: `` This , '' said my godmother in an undertone , `` is the child . ''
Parsing [sent. 327 len. 19]: Then she said in her naturally stern way of speaking , `` This is Esther , sir . ''
Parsing [sent. 328 len. 21]: The gentleman put up his eye-glasses to look at me and said , `` Come here , my dear ! ''
Parsing [sent. 329 len. 21]: He shook hands with me and asked me to take off my bonnet , looking at me all the while .
Parsing [sent. 330 len. 12]: When I had complied , he said , `` Ah ! ''
Parsing [sent. 331 len. 6]: and afterwards `` Yes ! ''
Parsing [sent. 332 len. 38]: And then , taking off his eye-glasses and folding them in a red case , and leaning back in his arm-chair , turning the case about in his two hands , he gave my godmother a nod .
Parsing [sent. 333 len. 16]: Upon that , my godmother said , `` You may go upstairs , Esther ! ''
Parsing [sent. 334 len. 10]: And I made him my curtsy and left him .
Parsing [sent. 335 len. 27]: It must have been two years afterwards , and I was almost fourteen , when one dreadful night my godmother and I sat at the fireside .
Parsing [sent. 336 len. 10]: I was reading aloud , and she was listening .
Parsing [sent. 337 len. 48]: I had come down at nine o'clock as I always did to read the Bible to her , and was reading from St. John how our Saviour stooped down , writing with his finger in the dust , when they brought the sinful woman to him . ''
Parsing [sent. 338 len. 36]: ` So when they continued asking him , he lifted up himself and said unto them , He that is without sin among you , let him first cast a stone at her ! ' ''
Parsing [sent. 339 len. 46]: I was stopped by my godmother 's rising , putting her hand to her head , and crying out in an awful voice from quite another part of the book , '' ` Watch ye , therefore , lest coming suddenly he find you sleeping .
Parsing [sent. 340 len. 16]: And what I say unto you , I say unto all , Watch ! ' ''
Parsing [sent. 341 len. 20]: In an instant , while she stood before me repeating these words , she fell down on the floor .
Parsing [sent. 342 len. 22]: I had no need to cry out ; her voice had sounded through the house and been heard in the street .
Parsing [sent. 343 len. 7]: She was laid upon her bed .
Parsing [sent. 344 len. 29]: For more than a week she lay there , little altered outwardly , with her old handsome resolute frown that I so well knew carved upon her face .
Parsing [sent. 345 len. 65]: Many and many a time , in the day and in the night , with my head upon the pillow by her that my whispers might be plainer to her , I kissed her , thanked her , prayed for her , asked her for her blessing and forgiveness , entreated her to give me the least sign that she knew or heard me .
Parsing [sent. 346 len. 6]: No , no , no .
Parsing [sent. 347 len. 5]: Her face was immovable .
Parsing [sent. 348 len. 14]: To the very last , and even afterwards , her frown remained unsoftened .
Parsing [sent. 349 len. 21]: On the day after my poor good godmother was buried , the gentleman in black with the white neckcloth reappeared .
Parsing [sent. 350 len. 24]: I was sent for by Mrs. Rachael , and found him in the same place , as if he had never gone away .
Parsing [sent. 351 len. 28]: `` My name is Kenge , '' he said ; `` you may remember it , my child ; Kenge and Carboy , Lincoln 's Inn . ''
Parsing [sent. 352 len. 12]: I replied that I remembered to have seen him once before .
Parsing [sent. 353 len. 9]: `` Pray be seated -- here near me .
Parsing [sent. 354 len. 11]: Do n't distress yourself ; it 's of no use .
Parsing [sent. 355 len. 45]: Mrs. Rachael , I need n't inform you who were acquainted with the late Miss Barbary 's affairs , that her means die with her and that this young lady , now her aunt is dead -- '' `` My aunt , sir ! ''
Parsing [sent. 356 len. 37]: `` It is really of no use carrying on a deception when no object is to be gained by it , '' said Mr. Kenge smoothly , `` Aunt in fact , though not in law .
Parsing [sent. 357 len. 5]: Do n't distress yourself !
Parsing [sent. 358 len. 4]: Do n't weep !
Parsing [sent. 359 len. 4]: Do n't tremble !
Parsing [sent. 360 len. 21]: Mrs. Rachael , our young friend has no doubt heard of -- the -- a -- Jarndyce and Jarndyce . ''
Parsing [sent. 361 len. 8]: `` Never , '' said Mrs. Rachael .
Parsing [sent. 362 len. 29]: `` Is it possible , '' pursued Mr. Kenge , putting up his eye-glasses , `` that our young friend -- I BEG you wo n't distress yourself !
Parsing [sent. 363 len. 9]: -- never heard of Jarndyce and Jarndyce ! ''
Parsing [sent. 364 len. 11]: I shook my head , wondering even what it was .
Parsing [sent. 365 len. 8]: `` Not of Jarndyce and Jarndyce ? ''
Parsing [sent. 366 len. 25]: said Mr. Kenge , looking over his glasses at me and softly turning the case about and about as if he were petting something .
Parsing [sent. 367 len. 11]: `` Not of one of the greatest Chancery suits known ?
Parsing [sent. 368 len. 18]: Not of Jarndyce and Jarndyce -- the -- a -- in itself a monument of Chancery practice .

Parsing [sent. 811 len. 67]: When we went downstairs we found a mug with `` A Present from Tunbridge Wells '' on it lighted up in the staircase window with a floating wick , and a young woman , with a swelled face bound up in a flannel bandage blowing the fire of the drawing-room -LRB- now connected by an open door with Mrs. Jellyby 's room -RRB- and choking dreadfully .
Parsing [sent. 812 len. 42]: It smoked to that degree , in short , that we all sat coughing and crying with the windows open for half an hour , during which Mrs. Jellyby , with the same sweetness of temper , directed letters about Africa .
Parsing [sent. 813 len. 57]: Her being so employed was , I must say , a great relief to me , for Richard told us that he had washed his hands in a pie-dish and that they had found the kettle on his dressing-table , and he made Ada laugh so that they made me laugh in the most ridiculous manner .
Parsing [sent. 814 len. 38]: Soon after seven o'clock we went down to dinner , carefully , by Mrs. Jellyby 's advice , for the stair-carpets , besides being very deficient in stair-wires , were so torn as to be absolute traps .
Parsing [sent. 815 len. 41]: We had a fine cod-fish , a piece of roast beef , a dish of cutlets , and a pudding ; an excellent dinner , if it had had any cooking to speak of , but it was almost raw .
Parsing [sent. 816 len. 34]: The young woman with the flannel bandage waited , and dropped everything on the table wherever it happened to go , and never moved it again until she put it on the stairs .
Parsing [sent. 817 len. 37]: The person I had seen in pattens , who I suppose to have been the cook , frequently came and skirmished with her at the door , and there appeared to be ill will between them .
Parsing [sent. 818 len. 50]: All through dinner -- which was long , in consequence of such accidents as the dish of potatoes being mislaid in the coal skuttle and the handle of the corkscrew coming off and striking the young woman in the chin -- Mrs. Jellyby preserved the evenness of her disposition .
Parsing [sent. 819 len. 39]: She told us a great deal that was interesting about Borrioboola -- Gha and the natives , and received so many letters that Richard , who sat by her , saw four envelopes in the gravy at once .
Parsing [sent. 820 len. 62]: Some of the letters were proceedings of ladies ' committees or resolutions of ladies ' meetings , which she read to us ; others were applications from people excited in various ways about the cultivation of coffee , and natives ; others required answers , and these she sent her eldest daughter from the table three or four times to write .
Parsing [sent. 821 len. 20]: She was full of business and undoubtedly was , as she had told us , devoted to the cause .

Parsing [sent. 823 len. 18]: As he never spoke a word , he might have been a native but for his complexion .
Parsing [sent. 824 len. 27]: It was not until we left the table and he remained alone with Richard that the possibility of his being Mr. Jellyby ever entered my head .
Parsing [sent. 825 len. 69]: But he WAS Mr. Jellyby ; and a loquacious young man called Mr. Quale , with large shining knobs for temples and his hair all brushed to the back of his head , who came in the evening , and told Ada he was a philanthropist , also informed her that he called the matrimonial alliance of Mrs. Jellyby with Mr. Jellyby the union of mind and matter .
Parsing [sent. 826 len. 83]: This young man , besides having a great deal to say for himself about Africa and a project of his for teaching the coffee colonists to teach the natives to turn piano-forte legs and establish an export trade , delighted in drawing Mrs. Jellyby out by saving , `` I believe now , Mrs. Jellyby , you have received as many as from one hundred and fifty to two hundred letters respecting Africa in a single day , have you not ? Parsing [sent. 1276 len. 19]: `` It is to me , and has been ever since I can remember , '' returned Ada .
Parsing [sent. 1277 len. 66]: `` I am grieved that I should be the enemy -- - as I suppose I am -- of a great number of relations and others , and that they should be my enemies -- as I suppose they are -- and that we should all be ruining one another without knowing how or why and be in constant doubt and discord all our lives .
Parsing [sent. 1278 len. 35]: It seems very strange , as there must be right somewhere , that an honest judge in real earnest has not been able to find out through all these years where it is . ''

Parsing [sent. 1297 len. 22]: The equable manner in which Mrs. Jellyby sustained both his absence and his restoration to the family circle surprised us all .

Parsing [sent. 1299 len. 17]: At one o'clock an open carriage arrived for us , and a cart for our luggage .
Parsing [sent. 1300 len. 113]: Mrs. Jellyby charged us with many remembrances to her good friend Mr. Jarndyce ; Caddy left her desk to see us depart , kissed me in the passage , and stood biting her pen and sobbing on the steps ; Peepy , I am happy to say , was asleep and spared the pain of separation -LRB- I was not without misgivings that he had gone to Newgate market in search of me -RRB- ; and all the other children got up behind the barouche and fell off , and we saw them , with great concern , scattered over the surface of Thavies Inn as we rolled out of its precincts .
Parsing [sent. 1301 len. 21]: Chapter VI -- Quite at Home The day had brightened very much , and still brightened as we went westward .
Parsing [sent. 1302 len. 51]: We went our way through the sunshine and the fresh air , wondering more and more at the extent of the streets , the brilliancy of the shops , the great traffic , and the crowds of people whom the pleasanter weather seemed to have brought out like many-coloured flowers .
Parsing [sent. 1303 len. 73]: By and by we began to leave the wonderful city and to proceed through suburbs which , of themselves , would have made a pretty large town in my eyes ; and at last we got into a real country road again , with windmills , rick-yards , milestones , farmers ' waggons , scents of old hay , swinging signs , and horse troughs : trees , fields , and hedge-rows .
Parsing [sent. 1304 len. 61]: It was delightful to see the green landscape before us and the immense metropolis behind ; and when a waggon with a train of beautiful horses , furnished with red trappings and clear-sounding bells , came by us with its music , I believe we could all three have sung to the bells , so cheerful were the influences around .
Parsing [sent. 1305 len. 26]: `` The whole road has been reminding me of my name-sake Whittington , '' said Richard , `` and that waggon is the finishing touch .

Parsing [sent. 1329 len. 40]: John Jarndyce '' I had perhaps less reason to be surprised than either of my companions , having never yet enjoyed an opportunity of thanking one who had been my benefactor and sole earthly dependence through so many years .
Parsing [sent. 1330 len. 45]: I had not considered how I could thank him , my gratitude lying too deep in my heart for that ; but I now began to consider how I could meet him without thanking him , and felt it would be very difficult indeed .
Parsing [sent. 1331 len. 59]: The notes revived in Richard and Ada a general impression that they both had , without quite knowing how they came by it , that their cousin Jarndyce could never bear acknowledgments for any kindness he performed and that sooner than receive any he would resort to the most singular expedients and evasions or would even run away .
Parsing [sent. 1332 len. 71]: Ada dimly remembered to have heard her mother tell , when she was a very little child , that he had once done her an act of uncommon generosity and that on her going to his house to thank him , he happened to see her through a window coming to the door , and immediately escaped by the back gate , and was not heard of for three months .
Parsing [sent. 1333 len. 29]: This discourse led to a great deal more on the same theme , and indeed it lasted us all day , and we talked of scarcely anything else .
Parsing [sent. 1334 len. 66]: If we did by any chance diverge into another subject , we soon returned to this , and wondered what the house would be like , and when we should get there , and whether we should see Mr. Jarndyce as soon as we arrived or after a delay , and what he would say to us , and what we should say to him .
Parsing [sent. 1335 len. 12]: All of which we wondered about , over and over again .
Parsing [sent. 1336 len. 47]: The roads were very heavy for the horses , but the pathway was generally good , so we alighted and walked up all the hills , and liked it so well that we prolonged our walk on the level ground when we got to the top .
Parsing [sent. 1337 len. 46]: At Barnet there were other horses waiting for us , but as they had only just been fed , we had to wait for them too , and got a long fresh walk over a common and an old battle-field before the carriage came up .
Parsing [sent. 1338 len. 37]: These delays so protracted the journey that the short day was spent and the long night had closed in before we came to St. Albans , near to which town Bleak House was , we knew .
Parsing [sent. 1339 len. 35]: By that time we were so anxious and nervous that even Richard confessed , as we rattled over the stones of the old street , to feeling an irrational desire to drive back again .
Parsing [sent. 1340 len. 29]: As to Ada and me , whom he had wrapped up with great care , the night being sharp and frosty , we trembled from head to foot .

Parsing [sent. 1342 len. 34]: There was a light sparkling on the top of a hill before us , and the driver , pointing to it with his whip and crying , `` That 's Bleak House ! ''

Parsing [sent. 1344 len. 35]: Presently we lost the light , presently saw it , presently lost it , presently saw it , and turned into an avenue of trees and cantered up towards where it was beaming brightly .
Parsing [sent. 1345 len. 30]: It was in a window of what seemed to be an old-fashioned house with three peaks in the roof in front and a circular sweep leading to the porch .
Parsing [sent. 1346 len. 66]: A bell was rung as we drew up , and amidst the sound of its deep voice in the still air , and the distant barking of some dogs , and a gush of light from the opened door , and the smoking and steaming of the heated horses , and the quickened beating of our own hearts , we alighted in no inconsiderable confusion .

Parsing [sent. 1435 len. 72]: It was one of those delightfully irregular houses where you go up and down steps out of one room into another , and where you come upon more rooms when you think you have seen all there are , and where there is a bountiful provision of little halls and passages , and where you find still older cottage-rooms in unexpected places with lattice windows and green growth pressing through them .

Parsing [sent. 1440 len. 110]: But if instead of going out at Ada 's door you came back into my room , and went out at the door by which you had entered it , and turned up a few crooked steps that branched off in an unexpected manner from the stairs , you lost yourself in passages , with mangles in them , and three-cornered tables , and a native Hindu chair , which was also a sofa , a box , and a bedstead , and looked in every form something between a bamboo skeleton and a great bird-cage , and had been brought from India nobody knew by whom or when .
Parsing [sent. 1441 len. 30]: From these you came on Richard 's room , which was part library , part sitting-room , part bedroom , and seemed indeed a comfortable compound of many rooms .

Parsing [sent. 1443 len. 51]: Out of that you came into another passage , where there were back-stairs and where you could hear the horses being rubbed down outside the stable and being told to `` Hold up '' and `` Get over , '' as they slipped about very much on the uneven stones .

Parsing [sent. 1445 len. 17]: The furniture , old-fashioned rather than old , like the house , was as pleasantly irregular .
Parsing [sent. 1446 len. 49]: Ada 's sleeping-room was all flowers -- in chintz and paper , in velvet , in needlework , in the brocade of two stiff courtly chairs which stood , each attended by a little page of a stool for greater state , on either side of the fire-place .
Parsing [sent. 1447 len. 68]: Our sitting-room was green and had framed and glazed upon the walls numbers of surprising and surprised birds , staring out of pictures at a real trout in a case , as brown and shining as if it had been served with gravy ; at the death of Captain Cook ; and at the whole process of preparing tea in China , as depicted by Chinese artists .
Parsing [sent. 1448 len. 39]: In my room there were oval engravings of the months -- ladies haymaking in short waists and large hats tied under the chin , for June ; smooth-legged noblemen pointing with cocked-hats to village steeples , for October .

Parsing [sent. 1452 len. 43]: They agreed in nothing but their perfect neatness , their display of the whitest linen , and their storing-up , wheresoever the existence of a drawer , small or large , rendered it possible , of quantities of rose-leaves and sweet lavender .
Parsing [sent. 1453 len. 82]: Such , with its illuminated windows , softened here and there by shadows of curtains , shining out upon the starlight night ; with its light , and warmth , and comfort ; with its hospitable jingle , at a distance , of preparations for dinner ; with the face of its generous master brightening everything we saw ; and just wind enough without to sound a low accompaniment to everything we heard , were our first impressions of Bleak House .

Parsing [sent. 1702 len. 74]: But I thought , occasionally , when Mr. Skimpole played some fragments of his own compositions or when , both at the piano and the violoncello , and at our table , he preserved with an absence of all effort his delightful spirits and his easy flow of conversation , that Richard and I seemed to retain the transferred impression of having been arrested since dinner and that it was very curious altogether .

Parsing [sent. 1797 len. 28]: Chapter VII -- The Ghost 's Walk While Esther sleeps , and while Esther wakes , it is still wet weather down at the place in Lincolnshire .
Parsing [sent. 1798 len. 27]: The rain is ever falling -- drip , drip , drip -- by day and night upon the broad flagged terrace-pavement , the Ghost 's Walk .
Parsing [sent. 1799 len. 22]: The weather is so very bad down in Lincolnshire that the liveliest imagination can scarcely apprehend its ever being fine again .
Parsing [sent. 1800 len. 61]: Not that there is any superabundant life of imagination on the spot , for Sir Leicester is not here -LRB- and , truly , even if he were , would not do much for it in that particular -RRB- , but is in Paris with my Lady ; and solitude , with dusky wings , sits brooding upon Chesney Wold .
Parsing [sent. 1801 len. 15]: There may be some motions of fancy among the lower animals at Chesney Wold .
Parsing [sent. 1802 len. 78]: The horses in the stables -- the long stables in a barren , red-brick court-yard , where there is a great bell in a turret , and a clock with a large face , which the pigeons who live near it and who love to perch upon its shoulders seem to be always consulting -- THEY may contemplate some mental pictures of fine weather on occasions , and may be better artists at them than the grooms .
Parsing [sent. 1803 len. 69]: The old roan , so famous for cross-country work , turning his large eyeball to the grated window near his rack , may remember the fresh leaves that glisten there at other times and the scents that stream in , and may have a fine run with the hounds , while the human helper , clearing out the next stall , never stirs beyond his pitchfork and birch-broom .
Parsing [sent. 1804 len. 48]: The grey , whose place is opposite the door and who with an impatient rattle of his halter pricks his ears and turns his head so wistfully when it is opened , and to whom the opener says , '' ` Woa grey , then , steady !
Parsing [sent. 1805 len. 6]: Noabody wants you to-day ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1806 len. 10]: may know it quite as well as the man .
Parsing [sent. 1807 len. 60]: The whole seemingly monotonous and uncompanionable half-dozen , stabled together , may pass the long wet hours when the door is shut in livelier communication than is held in the servants ' hall or at the Dedlock Arms , or may even beguile the time by improving -LRB- perhaps corrupting -RRB- the pony in the loose-box in the corner .
Parsing [sent. 1808 len. 81]: So the mastiff , dozing in his kennel in the court-yard with his large head on his paws , may think of the hot sunshine when the shadows of the stable-buildings tire his patience out by changing and leave him at one time of the day no broader refuge than the shadow of his own house , where he sits on end , panting and growling short , and very much wanting something to worry besides himself and his chain .
Parsing [sent. 1809 len. 53]: So now , half-waking and all-winking , he may recall the house full of company , the coach-houses full of vehicles , the stables fall of horses , and the out-buildings full of attendants upon horses , until he is undecided about the present and comes forth to see how it is .
Parsing [sent. 1810 len. 23]: Then , with that impatient shake of himself , he may growl in the spirit , `` Rain , rain , rain !
Parsing [sent. 1811 len. 10]: Nothing but rain -- and no family here ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1812 len. 13]: as he goes in again and lies down with a gloomy yawn .
Parsing [sent. 1813 len. 48]: So with the dogs in the kennel-buildings across the park , who have their resfless fits and whose doleful voices when the wind has been very obstinate have even made it known in the house itself -- upstairs , downstairs , and in my Lady 's chamber .
Parsing [sent. 1814 len. 16]: They may hunt the whole country-side , while the raindrops are pattering round their inactivity .
Parsing [sent. 1815 len. 49]: So the rabbits with their self-betraying tails , frisking in and out of holes at roots of trees , may be lively with ideas of the breezy days when their ears are blown about or of those seasons of interest when there are sweet young plants to gnaw .

Parsing [sent. 1817 len. 42]: The discontented goose , who stoops to pass under the old gateway , twenty feet high , may gabble out , if we only knew it , a waddling preference for weather when the gateway casts its shadow on the ground .
Parsing [sent. 1818 len. 17]: Be this as it may , there is not much fancy otherwise stirring at Chesney Wold .
Parsing [sent. 1819 len. 35]: If there be a little at any odd moment , it goes , like a little noise in that old echoing place , a long way and usually leads off to ghosts and mystery .
Parsing [sent. 1820 len. 45]: It has rained so hard and rained so long down in Lincolnshire that Mrs. Rouncewell , the old housekeeper at Chesney Wold , has several times taken off her spectacles and cleaned them to make certain that the drops were not upon the glasses .
Parsing [sent. 1821 len. 27]: Mrs. Rouncewell might have been sufficiently assured by hearing the rain , but that she is rather deaf , which nothing will induce her to believe .
Parsing [sent. 1822 len. 53]: She is a fine old lady , handsome , stately , wonderfully neat , and has such a back and such a stomacher that if her stays should turn out when she dies to have been a broad old-fashioned family fire-grate , nobody who knows her would have cause to be surprised .
Parsing [sent. 1823 len. 6]: Weather affects Mrs. Rouncewell little .
Parsing [sent. 1824 len. 25]: The house is there in all weathers , and the house , as she expresses it , `` is what she looks at . ''
Parsing [sent. 1825 len. 63]: She sits in her room -LRB- in a side passage on the ground floor , with an arched window commanding a smooth quadrangle , adorned at regular intervals with smooth round trees and smooth round blocks of stone , as if the trees were going to play at bowls with the stones -RRB- , and the whole house reposes on her mind .

Parsing [sent. 1831 len. 20]: Her progress in the family began in the time of the last Sir Leicester and originated in the still-room .
Parsing [sent. 1832 len. 11]: The present representative of the Dedlocks is an excellent master .
Parsing [sent. 1833 len. 34]: He supposes all his dependents to be utterly bereft of individual characters , intentions , or opinions , and is persuaded that he was born to supersede the necessity of their having any .
Parsing [sent. 1834 len. 31]: If he were to make a discovery to the contrary , he would be simply stunned -- would never recover himself , most likely , except to gasp and die .
Parsing [sent. 1835 len. 19]: But he is an excellent master still , holding it a part of his state to be so .
Parsing [sent. 1836 len. 20]: He has a great liking for Mrs. Rouncewell ; he says she is a most respectable , creditable woman .
Parsing [sent. 1837 len. 71]: He always shakes hands with her when he comes down to Chesney Wold and when he goes away ; and if he were very ill , or if he were knocked down by accident , or run over , or placed in any situation expressive of a Dedlock at a disadvantage , he would say if he could speak , `` Leave me , and send Mrs. Rouncewell here ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1838 len. 17]: feeling his dignity , at such a pass , safer with her than with anybody else .

Parsing [sent. 1840 len. 24]: She has had two sons , of whom the younger ran wild , and went for a soldier , and never came back .

Parsing [sent. 1842 len. 87]: Her second son would have been provided for at Chesney Wold and would have been made steward in due season , but he took , when he was a schoolboy , to constructing steam-engines out of saucepans and setting birds to draw their own water with the least possible amount of labour , so assisting them with artful contrivance of hydraulic pressure that a thirsty canary had only , in a literal sense , to put his shoulder to the wheel and the job was done .
Parsing [sent. 1843 len. 8]: This propensity gave Mrs. Rouncewell great uneasiness .

Parsing [sent. 1849 len. 82]: Farther north he went , and farther north he grew up ; and if Sir Leicester Dedlock ever saw him when he came to Chesney Wold to visit his mother , or ever thought of him afterwards , it is certain that he only regarded him as one of a body of some odd thousand conspirators , swarthy and grim , who were in the habit of turning out by torchlight two or three nights in the week for unlawful purposes .
Parsing [sent. 1850 len. 88]: Nevertheless , Mrs. Rouncewell 's son has , in the course of nature and art , grown up , and established himself , and married , and called unto him Mrs. Rouncewell 's grandson , who , being out of his apprenticeship , and home from a journey in far countries , whither he was sent to enlarge his knowledge and complete his preparations for the venture of this life , stands leaning against the chimney-piece this very day in Mrs. Rouncewell 's room at Chesney Wold .

Parsing [sent. 1918 len. 30]: The grandmother , who is pleased that he should have that interest , accompanies him -- though to do him justice , he is exceedingly unwilling to trouble her .

Parsing [sent. 1922 len. 19]: The old housekeeper , with a gracious severity of deportment , waves her hand towards the great staircase .
Parsing [sent. 1923 len. 26]: Mr. Guppy and his friend follow Rosa ; Mrs. Rouncewell and her grandson follow them ; a young gardener goes before to open the shutters .
Parsing [sent. 1924 len. 26]: As is usually the case with people who go over houses , Mr. Guppy and his friend are dead beat before they have well begun .
Parsing [sent. 1925 len. 39]: They straggle about in wrong places , look at wrong things , do n't care for the right things , gape when more rooms are opened , exhibit profound depression of spirits , and are clearly knocked up .
Parsing [sent. 1926 len. 39]: In each successive chamber that they enter , Mrs. Rouncewell , who is as upright as the house itself , rests apart in a window-seat or other such nook and listens with stately approval to Rosa 's exposition .
Parsing [sent. 1927 len. 17]: Her grandson is so attentive to it that Rosa is shyer than ever -- and prettier .
Parsing [sent. 1928 len. 39]: Thus they pass on from room to room , raising the pictured Dedlocks for a few brief minutes as the young gardener admits the light , and reconsigning them to their graves as he shuts it out again .
Parsing [sent. 1929 len. 40]: It appears to the afflicted Mr. Guppy and his inconsolable friend that there is no end to the Dedlocks , whose family greatness seems to consist in their never having done anything to distinguish themselves for seven hundred years .
Parsing [sent. 1930 len. 15]: Even the long drawing-room of Chesney Wold can not revive Mr. Guppy 's spirits .
Parsing [sent. 1931 len. 19]: He is so low that he droops on the threshold and has hardly strength of mind to enter .
Parsing [sent. 1932 len. 23]: But a portrait over the chimney-piece , painted by the fashionable artist of the day , acts upon him like a charm .
Parsing [sent. 1933 len. 6]: He recovers in a moment .
Parsing [sent. 1934 len. 18]: He stares at it with uncommon interest ; he seems to be fixed and fascinated by it .

Parsing [sent. 1936 len. 4]: says Mr. Guppy .

Parsing [sent. 2554 len. 221]: He was not only a very handsome old gentleman -- upright and stalwart as he had been described to us -- with a massive grey head , a fine composure of face when silent , a figure that might have become corpulent but for his being so continually in earnest that he gave it no rest , and a chin that might have subsided into a double chin but for the vehement emphasis in which it was constantly required to assist ; but he was such a true gentleman in his manner , so chivalrously polite , his face was lighted by a smile of so much sweetness and tenderness , and it seemed so plain that he had nothing to hide , but showed himself exactly as he was -- incapable , as Richard said , of anything on a limited scale , and firing away with those blank great guns because he carried no small arms whatever -- that really I could not help looking at him with equal pleasure as he sat at dinner , whether he smilingly conversed with Ada and me , or was led by Mr. Jarndyce into some great volley of superlatives , or threw up his head like a bloodhound and gave out that tremendous `` Ha , ha , ha !
