Parsing [sent. 2762 len. 28]: I rang the bell , the servant came , and Mr. Guppy , laying his written card upon the table and making a dejected bow , departed .
Parsing [sent. 2763 len. 23]: Raising my eyes as he went out , I once more saw him looking at me after he had passed the door .
Parsing [sent. 2764 len. 21]: I sat there for another hour or more , finishing my books and payments and getting through plenty of business .
Parsing [sent. 2765 len. 28]: Then I arranged my desk , and put everything away , and was so composed and cheerful that I thought I had quite dismissed this unexpected incident .
Parsing [sent. 2766 len. 33]: But , when I went upstairs to my own room , I surprised myself by beginning to laugh about it and then surprised myself still more by beginning to cry about it .
Parsing [sent. 2767 len. 44]: In short , I was in a flutter for a little while and felt as if an old chord had been more coarsely touched than it ever had been since the days of the dear old doll , long buried in the garden .
Parsing [sent. 2768 len. 40]: Chapter X -- The Law -- Writer On the eastern borders of Chancery Lane , that is to say , more particularly in Cook 's Court , Cursitor Street , Mr. Snagsby , law-stationer , pursues his lawful calling .
Parsing [sent. 2769 len. 143]: In the shade of Cook 's Court , at most times a shady place , Mr. Snagsby has dealt in all sorts of blank forms of legal process ; in skins and rolls of parchment ; in paper -- foolscap , brief , draft , brown , white , whitey-brown , and blotting ; in stamps ; in office-quills , pens , ink , India-rubber , pounce , pins , pencils , sealing-wax , and wafers ; in red tape and green ferret ; in pocket-books , almanacs , diaries , and law lists ; in string boxes , rulers , inkstands -- glass and leaden -- pen-knives , scissors , bodkins , and other small office-cutlery ; in short , in articles too numerous to mention , ever since he was out of his time and went into partnership with Peffer .
Parsing [sent. 2770 len. 37]: On that occasion , Cook 's Court was in a manner revolutionized by the new inscription in fresh paint , PEFFER AND SNAGSBY , displacing the time-honoured and not easily to be deciphered legend PEFFER only .
Parsing [sent. 2771 len. 32]: For smoke , which is the London ivy , had so wreathed itself round Peffer 's name and clung to his dwelling-place that the affectionate parasite quite overpowered the parent tree .
Parsing [sent. 2772 len. 10]: Peffer is never seen in Cook 's Court now .
Parsing [sent. 2773 len. 45]: He is not expected there , for he has been recumbent this quarter of a century in the churchyard of St. Andrews , Holborn , with the waggons and hackney-coaches roaring past him all the day and half the night like one great dragon .
Parsing [sent. 2774 len. 101]: If he ever steal forth when the dragon is at rest to air himself again in Cook 's Court until admonished to return by the crowing of the sanguine cock in the cellar at the little dairy in Cursitor Street , whose ideas of daylight it would be curious to ascertain , since he knows from his personal observation next to nothing about it -- if Peffer ever do revisit the pale glimpses of Cook 's Court , which no law-stationer in the trade can positively deny , he comes invisibly , and no one is the worse or wiser .
Parsing [sent. 2775 len. 65]: In his lifetime , and likewise in the period of Snagsby 's `` time '' of seven long years , there dwelt with Peffer in the same law-stationering premises a niece -- a short , shrewd niece , something too violently compressed about the waist , and with a sharp nose like a sharp autumn evening , inclining to be frosty towards the end .
Parsing [sent. 2776 len. 86]: The Cook 's Courtiers had a rumour flying among them that the mother of this niece did , in her daughter 's childhood , moved by too jealous a solicitude that her figure should approach perfection , lace her up every morning with her maternal foot against the bed-post for a stronger hold and purchase ; and further , that she exhibited internally pints of vinegar and lemon-juice , which acids , they held , had mounted to the nose and temper of the patient .
Parsing [sent. 2777 len. 50]: With whichsoever of the many tongues of Rumour this frothy report originated , it either never reached or never influenced the ears of young Snagsby , who , having wooed and won its fair subject on his arrival at man 's estate , entered into two partnerships at once .
Parsing [sent. 2778 len. 47]: So now , in Cook 's Court , Cursitor Street , Mr. Snagsby and the niece are one ; and the niece still cherishes her figure , which , however tastes may differ , is unquestionably so far precious that there is mighty little of it .
Parsing [sent. 2779 len. 25]: Mr. and Mrs. Snagsby are not only one bone and one flesh , but , to the neighbours ' thinking , one voice too .
Parsing [sent. 2780 len. 20]: That voice , appearing to proceed from Mrs. Snagsby alone , is heard in Cook 's Court very often .
Parsing [sent. 2781 len. 18]: Mr. Snagsby , otherwise than as he finds expression through these dulcet tones , is rarely heard .
Parsing [sent. 2782 len. 26]: He is a mild , bald , timid man with a shining head and a scrubby clump of black hair sticking out at the back .
Parsing [sent. 2783 len. 7]: He tends to meekness and obesity .
Parsing [sent. 2784 len. 62]: As he stands at his door in Cook 's Court in his grey shop-coat and black calico sleeves , looking up at the clouds , or stands behind a desk in his dark shop with a heavy flat ruler , snipping and slicing at sheepskin in company with his two ` prentices , he is emphatically a retiring and unassuming man .
Parsing [sent. 2785 len. 67]: From beneath his feet , at such times , as from a shrill ghost unquiet in its grave , there frequently arise complainings and lamentations in the voice already mentioned ; and haply , on some occasions when these reach a sharper pitch than usual , Mr. Snagsby mentions to the ` prentices , `` I think my little woman is a-giving it to Guster ! ''
Parsing [sent. 2786 len. 55]: This proper name , so used by Mr. Snagsby , has before now sharpened the wit of the Cook 's Courtiers to remark that it ought to be the name of Mrs. Snagsby , seeing that she might with great force and expression be termed a Guster , in compliment to her stormy character .
Parsing [sent. 2787 len. 96]: It is , however , the possession , and the only possession except fifty shillings per annum and a very small box indifferently filled with clothing , of a lean young woman from a workhouse -LRB- by some supposed to have been christened Augusta -RRB- who , although she was farmed or contracted for during her growing time by an amiable benefactor of his species resident at Tooting , and can not fail to have been developed under the most favourable circumstances , `` has fits , '' which the parish ca n't account for .
Parsing [sent. 2788 len. 88]: Guster , really aged three or four and twenty , but looking a round ten years older , goes cheap with this unaccountable drawback of fits , and is so apprehensive of being returned on the hands of her patron saint that except when she is found with her head in the pail , or the sink , or the copper , or the dinner , or anything else that happens to be near her at the time of her seizure , she is always at work .
Parsing [sent. 2789 len. 65]: She is a satisfaction to the parents and guardians of the ` prentices , who feel that there is little danger of her inspiring tender emotions in the breast of youth ; she is a satisfaction to Mrs. Snagsby , who can always find fault with her ; she is a satisfaction to Mr. Snagsby , who thinks it a charity to keep her .
Parsing [sent. 2790 len. 18]: The law-stationer 's establishment is , in Guster 's eyes , a temple of plenty and splendour .
Parsing [sent. 2791 len. 34]: She believes the little drawing-room upstairs , always kept , as one may say , with its hair in papers and its pinafore on , to be the most elegant apartment in Christendom .
Parsing [sent. 2792 len. 43]: The view it commands of Cook 's Court at one end -LRB- not to mention a squint into Cursitor Street -RRB- and of Coavinses ' the sheriff 's officer 's backyard at the other she regards as a prospect of unequalled beauty .
Parsing [sent. 2793 len. 39]: The portraits it displays in oil -- and plenty of it too -- of Mr. Snagsby looking at Mrs. Snagsby and of Mrs. Snagsby looking at Mr. Snagsby are in her eyes as achievements of Raphael or Titian .
Parsing [sent. 2794 len. 9]: Guster has some recompenses for her many privations .
Parsing [sent. 2795 len. 16]: Mr. Snagsby refers everything not in the practical mysteries of the business to Mrs. Snagsby .
Parsing [sent. 2796 len. 112]: She manages the money , reproaches the tax-gatherers , appoints the times and places of devotion on Sundays , licenses Mr. Snagsby 's entertainments , and acknowledges no responsibility as to what she thinks fit to provide for dinner , insomuch that she is the high standard of comparison among the neighbouring wives a long way down Chancery Lane on both sides , and even out in Holborn , who in any domestic passages of arms habitually call upon their husbands to look at the difference between their -LRB- the wives ' -RRB- position and Mrs. Snagsby 's , and their -LRB- the husbands ' -RRB- behaviour and Mr. Snagsby 's .
Parsing [sent. 2797 len. 57]: Rumour , always flying bat-like about Cook 's Court and skimming in and out at everybody 's windows , does say that Mrs. Snagsby is jealous and inquisitive and that Mr. Snagsby is sometimes worried out of house and home , and that if he had the spirit of a mouse he would n't stand it .
Parsing [sent. 2798 len. 54]: It is even observed that the wives who quote him to their self-willed husbands as a shining example in reality look down upon him and that nobody does so with greater superciliousness than one particular lady whose lord is more than suspected of laying his umbrella on her as an instrument of correction .
Parsing [sent. 2799 len. 96]: But these vague whisperings may arise from Mr. Snagsby 's being in his way rather a meditative and poetical man , loving to walk in Staple Inn in the summer-time and to observe how countrified the sparrows and the leaves are , also to lounge about the Rolls Yard of a Sunday afternoon and to remark -LRB- if in good spirits -RRB- that there were old times once and that you 'd find a stone coffin or two now under that chapel , he 'll be bound , if you was to dig for it .
Parsing [sent. 2800 len. 96]: He solaces his imagination , too , by thinking of the many Chancellors and Vices , and Masters of the Rolls who are deceased ; and he gets such a flavour of the country out of telling the two ` prentices how he HAS heard say that a brook `` as clear as crystial '' once ran right down the middle of Holborn , when Turnstile really was a turnstile , leading slap away into the meadows -- gets such a flavour of the country out of this that he never wants to go there .
Parsing [sent. 2801 len. 25]: The day is closing in and the gas is lighted , but is not yet fully effective , for it is not quite dark .
Parsing [sent. 2802 len. 31]: Mr. Snagsby standing at his shop-door looking up at the clouds sees a crow who is out late skim westward over the slice of sky belonging to Cook 's Court .
Parsing [sent. 2803 len. 18]: The crow flies straight across Chancery Lane and Lincoln 's Inn Garden into Lincoln 's Inn Fields .
Parsing [sent. 2804 len. 17]: Here , in a large house , formerly a house of state , lives Mr. Tulkinghorn .
Parsing [sent. 2805 len. 26]: It is let off in sets of chambers now , and in those shrunken fragments of its greatness , lawyers lie like maggots in nuts .
Parsing [sent. 2806 len. 62]: But its roomy staircases , passages , and antechambers still remain ; and even its painted ceilings , where Allegory , in Roman helmet and celestial linen , sprawls among balustrades and pillars , flowers , clouds , and big-legged boys , and makes the head ache -- as would seem to be Allegory 's object always , more or less .
Parsing [sent. 2807 len. 34]: Here , among his many boxes labelled with transcendent names , lives Mr. Tulkinghorn , when not speechlessly at home in country-houses where the great ones of the earth are bored to death .
Parsing [sent. 2808 len. 10]: Here he is to-day , quiet at his table .
Parsing [sent. 2809 len. 11]: An oyster of the old school whom nobody can open .
Parsing [sent. 2810 len. 20]: Like as he is to look at , so is his apartment in the dusk of the present afternoon .
Parsing [sent. 2811 len. 15]: Rusty , out of date , withdrawing from attention , able to afford it .
Parsing [sent. 2812 len. 43]: Heavy , broad-backed , old-fashioned , mahogany-and-horsehair chairs , not easily lifted ; obsolete tables with spindle-legs and dusty baize covers ; presentation prints of the holders of great titles in the last generation or the last but one , environ him .
Parsing [sent. 2813 len. 31]: A thick and dingy Turkey-carpet muffles the floor where he sits , attended by two candles in old-fashioned silver candlesticks that give a very insufficient light to his large room .
Parsing [sent. 2814 len. 29]: The titles on the backs of his books have retired into the binding ; everything that can have a lock has got one ; no key is visible .
Parsing [sent. 2815 len. 7]: Very few loose papers are about .
Parsing [sent. 2816 len. 14]: He has some manuscript near him , but is not referring to it .
Parsing [sent. 2817 len. 29]: With the round top of an inkstand and two broken bits of sealing-wax he is silently and slowly working out whatever train of indecision is in his mind .
Parsing [sent. 2818 len. 21]: Now tbe inkstand top is in the middle , now the red bit of sealing-wax , now the black bit .
Parsing [sent. 2819 len. 5]: That 's not it .
Parsing [sent. 2820 len. 11]: Mr. Tulkinghorn must gather them all up and begin again .
Parsing [sent. 2821 len. 40]: Here , beneath the painted ceiling , with foreshortened Allegory staring down at his intrusion as if it meant to swoop upon him , and he cutting it dead , Mr. Tulkinghorn has at once his house and office .
Parsing [sent. 2822 len. 33]: He keeps no staff , only one middle-aged man , usually a little out at elbows , who sits in a high pew in the hall and is rarely overburdened with business .
Parsing [sent. 2823 len. 9]: Mr. Tulkinghorn is not in a common way .
Parsing [sent. 2824 len. 5]: He wants no clerks .
Parsing [sent. 2825 len. 14]: He is a great reservoir of confidences , not to be so tapped .
Parsing [sent. 2826 len. 11]: His clients want HIM ; he is all in all .
Parsing [sent. 2827 len. 38]: Drafts that he requires to be drawn are drawn by special-pleaders in the temple on mysterious instructions ; fair copies that he requires to be made are made at the stationers ' , expense being no consideration .
Parsing [sent. 2828 len. 21]: The middle-aged man in the pew knows scarcely more of the affairs of the peerage than any crossing-sweeper in Holborn .
Parsing [sent. 2829 len. 21]: The red bit , the black bit , the inkstand top , the other inkstand top , the little sand-box .
Parsing [sent. 2830 len. 2]: So !
Parsing [sent. 2831 len. 15]: You to the middle , you to the right , you to the left .
Parsing [sent. 2832 len. 13]: This train of indecision must surely be worked out now or never .
Parsing [sent. 2833 len. 2]: Now !
Parsing [sent. 2834 len. 40]: Mr. Tulkinghorn gets up , adjusts his spectacles , puts on his hat , puts the manuscript in his pocket , goes out , tells the middle-aged man out at elbows , `` I shall be back presently . ''
Parsing [sent. 2835 len. 8]: Very rarely tells him anything more explicit .
Parsing [sent. 2836 len. 25]: Mr. Tulkinghorn goes , as the crow came -- not quite so straight , but nearly -- to Cook 's Court , Cursitor Street .
Parsing [sent. 2837 len. 32]: To Snagsby 's , Law -- Stationer 's , Deeds engrossed and copied , Law -- Writing executed in all its branches , & c. , & c. , & c .
Parsing [sent. 2838 len. 25]: It is somewhere about five or six o'clock in the afternoon , and a balmy fragrance of warm tea hovers in Cook 's Court .
Parsing [sent. 2839 len. 7]: It hovers about Snagsby 's door .
Parsing [sent. 2840 len. 16]: The hours are early there : dinner at half-past one and supper at half-past nine .
Parsing [sent. 2841 len. 31]: Mr. Snagsby was about to descend into the subterranean regions to take tea when he looked out of his door just now and saw the crow who was out late .
Parsing [sent. 2842 len. 6]: `` Master at home ? ''
Parsing [sent. 2843 len. 89]: Guster is minding the shop , for the ` prentices take tea in the kitchen with Mr. and Mrs. Snagsby ; consequently , the robe-maker 's two daughters , combing their curls at the two glasses in the two second-floor windows of the opposite house , are not driving the two ` prentices to distraction as they fondly suppose , but are merely awakening the unprofitable admiration of Guster , whose hair wo n't grow , and never would , and it is confidently thought , never will .

Parsing [sent. 2845 len. 4]: says Mr. Tulkinghorn .
Parsing [sent. 2846 len. 11]: Master is at home , and Guster will fetch him .
Parsing [sent. 2847 len. 46]: Guster disappears , glad to get out of the shop , which she regards with mingled dread and veneration as a storehouse of awful implements of the great torture of the law -- a place not to be entered after the gas is turned off .

Parsing [sent. 2861 len. 16]: Mr. Snagsby turns up the gas and coughs behind his hand , modestly anticipating profit .
Parsing [sent. 2862 len. 24]: Mr. Snagsby , as a timid man , is accustomed to cough with a variety of expressions , and so to save words .
Parsing [sent. 2863 len. 13]: `` You copied some affidavits in that cause for me lately . ''
Parsing [sent. 2864 len. 9]: `` Yes , sir , we did . ''

Parsing [sent. 2928 len. 22]: He 'll go at it right on end if you want him to , as long as ever you like . ''
Parsing [sent. 2929 len. 15]: It is quite dark now , and the gas-lamps have acquired their full effect .
Parsing [sent. 2930 len. 171]: Jostling against clerks going to post the day 's letters , and against counsel and attorneys going home to dinner , and against plaintiffs and defendants and suitors of all sorts , and against the general crowd , in whose way the forensic wisdom of ages has interposed a million of obstacles to the transaction of the commonest business of life ; diving through law and equity , and through that kindred mystery , the street mud , which is made of nobody knows what and collects about us nobody knows whence or how -- we only knowing in general that when there is too much of it we find it necessary to shovel it away -- the lawyer and the law-stationer come to a rag and bottle shop and general emporium of much disregarded merchandise , lying and being in the shadow of the wall of Lincoln 's Inn , and kept , as is announced in paint , to all whom it may concern , by one Krook .
Parsing [sent. 2931 len. 14]: `` This is where he lives , sir , '' says the law-stationer .
Parsing [sent. 2932 len. 11]: `` This is where he lives , is it ? ''
Parsing [sent. 2933 len. 5]: says the lawyer unconcernedly .

Parsing [sent. 2935 len. 10]: `` Are you not going in , sir ? ''

Parsing [sent. 2959 len. 4]: Take the candle .
Parsing [sent. 2960 len. 4]: Up there ! ''
Parsing [sent. 2961 len. 22]: Mr. Krook , with his cat beside him , stands at the bottom of the staircase , looking after Mr. Tulkinghorn .
Parsing [sent. 2962 len. 4]: `` Hi-hi ! ''
Parsing [sent. 2963 len. 9]: he says when Mr. Tulkinghorn has nearly disappeared .
Parsing [sent. 2964 len. 8]: The lawyer looks down over the hand-rail .
Parsing [sent. 2965 len. 11]: The cat expands her wicked mouth and snarls at him .
Parsing [sent. 2966 len. 6]: `` Order , Lady Jane !
Parsing [sent. 2967 len. 8]: Behave yourself to visitors , my lady !
Parsing [sent. 2968 len. 10]: You know what they say of my lodger ? ''
Parsing [sent. 2969 len. 10]: whispers Krook , going up a step or two .
Parsing [sent. 2970 len. 9]: `` What do they say of him ? ''
Parsing [sent. 2971 len. 23]: `` They say he has sold himself to the enemy , but you and I know better -- he do n't buy .
Parsing [sent. 2972 len. 29]: I 'll tell you what , though ; my lodger is so black-humoured and gloomy that I believe he 'd as soon make that bargain as any other .
Parsing [sent. 2973 len. 8]: Do n't put him out , sir .
Parsing [sent. 2974 len. 6]: That 's my advice ! ''
Parsing [sent. 2975 len. 10]: Mr. Tulkinghorn with a nod goes on his way .
Parsing [sent. 2976 len. 11]: He comes to the dark door on the second floor .
Parsing [sent. 2977 len. 19]: He knocks , receives no answer , opens it , and accidentally extinguishes his candle in doing so .
Parsing [sent. 2978 len. 18]: The air of the room is almost bad enough to have extinguished it if he had not .
Parsing [sent. 2979 len. 17]: It is a small room , nearly black with soot , and grease , and dirt .
Parsing [sent. 2980 len. 26]: In the rusty skeleton of a grate , pinched at the middle as if poverty had gripped it , a red coke fire burns low .
Parsing [sent. 2981 len. 24]: In the corner by the chimney stand a deal table and a broken desk , a wilderness marked with a rain of ink .
Parsing [sent. 2982 len. 36]: In another corner a ragged old portmanteau on one of the two chairs serves for cabinet or wardrobe ; no larger one is needed , for it collapses like the cheeks of a starved man .
Parsing [sent. 2983 len. 23]: The floor is bare , except that one old mat , trodden to shreds of rope-yarn , lies perishing upon the hearth .
Parsing [sent. 2984 len. 42]: No curtain veils the darkness of the night , but the discoloured shutters are drawn together , and through the two gaunt holes pierced in them , famine might be staring in -- the banshee of the man upon the bed .
Parsing [sent. 2985 len. 36]: For , on a low bed opposite the fire , a confusion of dirty patchwork , lean-ribbed ticking , and coarse sacking , the lawyer , hesitating just within the doorway , sees a man .
Parsing [sent. 2986 len. 14]: He lies there , dressed in shirt and trousers , with bare feet .
Parsing [sent. 2987 len. 39]: He has a yellow look in the spectral darkness of a candle that has guttered down until the whole length of its wick -LRB- still burning -RRB- has doubled over and left a tower of winding-sheet above it .
Parsing [sent. 2988 len. 33]: His hair is ragged , mingling with his whiskers and his beard -- the latter , ragged too , and grown , like the scum and mist around him , in neglect .
Parsing [sent. 2989 len. 64]: Foul and filthy as the room is , foul and filthy as the air is , it is not easy to perceive what fumes those are which most oppress the senses in it ; but through the general sickliness and faintness , and the odour of stale tobacco , there comes into the lawyer 's mouth the bitter , vapid taste of opium .
Parsing [sent. 2990 len. 7]: `` Hallo , my friend ! ''
Parsing [sent. 2991 len. 12]: he cries , and strikes his iron candlestick against the door .
Parsing [sent. 2992 len. 8]: He thinks he has awakened his friend .
Parsing [sent. 2993 len. 14]: He lies a little turned away , but his eyes are surely open .
Parsing [sent. 2994 len. 7]: `` Hallo , my friend ! ''
Parsing [sent. 2995 len. 4]: he cries again .
Parsing [sent. 2996 len. 3]: `` Hallo !
Parsing [sent. 2997 len. 3]: Hallo ! ''
Parsing [sent. 2998 len. 36]: As he rattles on the door , the candle which has drooped so long goes out and leaves him in the dark , with the gaunt eyes in the shutters staring down upon the bed .
Parsing [sent. 2999 len. 36]: Chapter XI -- Our Dear Brother A touch on the lawyer 's wrinkled hand as he stands in the dark room , irresolute , makes him start and say , `` What 's that ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3000 len. 21]: `` It 's me , '' returns the old man of the house , whose breath is in his ear .
Parsing [sent. 3001 len. 8]: `` Ca n't you wake him ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3002 len. 4]: `` No . ''
Parsing [sent. 3003 len. 10]: `` What have you done with your candle ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3004 len. 6]: `` It 's gone out .
Parsing [sent. 3005 len. 5]: Here it is . ''
Parsing [sent. 3006 len. 22]: Krook takes it , goes to the fire , stoops over the red embers , and tries to get a light .
Parsing [sent. 3007 len. 15]: The dying ashes have no light to spare , and his endeavours are vain .
Parsing [sent. 3008 len. 29]: Muttering , after an ineffectual call to his lodger , that he will go downstairs and bring a lighted candle from the shop , the old man departs .
Parsing [sent. 3009 len. 26]: Mr. Tulkinghorn , for some new reason that he has , does not await his return in the room , but on the stairs outside .
Parsing [sent. 3010 len. 23]: The welcome light soon shines upon the wall , as Krook comes slowly up with his green-eyed cat following at his heels .
Parsing [sent. 3011 len. 10]: `` Does the man generally sleep like this ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3012 len. 8]: inquired the lawyer in a low voice .
Parsing [sent. 3013 len. 3]: `` Hi !
Parsing [sent. 3014 len. 17]: I do n't know , '' says Krook , shaking his head and lifting his eyebrows .
Parsing [sent. 3015 len. 18]: `` I know next to nothing of his habits except that he keeps himself very close . ''
Parsing [sent. 3016 len. 9]: Thus whispering , they both go in together .

Parsing [sent. 3018 len. 8]: Not so the eyes upon the bed .

Parsing [sent. 3037 len. 49]: So Mr. Krook addresses a crazy little woman who is his female lodger , who appears and vanishes in a breath , who soon returns accompanied by a testy medical man brought from his dinner , with a broad , snuffy upper lip and a broad Scotch tongue .

Parsing [sent. 3044 len. 14]: `` It 's probable he wull have been dead aboot three hours . ''
Parsing [sent. 3045 len. 23]: `` About that time , I should say , '' observes a dark young man on the other side of the bed .

Parsing [sent. 3048 len. 7]: The dark young man says yes .
Parsing [sent. 3049 len. 24]: `` Then I 'll just tak ' my depairture , '' replies the other , `` for I 'm nae gude here ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3050 len. 15]: With which remark he finishes his brief attendance and returns to finish his dinner .
Parsing [sent. 3051 len. 32]: The dark young surgeon passes the candle across and across the face and carefully examines the law-writer , who has established his pretensions to his name by becoming indeed No one .
Parsing [sent. 3052 len. 14]: `` I knew this person by sight very well , '' says he .
Parsing [sent. 3053 len. 15]: `` He has purchased opium of me for the last year and a half .
Parsing [sent. 3054 len. 8]: Was anybody present related to him ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3055 len. 7]: glancing round upon the three bystanders .
Parsing [sent. 3056 len. 21]: `` I was his landlord , '' grimly answers Krook , taking the candle from the surgeon 's outstretched hand .
Parsing [sent. 3057 len. 14]: `` He told me once I was the nearest relation he had . ''
Parsing [sent. 3058 len. 22]: `` He has died , '' says the surgeon , `` of an over-dose of opium , there is no doubt .
Parsing [sent. 3059 len. 8]: The room is strongly flavoured with it .
Parsing [sent. 3060 len. 23]: There is enough here now , '' taking an old teapot from Mr. Krook , `` to kill a dozen people . ''
Parsing [sent. 3061 len. 11]: `` Do you think he did it on purpose ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3062 len. 3]: asks Krook .
Parsing [sent. 3063 len. 6]: `` Took the over-dose ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3064 len. 4]: `` Yes ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3065 len. 13]: Krook almost smacks his lips with the unction of a horrible interest .
Parsing [sent. 3066 len. 6]: `` I ca n't say .
Parsing [sent. 3067 len. 18]: I should think it unlikely , as he has been in the habit of taking so much .
Parsing [sent. 3068 len. 5]: But nobody can tell .
Parsing [sent. 3069 len. 9]: He was very poor , I suppose ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3070 len. 6]: `` I suppose he was .
Parsing [sent. 3071 len. 29]: His room -- do n't look rich , '' says Krook , who might have changed eyes with his cat , as he casts his sharp glance around .
Parsing [sent. 3072 len. 26]: `` But I have never been in it since he had it , and he was too close to name his circumstances to me . ''
Parsing [sent. 3073 len. 9]: `` Did he owe you any rent ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3074 len. 5]: `` Six weeks . ''
Parsing [sent. 3075 len. 8]: `` He will never pay it ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3076 len. 9]: says the young man , resuming his examination .
Parsing [sent. 3077 len. 32]: `` It is beyond a doubt that he is indeed as dead as Pharaoh ; and to judge from his appearance and condition , I should think it a happy release .
Parsing [sent. 3078 len. 20]: Yet he must have been a good figure when a youth , and I dare say , good-looking . ''
Parsing [sent. 3079 len. 31]: He says this , not unfeelingly , while sitting on the bedstead 's edge with his face towards that other face and his hand upon the region of the heart .
Parsing [sent. 3080 len. 24]: `` I recollect once thinking there was something in his manner , uncouth as it was , that denoted a fall in life .
Parsing [sent. 3081 len. 5]: Was that so ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3082 len. 6]: he continues , looking round .
Parsing [sent. 3083 len. 25]: Krook replies , `` You might as well ask me to describe the ladies whose heads of hair I have got in sacks downstairs .
Parsing [sent. 3084 len. 31]: Than that he was my lodger for a year and a half and lived -- or did n't live -- by law-writing , I know no more of him . ''
Parsing [sent. 3085 len. 77]: During this dialogue Mr. Tulkinghorn has stood aloof by the old portmanteau , with his hands behind him , equally removed , to all appearance , from all three kinds of interest exhibited near the bed -- from the young surgeon 's professional interest in death , noticeable as being quite apart from his remarks on the deceased as an individual ; from the old man 's unction ; and the little crazy woman 's awe .
Parsing [sent. 3086 len. 12]: His imperturbable face has been as inexpressive as his rusty clothes .
Parsing [sent. 3087 len. 13]: One could not even say he has been thinking all this while .
Parsing [sent. 3088 len. 13]: He has shown neither patience nor impatience , nor attention nor abstraction .

Parsing [sent. 3090 len. 26]: As easily might the tone of a delicate musical instrument be inferred from its case , as the tone of Mr. Tulkinghorn from his case .
Parsing [sent. 3091 len. 15]: He now interposes , addressing the young surgeon in his unmoved , professional way .
Parsing [sent. 3092 len. 38]: `` I looked in here , '' he observes , `` just before you , with the intention of giving this deceased man , whom I never saw alive , some employment at his trade of copying .
Parsing [sent. 3093 len. 15]: I had heard of him from my stationer -- Snagsby of Cook 's Court .
Parsing [sent. 3094 len. 19]: Since no one here knows anything about him , it might be as well to send for Snagsby .
Parsing [sent. 3095 len. 3]: Ah ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3096 len. 35]: to the little crazy woman , who has often seen him in court , and whom he has often seen , and who proposes , in frightened dumb-show , to go for the law-stationer .
Parsing [sent. 3097 len. 6]: `` Suppose you do ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3098 len. 20]: While she is gone , the surgeon abandons his hopeless investigation and covers its subject with the patchwork counterpane .

Parsing [sent. 3100 len. 15]: Mr. Tulkinghorn says nothing , but stands , ever , near the old portmanteau .
Parsing [sent. 3101 len. 13]: Mr. Snagsby arrives hastily in his grey coat and his black sleeves .
Parsing [sent. 3102 len. 22]: `` Dear me , dear me , '' he says ; `` and it has come to this , has it !
Parsing [sent. 3103 len. 5]: Bless my soul ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3104 len. 19]: `` Can you give the person of the house any information about this unfortunate creature , Snagsby ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3105 len. 4]: inquires Mr. Tulkinghorn .
Parsing [sent. 3106 len. 12]: `` He was in arrears with his rent , it seems .
Parsing [sent. 3107 len. 10]: And he must be buried , you know . ''
Parsing [sent. 3108 len. 37]: `` Well , sir , '' says Mr. Snagsby , coughing his apologetic cough behind his hand , `` I really do n't know what advice I could offer , except sending for the beadle . ''
Parsing [sent. 3109 len. 13]: `` I do n't speak of advice , '' returns Mr. Tulkinghorn .
Parsing [sent. 3110 len. 27]: `` I could advise -- '' `` No one better , sir , I am sure , '' says Mr. Snagsby , with his deferential cough .
Parsing [sent. 3111 len. 25]: `` I speak of affording some clue to his connexions , or to where he came from , or to anything concerning him . ''
Parsing [sent. 3112 len. 55]: `` I assure you , sir , '' says Mr. Snagsby after prefacing his reply with his cough of general propitiation , `` that I no more know where he came from than I know -- '' `` Where he has gone to , perhaps , '' suggests the surgeon to help him out .
Parsing [sent. 3113 len. 3]: A pause .
Parsing [sent. 3114 len. 7]: Mr. Tulkinghorn looking at the law-stationer .
Parsing [sent. 3115 len. 15]: Mr. Krook , with his mouth open , looking for somebody to speak next .
Parsing [sent. 3116 len. 59]: `` As to his connexions , sir , '' says Mr. Snagsby , `` if a person was to say to me , `` Snagsby , here 's twenty thousand pound down , ready for you in the Bank of England if you 'll only name one of 'em , ' I could n't do it , sir !
Parsing [sent. 3117 len. 40]: About a year and a half ago -- to the best of my belief , at the time when he first came to lodge at the present rag and bottle shop -- '' `` That was the time ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3118 len. 6]: says Krook with a nod .
Parsing [sent. 3119 len. 108]: `` About a year and a half ago , '' says Mr. Snagsby , strengthened , `` he came into our place one morning after breakfast , and finding my little woman -LRB- which I name Mrs. Snagsby when I use that appellation -RRB- in our shop , produced a specimen of his handwriting and gave her to understand that he was in want of copying work to do and was , not to put too fine a point upon it , '' a favourite apology for plain speaking with Mr. Snagsby , which he always offers with a sort of argumentative frankness , `` hard up !
Parsing [sent. 3120 len. 28]: My little woman is not in general partial to strangers , particular -- not to put too fine a point upon it -- when they want anything .
Parsing [sent. 3121 len. 54]: But she was rather took by something about this person , whether by his being unshaved , or by his hair being in want of attention , or by what other ladies ' reasons , I leave you to judge ; and she accepted of the specimen , and likewise of the address .
Parsing [sent. 3122 len. 36]: My little woman has n't a good ear for names , '' proceeds Mr. Snagsby after consulting his cough of consideration behind his hand , `` and she considered Nemo equally the same as Nimrod .
Parsing [sent. 3123 len. 31]: In consequence of which , she got into a habit of saying to me at meals , ` Mr. Snagsby , you have n't found Nimrod any work yet ! '
Parsing [sent. 3124 len. 22]: or ` Mr. Snagsby , why did n't you give that eight and thirty Chancery folio in Jarndyce to Nimrod ? '
Parsing [sent. 3125 len. 4]: or such like .
Parsing [sent. 3126 len. 69]: And that is the way he gradually fell into job-work at our place ; and that is the most I know of him except that he was a quick hand , and a hand not sparing of night-work , and that if you gave him out , say , five and forty folio on the Wednesday night , you would have it brought in on the Thursday morning .
Parsing [sent. 3127 len. 45]: All of which -- '' Mr. Snagsby concludes by politely motioning with his hat towards the bed , as much as to add , `` I have no doubt my honourable friend would confirm if he were in a condition to do it . ''

Parsing [sent. 3130 len. 5]: You can read ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3131 len. 17]: `` No , I ca n't , '' returns the old man with a sudden grin .

Parsing [sent. 3133 len. 10]: He will get into some trouble or difficulty otherwise .
Parsing [sent. 3134 len. 34]: Being here , I 'll wait if you make haste , and then I can testify on his behalf , if it should ever be necessary , that all was fair and right .
Parsing [sent. 3135 len. 26]: If you will hold the candle for Mr. Snagsby , my friend , he 'll soon see whether there is anything to help you . ''

Parsing [sent. 3137 len. 10]: Ah , to be sure , so there is !
Parsing [sent. 3138 len. 31]: Mr. Tulkinghorn does not appear to have seen it before , though he is standing so close to it , and though there is very little else , heaven knows .
Parsing [sent. 3139 len. 14]: The marine-store merchant holds the light , and the law-stationer conducts the search .
Parsing [sent. 3140 len. 20]: The surgeon leans against the corner of the chimney-piece ; Miss Flite peeps and trembles just within the door .
Parsing [sent. 3141 len. 57]: The apt old scholar of the old school , with his dull black breeches tied with ribbons at the knees , his large black waistcoat , his long-sleeved black coat , and his wisp of limp white neckerchief tied in the bow the peerage knows so well , stands in exactly the same place and attitude .
Parsing [sent. 3142 len. 89]: There are some worthless articles of clothing in the old portmanteau ; there is a bundle of pawnbrokers ' duplicates , those turnpike tickets on the road of poverty ; there is a crumpled paper , smelling of opium , on which are scrawled rough memoranda -- as , took , such a day , so many grains ; took , such another day , so many more -- begun some time ago , as if with the intention of being regularly continued , but soon left off .
Parsing [sent. 3143 len. 21]: There are a few dirty scraps of newspapers , all referring to coroners ' inquests ; there is nothing else .
Parsing [sent. 3144 len. 12]: They search the cupboard and the drawer of the ink-splashed table .

Parsing [sent. 3147 len. 11]: A knife and some odd halfpence are all he finds .
Parsing [sent. 3148 len. 19]: Mr. Snagsby 's suggestion is the practical suggestion after all , and the beadle must be called in .
Parsing [sent. 3149 len. 19]: So the little crazy lodger goes for the beadle , and the rest come out of the room .
Parsing [sent. 3150 len. 9]: `` Do n't leave the cat there ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3151 len. 11]: says the surgeon ; `` that wo n't do ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3152 len. 24]: Mr. Krook therefore drives her out before him , and she goes furtively downstairs , winding her lithe tail and licking her lips .
Parsing [sent. 3153 len. 5]: `` Good night ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3154 len. 12]: says Mr. Tulkinghorn , and goes home to Allegory and meditation .
Parsing [sent. 3155 len. 11]: By this time the news has got into the court .
Parsing [sent. 3156 len. 36]: Groups of its inhabitants assemble to discuss the thing , and the outposts of the army of observation -LRB- principally boys -RRB- are pushed forward to Mr. Krook 's window , which they closely invest .
Parsing [sent. 3157 len. 49]: A policeman has already walked up to the room , and walked down again to the door , where he stands like a tower , only condescending to see the boys at his base occasionally ; but whenever he does see them , they quail and fall back .
Parsing [sent. 3158 len. 46]: Mrs. Perkins , who has not been for some weeks on speaking terms with Mrs. Piper in consequence for an unpleasantness originating in young Perkins ' having `` fetched '' young Piper `` a crack , '' renews her friendly intercourse on this auspicious occasion .
Parsing [sent. 3159 len. 50]: The potboy at the corner , who is a privileged amateur , as possessing official knowledge of life and having to deal with drunken men occasionally , exchanges confidential communications with the policeman and has the appearance of an impregnable youth , unassailable by truncheons and unconfinable in station-houses .
Parsing [sent. 3160 len. 25]: People talk across the court out of window , and bare-headed scouts come hurrying in from Chancery Lane to know what 's the matter .
Parsing [sent. 3161 len. 31]: The general feeling seems to be that it 's a blessing Mr. Krook war n't made away with first , mingled with a little natural disappointment that he was not .
Parsing [sent. 3162 len. 11]: In the midst of this sensation , the beadle arrives .
Parsing [sent. 3163 len. 40]: The beadle , though generally understood in the neighbourhood to be a ridiculous institution , is not without a certain popularity for the moment , if it were only as a man who is going to see the body .
Parsing [sent. 3164 len. 33]: The policeman considers him an imbecile civilian , a remnant of the barbarous watchmen times , but gives him admission as something that must be borne with until government shall abolish him .
Parsing [sent. 3165 len. 24]: The sensation is heightened as the tidings spread from mouth to mouth that the beadle is on the ground and has gone in .
Parsing [sent. 3166 len. 22]: By and by the beadle comes out , once more intensifying the sensation , which has rather languished in the interval .
Parsing [sent. 3167 len. 26]: He is understood to be in want of witnesses for the inquest to-morrow who can tell the coroner and jury anything whatever respecting the deceased .
Parsing [sent. 3168 len. 12]: Is immediately referred to innumerable people who can tell nothing whatever .
Parsing [sent. 3169 len. 68]: Is made more imbecile by being constantly informed that Mrs. Green 's son `` was a law-writer his-self and knowed him better than anybody , '' which son of Mrs. Green 's appears , on inquiry , to be at the present time aboard a vessel bound for China , three months out , but considered accessible by telegraph on application to the Lords of the Admiralty .
Parsing [sent. 3170 len. 31]: Beadle goes into various shops and parlours , examining the inhabitants , always shutting the door first , and by exclusion , delay , and general idiotcy exasperating the public .
Parsing [sent. 3171 len. 7]: Policeman seen to smile to potboy .
Parsing [sent. 3172 len. 7]: Public loses interest and undergoes reaction .
Parsing [sent. 3173 len. 35]: Taunts the beadle in shrill youthful voices with having boiled a boy , choruses fragments of a popular song to that effect and importing that the boy was made into soup for the workhouse .
Parsing [sent. 3174 len. 46]: Policeman at last finds it necessary to support the law and seize a vocalist , who is released upon the flight of the rest on condition of his getting out of this then , come , and cutting it -- a condition he immediately observes .
Parsing [sent. 3175 len. 91]: So the sensation dies off for the time ; and the unmoved policeman -LRB- to whom a little opium , more or less , is nothing -RRB- , with his shining hat , stiff stock , inflexible great-coat , stout belt and bracelet , and all things fitting , pursues his lounging way with a heavy tread , beating the palms of his white gloves one against the other and stopping now and then at a street-corner to look casually about for anything between a lost child and a murder .
Parsing [sent. 3176 len. 48]: Under cover of the night , the feeble-minded beadle comes flitting about Chancery Lane with his summonses , in which every juror 's name is wrongly spelt , and nothing rightly spelt but the beadle 's own name , which nobody can read or wants to know .
Parsing [sent. 3177 len. 68]: The summonses served and his witnesses forewarned , the beadle goes to Mr. Krook 's to keep a small appointment he has made with certain paupers , who , presently arriving , are conducted upstairs , where they leave the great eyes in the shutter something new to stare at , in that last shape which earthly lodgings take for No one -- and for Every one .
Parsing [sent. 3178 len. 51]: And all that night the coffin stands ready by the old portmanteau ; and the lonely figure on the bed , whose path in life has lain through five and forty years , lies there with no more track behind him that any one can trace than a deserted infant .
Parsing [sent. 3179 len. 33]: Next day the court is all alive -- is like a fair , as Mrs. Perkins , more than reconciled to Mrs. Piper , says in amicable conversation with that excellent woman .
Parsing [sent. 3180 len. 69]: The coroner is to sit in the first-floor room at the Sol 's Arms , where the Harmonic Meetings take place twice a week and where the chair is filled by a gentleman of professional celebrity , faced by Little Swills , the comic vocalist , who hopes -LRB- according to the bill in the window -RRB- that his friends will rally round him and support first-rate talent .
Parsing [sent. 3181 len. 14]: The Sol 's Arms does a brisk stroke of business all the morning .
Parsing [sent. 3182 len. 33]: Even children so require sustaining under the general excitement that a pieman who has established himself for the occasion at the corner of the court says his brandy-balls go off like smoke .
Parsing [sent. 3183 len. 48]: What time the beadle , hovering between the door of Mr. Krook 's establishment and the door of the Sol 's Arms , shows the curiosity in his keeping to a few discreet spirits and accepts the compliment of a glass of ale or so in return .
Parsing [sent. 3184 len. 35]: At the appointed hour arrives the coroner , for whom the jurymen are waiting and who is received with a salute of skittles from the good dry skittle-ground attached to the Sol 's Arms .
Parsing [sent. 3185 len. 10]: The coroner frequents more public-houses than any man alive .
Parsing [sent. 3186 len. 24]: The smell of sawdust , beer , tobacco-smoke , and spirits is inseparable in his vocation from death in its most awful shapes .
Parsing [sent. 3187 len. 56]: He is conducted by the beadle and the landlord to the Harmonic Meeting Room , where he puts his hat on the piano and takes a Windsor-chair at the head of a long table formed of several short tables put together and ornamented with glutinous rings in endless involutions , made by pots and glasses .
Parsing [sent. 3188 len. 15]: As many of the jury as can crowd together at the table sit there .
Parsing [sent. 3189 len. 14]: The rest get among the spittoons and pipes or lean against the piano .
Parsing [sent. 3190 len. 35]: Over the coroner 's head is a small iron garland , the pendant handle of a bell , which rather gives the majesty of the court the appearance of going to be hanged presently .
Parsing [sent. 3191 len. 7]: Call over and swear the jury !
Parsing [sent. 3192 len. 55]: While the ceremony is in progress , sensation is created by the entrance of a chubby little man in a large shirt-collar , with a moist eye and an inflamed nose , who modestly takes a position near the door as one of the general public , but seems familiar with the room too .
Parsing [sent. 3193 len. 9]: A whisper circulates that this is Little Swills .
Parsing [sent. 3194 len. 29]: It is considered not unlikely that he will get up an imitation of the coroner and make it the principal feature of the Harmonic Meeting in the evenlng .
Parsing [sent. 3195 len. 10]: `` Well , gentlemen -- '' the coroner begins .
Parsing [sent. 3196 len. 8]: `` Silence there , will you ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3197 len. 4]: says the beadle .

Parsing [sent. 3205 len. 4]: cries the beadle .

Parsing [sent. 3270 len. 5]: Very well , gentlemen !
Parsing [sent. 3271 len. 33]: Here 's a man unknown , proved to have been in the habit of taking opium in large quantities for a year and a half , found dead of too much opium .

Parsing [sent. 3279 len. 22]: While the coroner buttons his great-coat , Mr. Tulkinghorn and he give private audience to the rejected witness in a corner .
Parsing [sent. 3280 len. 32]: That graceless creature only knows that the dead man -LRB- whom he recognized just now by his yellow face and black hair -RRB- was sometimes hooted and pursued about the streets .
Parsing [sent. 3281 len. 58]: That one cold winter night when he , the boy , was shivering in a doorway near his crossing , the man turned to look at him , and came back , and having questioned him and found that he had not a friend in the world , said , `` Neither have I. Not one ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3282 len. 14]: and gave him the price of a supper and a night 's lodging .

Parsing [sent. 3290 len. 14]: For some little time the jurymen hang about the Sol 's Arms colloquially .
Parsing [sent. 3291 len. 46]: In the sequel , half-a-dozen are caught up in a cloud of pipe-smoke that pervades the parlour of the Sol 's Arms ; two stroll to Hampstead ; and four engage to go half-price to the play at night , and top up with oysters .
Parsing [sent. 3292 len. 8]: Little Swills is treated on several hands .
Parsing [sent. 3293 len. 27]: Being asked what he thinks of the proceedings , characterizes them -LRB- his strength lying in a slangular direction -RRB- as `` a rummy start . ''
Parsing [sent. 3294 len. 47]: The landlord of the Sol 's Arms , finding Little Swills so popular , commends him highly to the jurymen and public , observing that for a song in character he do n't know his equal and that that man 's character-wardrobe would fill a cart .
Parsing [sent. 3295 len. 22]: Thus , gradually the Sol 's Arms melts into the shadowy night and then flares out of it strong in gas .
Parsing [sent. 3296 len. 34]: The Harmonic Meeting hour arriving , the gentleman of professional celebrity takes the chair , is faced -LRB- red-faced -RRB- by Little Swills ; their friends rally round them and support first-rate talent .
Parsing [sent. 3297 len. 39]: In the zenith of the evening , Little Swills says , `` Gentlemen , if you 'll permit me , I 'll attempt a short description of a scene of real life that came off here to-day . ''

Parsing [sent. 3299 len. 17]: The jingling piano at last is silent , and the Harmonic friends rally round their pillows .
Parsing [sent. 3300 len. 35]: Then there is rest around the lonely figure , now laid in its last earthly habitation ; and it is watched by the gaunt eyes in the shutters through some quiet hours of night .
Parsing [sent. 3301 len. 57]: If this forlorn man could have been prophetically seen lying here by the mother at whose breast he nestled , a little child , with eyes upraised to her loving face , and soft hand scarcely knowing how to close upon the neck to which it crept , what an impossibility the vision would have seemed !
Parsing [sent. 3302 len. 35]: Oh , if in brighter days the now-extinguished fire within him ever burned for one woman who held him in her heart , where is she , while these ashes are above the ground !
Parsing [sent. 3303 len. 48]: It is anything but a night of rest at Mr. Snagsby 's , in Cook 's Court , where Guster murders sleep by going , as Mr. Snagsby himself allows -- not to put too fine a point upon it -- out of one fit into twenty .
Parsing [sent. 3304 len. 31]: The occasion of this seizure is that Guster has a tender heart and a susceptible something that possibly might have been imagination , but for Tooting and her patron saint .
Parsing [sent. 3305 len. 130]: Be it what it may , now , it was so direfully impressed at tea-time by Mr. Snagsby 's account of the inquiry at which he had assisted that at supper-time she projected herself into the kitchen , preceded by a flying Dutch cheese , and fell into a fit of unusual duration , which she only came out of to go into another , and another , and so on through a chain of fits , with short intervals between , of which she has pathetically availed herself by consuming them in entreaties to Mrs. Snagsby not to give her warning `` when she quite comes to , '' and also in appeals to the whole establishment to lay her down on the stones and go to bed .
Parsing [sent. 3306 len. 56]: Hence , Mr. Snagsby , at last hearing the cock at the little dairy in Cursitor Street go into that disinterested ecstasy of his on the subject of daylight , says , drawing a long breath , though the most patient of men , `` I thought you was dead , I am sure ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3307 len. 50]: What question this enthusiastic fowl supposes he settles when he strains himself to such an extent , or why he should thus crow -LRB- so men crow on various triumphant public occasions , however -RRB- about what can not be of any moment to him , is his affair .
Parsing [sent. 3308 len. 13]: It is enough that daylight comes , morning comes , noon comes .
Parsing [sent. 3309 len. 83]: Then the active and intelligent , who has got into the morning papers as such , comes with his pauper company to Mr. Krook 's and bears off the body of our dear brother here departed to a hemmed-in churchyard , pestiferous and obscene , whence malignant diseases are communicated to the bodies of our dear brothers and sisters who have not departed , while our dear brothers and sisters who hang about official back-stairs -- would to heaven they HAD departed !
Parsing [sent. 3310 len. 7]: -- are very complacent and agreeable .
Parsing [sent. 3311 len. 34]: Into a beastly scrap of ground which a Turk would reject as a savage abomination and a Caffre would shudder at , they bring our dear brother here departed to receive Christian burial .
Parsing [sent. 3312 len. 96]: With houses looking on , on every side , save where a reeking little tunnel of a court gives access to the iron gate -- with every villainy of life in action close on death , and every poisonous element of death in action close on life -- here they lower our dear brother down a foot or two , here sow him in corruption , to be raised in corruption : an avenging ghost at many a sick-bedside , a shameful testimony to future ages how civilization and barbarism walked this boastful island together .
Parsing [sent. 3313 len. 24]: Come night , come darkness , for you can not come too soon or stay too long by such a place as this !
Parsing [sent. 3314 len. 30]: Come , straggling lights into the windows of the ugly houses ; and you who do iniquity therein , do it at least with this dread scene shut out !
Parsing [sent. 3315 len. 27]: Come , flame of gas , burning so sullenly above the iron gate , on which the poisoned air deposits its witch-ointment slimy to the touch !
Parsing [sent. 3316 len. 16]: It is well that you should call to every passerby , `` Look here ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3317 len. 18]: With the night comes a slouching figure through the tunnel-court to the outside of the iron gate .
Parsing [sent. 3318 len. 22]: It holds the gate with its hands and looks in between the bars , stands looking in for a little while .
Parsing [sent. 3319 len. 20]: It then , with an old broom it carries , softly sweeps the step and makes the archway clean .
Parsing [sent. 3320 len. 19]: It does so very busily and trimly , looks in again a little while , and so departs .
Parsing [sent. 3321 len. 6]: Jo , is it thou ?
Parsing [sent. 3322 len. 4]: Well , well !
Parsing [sent. 3323 len. 33]: Though a rejected witness , who `` ca n't exactly say '' what will be done to him in greater hands than men 's , thou art not quite in outer darkness .
Parsing [sent. 3324 len. 28]: There is something like a distant ray of light in thy muttered reason for this : `` He wos wery good to me , he wos ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3325 len. 24]: Chapter XII -- On the Watch It has left off raining down in Lincolnshire at last , and Chesney Wold has taken heart .
Parsing [sent. 3326 len. 20]: Mrs. Rouncewell is full of hospitable cares , for Sir Leicester and my Lady are coming home from Paris .
Parsing [sent. 3327 len. 16]: The fashionable intelligence has found it out and communicates the glad tidings to benighted England .
Parsing [sent. 3328 len. 47]: It has also found out that they will entertain a brilliant and distinguished circle of the ELITE of the BEAU MONDE -LRB- the fashionable intelligence is weak in English , but a giant refreshed in French -RRB- at the ancient and hospitable family seat in Lincolnshire .
Parsing [sent. 3329 len. 56]: For the greater honour of the brilliant and distinguished circle , and of Chesney Wold into the bargain , the broken arch of the bridge in the park is mended ; and the water , now retired within its proper limits and again spanned gracefully , makes a figure in the prospect from the house .
Parsing [sent. 3330 len. 24]: The clear , cold sunshine glances into the brittle woods and approvingly beholds the sharp wind scattering the leaves and drying the moss .
Parsing [sent. 3331 len. 25]: It glides over the park after the moving shadows of the clouds , and chases them , and never catches them , all day .
Parsing [sent. 3332 len. 23]: It looks in at the windows and touches the ancestral portraits with bars and patches of brightness never contemplated by the painters .
Parsing [sent. 3333 len. 32]: Athwart the picture of my Lady , over the great chimney-piece , it throws a broad bend-sinister of light that strikes down crookedly into the hearth and seems to rend it .
Parsing [sent. 3334 len. 41]: Through the same cold sunshine and the same sharp wind , my Lady and Sir Leicester , in their travelling chariot -LRB- my Lady 's woman and Sir Leicester 's man affectionate in the rumble -RRB- , start for home .
Parsing [sent. 3335 len. 97]: With a considerable amount of jingling and whip-cracking , and many plunging demonstrations on the part of two bare-backed horses and two centaurs with glazed hats , jack-boots , and flowing manes and tails , they rattle out of the yard of the Hotel Bristol in the Place Vendome and canter between the sun-and-shadow-chequered colonnade of the Rue de Rivoli and the garden of the ill-fated palace of a headless king and queen , off by the Place of Concord , and the Elysian Fields , and the Gate of the Star , out of Paris .
Parsing [sent. 3336 len. 24]: Sooth to say , they can not go away too fast , for even here my Lady Dedlock has been bored to death .
Parsing [sent. 3337 len. 21]: Concert , assembly , opera , theatre , drive , nothing is new to my Lady under the worn-out heavens .
Parsing [sent. 3338 len. 149]: Only last Sunday , when poor wretches were gay -- within the walls playing with children among the clipped trees and the statues in the Palace Garden ; walking , a score abreast , in the Elysian Fields , made more Elysian by performing dogs and wooden horses ; between whiles filtering -LRB- a few -RRB- through the gloomy Cathedral of Our Lady to say a word or two at the base of a pillar within flare of a rusty little gridiron-full of gusty little tapers ; without the walls encompassing Paris with dancing , love-making , wine-drinking , tobacco-smoking , tomb-visiting , billiard card and domino playing , quack-doctoring , and much murderous refuse , animate and inanimate -- only last Sunday , my Lady , in the desolation of Boredom and the clutch of Giant Despair , almost hated her own maid for being in spirits .
Parsing [sent. 3339 len. 12]: She can not , therefore , go too fast from Paris .
Parsing [sent. 3340 len. 50]: Weariness of soul lies before her , as it lies behind -- her Ariel has put a girdle of it round the whole earth , and it can not be unclasped -- but the imperfect remedy is always to fly from the last place where it has been experienced .
Parsing [sent. 3341 len. 20]: Fling Paris back into the distance , then , exchanging it for endless avenues and cross-avenues of wintry trees !
Parsing [sent. 3342 len. 63]: And , when next beheld , let it be some leagues away , with the Gate of the Star a white speck glittering in the sun , and the city a mere mound in a plain -- two dark square towers rising out of it , and light and shadow descending on it aslant , like the angels in Jacob 's dream !
Parsing [sent. 3343 len. 13]: Sir Leicester is generally in a complacent state , and rarely bored .
Parsing [sent. 3344 len. 16]: When he has nothing else to do , he can always contemplate his own greatness .
Parsing [sent. 3345 len. 15]: It is a considerable advantage to a man to have so inexhaustible a subject .
Parsing [sent. 3346 len. 22]: After reading his letters , he leans back in his corner of the carriage and generally reviews his importance to society .
Parsing [sent. 3347 len. 12]: `` You have an unusual amount of correspondence this morning ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3348 len. 8]: says my Lady after a long time .
Parsing [sent. 3349 len. 6]: She is fatigued with reading .
Parsing [sent. 3350 len. 9]: Has almost read a page in twenty miles .
Parsing [sent. 3351 len. 7]: `` Nothing in it , though .
Parsing [sent. 3352 len. 4]: Nothing whatever . ''

Parsing [sent. 3355 len. 4]: `` Ha ! ''

Parsing [sent. 3373 len. 17]: `` I should like to walk a little , '' says my Lady with unmistakable distinctness .
Parsing [sent. 3374 len. 8]: `` Please to stop the carriage . ''
Parsing [sent. 3375 len. 34]: The carriage is stopped , the affectionate man alights from the rumble , opens the door , and lets down the steps , obedient to an impatient motion of my Lady 's hand .
Parsing [sent. 3376 len. 31]: My Lady alights so quickly and walks away so quickly that Sir Leicester , for all his scrupulous politeness , is unable to assist her , and is left behind .
Parsing [sent. 3377 len. 16]: A space of a minute or two has elapsed before he comes up with her .
Parsing [sent. 3378 len. 34]: She smiles , looks very handsome , takes his arm , lounges with him for a quarter of a mile , is very much bored , and resumes her seat in the carriage .
Parsing [sent. 3379 len. 33]: The rattle and clatter continue through the greater part of three days , with more or less of bell-jingling and whip-cracking , and more or less plunging of centaurs and bare-backed horses .
Parsing [sent. 3380 len. 19]: Their courtly politeness to each other at the hotels where they tarry is the theme of general admiration .
Parsing [sent. 3381 len. 42]: Though my Lord IS a little aged for my Lady , says Madame , the hostess of the Golden Ape , and though he might be her amiable father , one can see at a glance that they love each other .
Parsing [sent. 3382 len. 25]: One observes my Lord with his white hair , standing , hat in hand , to help my Lady to and from the carriage .
Parsing [sent. 3383 len. 28]: One observes my Lady , how recognisant of my Lord 's politeness , with an inclination of her gracious head and the concession of her so-genteel fingers !
Parsing [sent. 3384 len. 4]: It is ravishing !
Parsing [sent. 3385 len. 18]: The sea has no appreciation of great men , but knocks them about like the small fry .
Parsing [sent. 3386 len. 29]: It is habitually hard upon Sir Leicester , whose countenance it greenly mottles in the manner of sage-cheese and in whose aristocratic system it effects a dismal revolution .
Parsing [sent. 3387 len. 9]: It is the Radical of Nature to him .
Parsing [sent. 3388 len. 35]: Nevertheless , his dignity gets over it after stopping to refit , and he goes on with my Lady for Chesney Wold , lying only one night in London on the way to Lincolnshire .
Parsing [sent. 3389 len. 66]: Through the same cold sunlight , colder as the day declines , and through the same sharp wind , sharper as the separate shadows of bare trees gloom together in the woods , and as the Ghost 's Walk , touched at the western corner by a pile of fire in the sky , resigns itself to coming night , they drive into the park .
Parsing [sent. 3390 len. 88]: The rooks , swinging in their lofty houses in the elm-tree avenue , seem to discuss the question of the occupancy of the carriage as it passes underneath , some agreeing that Sir Leicester and my Lady are come down , some arguing with malcontents who wo n't admit it , now all consenting to consider the question disposed of , now all breaking out again in violent debate , incited by one obstinate and drowsy bird who will persist in putting in a last contradictory croak .
Parsing [sent. 3391 len. 44]: Leaving them to swing and caw , the travelling chariot rolls on to the house , where fires gleam warmly through some of the windows , though not through so many as to give an inhabited expression to the darkening mass of front .
Parsing [sent. 3392 len. 11]: But the brilliant and distinguished circle will soon do that .
Parsing [sent. 3393 len. 20]: Mrs. Rouncewell is in attendance and receives Sir Leicester 's customary shake of the hand with a profound curtsy .
Parsing [sent. 3394 len. 9]: `` How do you do , Mrs. Rouncewell ?
Parsing [sent. 3395 len. 8]: I am glad to see you . ''
Parsing [sent. 3396 len. 18]: `` I hope I have the honour of welcoming you in good health , Sir Leicester ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3397 len. 9]: `` In excellent health , Mrs. Rouncewell . ''
Parsing [sent. 3398 len. 16]: `` My Lady is looking charmingly well , '' says Mrs. Rouncewell with another curtsy .
Parsing [sent. 3399 len. 23]: My Lady signifies , without profuse expenditure of words , that she is as wearily well as she can hope to be .
Parsing [sent. 3400 len. 41]: But Rosa is in the distance , behind the housekeeper ; and my Lady , who has not subdued the quickness of her observation , whatever else she may have conquered , asks , `` Who is that girl ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3401 len. 10]: `` A young scholar of mine , my Lady .
Parsing [sent. 3402 len. 3]: Rosa . ''
Parsing [sent. 3403 len. 7]: `` Come here , Rosa ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3404 len. 12]: Lady Dedlock beckons her , with even an appearance of interest .
Parsing [sent. 3405 len. 14]: `` Why , do you know how pretty you are , child ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3406 len. 11]: she says , touching her shoulder with her two forefingers .
Parsing [sent. 3407 len. 19]: Rosa , very much abashed , says , `` No , if you please , my Lady ! ''
Parsing [sent. 3408 len. 22]: and glances up , and glances down , and do n't know where to look , but looks all the prettier .
Parsing [sent. 3409 len. 7]: `` How old are you ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3410 len. 7]: `` Nineteen , my Lady . ''
Parsing [sent. 3411 len. 9]: `` Nineteen , '' repeats my Lady thoughtfully .
Parsing [sent. 3412 len. 12]: `` Take care they do n't spoil you by flattery . ''
Parsing [sent. 3413 len. 7]: `` Yes , my Lady . ''
Parsing [sent. 3414 len. 34]: My Lady taps her dimpled cheek with the same delicate gloved fingers and goes on to the foot of the oak staircase , where Sir Leicester pauses for her as her knightly escort .
Parsing [sent. 3415 len. 44]: A staring old Dedlock in a panel , as large as life and as dull , looks as if he did n't know what to make of it , which was probably his general state of mind in the days of Queen Elizabeth .
Parsing [sent. 3416 len. 20]: That evening , in the housekeeper 's room , Rosa can do nothing but murmur Lady Dedlock 's praises .
Parsing [sent. 3417 len. 31]: She is so affable , so graceful , so beautiful , so elegant ; has such a sweet voice and such a thrilling touch that Rosa can feel it yet !
Parsing [sent. 3418 len. 19]: Mrs. Rouncewell confirms all this , not without personal pride , reserving only the one point of affability .
Parsing [sent. 3419 len. 10]: Mrs. Rouncewell is not quite sure as to that .
Parsing [sent. 3420 len. 62]: Heaven forbid that she should say a syllable in dispraise of any member of that excellent family , above all , of my Lady , whom the whole world admires ; but if my Lady would only be `` a little more free , '' not quite so cold and distant , Mrs. Rounceweil thinks she would be more affable . ''
Parsing [sent. 3421 len. 49]: 'T is almost a pity , '' Mrs. Rouncewell adds -- only `` almost '' because it borders on impiety to suppose that anything could be better than it is , in such an express dispensation as the Dedlock affairs -- `` that my Lady has no family .

Parsing [sent. 3423 len. 14]: `` Might not that have made her still more proud , grandmother ? ''
Parsing [sent. 3424 len. 19]: says Watt , who has been home and come back again , he is such a good grandson .

Parsing [sent. 3432 len. 5]: Only a joke ! ''

Parsing [sent. 3438 len. 16]: He happens to glance at Rosa , who looks down and is very shy indeed .
Parsing [sent. 3439 len. 40]: But according to the old superstition , it should be Rosa 's ears that burn , and not her fresh bright cheeks , for my Lady 's maid is holding forth about her at this moment with surpassing energy .
Parsing [sent. 3440 len. 58]: My Lady 's maid is a Frenchwoman of two and thirty , from somewhere in the southern country about Avignon and Marseilles , a large-eyed brown woman with black hair who would be handsome but for a certain feline mouth and general uncomfortable tightness of face , rendering the jaws too eager and the skull too prominent .
Parsing [sent. 3441 len. 49]: There is something indefinably keen and wan about her anatomy , and she has a watchful way of looking out of the corners of her eyes without turning her head which could be pleasantly dispensed with , especially when she is in an ill humour and near knives .
Parsing [sent. 3442 len. 31]: Through all the good taste of her dress and little adornments , these objections so express themselves that she seems to go about like a very neat she-wolf imperfectly tamed .
Parsing [sent. 3443 len. 81]: Besides being accomplished in all the knowledge appertaining to her post , she is almost an Englishwoman in her acquaintance with the language ; consequently , she is in no want of words to shower upon Rosa for having attracted my Lady 's attention , and she pours them out with such grim ridicule as she sits at dinner that her companion , the affectionate man , is rather relieved when she arrives at the spoon stage of that performance .

Parsing [sent. 3454 len. 96]: In short , it is such an admirable thing that Mademoiselle Hortense ca n't forget it ; but at meals for days afterwards , even among her countrywomen and others attached in like capacity to the troop of visitors , relapses into silent enjoyment of the joke -- an enjoyment expressed , in her own convivial manner , by an additional tightness of face , thin elongation of compressed lips , and sidewise look , which intense appreciation of humour is frequently reflected in my Lady 's mirrors when my Lady is not among them .
Parsing [sent. 3455 len. 20]: All the mirrors in the house are brought into action now , many of them after a long blank .
Parsing [sent. 3456 len. 81]: They reflect handsome faces , simpering faces , youthful faces , faces of threescore and ten that will not submit to be old ; the entire collection of faces that have come to pass a January week or two at Chesney Wold , and which the fashionable intelligence , a mighty hunter before the Lord , hunts with a keen scent , from their breaking cover at the Court of St. James 's to their being run down to death .
Parsing [sent. 3457 len. 8]: The place in Lincolnshire is all alive .
Parsing [sent. 3458 len. 31]: By day guns and voices are heard ringing in the woods , horsemen and carriages enliven the park roads , servants and hangers-on pervade the village and the Dedlock Arms .
Parsing [sent. 3459 len. 42]: Seen by night from distant openings in the trees , the row of windows in the long drawing-room , where my Lady 's picture hangs over the great chimney-piece , is like a row of jewels set in a black frame .
Parsing [sent. 3460 len. 29]: On Sunday the chill little church is almost warmed by so much gallant company , and the general flavour of the Dedlock dust is quenched in delicate perfumes .
Parsing [sent. 3461 len. 25]: The brilliant and distinguished circle comprehends within it no contracted amount of education , sense , courage , honour , beauty , and virtue .
Parsing [sent. 3462 len. 16]: Yet there is something a little wrong about it in despite of its immense advantages .
Parsing [sent. 3463 len. 5]: What can it be ?
Parsing [sent. 3464 len. 2]: Dandyism ?
Parsing [sent. 3465 len. 37]: There is no King George the Fourth now -LRB- more the pity -RRB- to set the dandy fashion ; there are no clear-starched jack-towel neckcloths , no short-waisted coats , no false calves , no stays .
Parsing [sent. 3466 len. 35]: There are no caricatures , now , of effeminate exquisites so arrayed , swooning in opera boxes with excess of delight and being revived by other dainty creatures poking long-necked scent-bottles at their noses .
Parsing [sent. 3467 len. 40]: There is no beau whom it takes four men at once to shake into his buckskins , or who goes to see all the executions , or who is troubled with the self-reproach of having once consumed a pea .
Parsing [sent. 3468 len. 49]: But is there dandyism in the brilliant and distinguished circle notwithstanding , dandyism of a more mischievous sort , that has got below the surface and is doing less harmless things than jack-towelling itself and stopping its own digestion , to which no rational person need particularly object ?
Parsing [sent. 3469 len. 4]: Why , yes .
Parsing [sent. 3470 len. 6]: It can not be disguised .
Parsing [sent. 3471 len. 30]: There ARE at Chesney Wold this January week some ladies and gentlemen of the newest fashion , who have set up a dandyism -- in religion , for instance .
Parsing [sent. 3472 len. 55]: Who in mere lackadaisical want of an emotion have agreed upon a little dandy talk about the vulgar wanting faith in things in general , meaning in the things that have been tried and found wanting , as though a low fellow should unaccountably lose faith in a bad shilling after finding it out !
Parsing [sent. 3473 len. 28]: Who would make the vulgar very picturesque and faithful by putting back the hands upon the clock of time and cancelling a few hundred years of history .
Parsing [sent. 3474 len. 37]: There are also ladies and gentlemen of another fashion , not so new , but very elegant , who have agreed to put a smooth glaze on the world and to keep down all its realities .
Parsing [sent. 3475 len. 9]: For whom everything must be languid and pretty .
Parsing [sent. 3476 len. 8]: Who have found out the perpetual stoppage .
Parsing [sent. 3477 len. 12]: Who are to rejoice at nothing and be sorry for nothing .
Parsing [sent. 3478 len. 9]: Who are not to be disturbed by ideas .
Parsing [sent. 3479 len. 51]: On whom even the fine arts , attending in powder and walking backward like the Lord Chamberlain , must array themselves in the milliners ' and tailors ' patterns of past generations and be particularly careful not to be in earnest or to receive any impress from the moving age .
Parsing [sent. 3480 len. 47]: Then there is my Lord Boodle , of considerable reputation with his party , who has known what office is and who tells Sir Leicester Dedlock with much gravity , after dinner , that he really does not see to what the present age is tending .
Parsing [sent. 3481 len. 32]: A debate is not what a debate used to be ; the House is not what the House used to be ; even a Cabinet is not what it formerly was .
Parsing [sent. 3482 len. 74]: He perceives with astonishment that supposing the present government to be overthrown , the limited choice of the Crown , in the formation of a new ministry , would lie between Lord Coodle and Sir Thomas Doodle -- supposing it to be impossible for the Duke of Foodle to act with Goodle , which may be assumed to be the case in consequence of the breach arising out of that affair with Hoodle .
Parsing [sent. 3483 len. 42]: Then , giving the Home Department and the leadership of the House of Commons to Joodle , the Exchequer to Koodle , the Colonies to Loodle , and the Foreign Office to Moodle , what are you to do with Noodle ?
Parsing [sent. 3484 len. 17]: You ca n't offer him the Presidency of the Council ; that is reserved for Poodle .
Parsing [sent. 3485 len. 19]: You ca n't put him in the Woods and Forests ; that is hardly good enough for Quoodle .
Parsing [sent. 3486 len. 3]: What follows ?
Parsing [sent. 3487 len. 33]: That the country is shipwrecked , lost , and gone to pieces -LRB- as is made manifest to the patriotism of Sir Leicester Dedlock -RRB- because you ca n't provide for Noodle !
Parsing [sent. 3488 len. 52]: On the other hand , the Right Honourable William Buffy , M.P. , contends across the table with some one else that the shipwreck of the country -- about which there is no doubt ; it is only the manner of it that is in question -- is attributable to Cuffy .
Parsing [sent. 3489 len. 102]: If you had done with Cuffy what you ought to have done when he first came into Parliament , and had prevented him from going over to Duffy , you would have got him into alliance with Fuffy , you would have had with you the weight attaching as a smart debater to Guffy , you would have brought to bear upon the elections the wealth of Huffy , you would have got in for three counties Juffy , Kuffy , and Luffy , and you would have strengthened your administration by the official knowledge and the business habits of Muffy .
Parsing [sent. 3490 len. 19]: All this , instead of being as you now are , dependent on the mere caprice of Puffy !
Parsing [sent. 3491 len. 50]: As to this point , and as to some minor topics , there are differences of opinion ; but it is perfectly clear to the brilliant and distinguished circle , all round , that nobody is in question but Boodle and his retinue , and Buffy and HIS retinue .
Parsing [sent. 3492 len. 12]: These are the great actors for whom the stage is reserved .
Parsing [sent. 3493 len. 79]: A People there are , no doubt -- a certain large number of supernumeraries , who are to be occasionally addressed , and relied upon for shouts and choruses , as on the theatrical stage ; but Boodle and Buffy , their followers and families , their heirs , executors , administrators , and assigns , are the born first-actors , managers , and leaders , and no others can appear upon the scene for ever and ever .
Parsing [sent. 3494 len. 29]: In this , too , there is perhaps more dandyism at Chesney Wold than the brilliant and distinguished circle will find good for itself in the long run .
Parsing [sent. 3495 len. 33]: For it is , even with the stillest and politest circles , as with the circle the necromancer draws around him -- very strange appearances may be seen in active motion outside .
Parsing [sent. 3496 len. 21]: With this difference , that being realities and not phantoms , there is the greater danger of their breaking in .

Parsing [sent. 3498 len. 6]: Only one room is empty .
Parsing [sent. 3499 len. 23]: It is a turret chamber of the third order of merit , plainly but comfortably furnished and having an old-fashioned business air .
Parsing [sent. 3500 len. 23]: It is Mr. Tulkinghorn 's room , and is never bestowed on anybody else , for he may come at any time .
Parsing [sent. 3501 len. 6]: He is not come yet .
Parsing [sent. 3502 len. 71]: It is his quiet habit to walk across the park from the village in fine weather , to drop into this room as if he had never been out of it since he was last seen there , to request a servant to inform Sir Leicester that he is arrived in case he should be wanted , and to appear ten minutes before dinner in the shadow of the library-door .
Parsing [sent. 3503 len. 46]: He sleeps in his turret with a complaining flag-staff over his head , and has some leads outside on which , any fine morning when he is down here , his black figure may be seen walking before breakfast like a larger species of rook .
Parsing [sent. 3504 len. 23]: Every day before dinner , my Lady looks for him in the dusk of the library , but he is not there .

Parsing [sent. 3507 len. 16]: Every night the answer is , `` No , my Lady , not yet . ''

Parsing [sent. 3514 len. 48]: At length , one afternoon a little before sunset , when the bright groups of figures which have for the last hour or two enlivened the Ghost 's Walk are all dispersed and only Sir Leicester and my Lady remain upon the terrace , Mr. Tulkinghorn appears .
