Parsing [sent. 8357 len. 5]: And downstairs he shuffles .
Parsing [sent. 8358 len. 36]: But downstairs is the charitable Guster , holding by the handrail of the kitchen stairs and warding off a fit , as yet doubtfully , the same having been induced by Mrs. Snagsby 's screaming .
Parsing [sent. 8359 len. 29]: She has her own supper of bread and cheese to hand to Jo , with whom she ventures to interchange a word or so for the first time .
Parsing [sent. 8360 len. 14]: `` Here 's something to eat , poor boy , '' says Guster .
Parsing [sent. 8361 len. 11]: `` Thank ` ee , mum , '' says Jo .
Parsing [sent. 8362 len. 6]: `` Are you hungry ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8363 len. 4]: `` Jist ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8364 len. 3]: says Jo .
Parsing [sent. 8365 len. 14]: `` What 's gone of your father and your mother , eh ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8366 len. 12]: Jo stops in the middle of a bite and looks petrified .
Parsing [sent. 8367 len. 40]: For this orphan charge of the Christian saint whose shrine was at Tooting has patted him on the shoulder , and it is the first time in his life that any decent hand has been so laid upon him .
Parsing [sent. 8368 len. 13]: `` I never know 'd nothink about 'em , '' says Jo .
Parsing [sent. 8369 len. 13]: `` No more did n't I of mine , '' cries Guster .
Parsing [sent. 8370 len. 22]: She is repressing symptoms favourable to the fit when she seems to take alarm at something and vanishes down the stairs .
Parsing [sent. 8371 len. 16]: `` Jo , '' whispers the law-stationer softly as the boy lingers on the step .
Parsing [sent. 8372 len. 9]: `` Here I am , Mr. Snagsby ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8373 len. 16]: `` I did n't know you were gone -- there 's another half-crown , Jo .
Parsing [sent. 8374 len. 21]: It was quite right of you to say nothing about the lady the other night when we were out together .
Parsing [sent. 8375 len. 5]: It would breed trouble .
Parsing [sent. 8376 len. 10]: You ca n't be too quiet , Jo . ''
Parsing [sent. 8377 len. 8]: `` I am fly , master ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8378 len. 6]: And so , good night .
Parsing [sent. 8379 len. 22]: A ghostly shade , frilled and night-capped , follows the law-stationer to the room he came from and glides higher up .
Parsing [sent. 8380 len. 34]: And henceforth he begins , go where he will , to be attended by another shadow than his own , hardly less constant than his own , hardly less quiet than his own .
Parsing [sent. 8381 len. 20]: And into whatsoever atmosphere of secrecy his own shadow may pass , let all concerned in the secrecy beware !
Parsing [sent. 8382 len. 24]: For the watchful Mrs. Snagsby is there too -- bone of his bone , flesh of his flesh , shadow of his shadow .
Parsing [sent. 8383 len. 31]: Chapter XXVI -- Sharpshooters Wintry morning , looking with dull eyes and sallow face upon the neighbourhood of Leicester Square , finds its inhabitants unwilling to get out of bed .
Parsing [sent. 8384 len. 38]: Many of them are not early risers at the brightest of times , being birds of night who roost when the sun is high and are wide awake and keen for prey when the stars shine out .
Parsing [sent. 8385 len. 43]: Behind dingy blind and curtain , in upper story and garret , skulking more or less under false names , false hair , false titles , false jewellery , and false histories , a colony of brigands lie in their first sleep .
Parsing [sent. 8386 len. 78]: Gentlemen of the green-baize road who could discourse from personal experience of foreign galleys and home treadmills ; spies of strong governments that eternally quake with weakness and miserable fear , broken traitors , cowards , bullies , gamesters , shufflers , swindlers , and false witnesses ; some not unmarked by the branding-iron beneath their dirty braid ; all with more cruelty in them than was in Nero , and more crime than is in Newgate .
Parsing [sent. 8387 len. 78]: For howsoever bad the devil can be in fustian or smock-frock -LRB- and he can be very bad in both -RRB- , he is a more designing , callous , and intolerable devil when he sticks a pin in his shirt-front , calls himself a gentleman , backs a card or colour , plays a game or so of billiards , and knows a little about bills and promissory notes than in any other form he wears .
Parsing [sent. 8388 len. 23]: And in such form Mr. Bucket shall find him , when he will , still pervading the tributary channels of Leicester Square .
Parsing [sent. 8389 len. 12]: But the wintry morning wants him not and wakes him not .
Parsing [sent. 8390 len. 12]: It wakes Mr. George of the shooting gallery and his familiar .
Parsing [sent. 8391 len. 11]: They arise , roll up and stow away their mattresses .
Parsing [sent. 8392 len. 47]: Mr. George , having shaved himself before a looking-glass of minute proportions , then marches out , bare-headed and bare-chested , to the pump in the little yard and anon comes back shining with yellow soap , friction , drifting rain , and exceedingly cold water .
Parsing [sent. 8393 len. 146]: As he rubs himself upon a large jack-towel , blowing like a military sort of diver just come up , his hair curling tighter and tighter on his sunburnt temples the more he rubs it so that it looks as if it never could be loosened by any less coercive instrument than an iron rake or a curry-comb -- as he rubs , and puffs , and polishes , and blows , turning his head from side to side the more conveniently to excoriate his throat , and standing with his body well bent forward to keep the wet from his martial legs , Phil , on his knees lighting a fire , looks round as if it were enough washing for him to see all that done , and sufficient renovation for one day to take in the superfluous health his master throws off .
Parsing [sent. 8394 len. 45]: When Mr. George is dry , he goes to work to brush his head with two hard brushes at once , to that unmerciful degree that Phil , shouldering his way round the gallery in the act of sweeping it , winks with sympathy .
Parsing [sent. 8395 len. 16]: This chafing over , the ornamental part of Mr. George 's toilet is soon performed .
Parsing [sent. 8396 len. 36]: He fills his pipe , lights it , and marches up and down smoking , as his custom is , while Phil , raising a powerful odour of hot rolls and coffee , prepares breakfast .
Parsing [sent. 8397 len. 9]: He smokes gravely and marches in slow time .
Parsing [sent. 8398 len. 16]: Perhaps this morning 's pipe is devoted to the memory of Gridley in his grave .
Parsing [sent. 8399 len. 30]: `` And so , Phil , '' says George of the shooting gallery after several turns in silence , `` you were dreaming of the country last night ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8400 len. 21]: Phil , by the by , said as much in a tone of surprise as he scrambled out of bed .
Parsing [sent. 8401 len. 8]: `` Yes , guv ` ner . ''
Parsing [sent. 8402 len. 7]: `` What was it like ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8403 len. 19]: `` I hardly know what it was like , guv ` ner , '' said Phil , considering .
Parsing [sent. 8404 len. 11]: `` How did you know it was the country ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8405 len. 10]: `` On account of the grass , I think .
Parsing [sent. 8406 len. 13]: And the swans upon it , '' says Phil after further consideration .
Parsing [sent. 8407 len. 11]: `` What were the swans doing on the grass ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8408 len. 14]: `` They was a-eating of it , I expect , '' says Phil .
Parsing [sent. 8409 len. 15]: The master resumes his march , and the man resumes his preparation of breakfast .
Parsing [sent. 8410 len. 71]: It is not necessarily a lengthened preparation , being limited to the setting forth of very simple breakfast requisites for two and the broiling of a rasher of bacon at the fire in the rusty grate ; but as Phil has to sidle round a considerable part of the gallery for every object he wants , and never brings two objects at once , it takes time under the circumstances .
Parsing [sent. 8411 len. 7]: At length the breakfast is ready .
Parsing [sent. 8412 len. 33]: Phil announcing it , Mr. George knocks the ashes out of his pipe on the hob , stands his pipe itself in the chimney corner , and sits down to the meal .
Parsing [sent. 8413 len. 28]: When he has helped himself , Phil follows suit , sitting at the extreme end of the little oblong table and taking his plate on his knees .
Parsing [sent. 8414 len. 21]: Either in humility , or to hide his blackened hands , or because it is his natural manner of eating .
Parsing [sent. 8415 len. 32]: `` The country , '' says Mr. George , plying his knife and fork ; `` why , I suppose you never clapped your eyes on the country , Phil ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8416 len. 16]: `` I see the marshes once , '' says Phil , contentedly eating his breakfast .
Parsing [sent. 8417 len. 5]: `` What marshes ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8418 len. 10]: `` THE marshes , commander , '' returns Phil .
Parsing [sent. 8419 len. 6]: `` Where are they ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8420 len. 23]: `` I do n't know where they are , '' says Phil ; `` but I see 'em , guv ` ner .
Parsing [sent. 8421 len. 4]: They was flat .
Parsing [sent. 8422 len. 4]: And miste . ''
Parsing [sent. 8423 len. 24]: Governor and commander are interchangeable terms with Phil , expressive of the same respect and deference and applicable to nobody but Mr. George .
Parsing [sent. 8424 len. 11]: `` I was born in the country , Phil . ''
Parsing [sent. 8425 len. 8]: `` Was you indeed , commander ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8426 len. 3]: `` Yes .
Parsing [sent. 8427 len. 5]: And bred there . ''
Parsing [sent. 8428 len. 29]: Phil elevates his one eyebrow , and after respectfully staring at his master to express interest , swallows a great gulp of coffee , still staring at him .
Parsing [sent. 8429 len. 19]: `` There 's not a bird 's note that I do n't know , '' says Mr. George .
Parsing [sent. 8430 len. 14]: `` Not many an English leaf or berry that I could n't name .
Parsing [sent. 8431 len. 17]: Not many a tree that I could n't climb yet if I was put to it .
Parsing [sent. 8432 len. 9]: I was a real country boy , once .
Parsing [sent. 8433 len. 9]: My good mother lived in the country . ''
Parsing [sent. 8434 len. 18]: `` She must have been a fine old lady , guv ` ner , '' Phil observes .
Parsing [sent. 8435 len. 3]: `` Aye !
Parsing [sent. 8436 len. 17]: And not so old either , five and thirty years ago , '' says Mr. George .
Parsing [sent. 8437 len. 26]: `` But I 'll wager that at ninety she would be near as upright as me , and near as broad across the shoulders . ''
Parsing [sent. 8438 len. 12]: `` Did she die at ninety , guv ` ner ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8439 len. 3]: inquires Phil .
Parsing [sent. 8440 len. 3]: `` No .
Parsing [sent. 8441 len. 2]: Bosh !
Parsing [sent. 8442 len. 11]: Let her rest in peace , God bless her ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8443 len. 4]: says the trooper .
Parsing [sent. 8444 len. 15]: `` What set me on about country boys , and runaways , and good-for-nothings ?
Parsing [sent. 8445 len. 6]: You , to be sure !
Parsing [sent. 8446 len. 15]: So you never clapped your eyes upon the country -- marshes and dreams excepted .
Parsing [sent. 8447 len. 3]: Eh ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8448 len. 5]: Phil shakes his head .
Parsing [sent. 8449 len. 9]: `` Do you want to see it ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8450 len. 17]: `` N-no , I do n't know as I do , particular , '' says Phil .
Parsing [sent. 8451 len. 11]: `` The town 's enough for you , eh ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8452 len. 37]: `` Why , you see , commander , '' says Phil , `` I ai n't acquainted with anythink else , and I doubt if I ai n't a-getting too old to take to novelties . ''
Parsing [sent. 8453 len. 9]: `` How old ARE you , Phil ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8454 len. 15]: asks the trooper , pausing as he conveys his smoking saucer to his lips .
Parsing [sent. 8455 len. 14]: `` I 'm something with a eight in it , '' says Phil .
Parsing [sent. 8456 len. 7]: `` It ca n't be eighty .
Parsing [sent. 8457 len. 4]: Nor yet eighteen .
Parsing [sent. 8458 len. 8]: It 's betwixt 'em , somewheres . ''
Parsing [sent. 8459 len. 41]: Mr. George , slowly putting down his saucer without tasting its contents , is laughingly beginning , `` Why , what the deuce , Phil -- '' when he stops , seeing that Phil is counting on his dirty fingers .
Parsing [sent. 8460 len. 24]: `` I was just eight , '' says Phil , `` agreeable to the parish calculation , when I went with the tinker .
Parsing [sent. 8461 len. 43]: I was sent on a errand , and I see him a-sittin under a old buildin with a fire all to himself wery comfortable , and he says , ` Would you like to come along a me , my man ? '
Parsing [sent. 8462 len. 19]: I says ` Yes , ' and him and me and the fire goes home to Clerkenwell together .
Parsing [sent. 8463 len. 6]: That was April Fool Day .
Parsing [sent. 8464 len. 39]: I was able to count up to ten ; and when April Fool Day come round again , I says to myself , ` Now , old chap , you 're one and a eight in it . '
Parsing [sent. 8465 len. 25]: April Fool Day after that , I says , ` Now , old chap , you 're two and a eight in it . '
Parsing [sent. 8466 len. 23]: In course of time , I come to ten and a eight in it ; two tens and a eight in it .
Parsing [sent. 8467 len. 29]: When it got so high , it got the upper hand of me , but this is how I always know there 's a eight in it . ''
Parsing [sent. 8468 len. 4]: `` Ah ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8469 len. 8]: says Mr. George , resuming his breakfast .
Parsing [sent. 8470 len. 8]: `` And where 's the tinker ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8471 len. 31]: `` Drink put him in the hospital , guv ` ner , and the hospital put him -- in a glass-case , I HAVE heerd , '' Phil replies mysteriously .
Parsing [sent. 8472 len. 8]: `` By that means you got promotion ?
Parsing [sent. 8473 len. 7]: Took the business , Phil ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8474 len. 10]: `` Yes , commander , I took the business .
Parsing [sent. 8475 len. 5]: Such as it was .
Parsing [sent. 8476 len. 37]: It was n't much of a beat -- round Saffron Hill , Hatton Garden , Clerkenwell , Smiffeld , and there -- poor neighbourhood , where they uses up the kettles till they 're past mending .
Parsing [sent. 8477 len. 25]: Most of the tramping tinkers used to come and lodge at our place ; that was the best part of my master 's earnings .
Parsing [sent. 8478 len. 8]: But they did n't come to me .
Parsing [sent. 8479 len. 6]: I war n't like him .
Parsing [sent. 8480 len. 8]: He could sing 'em a good song .
Parsing [sent. 8481 len. 4]: I could n't !
Parsing [sent. 8482 len. 23]: He could play 'em a tune on any sort of pot you please , so as it was iron or block tin .
Parsing [sent. 8483 len. 24]: I never could do nothing with a pot but mend it or bile it -- never had a note of music in me .
Parsing [sent. 8484 len. 15]: Besides , I was too ill-looking , and their wives complained of me . ''
Parsing [sent. 8485 len. 6]: `` They were mighty particular .
Parsing [sent. 8486 len. 11]: You would pass muster in a crowd , Phil ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8487 len. 8]: says the trooper with a pleasant smile .
Parsing [sent. 8488 len. 15]: `` No , guv ` ner , '' returns Phil , shaking his head .
Parsing [sent. 8489 len. 7]: `` No , I should n't .
Parsing [sent. 8490 len. 114]: I was passable enough when I went with the tinker , though nothing to boast of then ; but what with blowing the fire with my mouth when I was young , and spileing my complexion , and singeing my hair off , and swallering the smoke , and what with being nat ` rally unfort ` nate in the way of running against hot metal and marking myself by sich means , and what with having turn-ups with the tinker as I got older , almost whenever he was too far gone in drink -- which was almost always -- my beauty was queer , wery queer , even at that time .
Parsing [sent. 8491 len. 59]: As to since , what with a dozen years in a dark forge where the men was given to larking , and what with being scorched in a accident at a gas-works , and what with being blowed out of winder case-filling at the firework business , I am ugly enough to be made a show on ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8492 len. 21]: Resigning himself to which condition with a perfectly satisfied manner , Phil begs the favour of another cup of coffee .
Parsing [sent. 8493 len. 22]: While drinking it , he says , `` It was after the case-filling blow-up when I first see you , commander .
Parsing [sent. 8494 len. 4]: You remember ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8495 len. 6]: `` I remember , Phil .
Parsing [sent. 8496 len. 9]: You were walking along in the sun . ''
Parsing [sent. 8497 len. 29]: `` Crawling , guv ` ner , again a wall -- '' `` True , Phil -- shouldering your way on -- '' `` In a night-cap ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8498 len. 5]: exclaims Phil , excited .
Parsing [sent. 8499 len. 16]: `` In a night-cap -- '' `` And hobbling with a couple of sticks ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8500 len. 7]: cries Phil , still more excited .
Parsing [sent. 8501 len. 7]: `` With a couple of sticks .
Parsing [sent. 8502 len. 41]: When -- '' `` When you stops , you know , '' cries Phil , putting down his cup and saucer and hastily removing his plate from his knees , `` and says to me , ` What , comrade !
Parsing [sent. 8503 len. 8]: You have been in the wars ! '
Parsing [sent. 8504 len. 45]: I did n't say much to you , commander , then , for I was took by surprise that a person so strong and healthy and bold as you was should stop to speak to such a limping bag of bones as I was .
Parsing [sent. 8505 len. 39]: But you says to me , says you , delivering it out of your chest as hearty as possible , so that it was like a glass of something hot , ` What accident have you met with ?
Parsing [sent. 8506 len. 6]: You have been badly hurt .
Parsing [sent. 8507 len. 7]: What 's amiss , old boy ?
Parsing [sent. 8508 len. 10]: Cheer up , and tell us about it ! '
Parsing [sent. 8509 len. 3]: Cheer up !
Parsing [sent. 8510 len. 5]: I was cheered already !
Parsing [sent. 8511 len. 32]: I says as much to you , you says more to me , I says more to you , you says more to me , and here I am , commander !
Parsing [sent. 8512 len. 7]: Here I am , commander ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8513 len. 16]: cries Phil , who has started from his chair and unaccountably begun to sidle away .
Parsing [sent. 8514 len. 23]: `` If a mark 's wanted , or if it will improve the business , let the customers take aim at me .
Parsing [sent. 8515 len. 7]: They ca n't spoil MY beauty .
Parsing [sent. 8516 len. 5]: I 'M all right .
Parsing [sent. 8517 len. 3]: Come on !
Parsing [sent. 8518 len. 15]: If they want a man to box at , let 'em box at me .
Parsing [sent. 8519 len. 9]: Let 'em knock me well about the head .
Parsing [sent. 8520 len. 5]: I do n't mind .
Parsing [sent. 8521 len. 23]: If they want a light-weight to be throwed for practice , Cornwall , Devonshire , or Lancashire , let 'em throw me .
Parsing [sent. 8522 len. 6]: They wo n't hurt ME .
Parsing [sent. 8523 len. 15]: I have been throwed , all sorts of styles , all my life ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8524 len. 56]: With this unexpected speech , energetically delivered and accompanied by action illustrative of the various exercises referred to , Phil Squod shoulders his way round three sides of the gallery , and abruptly tacking off at his commander , makes a butt at him with his head , intended to express devotion to his service .
Parsing [sent. 8525 len. 9]: He then begins to clear away the breakfast .
Parsing [sent. 8526 len. 27]: Mr. George , after laughing cheerfully and clapping him on the shoulder , assists in these arrangements and helps to get the gallery into business order .
Parsing [sent. 8527 len. 35]: That done , he takes a turn at the dumb-bells , and afterwards weighing himself and opining that he is getting `` too fleshy , '' engages with great gravity in solitary broadsword practice .
Parsing [sent. 8528 len. 53]: Meanwhile Phil has fallen to work at his usual table , where he screws and unscrews , and cleans , and files , and whistles into small apertures , and blackens himself more and more , and seems to do and undo everything that can be done and undone about a gun .
Parsing [sent. 8529 len. 27]: Master and man are at length disturbed by footsteps in the passage , where they make an unusual sound , denoting the arrival of unusual company .
Parsing [sent. 8530 len. 33]: These steps , advancing nearer and nearer to the gallery , bring into it a group at first sight scarcely reconcilable with any day in the year but the fifth of November .
Parsing [sent. 8531 len. 70]: It consists of a limp and ugly figure carried in a chair by two bearers and attended by a lean female with a face like a pinched mask , who might be expected immediately to recite the popular verses commemorative of the time when they did contrive to blow Old England up alive but for her keeping her lips tightly and defiantly closed as the chair is put down .
Parsing [sent. 8532 len. 13]: At which point the figure in it gasping , `` O Lord !
Parsing [sent. 8533 len. 5]: Oh , dear me !
Parsing [sent. 8534 len. 5]: I am shaken ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8535 len. 16]: adds , `` How de do , my dear friend , how de do ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8536 len. 26]: Mr. George then descries , in the procession , the venerable Mr. Smallweed out for an airing , attended by his granddaughter Judy as body-guard .
Parsing [sent. 8537 len. 39]: `` Mr. George , my dear friend , '' says Grandfather Smallweed , removing his right arm from the neck of one of his bearers , whom he has nearly throttled coming along , `` how de do ?
Parsing [sent. 8538 len. 12]: You 're surprised to see me , my dear friend . ''
Parsing [sent. 8539 len. 22]: `` I should hardly have been more surprised to have seen your friend in the city , '' returns Mr. George .
Parsing [sent. 8540 len. 12]: `` I am very seldom out , '' pants Mr. Smallweed .
Parsing [sent. 8541 len. 10]: `` I have n't been out for many months .
Parsing [sent. 8542 len. 9]: It 's inconvenient -- and it comes expensive .
Parsing [sent. 8543 len. 14]: But I longed so much to see you , my dear Mr. George .
Parsing [sent. 8544 len. 7]: How de do , sir ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8545 len. 11]: `` I am well enough , '' says Mr. George .
Parsing [sent. 8546 len. 9]: `` I hope you are the same . ''
Parsing [sent. 8547 len. 13]: `` You ca n't be too well , my dear friend . ''
Parsing [sent. 8548 len. 8]: Mr. Smallweed takes him by both hands .
Parsing [sent. 8549 len. 8]: `` I have brought my granddaughter Judy .
Parsing [sent. 8550 len. 7]: I could n't keep her away .
Parsing [sent. 8551 len. 9]: She longed so much to see you . ''
Parsing [sent. 8552 len. 3]: `` Hum !
Parsing [sent. 8553 len. 6]: She hears it calmly ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8554 len. 4]: mutters Mr. George .
Parsing [sent. 8555 len. 47]: `` So we got a hackney-cab , and put a chair in it , and just round the corner they lifted me out of the cab and into the chair , and carried me here that I might see my dear friend in his own establishment !
Parsing [sent. 8556 len. 34]: This , '' says Grandfather Smallweed , alluding to the bearer , who has been in danger of strangulation and who withdraws adjusting his windpipe , `` is the driver of the cab .
Parsing [sent. 8557 len. 5]: He has nothing extra .
Parsing [sent. 8558 len. 9]: It is by agreement included in his fare .
Parsing [sent. 8559 len. 21]: This person , '' the other bearer , `` we engaged in the street outside for a pint of beer .
Parsing [sent. 8560 len. 4]: Which is twopence .
Parsing [sent. 8561 len. 7]: Judy , give the person twopence .
Parsing [sent. 8562 len. 27]: I was not sure you had a workman of your own here , my dear friend , or we need n't have employed this person . ''
Parsing [sent. 8563 len. 18]: Grandfather Smallweed refers to Phil with a glance of considerable terror and a half-subdued `` O Lord !
Parsing [sent. 8564 len. 6]: Oh , dear me ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8565 len. 64]: Nor in his apprehension , on the surface of things , without some reason , for Phil , who has never beheld the apparition in the black-velvet cap before , has stopped short with a gun in his hand with much of the air of a dead shot intent on picking Mr. Smallweed off as an ugly old bird of the crow species .
Parsing [sent. 8566 len. 18]: `` Judy , my child , '' says Grandfather Smallweed , `` give the person his twopence .
Parsing [sent. 8567 len. 12]: It 's a great deal for what he has done . ''
Parsing [sent. 8568 len. 66]: The person , who is one of those extraordinary specimens of human fungus that spring up spontaneously in the western streets of London , ready dressed in an old red jacket , with a `` mission '' for holding horses and calling coaches , received his twopence with anything but transport , tosses the money into the air , catches it over-handed , and retires .
Parsing [sent. 8569 len. 26]: `` My dear Mr. George , '' says Grandfather Smallweed , `` would you be so kind as help to carry me to the fire ?
Parsing [sent. 8570 len. 19]: I am accustomed to a fire , and I am an old man , and I soon chill .
Parsing [sent. 8571 len. 6]: Oh , dear me ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8572 len. 37]: His closing exclamation is jerked out of the venerable gentleman by the suddenness with which Mr. Squod , like a genie , catches him up , chair and all , and deposits him on the hearth-stone .
Parsing [sent. 8573 len. 5]: `` O Lord ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8574 len. 6]: says Mr. Smallweed , panting .
Parsing [sent. 8575 len. 6]: `` Oh , dear me !
Parsing [sent. 8576 len. 5]: Oh , my stars !
Parsing [sent. 8577 len. 14]: My dear friend , your workman is very strong -- and very prompt .
Parsing [sent. 8578 len. 8]: O Lord , he is very prompt !
Parsing [sent. 8579 len. 8]: Judy , draw me back a little .
Parsing [sent. 8580 len. 27]: I 'm being scorched in the legs , '' which indeed is testified to the noses of all present by the smell of his worsted stockings .
Parsing [sent. 8581 len. 45]: The gentle Judy , having backed her grandfather a little way from the fire , and having shaken him up as usual , and having released his overshadowed eye from its black-velvet extinguisher , Mr. Smallweed again says , `` Oh , dear me !
Parsing [sent. 8582 len. 4]: O Lord ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8583 len. 16]: and looking about and meeting Mr. George 's glance , again stretches out both hands .
Parsing [sent. 8584 len. 5]: `` My dear friend !
Parsing [sent. 8585 len. 6]: So happy in this meeting !
Parsing [sent. 8586 len. 6]: And this is your establishment ?
Parsing [sent. 8587 len. 6]: It 's a delightful place .
Parsing [sent. 8588 len. 5]: It 's a picture !
Parsing [sent. 8589 len. 18]: You never find that anything goes off here accidentally , do you , my dear friend ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8590 len. 9]: adds Grandfather Smallweed , very ill at ease .
Parsing [sent. 8591 len. 5]: `` No , no .
Parsing [sent. 8592 len. 6]: No fear of that . ''
Parsing [sent. 8593 len. 5]: `` And your workman .

Parsing [sent. 8596 len. 16]: `` He has never hurt anybody but himself , '' says Mr. George , smiling .

Parsing [sent. 8599 len. 12]: `` He might n't mean it -- or he even might .
Parsing [sent. 8600 len. 18]: Mr. George , will you order him to leave his infernal firearms alone and go away ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8601 len. 21]: Obedient to a nod from the trooper , Phil retires , empty-handed , to the other end of the gallery .

Parsing [sent. 8868 len. 62]: With that , he takes three strides forward to replace the papers on the lawyer 's table and three strides backward to resume his former station , where he stands perfectly upright , now looking at the ground and now at the painted ceillhg , with his hands behind him as if to prevent himself from accepting any other document whatever .
Parsing [sent. 8869 len. 51]: Under this provocation , Mr. Smallweed 's favourite adjective of disparagement is so close to his tongue that he begins the words `` my dear friend '' with the monosyllable `` brim , '' thus converting the possessive pronoun into brimmy and appearing to have an impediment in his speech .
Parsing [sent. 8870 len. 51]: Once past this difficulty , however , he exhorts his dear friend in the tenderest manner not to be rash , but to do what so eminent a gentleman requires , and to do it with a good grace , confident that it must be unobjectionable as well as profitable .

Parsing [sent. 9095 len. 16]: This so intensifies his dudgeon that for five minutes he is in an ill humour .
Parsing [sent. 9096 len. 18]: But he whistles that off like the rest of it and marches home to the shooting gallery .
Parsing [sent. 9097 len. 44]: Chapter XXVIII -- The Ironmaster Sir Leicester Dedlock has got the better , for the time being , of the family gout and is once more , in a literal no less than in a figurative point of view , upon his legs .
Parsing [sent. 9098 len. 41]: He is at his place in Lincolnshire ; but the waters are out again on the low-lying grounds , and the cold and damp steal into Chesney Wold , though well defended , and eke into Sir Leicester 's bones .
Parsing [sent. 9099 len. 45]: The blazing fires of faggot and coal -- Dedlock timber and antediluvian forest -- that blaze upon the broad wide hearths and wink in the twilight on the frowning woods , sullen to see how trees are sacrificed , do not exclude the enemy .
Parsing [sent. 9100 len. 37]: The hot-water pipes that trail themselves all over the house , the cushioned doors and windows , and the screens and curtains fail to supply the fires ' deficiencies and to satisfy Sir Leicester 's need .
Parsing [sent. 9101 len. 26]: Hence the fashionable intelligence proclaims one morning to the listening earth that Lady Dedlock is expected shortly to return to town for a few weeks .
Parsing [sent. 9102 len. 14]: It is a melancholy truth that even great men have their poor relations .
Parsing [sent. 9103 len. 38]: Indeed great men have often more than their fair share of poor relations , inasmuch as very red blood of the superior quality , like inferior blood unlawfully shed , WILL cry aloud and WILL be heard .
Parsing [sent. 9104 len. 24]: Sir Leicester 's cousins , in the remotest degree , are so many murders in the respect that they `` will out . ''
Parsing [sent. 9105 len. 52]: Among whom there are cousins who are so poor that one might almost dare to think it would have been the happier for them never to have been plated links upon the Dedlock chain of gold , but to have been made of common iron at first and done base service .
Parsing [sent. 9106 len. 27]: Service , however -LRB- with a few limited reservations , genteel but not profitable -RRB- , they may not do , being of the Dedlock dignity .
Parsing [sent. 9107 len. 63]: So they visit their richer cousins , and get into debt when they can , and live but shabbily when they ca n't , and find -- the women no husbands , and the men no wives -- and ride in borrowed carriages , and sit at feasts that are never of their own making , and so go through high life .
Parsing [sent. 9108 len. 26]: The rich family sum has been divided by so many figures , and they are the something over that nobody knows what to do with .
Parsing [sent. 9109 len. 26]: Everybody on Sir Leicester Dedlock 's side of the question and of his way of thinking would appear to be his cousin more or less .
Parsing [sent. 9110 len. 29]: From my Lord Boodle , through the Duke of Foodle , down to Noodle , Sir Leicester , like a glorious spider , stretches his threads of relationship .
Parsing [sent. 9111 len. 64]: But while he is stately in the cousinship of the Everybodys , he is a kind and generous man , according to his dignified way , in the cousinship of the Nobodys ; and at the present time , in despite of the damp , he stays out the visit of several such cousins at Chesney Wold with the constancy of a martyr .
Parsing [sent. 9112 len. 45]: Of these , foremost in the front rank stands Volumnia Dedlock , a young lady -LRB- of sixty -RRB- who is doubly highly related , having the honour to be a poor relation , by the mother 's side , to another great family .
Parsing [sent. 9113 len. 55]: Miss Volumnia , displaying in early life a pretty talent for cutting ornaments out of coloured paper , and also for singing to the guitar in the Spanish tongue , and propounding French conundrums in country houses , passed the twenty years of her existence between twenty and forty in a sufficiently agreeable manner .
Parsing [sent. 9114 len. 50]: Lapsing then out of date and being considered to bore mankind by her vocal performances in the Spanish language , she retired to Bath , where she lives slenderly on an annual present from Sir Leicester and whence she makes occasional resurrections in the country houses of her cousins .
Parsing [sent. 9115 len. 28]: She has an extensive acquaintance at Bath among appalling old gentlemen with thin legs and nankeen trousers , and is of high standing in that dreary city .
Parsing [sent. 9116 len. 35]: But she is a little dreaded elsewhere in consequence of an indiscreet profusion in the article of rouge and persistency in an obsolete pearl necklace like a rosary of little bird 's - eggs .
Parsing [sent. 9117 len. 19]: In any country in a wholesome state , Volumnia would be a clear case for the pension list .
Parsing [sent. 9118 len. 36]: Efforts have been made to get her on it , and when William Buffy came in , it was fully expected that her name would be put down for a couple of hundred a year .
Parsing [sent. 9119 len. 45]: But William Buffy somehow discovered , contrary to all expectation , that these were not the times when it could be done , and this was the first clear indication Sir Leicester Dedlock had conveyed to him that the country was going to pieces .
Parsing [sent. 9120 len. 29]: There is likewise the Honourable Bob Stables , who can make warm mashes with the skill of a veterinary surgeon and is a better shot than most gamekeepers .
Parsing [sent. 9121 len. 26]: He has been for some time particularly desirous to serve his country in a post of good emoluments , unaccompanied by any trouble or responsibility .

Parsing [sent. 9123 len. 86]: The rest of the cousins are ladies and gentlemen of various ages and capacities , the major part amiable and sensible and likely to have done well enough in life if they could have overcome their cousinship ; as it is , they are almost all a little worsted by it , and lounge in purposeless and listless paths , and seem to be quite as much at a loss how to dispose of themselves as anybody else can be how to dispose of them .
Parsing [sent. 9124 len. 14]: In this society , and where not , my Lady Dedlock reigns supreme .

Parsing [sent. 9288 len. 17]: Indeed there is nothing in the world I would n't do to show how much . ''
Parsing [sent. 9289 len. 23]: `` And I do n't think you would wish to leave me just yet , Rosa , even for a lover ? ''
Parsing [sent. 9290 len. 6]: `` No , my Lady !
Parsing [sent. 9291 len. 5]: Oh , no ! ''
Parsing [sent. 9292 len. 14]: Rosa looks up for the first time , quite frightened at the thought .
Parsing [sent. 9293 len. 8]: `` Confide in me , my child .
Parsing [sent. 9294 len. 5]: Do n't fear me .
Parsing [sent. 9295 len. 24]: I wish you to be happy , and will make you so -- if I can make anybody happy on this earth . ''
Parsing [sent. 9296 len. 15]: Rosa , with fresh tears , kneels at her feet and kisses her hand .
Parsing [sent. 9297 len. 39]: My Lady takes the hand with which she has caught it , and standing with her eyes fixed on the fire , puts it about and about between her own two hands , and gradually lets it fall .
Parsing [sent. 9298 len. 20]: Seeing her so absorbed , Rosa softly withdraws ; but still my Lady 's eyes are on the fire .
Parsing [sent. 9299 len. 5]: In search of what ?
Parsing [sent. 9300 len. 26]: Of any hand that is no more , of any hand that never was , of any touch that might have magically changed her life ?
Parsing [sent. 9301 len. 18]: Or does she listen to the Ghost 's Walk and think what step does it most resemble ?
Parsing [sent. 9302 len. 4]: A man 's ?
Parsing [sent. 9303 len. 4]: A woman 's ?
Parsing [sent. 9304 len. 17]: The pattering of a little child 's feet , ever coming on -- on -- on ?
Parsing [sent. 9305 len. 26]: Some melancholy influence is upon her , or why should so proud a lady close the doors and sit alone upon the hearth so desolate ?
Parsing [sent. 9306 len. 15]: Volumnia is away next day , and all the cousins are scattered before dinner .
Parsing [sent. 9307 len. 42]: Not a cousin of the batch but is amazed to hear from Sir Leicester at breakfast-time of the obliteration of landmarks , and opening of floodgates , and cracking of the framework of society , manifested through Mrs. Rouncewell 's son .
Parsing [sent. 9308 len. 49]: Not a cousin of the batch but is really indignant , and connects it with the feebleness of William Buffy when in office , and really does feel deprived of a stake in the country -- or the pension list -- or something -- by fraud and wrong .
Parsing [sent. 9309 len. 40]: As to Volumnia , she is handed down the great staircase by Sir Leicester , as eloquent upon the theme as if there were a general rising in the north of England to obtain her rouge-pot and pearl necklace .
Parsing [sent. 9310 len. 77]: And thus , with a clatter of maids and valets -- for it is one appurtenance of their cousinship that however difficult they may find it to keep themselves , they MUST keep maids and valets -- the cousins disperse to the four winds of heaven ; and the one wintry wind that blows to-day shakes a shower from the trees near the deserted house , as if all the cousins had been changed into leaves .
Parsing [sent. 9311 len. 51]: Chapter XXIX -- The Young Man Chesney Wold is shut up , carpets are rolled into great scrolls in corners of comfortless rooms , bright damask does penance in brown holland , carving and gilding puts on mortification , and the Dedlock ancestors retire from the light of day again .
Parsing [sent. 9312 len. 29]: Around and around the house the leaves fall thick , but never fast , for they come circling down with a dead lightness that is sombre and slow .
Parsing [sent. 9313 len. 30]: Let the gardener sweep and sweep the turf as he will , and press the leaves into full barrows , and wheel them off , still they lie ankle-deep .
Parsing [sent. 9314 len. 22]: Howls the shrill wind round Chesney Wold ; the sharp rain beats , the windows rattle , and the chimneys growl .
Parsing [sent. 9315 len. 21]: Mists hide in the avenues , veil the points of view , and move in funeral-wise across the rising grounds .
Parsing [sent. 9316 len. 46]: On all the house there is a cold , blank smell like the smell of a little church , though something dryer , suggesting that the dead and buried Dedlocks walk there in the long nights and leave the flavour of their graves behind them .
Parsing [sent. 9317 len. 46]: But the house in town , which is rarely in the same mind as Chesney Wold at the same time , seldom rejoicing when it rejoices or mourning when it mourns , expecting when a Dedlock dies -- the house in town shines out awakened .
Parsing [sent. 9318 len. 70]: As warm and bright as so much state may be , as delicately redolent of pleasant scents that bear no trace of winter as hothouse flowers can make it , soft and hushed so that the ticking of the clocks and the crisp burning of the fires alone disturb the stillness in the rooms , it seems to wrap those chilled bones of Sir Leicester 's in rainbow-coloured wool .
Parsing [sent. 9319 len. 36]: And Sir Leicester is glad to repose in dignified contentment before the great fire in the library , condescendingly perusing the backs of his books or honouring the fine arts with a glance of approbation .
Parsing [sent. 9320 len. 10]: For he has his pictures , ancient and modern .
Parsing [sent. 9321 len. 29]: Some of the Fancy Ball School in which art occasionally condescends to become a master , which would be best catalogued like the miscellaneous articles in a sale .
Parsing [sent. 9322 len. 47]: As ' `` Three high-backed chairs , a table and cover , long-necked bottle -LRB- containing wine -RRB- , one flask , one Spanish female 's costume , three-quarter face portrait of Miss Jogg the model , and a suit of armour containing Don Quixote . ''
Parsing [sent. 9323 len. 57]: Or `` One stone terrace -LRB- cracked -RRB- , one gondola in distance , one Venetian senator 's dress complete , richly embroidered white satin costume with profile portrait of Miss Jogg the model , one Scimitar superbly mounted in gold with jewelled handle , elaborate Moorish dress -LRB- very rare -RRB- , and Othello . ''
Parsing [sent. 9324 len. 24]: Mr. Tulkinghorn comes and goes pretty often , there being estate business to do , leases to be renewed , and so on .
Parsing [sent. 9325 len. 33]: He sees my Lady pretty often , too ; and he and she are as composed , and as indifferent , and take as little heed of one another , as ever .
Parsing [sent. 9326 len. 17]: Yet it may be that my Lady fears this Mr. Tulkinghorn and that he knows it .
Parsing [sent. 9327 len. 22]: It may be that he pursues her doggedly and steadily , with no touch of compunction , remorse , or pity .
Parsing [sent. 9328 len. 35]: It may be that her beauty and all the state and brilliancy surrounding her only gives him the greater zest for what he is set upon and makes him the more inflexible in it .
Parsing [sent. 9329 len. 136]: Whether he be cold and cruel , whether immovable in what he has made his duty , whether absorbed in love of power , whether determined to have nothing hidden from him in ground where he has burrowed among secrets all his life , whether he in his heart despises the splendour of which he is a distant beam , whether he is always treasuring up slights and offences in the affability of his gorgeous clients -- whether he be any of this , or all of this , it may be that my Lady had better have five thousand pairs of fashionahle eyes upon her , in distrustful vigilance , than the two eyes of this rusty lawyer with his wisp of neckcloth and his dull black breeches tied with ribbons at the knees .
Parsing [sent. 9330 len. 26]: Sir Leicester sits in my Lady 's room -- that room in which Mr. Tulkinghorn read the affidavit in Jarndyce and Jarndyce -- particularly complacent .
Parsing [sent. 9331 len. 19]: My Lady , as on that day , sits before the fire with her screen in her hand .
Parsing [sent. 9332 len. 26]: Sir Leicester is particularly complacent because he has found in his newspaper some congenial remarks bearing directly on the floodgates and the framework of society .
Parsing [sent. 9333 len. 27]: They apply so happily to the late case that Sir Leicester has come from the library to my Lady 's room expressly to read them aloud .
Parsing [sent. 9334 len. 40]: `` The man who wrote this article , '' he observes by way of preface , nodding at the fire as if he were nodding down at the man from a mount , `` has a well-balanced mind . ''
Parsing [sent. 9335 len. 65]: The man 's mind is not so well balanced but that he bores my Lady , who , after a languid effort to listen , or rather a languid resignation of herself to a show of listening , becomes distraught and falls into a contemplation of the fire as if it were her fire at Chesney Wold , and she had never left it .
Parsing [sent. 9336 len. 67]: Sir Leicester , quite unconscious , reads on through his double eye-glass , occasionally stopping to remove his glass and express approval , as `` Very true indeed , '' `` Very properly put , '' `` I have frequently made the same remark myself , '' invariably losing his place after each observation , and going up and down the column to find it again .
Parsing [sent. 9337 len. 39]: Sir Leicester is reading with infinite gravity and state when the door opens , and the Mercury in powder makes this strange announcement , `` The young man , my Lady , of the name of Guppy . ''
Parsing [sent. 9338 len. 23]: Sir Leicester pauses , stares , repeats in a killing voice , `` The young man of the name of Guppy ? ''
Parsing [sent. 9339 len. 31]: Looking round , he beholds the young man of the name of Guppy , much discomfited and not presenting a very impressive letter of introduction in his manner and appearance .

Parsing [sent. 9341 len. 23]: `` I beg your pardon , Sir Leicester , but my Lady said she would see the young man whenever he called .
Parsing [sent. 9342 len. 13]: I was not aware that you were here , Sir Leicester . ''

Parsing [sent. 9513 len. 25]: Chapter XXX -- Esther 's Narrative Richard had been gone away some time when a visitor came to pass a few days with us .
Parsing [sent. 9514 len. 6]: It was an elderly lady .
Parsing [sent. 9515 len. 72]: It was Mrs. Woodcourt , who , having come from Wales to stay with Mrs. Bayham Badger and having written to my guardian , `` by her son Allan 's desire , '' to report that she had heard from him and that he was well `` and sent his kind remembrances to all of us , '' had been invited by my guardian to make a visit to Bleak House .
Parsing [sent. 9516 len. 8]: She stayed with us nearly three weeks .
Parsing [sent. 9517 len. 22]: She took very kindly to me and was extremely confidential , so much so that sometimes she almost made me uncomfortable .
Parsing [sent. 9518 len. 41]: I had no right , I knew very well , to be uncomfortable because she confided in me , and I felt it was unreasonable ; still , with all I could do , I could not quite help it .
Parsing [sent. 9519 len. 35]: She was such a sharp little lady and used to sit with her hands folded in each other looking so very watchful while she talked to me that perhaps I found that rather irksome .
Parsing [sent. 9520 len. 27]: Or perhaps it was her being so upright and trim , though I do n't think it was that , because I thought that quaintly pleasant .
Parsing [sent. 9521 len. 23]: Nor can it have been the general expression of her face , which was very sparkling and pretty for an old lady .
Parsing [sent. 9522 len. 8]: I do n't know what it was .
Parsing [sent. 9523 len. 15]: Or at least if I do now , I thought I did not then .
Parsing [sent. 9524 len. 10]: Or at least -- but it do n't matter .
Parsing [sent. 9525 len. 50]: Of a night when I was going upstairs to bed , she would invite me into her room , where she sat before the fire in a great chair ; and , dear me , she would tell me about Morgan ap -- Kerrig until I was quite low-spirited !

Parsing [sent. 9612 len. 40]: To be sure , this was news indeed ; and I thought we never should have done talking about it , we had so much to say to Caddy , and Caddy had so much to say to us .
Parsing [sent. 9613 len. 104]: It seemed that Caddy 's unfortunate papa had got over his bankruptcy -- `` gone through the Gazette , '' was the expression Caddy used , as if it were a tunnel -- with the general clemency and commiseration of his creditors , and had got rid of his affairs in some blessed manner without succeeding in understanding them , and had given up everything he possessed -LRB- which was not worth much , I should think , to judge from the state of the furniture -RRB- , and had satisfied every one concerned that he could do no more , poor man .

Parsing [sent. 9654 len. 6]: Now , mercy upon us !

Parsing [sent. 9660 len. 19]: When I say I went home with Caddy , I mean to the furnished lodging in Hatton Garden .
Parsing [sent. 9661 len. 79]: We went to Newman Street two or three times , where preparations were in progress too -- a good many , I observed , for enhancing the comforts of old Mr. Turveydrop , and a few for putting the newly married couple away cheaply at the top of the house -- but our great point was to make the furnished lodging decent for the wedding-breakfast and to imbue Mrs. Jellyby beforehand with some faint sense of the occasion .
Parsing [sent. 9662 len. 52]: The latter was the more difficult thing of the two because Mrs. Jellyby and an unwholesome boy occupied the front sitting-room -LRB- the back one was a mere closet -RRB- , and it was littered down with waste-paper and Borrioboolan documents , as an untidy stable might be littered with straw .

Parsing [sent. 9667 len. 19]: The poor children scrambled up and tumbled down the house as they had always been accustomed to do .
Parsing [sent. 9668 len. 69]: The production of these devoted little sacrifices in any presentable condition being quite out of the question at a week 's notice , I proposed to Caddy that we should make them as happy as we could on her marriage morning in the attic where they all slept , and should confine our greatest efforts to her mama and her mama 's room , and a clean breakfast .
Parsing [sent. 9669 len. 37]: In truth Mrs. Jellyby required a good deal of attention , the lattice-work up her back having widened considerably since I first knew her and her hair looking like the mane of a dustman 's horse .

Parsing [sent. 9676 len. 22]: On our going downstairs again , Mrs. Jellyby asked me whether this troublesome business was really to take place next Wednesday .

Parsing [sent. 9688 len. 43]: I thought it very curious to see her looking on serenely from her writing-table while Caddy and I discussed it , occasionally shaking her head at us with a half-reproachful smile like a superior spirit who could just bear with our trifling .
Parsing [sent. 9689 len. 46]: The state in which her dresses were , and the extraordinary confusion in which she kept them , added not a little to our difficulty ; but at length we devised something not very unlike what a common-place mother might wear on such an occasion .
Parsing [sent. 9690 len. 55]: The abstracted manner in which Mrs. Jellyby would deliver herself up to having this attire tried on by the dressmaker , and the sweetness with which she would then observe to me how sorry she was that I had not turned my thoughts to Africa , were consistent with the rest of her behaviour .
Parsing [sent. 9691 len. 60]: The lodging was rather confined as to space , but I fancied that if Mrs. Jellyby 's household had been the only lodgers in Saint Paul 's or Saint Peter 's , the sole advantage they would have found in the size of the building would have been its affording a great deal of room to be dirty in .
Parsing [sent. 9692 len. 77]: I believe that nothing belonging to the family which it had been possible to break was unbroken at the time of those preparations for Caddy 's marriage , that nothing which it had been possible to spoil in any way was unspoilt , and that no domestic object which was capable of collecting dirt , from a dear child 's knee to the door-plate , was without as much dirt as could well accumulate upon it .
Parsing [sent. 9693 len. 53]: Poor Mr. Jellyby , who very seldom spoke and almost always sat when he was at home with his head against the wall , became interested when he saw that Caddy and I were attempting to establish some order among all this waste and ruin and took off his coat to help .

Parsing [sent. 9835 len. 44]: Chapter XXXI -- Nurse and Patient I had not been at home again many days when one evening I went upstairs into my own room to take a peep over Charley 's shoulder and see how she was getting on with her copy-book .
Parsing [sent. 9836 len. 53]: Writing was a trying business to Charley , who seemed to have no natural power over a pen , but in whose hand every pen appeared to become perversely animated , and to go wrong and crooked , and to stop , and splash , and sidle into corners like a saddle-donkey .
Parsing [sent. 9837 len. 32]: It was very odd to see what old letters Charley 's young hand had made , they so wrinkled , and shrivelled , and tottering , it so plump and round .
Parsing [sent. 9838 len. 19]: Yet Charley was uncommonly expert at other things and had as nimble little fingers as I ever watched .

Parsing [sent. 10131 len. 63]: After that she came beneath the window even oftener than she had come to the door , and if I had learnt to love her dear sweet voice before when we were hardly ever apart , how did I learn to love it then , when I stood behind the window-curtain listening and replying , but not so much as looking out !
Parsing [sent. 10132 len. 15]: How did I learn to love it afterwards , when the harder time came !
Parsing [sent. 10133 len. 45]: They put a bed for me in our sitting-room ; and by keeping the door wide open , I turned the two rooms into one , now that Ada had vacated that part of the house , and kept them always fresh and airy .
Parsing [sent. 10134 len. 68]: There was not a servant in or about the house but was so good that they would all most gladly have come to me at any hour of the day or night without the least fear or unwillingness , but I thought it best to choose one worthy woman who was never to see Ada and whom I could trust to come and go with all precaution .
Parsing [sent. 10135 len. 40]: Through her means I got out to take the air with my guardian when there was no fear of meeting Ada , and wanted for nothing in the way of attendance , any more than in any other respect .
Parsing [sent. 10136 len. 31]: And thus poor Charley sickened and grew worse , and fell into heavy danger of death , and lay severely ill for many a long round of day and night .
Parsing [sent. 10137 len. 71]: So patient she was , so uncomplaining , and inspired by such a gentle fortitude that very often as I sat by Charley holding her head in my arms -- repose would come to her , so , when it would come to her in no other attitude -- I silently prayed to our Father in heaven that I might not forget the lesson which this little sister taught me .
Parsing [sent. 10138 len. 48]: I was very sorrowful to think that Charley 's pretty looks would change and be disfigured , even if she recovered -- she was such a child with her dimpled face -- but that thought was , for the greater part , lost in her greater peril .
Parsing [sent. 10139 len. 60]: When she was at the worst , and her mind rambled again to the cares of her father 's sick bed and the little children , she still knew me so far as that she would be quiet in my arms when she could lie quiet nowhere else , and murmur out the wanderings of her mind less restlessly .
Parsing [sent. 10140 len. 39]: At those times I used to think , how should I ever tell the two remaining babies that the baby who had learned of her faithful heart to be a mother to them in their need was dead !
Parsing [sent. 10141 len. 40]: There were other times when Charley knew me well and talked to me , telling me that she sent her love to Tom and Emma and that she was sure Tom would grow up to be a good man .
Parsing [sent. 10142 len. 65]: At those times Charley would speak to me of what she had read to her father as well as she could to comfort him , of that young man carried out to be buried who was the only son of his mother and she was a widow , of the ruler 's daughter raised up by the gracious hand upon her bed of death .
Parsing [sent. 10143 len. 67]: And Charley told me that when her father died she had kneeled down and prayed in her first sorrow that he likewise might be raised up and given back to his poor children , and that if she should never get better and should die too , she thought it likely that it might come into Tom 's mind to offer the same prayer for her .
Parsing [sent. 10144 len. 33]: Then would I show Tom how these people of old days had been brought back to life on earth , only that we might know our hope to be restored to heaven !
Parsing [sent. 10145 len. 28]: But of all the various times there were in Charley 's illness , there was not one when she lost the gentle qualities I have spoken of .
Parsing [sent. 10146 len. 39]: And there were many , many when I thought in the night of the last high belief in the watching angel , and the last higher trust in God , on the part of her poor despised father .
Parsing [sent. 10147 len. 6]: And Charley did not die .
Parsing [sent. 10148 len. 20]: She flutteringiy and slowly turned the dangerous point , after long lingering there , and then began to mend .
Parsing [sent. 10149 len. 44]: The hope that never had been given , from the first , of Charley being in outward appearance Charley any more soon began to be encouraged ; and even that prospered , and I saw her growing into her old childish likeness again .
Parsing [sent. 10150 len. 40]: It was a great morning when I could tell Ada all this as she stood out in the garden ; and it was a great evening when Charley and I at last took tea together in the next room .
Parsing [sent. 10151 len. 14]: But on that same evening , I felt that I was stricken cold .
Parsing [sent. 10152 len. 33]: Happily for both of us , it was not until Charley was safe in bed again and placidly asleep that I began to think the contagion of her illness was upon me .
Parsing [sent. 10153 len. 34]: I had been able easily to hide what I felt at tea-time , but I was past that already now , and I knew that I was rapidly following in Charley 's steps .
Parsing [sent. 10154 len. 37]: I was well enough , however , to be up early in the morning , and to return my darling 's cheerful blessing from the garden , and to talk with her as long as usual .
Parsing [sent. 10155 len. 55]: But I was not free from an impression that I had been walking about the two rooms in the night , a little beside myself , though knowing where I was ; and I felt confused at times -- with a curious sense of fullness , as if I were becoming too large altogether .
Parsing [sent. 10156 len. 35]: In the evening I was so much worse that I resolved to prepare Charley , with which view I said , `` You 're getting quite strong , Charley , are you not ? '
Parsing [sent. 10157 len. 6]: `` Oh , quite ! ''
Parsing [sent. 10158 len. 3]: said Charley .
Parsing [sent. 10159 len. 15]: `` Strong enough to be told a secret , I think , Charley ? ''
Parsing [sent. 10160 len. 10]: `` Quite strong enough for that , miss ! ''
Parsing [sent. 10161 len. 3]: cried Charley .
Parsing [sent. 10162 len. 48]: But Charley 's face fell in the height of her delight , for she saw the secret in MY face ; and she came out of the great chair , and fell upon my bosom , and said `` Oh , miss , it 's my doing !

Parsing [sent. 10164 len. 14]: and a great deal more out of the fullness of her grateful heart .

Parsing [sent. 10170 len. 6]: Oh , my dear ! ''

Parsing [sent. 10203 len. 54]: Chapter XXXII -- The Appointed Time It is night in Lincoln 's Inn -- perplexed and troublous valley of the shadow of the law , where suitors generally find but little day -- and fat candles are snuffed out in offices , and clerks have rattled down the crazy wooden stairs and dispersed .
Parsing [sent. 10204 len. 40]: The bell that rings at nine o'clock has ceased its doleful clangour about nothing ; the gates are shut ; and the night-porter , a solemn warder with a mighty power of sleep , keeps guard in his lodge .
Parsing [sent. 10205 len. 34]: From tiers of staircase windows clogged lamps like the eyes of Equity , bleared Argus with a fathomless pocket for every eye and an eye upon it , dimly blink at the stars .
Parsing [sent. 10206 len. 50]: In dirty upper casements , here and there , hazy little patches of candlelight reveal where some wise draughtsman and conveyancer yet toils for the entanglement of real estate in meshes of sheep-skin , in the average ratio of about a dozen of sheep to an acre of land .
Parsing [sent. 10207 len. 32]: Over which bee-like industry these benefactors of their species linger yet , though office-hours be past , that they may give , for every day , some good account at last .
Parsing [sent. 10208 len. 27]: In the neighbouring court , where the Lord Chancellor of the rag and bottle shop dwells , there is a general tendency towards beer and supper .
Parsing [sent. 10209 len. 81]: Mrs. Piper and Mrs. Perkins , whose respective sons , engaged with a circle of acquaintance in the game of hide and seek , have been lying in ambush about the by-ways of Chancery Lane for some hours and scouring the plain of the same thoroughfare to the confusion of passengers -- Mrs. Piper and Mrs. Perkins have but now exchanged congratulations on the children being abed , and they still linger on a door-step over a few parting words .
Parsing [sent. 10210 len. 39]: Mr. Krook and his lodger , and the fact of Mr. Krook 's being `` continually in liquor , '' and the testamentary prospects of the young man are , as usual , the staple of their conversation .
Parsing [sent. 10211 len. 88]: But they have something to say , likewise , of the Harmonic Meeting at the Sol 's Arms , where the sound of the piano through the partly opened windows jingles out into the court , and where Little Swills , after keeping the lovers of harmony in a roar like a very Yorick , may now be heard taking the gruff line in a concerted piece and sentimentally adjuring his friends and patrons to `` Listen , listen , listen , tew the wa-ter fall ! ''
Parsing [sent. 10212 len. 87]: Mrs. Perkins and Mrs. Piper compare opinions on the subject of the young lady of professional celebrity who assists at the Harmonic Meetings and who has a space to herself in the manuscript announcement in the window , Mrs. Perkins possessing information that she has been married a year and a half , though announced as Miss M. Melvilleson , the noted siren , and that her baby is clandestinely conveyed to the Sol 's Arms every night to receive its natural nourishment during the entertainments .
Parsing [sent. 10213 len. 23]: `` Sooner than which , myself , '' says Mrs. Perkins , `` I would get my living by selling lucifers . ''
Parsing [sent. 10214 len. 43]: Mrs. Piper , as in duty bound , is of the same opinion , holding that a private station is better than public applause , and thanking heaven for her own -LRB- and , by implication , Mrs. Perkins ' -RRB- respectability .
Parsing [sent. 10215 len. 64]: By this time the pot-boy of the Sol 's Arms appearing with her supper-pint well frothed , Mrs. Piper accepts that tankard and retires indoors , first giving a fair good night to Mrs. Perkins , who has had her own pint in her hand ever since it was fetched from the same hostelry by young Perkins before he was sent to bed .
Parsing [sent. 10216 len. 39]: Now there is a sound of putting up shop -- shutters in the court and a smell as of the smoking of pipes ; and shooting stars are seen in upper windows , further indicating retirement to rest .
Parsing [sent. 10217 len. 41]: Now , too , the policeman begins to push at doors ; to try fastenings ; to be suspicious of bundles ; and to administer his beat , on the hypothesis that every one is either robbing or being robbed .
Parsing [sent. 10218 len. 28]: It is a close night , though the damp cold is searching too , and there is a laggard mist a little way up in the air .
Parsing [sent. 10219 len. 36]: It is a fine steaming night to turn the slaughter-houses , the unwholesome trades , the sewerage , bad water , and burial-grounds to account , and give the registrar of deaths some extra business .
Parsing [sent. 10220 len. 39]: It may be something in the air -- there is plenty in it -- or it may be something in himself that is in fault ; but Mr. Weevle , otherwise Jobling , is very ill at ease .
Parsing [sent. 10221 len. 18]: He comes and goes between his own room and the open street door twenty times an hour .
Parsing [sent. 10222 len. 11]: He has been doing so ever since it fell dark .
Parsing [sent. 10223 len. 52]: Since the Chancellor shut up his shop , which he did very early to-night , Mr. Weevle has been down and up , and down and up -LRB- with a cheap tight velvet skull-cap on his head , making his whiskers look out of all proportion -RRB- , oftener than before .
Parsing [sent. 10224 len. 36]: It is no phenomenon that Mr. Snagsby should be ill at ease too , for he always is so , more or less , under the oppressive influence of the secret that is upon him .
Parsing [sent. 10225 len. 39]: Impelled by the mystery of which he is a partaker and yet in which he is not a sharer , Mr. Snagsby haunts what seems to be its fountain-head -- the rag and bottle shop in the court .
Parsing [sent. 10226 len. 8]: It has an irresistible attraction for him .
Parsing [sent. 10227 len. 51]: Even now , coming round by the Sol 's Arms with the intention of passing down the court , and out at the Chancery Lane end , and so terminating his unpremeditated after-supper stroll of ten minutes ' long from his own door and back again , Mr. Snagsby approaches .

Parsing [sent. 10338 len. 31]: Finding by this time that his friend is not to be wheedled into a more sociable humour , Mr. Guppy puts about upon the ill-used tack and remonstrates with him .
Parsing [sent. 10339 len. 61]: `` Tony , '' says he , `` I can make allowances for lowness of spirits , for no man knows what it is when it does come upon a man better than I do , and no man perhaps has a better right to know it than a man who has an unrequited image imprinted on his ` eart .
Parsing [sent. 10340 len. 42]: But there are bounds to these things when an unoffending party is in question , and I will acknowledge to you , Tony , that I do n't think your manner on the present occasion is hospitable or quite gentlemanly . ''
Parsing [sent. 10341 len. 14]: `` This is strong language , William Guppy , '' returns Mr. Weevle .
Parsing [sent. 10342 len. 24]: `` Sir , it may be , '' retorts Mr. William Guppy , `` but I feel strongly when I use it . ''

Parsing [sent. 10546 len. 51]: The Lord Chancellor of that court , true to his title in his last act , has died the death of all lord chancellors in all courts and of all authorities in all places under all names soever , where false pretences are made , and where injustice is done .
Parsing [sent. 10547 len. 69]: Call the death by any name your Highness will , attribute it to whom you will , or say it might have been prevented how you will , it is the same death eternally -- inborn , inbred , engendered in the corrupted humours of the vicious body itself , and that only -- spontaneous combustion , and none other of all the deaths that can be died .
Parsing [sent. 10548 len. 76]: Chapter XXXIII -- Interlopers Now do those two gentlemen not very neat about the cuffs and buttons who attended the last coroner 's inquest at the Sol 's Arms reappear in the precincts with surprising swiftness -LRB- being , in fact , breathlessly fetched by the active and intelligent beadle -RRB- , and institute perquisitions through the court , and dive into the Sol 's parlour , and write with ravenous little pens on tissue-paper .
Parsing [sent. 10549 len. 45]: Now do they note down , in the watches of the night , how the neighbourhood of Chancery Lane was yesterday , at about midnight , thrown into a state of the most intense agitation and excitement by the following alarming and horrible discovery .
Parsing [sent. 10550 len. 126]: Now do they set forth how it will doubtless be remembered that some time back a painful sensation was created in the public mind by a case of mysterious death from opium occurring in the first floor of the house occupied as a rag , bottle , and general marine store shop , by an eccentric individual of intemperate habits , far advanced in life , named Krook ; and how , by a remarkable coincidence , Krook was examined at the inquest , which it may be recollected was held on that occasion at the Sol 's Arms , a well-conducted tavern immediately adjoining the premises in question on the west side and licensed to a highly respectable landlord , Mr. James George Bogsby .
Parsing [sent. 10551 len. 184]: Now do they show -LRB- in as many words as possible -RRB- how during some hours of yesterday evening a very peculiar smell was observed by the inhabitants of the court , in which the tragical occurrence which forms the subject of that present account transpired ; and which odour was at one time so powerful that Mr. Swills , a comic vocalist professionally engaged by Mr. J. G. Bogsby , has himself stated to our reporter that he mentioned to Miss M. Melvilleson , a lady of some pretensions to musical ability , likewise engaged by Mr. J. G. Bogsby to sing at a series of concerts called Harmonic Assemblies , or Meetings , which it would appear are held at the Sol 's Arms under Mr. Bogsby 's direction pursuant to the Act of George the Second , that he -LRB- Mr. Swills -RRB- found his voice seriously affected by the impure state of the atmosphere , his jocose expression at the time being that he was like an empty post-office , for he had n't a single note in him .
Parsing [sent. 10552 len. 58]: How this account of Mr. Swills is entirely corroborated by two intelligent married females residing in the same court and known respectively by the names of Mrs. Piper and Mrs. Perkins , both of whom observed the foetid effluvia and regarded them as being emitted from the premises in the occupation of Krook , the unfortunate deceased .
Parsing [sent. 10553 len. 65]: All this and a great deal more the two gentlemen who have formed an amicable partnership in the melancholy catastrophe write down on the spot ; and the boy population of the court -LRB- out of bed in a moment -RRB- swarm up the shutters of the Sol 's Arms parlour , to behold the tops of their heads while they are about it .
Parsing [sent. 10554 len. 39]: The whole court , adult as well as boy , is sleepless for that night , and can do nothing but wrap up its many heads , and talk of the ill-fated house , and look at it .
Parsing [sent. 10555 len. 28]: Miss Flite has been bravely rescued from her chamber , as if it were in flames , and accommodated with a bed at the Sol 's Arms .
Parsing [sent. 10556 len. 36]: The Sol neither turns off its gas nor shuts its door all night , for any kind of public excitement makes good for the Sol and causes the court to stand in need of comfort .
Parsing [sent. 10557 len. 21]: The house has not done so much in the stomachic article of cloves or in brandy-and-water warm since the inquest .
Parsing [sent. 10558 len. 31]: The moment the pot-boy heard what had happened , he rolled up his shirt-sleeves tight to his shoulders and said , `` There 'll be a run upon us ! ''
Parsing [sent. 10559 len. 45]: In the first outcry , young Piper dashed off for the fire-engines and returned in triumph at a jolting gallop perched up aloft on the Phoenix and holding on to that fabulous creature with all his might in the midst of helmets and torches .
Parsing [sent. 10560 len. 38]: One helmet remains behind after careful investigation of all chinks and crannies and slowly paces up and down before the house in company with one of the two policemen who have likewise been left in charge thereof .
Parsing [sent. 10561 len. 22]: To this trio everybody in the court possessed of sixpence has an insatiate desire to exhibit hospitality in a liquid form .
Parsing [sent. 10562 len. 32]: Mr. Weevle and his friend Mr. Guppy are within the bar at the Sol and are worth anything to the Sol that the bar contains if they will only stay there .
Parsing [sent. 10563 len. 52]: `` This is not a time , says Mr. Bogsby , `` to haggle about money , '' though he looks something sharply after it , over the counter ; `` give your orders , you two gentlemen , and you 're welcome to whatever you put a name to . ''
Parsing [sent. 10564 len. 69]: Thus entreated , the two gentlemen -LRB- Mr. Weevle especially -RRB- put names to so many things that in course of time they find it difficult to put a name to anything quite distinctly , though they still relate to all new-comers some version of the night they have had of it , and of what they said , and what they thought , and what they saw .
Parsing [sent. 10565 len. 35]: Meanwhile , one or other of the policemen often flits about the door , and pushing it open a little way at the full length of his arm , looks in from outer gloom .
Parsing [sent. 10566 len. 22]: Not that he has any suspicions , but that he may as well know what they are up to in there .
Parsing [sent. 10567 len. 42]: Thus night pursues its leaden course , finding the court still out of bed through the unwonted hours , still treating and being treated , still conducting itself similarly to a court that has had a little money left it unexpectedly .
Parsing [sent. 10568 len. 39]: Thus night at length with slow-retreating steps departs , and the lamp-lighter going his rounds , like an executioner to a despotic king , strikes off the little heads of fire that have aspired to lessen the darkness .
Parsing [sent. 10569 len. 9]: Thus the day cometh , whether or no .
Parsing [sent. 10570 len. 22]: And the day may discern , even with its dim London eye , that the court has been up all night .
Parsing [sent. 10571 len. 39]: Over and above the faces that have fallen drowsily on tables and the heels that lie prone on hard floors instead of beds , the brick and mortar physiognomy of the very court itself looks worn and jaded .
Parsing [sent. 10572 len. 54]: And now the neighbourhood , waking up and beginning to hear of what has happened , comes streaming in , half dressed , to ask questions ; and the two policemen and the helmet -LRB- who are far less impressible externally than the court -RRB- have enough to do to keep the door .

G. B. is induced to do so at a considerable extra expense in consequence of a wish which has been very generally expressed at the bar by a large body of respectable individuals and in homage to a late melancholy event which has aroused so much sensation . ''
Parsing [sent. 10792 len. 39]: There is one point connected with the deceased upon which the court is particularly anxious , namely , that the fiction of a full-sized coffin should be preserved , though there is so little to put in it .
Parsing [sent. 10793 len. 49]: Upon the undertaker 's stating in the Sol 's bar in the course of the day that he has received orders to construct `` a six-footer , '' the general solicitude is much relieved , and it is considered that Mr. Smallweed 's conduct does him great honour .
Parsing [sent. 10794 len. 63]: Out of the court , and a long way out of it , there is considerable excitement too , for men of science and philosophy come to look , and carriages set down doctors at the corner who arrive with the same intent , and there is more learned talk about inflammable gases and phosphuretted hydrogen than the court has ever imagined .
Parsing [sent. 10795 len. 203]: Some of these authorities -LRB- of course the wisest -RRB- hold with indignation that the deceased had no business to die in the alleged manner ; and being reminded by other authorities of a certain inquiry into the evidence for such deaths reprinted in the sixth volume of the Philosophical Transactions ; and also of a book not quite unknown on English medical jurisprudence ; and likewise of the Italian case of the Countess Cornelia Baudi as set forth in detail by one Bianchini , prebendary of Verona , who wrote a scholarly work or so and was occasionally heard of in his time as having gleams of reason in him ; and also of the testimony of Messrs. Fodere and Mere , two pestilent Frenchmen who WOULD investigate the subject ; and further , of the corroborative testimony of Monsieur Le Cat , a rather celebrated French surgeon once upon a time , who had the unpoliteness to live in a house where such a case occurred and even to write an account of it -- still they regard the late Mr. Krook 's obstinacy in going out of the world by any such by-way as wholly unjustifiable and personally offensive .
Parsing [sent. 10796 len. 33]: The less the court understands of all this , the more the court likes it , and the greater enjoyment it has in the stock in trade of the Sol 's Arms .
Parsing [sent. 10797 len. 81]: Then there comes the artist of a picture newspaper , with a foreground and figures ready drawn for anything from a wreck on the Cornish coast to a review in Hyde Park or a meeting in Manchester , and in Mrs. Perkins ' own room , memorable evermore , he then and there throws in upon the block Mr. Krook 's house , as large as life ; in fact , considerably larger , making a very temple of it .
Parsing [sent. 10798 len. 38]: Similarly , being permitted to look in at the door of the fatal chamber , he depicts that apartment as three-quarters of a mile long by fifty yards high , at which the court is particularly charmed .

Parsing [sent. 10801 len. 12]: After which the six-footer comes into action and is much admired .
Parsing [sent. 10802 len. 62]: In all these proceedings Mr. Guppy has so slight a part , except when he gives his evidence , that he is moved on like a private individual and can only haunt the secret house on the outside , where he has the mortification of seeing Mr. Smallweed padlocking the door , and of bitterly knowing himself to be shut out .

Parsing [sent. 10931 len. 67]: The old girl never appears in walking trim , in any season of the year , without a grey cloth cloak , coarse and much worn but very clean , which is , undoubtedly , the identical garment rendered so interesting to Mr. Bagnet by having made its way home to Europe from another quarter of the globe in company with Mrs. Bagnet and an umbrella .
Parsing [sent. 10932 len. 19]: The latter faithful appendage is also invariably a part of the old girl 's presence out of doors .
Parsing [sent. 10933 len. 82]: It is of no colour known in this life and has a corrugated wooden crook for a handle , with a metallic object let into its prow , or beak , resembling a little model of a fanlight over a street door or one of the oval glasses out of a pair of spectacles , which ornamental object has not that tenacious capacity of sticking to its post that might be desired in an article long associated with the British army .
Parsing [sent. 10934 len. 49]: The old girl 's umbrella is of a flabby habit of waist and seems to be in need of stays -- an appearance that is possibly referable to its having served through a series of years at home as a cupboard and on journeys as a carpet bag .
Parsing [sent. 10935 len. 53]: She never puts it up , having the greatest reliance on her well-proved cloak with its capacious hood , but generally uses the instrument as a wand with which to point out joints of meat or bunches of greens in marketing or to arrest the attention of tradesmen by a friendly poke .
Parsing [sent. 10936 len. 21]: Without her market-basket , which is a sort of wicker well with two flapping lids , she never stirs abroad .

Parsing [sent. 11251 len. 4]: Not good company ?
Parsing [sent. 11252 len. 10]: Well , I am afraid I am not . ''
Parsing [sent. 11253 len. 12]: `` He ai n't at all like Blulfy , mother ! ''
Parsing [sent. 11254 len. 4]: cries little Malta .
Parsing [sent. 11255 len. 16]: `` Because he ai n't well , I think , mother , '' adds Quebec .
Parsing [sent. 11256 len. 16]: `` Sure that 's a bad sign not to be like Bluffy , too ! ''
Parsing [sent. 11257 len. 9]: returns the trooper , kissing the young damsels .
Parsing [sent. 11258 len. 18]: `` But it 's true , '' with a sigh , `` true , I am afraid .
Parsing [sent. 11259 len. 8]: These little ones are always right ! ''
Parsing [sent. 11260 len. 64]: `` George , '' says Mrs. Bagnet , working busily , `` if I thought you cross enough to think of anything that a shrill old soldier 's wife -- who could have bitten her tongue off afterwards and ought to have done it almost -- said this morning , I do n't know what I should n't say to you now . Parsing [sent. 11261 len. 13]: `` My kind soul of a darling , '' returns the trooper .

Parsing [sent. 11266 len. 3]: says George .
Parsing [sent. 11267 len. 10]: `` I am glad of your good opinion . ''
