Parsing [sent. 11269 len. 35]: After looking at it for a little while as she plies her needle , he looks to young Woolwich , sitting on his stool in the corner , and beckons that fifer to him .
Parsing [sent. 11270 len. 32]: `` See there , my boy , '' says George , very gently smoothing the mother 's hair with his hand , `` there 's a good loving forehead for you !
Parsing [sent. 11271 len. 10]: All bright with love of you , my boy .
Parsing [sent. 11272 len. 34]: A little touched by the sun and the weather through following your father about and taking care of you , but as fresh and wholesome as a ripe apple on a tree . ''
Parsing [sent. 11273 len. 21]: Mr. Bagnet 's face expresses , so far as in its wooden material lies , the highest approbation and acquiescence .
Parsing [sent. 11274 len. 46]: `` The time will come , my boy , '' pursues the trooper , `` when this hair of your mother 's will be grey , and this forehead all crossed and re-crossed with wrinkles , and a fine old lady she 'll be then .

Parsing [sent. 11276 len. 28]: For of all the many things that you can think of when you are a man , you had better have THAT by you , Woolwich ! ''
Parsing [sent. 11277 len. 41]: Mr. George concludes by rising from his chair , seating the boy beside his mother in it , and saying , with something of a hurry about him , that he 'll smoke his pipe in the street a bit .
Parsing [sent. 11278 len. 26]: Chapter XXXV -- Esther 's Narrative I lay ill through several weeks , and the usual tenor of my life became like an old remembrance .
Parsing [sent. 11279 len. 28]: But this was not the effect of time so much as of the change in all my habits made by the helplessness and inaction of a sick-room .
Parsing [sent. 11280 len. 42]: Before I had been confined to it many days , everything else seemed to have retired into a remote distance where there was little or no separation between the various stages of my life which had been really divided by years .
Parsing [sent. 11281 len. 32]: In falling ill , I seemed to have crossed a dark lake and to have left all my experiences , mingled together by the great distance , on the healthy shore .
Parsing [sent. 11282 len. 64]: My housekeeping duties , though at first it caused me great anxiety to think that they were unperformed , were soon as far off as the oldest of the old duties at Greenleaf or the summer afternoons when I went home from school with my portfolio under my arm , and my childish shadow at my side , to my godmother 's house .
Parsing [sent. 11283 len. 22]: I had never known before how short life really was and into how small a space the mind could put it .
Parsing [sent. 11284 len. 24]: While I was very ill , the way in which these divisions of time became confused with one another distressed my mind exceedingly .
Parsing [sent. 11285 len. 46]: At once a child , an elder girl , and the little woman I had been so happy as , I was not only oppressed by cares and difficulties adapted to each station , but by the great perplexity of endlessly trying to reconcile them .
Parsing [sent. 11286 len. 27]: I suppose that few who have not been in such a condition can quite understand what I mean or what painful unrest arose from this source .
Parsing [sent. 11287 len. 72]: For the same reason I am almost afraid to hint at that time in my disorder -- it seemed one long night , but I believe there were both nights and days in it -- when I laboured up colossal staircases , ever striving to reach the top , and ever turned , as I have seen a worm in a garden path , by some obstruction , and labouring again .
Parsing [sent. 11288 len. 71]: I knew perfectly at intervals , and I think vaguely at most times , that I was in my bed ; and I talked with Charley , and felt her touch , and knew her very well ; yet I would find myself complaining , `` Oh , more of these never-ending stairs , Charley -- more and more -- piled up to the sky ' , I think ! ''
Parsing [sent. 11289 len. 5]: and labouring on again .
Parsing [sent. 11290 len. 42]: Dare I hint at that worse time when , strung together somewhere in great black space , there was a flaming necklace , or ring , or starry circle of some kind , of which I was one of the beads !
Parsing [sent. 11291 len. 31]: And when my only prayer was to be taken off from the rest and when it was such inexplicable agony and misery to be a part of the dreadful thing ?
Parsing [sent. 11292 len. 21]: Perhaps the less I say of these sick experiences , the less tedious and the more intelligible I shall be .
Parsing [sent. 11293 len. 21]: I do not recall them to make others unhappy or because I am now the least unhappy in remembering them .
Parsing [sent. 11294 len. 23]: It may be that if we knew more of such strange afflictions we might be the better able to alleviate their intensity .
Parsing [sent. 11295 len. 68]: The repose that succeeded , the long delicious sleep , the blissful rest , when in my weakness I was too calm to have any care for myself and could have heard -LRB- or so I think now -RRB- that I was dying , with no other emotion than with a pitying love for those I left behind -- this state can be perhaps more widely understood .
Parsing [sent. 11296 len. 39]: I was in this state when I first shrunk from the light as it twinkled on me once more , and knew with a boundless joy for which no words are rapturous enough that I should see again .
Parsing [sent. 11297 len. 76]: I had heard my Ada crying at the door , day and night ; I had heard her calling to me that I was cruel and did not love her ; I had heard her praying and imploring to be let in to nurse and comfort me and to leave my bedside no more ; but I had only said , when I could speak , `` Never , my sweet girl , never ! ''
Parsing [sent. 11298 len. 25]: and I had over and over again reminded Charley that she was to keep my darling from the room whether I lived or died .
Parsing [sent. 11299 len. 27]: Charley had been true to me in that time of need , and with her little hand and her great heart had kept the door fast .
Parsing [sent. 11300 len. 55]: But now , my sight strengthening and the glorious light coming every day more fully and brightly on me , I could read the letters that my dear wrote to me every morning and evening and could put them to my lips and lay my cheek upon them with no fear of hurting her .
Parsing [sent. 11301 len. 33]: I could see my little maid , so tender and so careful , going about the two rooms setting everything in order and speaking cheerfully to Ada from the open window again .
Parsing [sent. 11302 len. 28]: I could understand the stillness in the house and the thoughtfulness it expressed on the part of all those who had always been so good to me .
Parsing [sent. 11303 len. 26]: I could weep in the exquisite felicity of my heart and be as happy in my weakness as ever I had been in my strength .
Parsing [sent. 11304 len. 10]: By and by my strength began to be restored .
Parsing [sent. 11305 len. 66]: Instead of lying , with so strange a calmness , watching what was done for me , as if it were done for some one else whom I was quietly sorry for , I helped it a little , and so on to a little more and much more , until I became useful to myself , and interested , and attached to life again .
Parsing [sent. 11306 len. 27]: How well I remember the pleasant afternoon when I was raised in bed with pillows for the first time to enjoy a great tea-drinking with Charley !
Parsing [sent. 11307 len. 99]: The little creature -- sent into the world , surely , to minister to the weak and sick -- was so happy , and so busy , and stopped so often in her preparations to lay her head upon my bosom , and fondle me , and cry with joyful tears she was so glad , she was so glad , that I was obliged to say , `` Charley , if you go on in this way , I must lie down again , my darling , for I am weaker than I thought I was ! ''
Parsing [sent. 11308 len. 47]: So Charley became as quiet as a mouse and took her bright face here and there across and across the two rooms , out of the shade into the divine sunshine , and out of the sunshine into the shade , while I watched her peacefully .
Parsing [sent. 11309 len. 66]: When all her preparations were concluded and the pretty tea-table with its little delicacies to tempt me , and its white cloth , and its flowers , and everything so lovingly and beautifully arranged for me by Ada downstairs , was ready at the bedside , I felt sure I was steady enough to say something to Charley that was not new to my thoughts .
Parsing [sent. 11310 len. 35]: First I complimented Charley on the room , and indeed it was so fresh and airy , so spotless and neat , that I could scarce believe I had been lying there so long .
Parsing [sent. 11311 len. 12]: This delighted Charley , and her face was brighter than before .
Parsing [sent. 11312 len. 26]: `` Yet , Charley , '' said I , looking round , `` I miss something , surely , that I am accustomed to ? ''
Parsing [sent. 11313 len. 19]: Poor little Charley looked round too and pretended to shake her head as if there were nothing absent .
Parsing [sent. 11314 len. 12]: `` Are the pictures all as they used to be ? ''
Parsing [sent. 11315 len. 4]: I asked her .
Parsing [sent. 11316 len. 12]: `` Every one of them , miss , '' said Charley .

Parsing [sent. 11320 len. 10]: Ah , I know what it is , Charley !

Parsing [sent. 11323 len. 8]: I had thought of this very often .
Parsing [sent. 11324 len. 7]: I was now certain of it .

Parsing [sent. 11335 len. 3]: I thought .

Parsing [sent. 11457 len. 18]: `` So sagacious , our young friend , '' said she to me in her mysterious way .

Parsing [sent. 11459 len. 4]: But ve-ry sagacious !
Parsing [sent. 11460 len. 11]: Well , my dear , it 's a pretty anecdote .
Parsing [sent. 11461 len. 3]: Nothing more .
Parsing [sent. 11462 len. 6]: Still I think it charming .

Parsing [sent. 11464 len. 5]: `` Just so ! ''
Parsing [sent. 11465 len. 8]: Miss Flite acquiesced with the greatest suavity .
Parsing [sent. 11466 len. 3]: `` Jenny .
Parsing [sent. 11467 len. 2]: Ye-es !
Parsing [sent. 11468 len. 50]: And what does she tell our young friend but that there has been a lady with a veil inquiring at her cottage after my dear Fitz Jarndyce 's health and taking a handkerchief away with her as a little keepsake merely because it was my amiable Fitz Jarndyce 's !
Parsing [sent. 11469 len. 16]: Now , you know , so very prepossessing in the lady with the veil ! ''

Parsing [sent. 11471 len. 25]: I think , if you please , partly because it was yours , miss , and partly because it had covered the baby . ''

Parsing [sent. 11474 len. 4]: And so dear !
Parsing [sent. 11475 len. 14]: My love , she 's clearer than any counsel I ever heard ! ''

Parsing [sent. 11478 len. 3]: Well ? ''

Parsing [sent. 11480 len. 33]: And Jenny wants you to know that she would n't have made away with it herself for a heap of money but that the lady took it and left some money instead .

Parsing [sent. 11482 len. 9]: `` Why , who can she be ? ''

Parsing [sent. 11485 len. 10]: And I understand she leads him a terrible life .

Parsing [sent. 11487 len. 22]: I did not think very much about this lady then , for I had an impression that it might be Caddy .
Parsing [sent. 11488 len. 62]: Besides , my attention was diverted by my visitor , who was cold after her ride and looked hungry and who , our dinner being brought in , required some little assistance in arraying herself with great satisfaction in a pitiable old scarf and a much-worn and often-mended pair of gloves , which she had brought down in a paper parcel .
Parsing [sent. 11489 len. 65]: I had to preside , too , over the entertainment , consisting of a dish of fish , a roast fowl , a sweetbread , vegetables , pudding , and Madeira ; and it was so pleasant to see how she enjoyed it , and with what state and ceremony she did honour to it , that I was soon thinking of nothing else .
Parsing [sent. 11490 len. 64]: When we had finished and had our little dessert before us , embellished by the hands of my dear , who would yield the superintendence of everything prepared for me to no one , Miss Flite was so very chatty and happy that I thought I would lead her to her own history , as she was always pleased to talk about herself .

Parsing [sent. 11617 len. 5]: Death in all shapes .
Parsing [sent. 11618 len. 6]: Hundreds of dead and dying .
Parsing [sent. 11619 len. 7]: Fire , storm , and darkness .
Parsing [sent. 11620 len. 9]: Numbers of the drowning thrown upon a rock .
Parsing [sent. 11621 len. 14]: There , and through it all , my dear physician was a hero .
Parsing [sent. 11622 len. 6]: Calm and brave through everything .
Parsing [sent. 11623 len. 50]: Saved many lives , never complained in hunger and thirst , wrapped naked people in his spare clothes , took the lead , showed them what to do , governed them , tended the sick , buried the dead , and brought the poor survivors safely off at last !
Parsing [sent. 11624 len. 12]: My dear , the poor emaciated creatures all but worshipped him .
Parsing [sent. 11625 len. 16]: They fell down at his feet when they got to the land and blessed him .
Parsing [sent. 11626 len. 7]: The whole country rings with it .
Parsing [sent. 11627 len. 2]: Stay !

Parsing [sent. 11629 len. 18]: I have got it there , and you shall read it , you shall read it ! ''
Parsing [sent. 11630 len. 55]: And I DID read all the noble history , though very slowly and imperfectly then , for my eyes were so dimmed that I could not see the words , and I cried so much that I was many times obliged to lay down the long account she had cut out of the newspaper .
Parsing [sent. 11631 len. 57]: I felt so triumphant ever to have known the man who had done such generous and gallant deeds , I felt such glowing exultation in his renown , I so admired and loved what he had done , that I envied the storm-worn people who had fallen at his feet and blessed him as their preserver .
Parsing [sent. 11632 len. 28]: I could myself have kneeled down then , so far away , and blessed him in my rapture that he should be so truly good and brave .
Parsing [sent. 11633 len. 23]: I felt that no one -- mother , sister , wife -- could honour him more than I. I did , indeed !
Parsing [sent. 11634 len. 64]: My poor little visitor made me a present of the account , and when as the evening began to close in she rose to take her leave , lest she should miss the coach by which she was to return , she was still full of the shipwreck , which I had not yet sufflciently composed myself to understand in all its details .
Parsing [sent. 11635 len. 30]: `` My dear , '' said she as she carefully folded up her scarf and gloves , `` my brave physician ought to have a title bestowed upon him .
Parsing [sent. 11636 len. 6]: And no doubt he will .
Parsing [sent. 11637 len. 7]: You are of that opinlon ? ''
Parsing [sent. 11638 len. 8]: That he well deserved one , yes .
Parsing [sent. 11639 len. 9]: That he would ever have one , no .
Parsing [sent. 11640 len. 8]: `` Why not , Fitz Jarndyce ? ''
Parsing [sent. 11641 len. 5]: she asked rather sharply .
Parsing [sent. 11642 len. 40]: I said it was not the custom in England to confer titles on men distinguished by peaceful services , however good and great , unless occasionally when they consisted of the accumulation of some very large amount of money .
Parsing [sent. 11643 len. 18]: `` Why , good gracious , '' said Miss Flite , `` how can you say that ?

Parsing [sent. 11645 len. 10]: Look round you , my dear , and consider .
Parsing [sent. 11646 len. 32]: YOU must be rambling a little now , I think , if you do n't know that this is the great reason why titles will always last in the land ! ''
Parsing [sent. 11647 len. 20]: I am afraid she believed what she said , for there were moments when she was very mad indeed .
Parsing [sent. 11648 len. 17]: And now I must part with the little secret I have thus far tried to keep .
Parsing [sent. 11649 len. 33]: I had thought , sometimes , that Mr. Woodcourt loved me and that if he had been richer he would perhaps have told me that he loved me before he went away .
Parsing [sent. 11650 len. 21]: I had thought , sometimes , that if he had done so , I should have been glad of it .
Parsing [sent. 11651 len. 13]: But how much better it was now that this had never happened !
Parsing [sent. 11652 len. 47]: What should I have suffered if I had had to write to him and tell him that the poor face he had known as mine was quite gone from me and that I freely released him from his bondage to one whom he had never seen !
Parsing [sent. 11653 len. 11]: Oh , it was so much better as it was !
Parsing [sent. 11654 len. 119]: With a great pang mercifully spared me , I could take back to my heart my childish prayer to be all he had so brightly shown himself ; and there was nothing to be undone : no chain for me to break or for him to drag ; and I could go , please God , my lowly way along the path of duty , and he could go his nobler way upon its broader road ; and though we were apart upon the journey , I might aspire to meet him , unselfishly , innocently , better far than he had thought me when I found some favour in his eyes , at the journey 's end .
Parsing [sent. 11655 len. 19]: Chapter XXXVI -- Chesney Wold Charley and I did not set off alone upon our expedition into Lincolnshire .
Parsing [sent. 11656 len. 37]: My guardian had made up his mind not to lose sight of me until I was safe in Mr. Boythorn 's house , so he accompanied us , and we were two days upon the road .
Parsing [sent. 11657 len. 45]: I found every breath of air , and every scent , and every flower and leaf and blade of grass , and every passing cloud , and everything in nature , more beautiful and wonderful to me than I had ever found it yet .
Parsing [sent. 11658 len. 9]: This was my first gain from my illness .
Parsing [sent. 11659 len. 18]: How little I had lost , when the wide world was so full of delight for me .
Parsing [sent. 11660 len. 25]: My guardian intending to go back immediately , we appointed , on our way down , a day when my dear girl should come .
Parsing [sent. 11661 len. 36]: I wrote her a letter , of which he took charge , and he left us within half an hour of our arrival at our destination , on a delightful evening in the early summer-time .
Parsing [sent. 11662 len. 38]: If a good fairy had built the house for me with a wave of her wand , and I had been a princess and her favoured god-child , I could not have been more considered in it .
Parsing [sent. 11663 len. 41]: So many preparations were made for me and such an endearing remembrance was shown of all my little tastes and likings that I could have sat down , overcome , a dozen times before I had revisited half the rooms .
Parsing [sent. 11664 len. 16]: I did better than that , however , by showing them all to Charley instead .
Parsing [sent. 11665 len. 40]: Charley 's delight calmed mine ; and after we had had a walk in the garden , and Charley had exhausted her whole vocabulary of admiring expressions , I was as tranquilly happy as I ought to have been .
Parsing [sent. 11666 len. 43]: It was a great comfort to be able to say to myself after tea , `` Esther , my dear , I think you are quite sensible enough to sit down now and write a note of thanks to your host . ''
Parsing [sent. 11667 len. 37]: He had left a note of welcome for me , as sunny as his own face , and had confided his bird to my care , which I knew to be his highest mark of confidence .
Parsing [sent. 11668 len. 86]: Accordingly I wrote a little note to him in London , telling him how all his favourite plants and trees were looking , and how the most astonishing of birds had chirped the honours of the house to me in the most hospitable manner , and how , after singing on my shoulder , to the inconceivable rapture of my little maid , he was then at roost in the usual corner of his cage , but whether dreaming or no I could not report .
Parsing [sent. 11669 len. 41]: My note finished and sent off to the post , I made myself very busy in unpacking and arranging ; and I sent Charley to bed in good time and told her I should want her no more that night .
Parsing [sent. 11670 len. 21]: For I had not yet looked in the glass and had never asked to have my own restored to me .
Parsing [sent. 11671 len. 33]: I knew this to be a weakness which must be overcome , but I had always said to myself that I would begin afresh when I got to where I now was .
Parsing [sent. 11672 len. 54]: Therefore I had wanted to be alone , and therefore I said , now alone , in my own room , `` Esther , if you are to be happy , if you are to have any right to pray to be true-hearted , you must keep your word , my dear . ''
Parsing [sent. 11673 len. 24]: I was quite resolved to keep it , but I sat down for a little while first to reflect upon all my blessings .
Parsing [sent. 11674 len. 12]: And then I said my prayers and thought a little more .
Parsing [sent. 11675 len. 18]: My hair had not been cut off , though it had been in danger more than once .
Parsing [sent. 11676 len. 6]: It was long and thick .
Parsing [sent. 11677 len. 20]: I let it down , and shook it out , and went up to the glass upon the dressing-table .
Parsing [sent. 11678 len. 10]: There was a little muslin curtain drawn across it .
Parsing [sent. 11679 len. 25]: I drew it back and stood for a moment looking through such a veil of my own hair that I could see nothing else .
Parsing [sent. 11680 len. 25]: Then I put my hair aside and looked at the reflection in the mirror , encouraged by seeing how placidly it looked at me .
Parsing [sent. 11681 len. 13]: I was very much changed -- oh , very , very much .
Parsing [sent. 11682 len. 31]: At first my face was so strange to me that I think I should have put my hands before it and started back but for the encouragement I have mentioned .
Parsing [sent. 11683 len. 26]: Very soon it became more familiar , and then I knew the extent of the alteration in it better than I had done at first .
Parsing [sent. 11684 len. 27]: It was not like what I had expected , but I had expected nothing definite , and I dare say anything definite would have surprised me .
Parsing [sent. 11685 len. 22]: I had never been a beauty and had never thought myself one , but I had been very different from this .
Parsing [sent. 11686 len. 6]: It was all gone now .
Parsing [sent. 11687 len. 31]: Heaven was so good to me that I could let it go with a few not bitter tears and could stand there arranging my hair for the night quite thankfully .
Parsing [sent. 11688 len. 19]: One thing troubled me , and I considered it for a long time before I went to sleep .
Parsing [sent. 11689 len. 8]: I had kept Mr. Woodcourt 's flowers .
Parsing [sent. 11690 len. 20]: When they were withered I had dried them and put them in a book that I was fond of .
Parsing [sent. 11691 len. 8]: Nobody knew this , not even Ada .
Parsing [sent. 11692 len. 29]: I was doubtful whether I had a right to preserve what he had sent to one so different -- whether it was generous towards him to do it .
Parsing [sent. 11693 len. 37]: I wished to be generous to him , even in the secret depths of my heart , which he would never know , because I could have loved him -- could have been devoted to him .
Parsing [sent. 11694 len. 42]: At last I came to the conclusion that I might keep them if I treasured them only as a remembrance of what was irrevocably past and gone , never to be looked back on any more , in any other light .
Parsing [sent. 11695 len. 8]: I hope this may not seem trivial .
Parsing [sent. 11696 len. 7]: I was very much in earnest .
Parsing [sent. 11697 len. 23]: I took care to be up early in the morning and to be before the glass when Charley came in on tiptoe .
Parsing [sent. 11698 len. 8]: `` Dear , dear , miss ! ''
Parsing [sent. 11699 len. 5]: cried Charley , starting .
Parsing [sent. 11700 len. 6]: `` Is that you ? ''
Parsing [sent. 11701 len. 15]: `` Yes , Charley , '' said I , quietly putting up my hair .
Parsing [sent. 11702 len. 13]: `` And I am very well indeed , and very happy . ''
Parsing [sent. 11703 len. 20]: I saw it was a weight off Charley 's mind , but it was a greater weight off mine .
Parsing [sent. 11704 len. 11]: I knew the worst now and was composed to it .
Parsing [sent. 11705 len. 36]: I shall not conceal , as I go on , the weaknesses I could not quite conquer , but they always passed from me soon and the happier frame of mind stayed by me faithfully .
Parsing [sent. 11706 len. 37]: Wishing to be fully re-established in my strength and my good spirits before Ada came , I now laid down a little series of plans with Charley for being in the fresh air all day long .
Parsing [sent. 11707 len. 62]: We were to be out before breakfast , and were to dine early , and were to be out again before and after dinner , and were to talk in the garden after tea , and were to go to rest betimes , and were to climb every hill and explore every road , lane , and field in the neighbourhood .
Parsing [sent. 11708 len. 64]: As to restoratives and strengthening delicacies , Mr. Boythorn 's good housekeeper was for ever trotting about with something to eat or drink in her hand ; I could not even be heard of as resting in the park but she would come trotting after me with a basket , her cheerful face shining with a lecture on the importance of frequent nourishment .
Parsing [sent. 11709 len. 42]: Then there was a pony expressly for my riding , a chubby pony with a short neck and a mane all over his eyes who could canter -- when he would -- so easily and quietly that he was a treasure .
Parsing [sent. 11710 len. 30]: In a very few days he would come to me in the paddock when I called him , and eat out of my hand , and follow me about .
Parsing [sent. 11711 len. 104]: We arrived at such a capital understanding that when he was jogging with me lazily , and rather obstinately , down some shady lane , if I patted his neck and said , `` Stubbs , I am surprised you do n't canter when you know how much I like it ; and I think you might oblige me , for you are only getting stupid and going to sleep , '' he would give his head a comical shake or two and set off directly , while Charley would stand still and laugh with such enjoyment that her laughter was like music .
Parsing [sent. 11712 len. 25]: I do n't know who had given Stubbs his name , but it seemed to belong to him as naturally as his rough coat .
Parsing [sent. 11713 len. 81]: Once we put him in a little chaise and drove him triumphantly through the green lanes for five miles ; but all at once , as we were extolling him to the skies , he seemed to take it ill that he should have been accompanied so far by the circle of tantalizing little gnats that had been hovering round and round his ears the whole way without appearing to advance an inch , and stopped to think about it .
Parsing [sent. 11714 len. 60]: I suppose he came to the decision that it was not to be borne , for he steadily refused to move until I gave the reins to Charley and got out and walked , when he followed me with a sturdy sort of good humour , putting his head under my arm and rubbing his ear against my sleeve .
Parsing [sent. 11715 len. 50]: It was in vain for me to say , `` Now , Stubbs , I feel quite sure from what I know of you that you will go on if I ride a little while , '' for the moment I left him , he stood stock still again .
Parsing [sent. 11716 len. 28]: Consequently I was obliged to lead the way , as before ; and in this order we returned home , to the great delight of the village .
Parsing [sent. 11717 len. 56]: Charley and I had reason to call it the most friendly of villages , I am sure , for in a week 's time the people were so glad to see us go by , though ever so frequently in the course of a day , that there were faces of greeting in every cottage .
Parsing [sent. 11718 len. 29]: I had known many of the grown people before and almost all the children , but now the very steeple began to wear a familiar and affectionate look .
Parsing [sent. 11719 len. 38]: Among my new friends was an old old woman who lived in such a little thatched and whitewashed dwelling that when the outside shutter was turned up on its hinges , it shut up the whole house-front .
Parsing [sent. 11720 len. 47]: This old lady had a grandson who was a sailor , and I wrote a letter to him for her and drew at the top of it the chimney-corner in which she had brought him up and where his old stool yet occupied its old place .
Parsing [sent. 11721 len. 77]: This was considered by the whole village the most wonderful achievement in the world , but when an answer came back all the way from Plymouth , in which he mentioned that he was going to take the picture all the way to America , and from America would write again , I got all the credit that ought to have been given to the post-office and was invested with the merit of the whole system .
Parsing [sent. 11722 len. 66]: Thus , what with being so much in the air , playing with so many children , gossiping with so many people , sitting on invitation in so many cottages , going on with Charley 's education , and writing long letters to Ada every day , I had scarcely any time to think about that little loss of mine and was almost always cheerful .
Parsing [sent. 11723 len. 23]: If I did think of it at odd moments now and then , I had only to be busy and forget it .
Parsing [sent. 11724 len. 35]: I felt it more than I had hoped I should once when a child said , `` Mother , why is the lady not a pretty lady now like she used to be ? ''
Parsing [sent. 11725 len. 38]: But when I found the child was not less fond of me , and drew its soft hand over my face with a kind of pitying protection in its touch , that soon set me up again .
Parsing [sent. 11726 len. 30]: There were many little occurrences which suggested to me , with great consolation , how natural it is to gentle hearts to be considerate and delicate towards any inferiority .
Parsing [sent. 11727 len. 7]: One of these particularly touched me .
Parsing [sent. 11728 len. 25]: I happened to stroll into the little church when a marriage was just concluded , and the young couple had to sign the register .
Parsing [sent. 11729 len. 30]: The bridegroom , to whom the pen was handed first , made a rude cross for his mark ; the bride , who came next , did the same .
Parsing [sent. 11730 len. 45]: Now , I had known the bride when I was last there , not only as the prettiest girl in the place , but as having quite distinguished herself in the school , and I could not help looking at her with some surprise .
Parsing [sent. 11731 len. 57]: She came aside and whispered to me , while tears of honest love and admiration stood in her bright eyes , `` He 's a dear good fellow , miss ; but he ca n't write yet -- he 's going to learn of me -- and I would n't shame him for the world ! ''
Parsing [sent. 11732 len. 26]: Why , what had I to fear , I thought , when there was this nobility in the soul of a labouring man 's daughter !
Parsing [sent. 11733 len. 33]: The air blew as freshly and revivingly upon me as it had ever blown , and the healthy colour came into my new face as it had come into my old one .
Parsing [sent. 11734 len. 28]: Charley was wonderful to see , she was so radiant and so rosy ; and we both enjoyed the whole day and slept soundly the whole night .
Parsing [sent. 11735 len. 24]: There was a favourite spot of mine in the park-woods of Chesney Wold where a seat had been erected commanding a lovely view .
Parsing [sent. 11736 len. 33]: The wood had been cleared and opened to improve this point of sight , and the bright sunny landscape beyond was so beautiful that I rested there at least once every day .
Parsing [sent. 11737 len. 65]: A picturesque part of the Hall , called the Ghost 's Walk , was seen to advantage from this higher ground ; and the startling name , and the old legend in the Dedlock family which I had heard from Mr. Boythorn accounting for it , mingled with the view and gave it something of a mysterious interest in addition to its real charms .
Parsing [sent. 11738 len. 42]: There was a bank here , too , which was a famous one for violets ; and as it was a daily delight of Charley 's to gather wild flowers , she took as much to the spot as I did .
Parsing [sent. 11739 len. 21]: It would be idle to inquire now why I never went close to the house or never went inside it .
Parsing [sent. 11740 len. 18]: The family were not there , I had heard on my arrival , and were not expected .
Parsing [sent. 11741 len. 52]: I was far from being incurious or uninterested about the building ; on the contrary , I often sat in this place wondering how the rooms ranged and whether any echo like a footstep really did resound at times , as the story said , upon the lonely Ghost 's Walk .
Parsing [sent. 11742 len. 27]: The indefinable feeling with which Lady Dedlock had impressed me may have had some influence in keeping me from the house even when she was absent .
Parsing [sent. 11743 len. 5]: I am not sure .
Parsing [sent. 11744 len. 27]: Her face and figure were associated with it , naturally ; but I can not say that they repelled me from it , though something did .
Parsing [sent. 11745 len. 26]: For whatever reason or no reason , I had never once gone near it , down to the day at which my story now arrives .
Parsing [sent. 11746 len. 24]: I was resting at my favourite point after a long ramble , and Charley was gathering violets at a little distance from me .
Parsing [sent. 11747 len. 43]: I had been looking at the Ghost 's Walk lying in a deep shade of masonry afar off and picturing to myself the female shape that was said to haunt it when I became aware of a figure approaching through the wood .
Parsing [sent. 11748 len. 42]: The perspective was so long and so darkened by leaves , and the shadows of the branches on the ground made it so much more intricate to the eye , that at first I could not discern what figure it was .
Parsing [sent. 11749 len. 21]: By little and little it revealed itself to be a woman 's -- a lady 's -- Lady Dedlock 's .
Parsing [sent. 11750 len. 27]: She was alone and coming to where I sat with a much quicker step , I observed to my surprise , than was usual with her .

Parsing [sent. 11754 len. 79]: Not so much by her hurried gesture of entreaty , not so much by her quick advance and outstretched hands , not so much by the great change in her manner and the absence of her haughty self-restraint , as by a something in her face that I had pined for and dreamed of when I was a little child , something I had never seen in any face , something I had never seen in hers before .

Parsing [sent. 11783 len. 61]: That it was not for me , then resting for the first time on my mother 's bosom , to take her to account for having given me life , but that my duty was to bless her and receive her , though the whole world turned from her , and that I only asked her leave to do it .
Parsing [sent. 11784 len. 43]: I held my mother in my embrace , and she held me in hers , and among the still woods in the silence of the summer day there seemed to be nothing but our two troubled minds that was not at peace .
Parsing [sent. 11785 len. 19]: `` To bless and receive me , '' groaned my mother , `` it is far too late .
Parsing [sent. 11786 len. 17]: I must travel my dark road alone , and it will lead me where it will .

Parsing [sent. 11789 len. 10]: I bear it , and I hide it . ''

Parsing [sent. 11804 len. 51]: Whether she preserved her secret until death or it came to be discovered and she brought dishonour and disgrace upon the name she had taken , it was her solitary struggle always ; and no affection could come near her , and no human creature could render her any aid .

Parsing [sent. 11806 len. 3]: I asked .

Parsing [sent. 11852 len. 136]: I explained , as nearly as I could then , or can recall now -- for my agitation and distress throughout were so great that I scarcely understood myself , though every word that was uttered in the mother 's voice , so unfamiliar and so melancholy to me , which in my childhood I had never learned to love and recognize , had never been sung to sleep with , had never heard a blessing from , had never had a hope inspired by , made an enduring impression on my memory -- I say I explained , or tried to do it , how I had only hoped that Mr. Jarndyce , who had been the best of fathers to me , might be able to afford some counsel and support to her .

Parsing [sent. 11868 len. 42]: Stunned as I was , as weak and helpless at first as I had ever been in my sick chamber , the necessity of guarding against the danger of discovery , or even of the remotest suspicion , did me service .

Parsing [sent. 11870 len. 34]: It was not a little while before I could succeed or could even restrain bursts of grief , but after an hour or so I was better and felt that I might return .

Parsing [sent. 11874 len. 68]: Her elder and only sister , the godmother of my childhood , discovering signs of life in me when I had been laid aside as dead , had in her stern sense of duty , with no desire or willingness that I should live , reared me in rigid secrecy and had never again beheld my mother 's face from within a few hours of my birth .
Parsing [sent. 11875 len. 47]: So strangely did I hold my place in this world that until within a short time back I had never , to my own mother 's knowledge , breathed -- had been buried -- had never been endowed with life -- had never borne a name .

Parsing [sent. 11883 len. 45]: That I was so confused and shaken as to be possessed by a belief that it was right and had been intended that I should die in my birth , and that it was wrong and not intended that I should be then alive .
Parsing [sent. 11884 len. 9]: These are the real feelings that I had .
Parsing [sent. 11885 len. 30]: I fell asleep worn out , and when I awoke I cried afresh to think that I was back in the world with my load of trouble for others .
Parsing [sent. 11886 len. 64]: I was more than ever frightened of myself , thinking anew of her against whom I was a witness , of the owner of Chesney Wold , of the new and terrible meaning of the old words now moaning in my ear like a surge upon the shore , `` Your mother , Esther , was your disgrace , and you are hers .
Parsing [sent. 11887 len. 31]: The time will come -- and soon enough -- when you will understand this better , and will feel it too , as no one save a woman can . ''
Parsing [sent. 11888 len. 24]: With them , those other words returned , `` Pray daily that the sins of others be not visited upon your head . ''
Parsing [sent. 11889 len. 32]: I could not disentangle all that was about me , and I felt as if the blame and the shame were all in me , and the visitation had come down .
Parsing [sent. 11890 len. 21]: The day waned into a gloomy evening , overcast and sad , and I still contended with the same distress .
Parsing [sent. 11891 len. 46]: I went out alone , and after walking a little in the park , watching the dark shades falling on the trees and the fitful flight of the bats , which sometimes almost touched me , was attracted to the house for the first time .
Parsing [sent. 11892 len. 19]: Perhaps I might not have gone near it if I had been in a stronger frame of mind .
Parsing [sent. 11893 len. 14]: As it was , I took the path that led close by it .
Parsing [sent. 11894 len. 97]: I did not dare to linger or to look up , but I passed before the terrace garden with its fragrant odours , and its broad walks , and its well-kept beds and smooth turf ; and I saw how beautiful and grave it was , and how the old stone balustrades and parapets , and wide flights of shallow steps , were seamed by time and weather ; and how the trained moss and ivy grew about them , and around the old stone pedestal of the sun-dial ; and I heard the fountain falling .
Parsing [sent. 11895 len. 47]: Then the way went by long lines of dark windows diversified by turreted towers and porches of eccentric shapes , where old stone lions and grotesque monsters bristled outside dens of shadow and snarled at the evening gloom over the escutcheons they held in their grip .
Parsing [sent. 11896 len. 83]: Thence the path wound underneath a gateway , and through a court-yard where the principal entrance was -LRB- I hurried quickly on -RRB- , and by the stables where none but deep voices seemed to be , whether in the murmuring of the wind through the strong mass of ivy holding to a high red wall , or in the low complaining of the weathercock , or in the barking of the dogs , or in the slow striking of a clock .
Parsing [sent. 11897 len. 52]: So , encountering presently a sweet smell of limes , whose rustling I could hear , I turned with the turning of the path to the south front , and there above me were the balustrades of the Ghost 's Walk and one lighted window that might be my mother 's .
Parsing [sent. 11898 len. 25]: The way was paved here , like the terrace overhead , and my footsteps from being noiseless made an echoing sound upon the flags .
Parsing [sent. 11899 len. 83]: Stopping to look at nothing , but seeing all I did see as I went , I was passing quickly on , and in a few moments should have passed the lighted window , when my echoing footsteps brought it suddenly into my mind that there was a dreadful truth in the legend of the Ghost 's Walk , that it was I who was to bring calamity upon the stately house and that my warning feet were haunting it even then .
Parsing [sent. 11900 len. 48]: Seized with an augmented terror of myself which turned me cold , I ran from myself and everything , retraced the way by which I had come , and never paused until I had gained the lodge-gate , and the park lay sullen and black behind me .

Parsing [sent. 11902 len. 113]: But from my darling who was coming on the morrow , I found a joyful letter , full of such loving anticipation that I must have been of marble if it had not moved me ; from my guardian , too , I found another letter , asking me to tell Dame Durden , if I should see that little woman anywhere , that they had moped most pitiably without her , that the housekeeping was going to rack and ruin , that nobody else could manage the keys , and that everybody in and about the house declared it was not the same house and was becoming rebellious for her return .

Parsing [sent. 12358 len. 62]: The first few mornings were mornings of so much bustle and business , devoted to such settlements of accounts , such repeated journeys to and fro between the growlery and all other parts of the house , so many rearrangements of drawers and presses , and such a general new beginning altogether , that I had not a moment 's leisure .

Parsing [sent. 12514 len. 19]: I must say for Mr. Guppy that the snuffling manner he had had upon him improved very much .

Parsing [sent. 12516 len. 46]: `` If you will allow me to finish what I have to say at once so that I may have no occasion to resume , '' I went on , seeing him about to speak , `` you will do me a kindness , sir .
Parsing [sent. 12517 len. 39]: I come to you as privately as possible because you announced this impression of yours to me in a confidence which I have really wished to respect -- and which I always have respected , as you remember .
Parsing [sent. 12518 len. 6]: I have mentioned my illness .
Parsing [sent. 12519 len. 34]: There really is no reason why I should hesitate to say that I know very well that any little delicacy I might have had in making a request to you is quite removed .
Parsing [sent. 12520 len. 26]: Therefore I make the entreaty I have now preferred , and I hope you will have sufficient consideration for me to accede to it . ''
Parsing [sent. 12521 len. 69]: I must do Mr. Guppy the further justice of saying that he had looked more and more ashamed and that he looked most ashamed and very earnest when he now replied with a burning face , `` Upon my word and honour , upon my life , upon my soul , Miss Summerson , as I am a living man , I 'll act according to your wish !
Parsing [sent. 12522 len. 11]: I 'll never go another step in opposition to it .
Parsing [sent. 12523 len. 16]: I 'll take my oath to it if it will be any satisfaction to you .
Parsing [sent. 12524 len. 74]: In what I promise at this present time touching the matters now in question , '' continued Mr. Guppy rapidly , as if he were repeating a familiar form of words , `` I speak the truth , the whole truth , and nothing but the truth , so -- '' `` I am quite satisfied , '' said I , rising at this point , `` and I thank you very much .
Parsing [sent. 12525 len. 10]: Caddy , my dear , I am ready ! ''
Parsing [sent. 12526 len. 28]: Mr. Guppy 's mother returned with Caddy -LRB- now making me the recipient of her silent laughter and her nudges -RRB- , and we took our leave .
Parsing [sent. 12527 len. 31]: Mr. Guppy saw us to the door with the air of one who was either imperfectly awake or walking in his sleep ; and we left him there , staring .
Parsing [sent. 12528 len. 48]: But in a minute he came after us down the street without any hat , and with his long hair all blown about , and stopped us , saying fervently , `` Miss Summerson , upon my honour and soul , you may depend upon me ! ''
Parsing [sent. 12529 len. 13]: `` I do , '' said I , `` quite confidently . ''
Parsing [sent. 12530 len. 61]: `` I beg your pardon , miss , '' said Mr. Guppy , going with one leg and staying with the other , `` but this lady being present -- your own witness -- it might be a satisfaction to your mind -LRB- which I should wish to set at rest -RRB- if you was to repeat those admissions . ''
Parsing [sent. 12531 len. 51]: `` Well , Caddy , '' said I , turning to her , `` perhaps you will not be surprised when I tell you , my dear , that there never has been any engagement -- '' `` No proposal or promise of marriage whatsoever , '' suggested Mr. Guppy .

Parsing [sent. 12534 len. 11]: `` Thank you , miss , '' said Mr. Guppy .
Parsing [sent. 12535 len. 19]: `` Very full -- er -- excuse me -- lady 's name , Christian and surname both ? ''

Parsing [sent. 12543 len. 9]: He ran home and came running back again .
Parsing [sent. 12544 len. 61]: `` Touching that matter , you know , I really and truly am very sorry that my arrangements in life , combined with circumstances over which I have no control , should prevent a renewal of what was wholly terminated some time back , '' said Mr. Guppy to me forlornly and despondently , `` but it could n't be .

Parsing [sent. 12553 len. 28]: I did so with a lightened heart ; but when we last looked back , Mr. Guppy was still oscillating in the same troubled state of mind .
Parsing [sent. 12554 len. 53]: Chapter XXXIX -- Attorney and Client The name of Mr. Vholes , preceded by the legend Ground -- Floor , is inscribed upon a door-post in Symond 's Inn , Chancery Lane -- a little , pale , wall-eyed , woebegone inn like a large dust-binn of two compartments and a sifter .
Parsing [sent. 12555 len. 46]: It looks as if Symond were a sparing man in his way and constructed his inn of old building materials which took kindly to the dry rot and to dirt and all things decaying and dismal , and perpetuated Symond 's memory with congenial shabbiness .
Parsing [sent. 12556 len. 16]: Quartered in this dingy hatchment commemorative of Symond are the legal bearings of Mr. Vholes .
Parsing [sent. 12557 len. 26]: Mr. Vholes 's office , in disposition retiring and in situation retired , is squeezed up in a corner and blinks at a dead wall .
Parsing [sent. 12558 len. 44]: Three feet of knotty-floored dark passage bring the client to Mr. Vholes 's jet-black door , in an angle profoundly dark on the brightest midsummer morning and encumbered by a black bulk-head of cellarage staircase against which belated civilians generally strike their brows .
Parsing [sent. 12559 len. 41]: Mr. Vholes 's chambers are on so small a scale that one clerk can open the door without getting off his stool , while the other who elbows him at the same desk has equal facilities for poking the fire .
Parsing [sent. 12560 len. 43]: A smell as of unwholesome sheep blending with the smell of must and dust is referable to the nightly -LRB- and often daily -RRB- consumption of mutton fat in candles and to the fretting of parchment forms and skins in greasy drawers .
Parsing [sent. 12561 len. 8]: The atmosphere is otherwise stale and close .
Parsing [sent. 12562 len. 62]: The place was last painted or whitewashed beyond the memory of man , and the two chimneys smoke , and there is a loose outer surface of soot evervwhere , and the dull cracked windows in their heavy frames have but one piece of character in them , which is a determination to be always dirty and always shut unless coerced .
Parsing [sent. 12563 len. 25]: This accounts for the phenomenon of the weaker of the two usually having a bundle of firewood thrust between its jaws in hot weather .
Parsing [sent. 12564 len. 8]: Mr. Vholes is a very respectable man .
Parsing [sent. 12565 len. 15]: He has not a large business , but he is a very respectable man .
Parsing [sent. 12566 len. 23]: He is allowed by the greater attorneys who have made good fortunes or are making them to be a most respectable man .
Parsing [sent. 12567 len. 16]: He never misses a chance in his practice , which is a mark of respectability .
Parsing [sent. 12568 len. 13]: He never takes any pleasure , which is another mark of respectability .
Parsing [sent. 12569 len. 13]: He is reserved and serious , which is another mark of respectability .
Parsing [sent. 12570 len. 10]: His digestion is impaired , which is highly respectable .
Parsing [sent. 12571 len. 17]: And he is making hay of the grass which is flesh , for his three daughters .
Parsing [sent. 12572 len. 13]: And his father is dependent on him in the Vale of Taunton .
Parsing [sent. 12573 len. 15]: The one great principle of the English law is to make business for itself .
Parsing [sent. 12574 len. 18]: There is no other principle distinctly , certainly , and consistently maintained through all its narrow turnings .
Parsing [sent. 12575 len. 22]: Viewed by this light it becomes a coherent scheme and not the monstrous maze the laity are apt to think it .
Parsing [sent. 12576 len. 28]: Let them but once clearly perceive that its grand principle is to make business for itself at their expense , and surely they will cease to grumble .
Parsing [sent. 12577 len. 37]: But not perceiving this quite plainly -- only seeing it by halves in a confused way -- the laity sometimes suffer in peace and pocket , with a bad grace , and DO grumble very much .
Parsing [sent. 12578 len. 14]: Then this respectability of Mr. Vholes is brought into powerful play against them .
Parsing [sent. 12579 len. 10]: `` Repeal this statute , my good sir ? ''
Parsing [sent. 12580 len. 8]: says Mr. Kenge to a smarting client .
Parsing [sent. 12581 len. 8]: `` Repeal it , my dear sir ?
Parsing [sent. 12582 len. 6]: Never , with my consent .
Parsing [sent. 12583 len. 43]: Alter this law , sir , and what will be the effect of your rash proceeding on a class of practitioners very worthily represented , allow me to say to you , by the opposite attorney in the case , Mr. Vholes ?
Parsing [sent. 12584 len. 16]: Sir , that class of practitioners would be swept from the face of the earth .
Parsing [sent. 12585 len. 27]: Now you can not afford -- I will say , the social system can not afford -- to lose an order of men like Mr. Vholes .
Parsing [sent. 12586 len. 10]: Diligent , persevering , steady , acute in business .
Parsing [sent. 12587 len. 48]: My dear sir , I understand your present feelings against the existing state of things , which I grant to be a little hard in your case ; but I can never raise my voice for the demolition of a class of men like Mr. Vholes . ''
Parsing [sent. 12588 len. 29]: The respectability of Mr. Vholes has even been cited with crushing effect before Parliamentary committees , as in the following blue minutes of a distinguished attorney 's evidence .
Parsing [sent. 12589 len. 28]: `` Question -LRB- number five hundred and seventeen thousand eight hundred and sixty-nine -RRB- : If I understand you , these forms of practice indisputably occasion delay ?
Parsing [sent. 12590 len. 7]: Answer : Yes , some delay .
Parsing [sent. 12591 len. 6]: Question : And great expense ?
Parsing [sent. 12592 len. 13]: Answer : Most assuredly they can not be gone through for nothing .
Parsing [sent. 12593 len. 6]: Question : And unspeakable vexation ?
Parsing [sent. 12594 len. 10]: Answer : I am not prepared to say that .
Parsing [sent. 12595 len. 12]: They have never given ME any vexation ; quite the contrary .
Parsing [sent. 12596 len. 15]: Question : But you think that their abolition would damage a class of practitioners ?
Parsing [sent. 12597 len. 9]: Answer : I have no doubt of it .
Parsing [sent. 12598 len. 11]: Question : Can you instance any type of that class ?
Parsing [sent. 12599 len. 4]: Answer : Yes .
Parsing [sent. 12600 len. 7]: I would unhesitatingly mention Mr. Vholes .
Parsing [sent. 12601 len. 5]: He would be ruined .
Parsing [sent. 12602 len. 15]: Question : Mr. Vholes is considered , in the profession , a respectable man ?
Parsing [sent. 12603 len. 30]: Answer : '' -- which proved fatal to the inquiry for ten years -- `` Mr. Vholes is considered , in the profession , a MOST respectable man . ''
Parsing [sent. 12604 len. 70]: So in familiar conversation , private authorities no less disinterested will remark that they do n't know what this age is coming to , that we are plunging down precipices , that now here is something else gone , that these changes are death to people like Vholes -- a man of undoubted respectability , with a father in the Vale of Taunton , and three daughters at home .
Parsing [sent. 12605 len. 22]: Take a few steps more in this direction , say they , and what is to become of Vholes 's father ?
Parsing [sent. 12606 len. 5]: Is he to perish ?
Parsing [sent. 12607 len. 6]: And of Vholes 's daughters ?
Parsing [sent. 12608 len. 9]: Are they to be shirt-makers , or governesses ?
Parsing [sent. 12609 len. 39]: As though , Mr. Vholes and his relations being minor cannibal chiefs and it being proposed to abolish cannibalism , indignant champions were to put the case thus : Make man-eating unlawful , and you starve the Vholeses !
Parsing [sent. 12610 len. 46]: In a word , Mr. Vholes , with his three daughters and his father in the Vale of Taunton , is continually doing duty , like a piece of timber , to shore up some decayed foundation that has become a pitfall and a nuisance .
Parsing [sent. 12611 len. 49]: And with a great many people in a great many instances , the question is never one of a change from wrong to right -LRB- which is quite an extraneous consideration -RRB- , but is always one of injury or advantage to that eminently respectable legion , Vholes .
Parsing [sent. 12612 len. 17]: The Chancellor is , within these ten minutes , `` up '' for the long vacation .
Parsing [sent. 12613 len. 41]: Mr. Vholes , and his young client , and several blue bags hastily stuffed out of all regularity of form , as the larger sort of serpents are in their first gorged state , have returned to the official den .
Parsing [sent. 12614 len. 51]: Mr. Vholes , quiet and unmoved , as a man of so much respectability ought to be , takes off his close black gloves as if he were skinning his hands , lifts off his tight hat as if he were scalping himself , and sits down at his desk .

Parsing [sent. 12617 len. 3]: says Richard .

Parsing [sent. 12649 len. 33]: But your interests demand that I should be cool and methodical , Mr. Carstone ; and I can not be otherwise -- no , sir , not even to please you . ''

Parsing [sent. 12654 len. 16]: I am to be found here , day by day , attending to your interests .
Parsing [sent. 12655 len. 18]: That is my duty , Mr. C. , and term-time or vacation makes no difference to me .
Parsing [sent. 12656 len. 21]: If you wish to consult me as to your interests , you will find me here at all times alike .

Parsing [sent. 12658 len. 4]: I do n't .

Parsing [sent. 12663 len. 9]: There is encouragement in the sound to him .

Parsing [sent. 12665 len. 54]: `` I am perfectly aware , Mr. Vholes , '' says Richard , more familiarly and good-humouredly , `` that you are the most reliable fellow in the world and that to have to do with you is to have to do with a man of business who is not to be hoodwinked .
Parsing [sent. 12666 len. 65]: But put yourself in my case , dragging on this dislocated life , sinking deeper and deeper into difficulty every day , continually hoping and continually disappointed , conscious of change upon change for the worse in myself , and of no change for the better in anything else , and you will find it a dark-looking case sometimes , as I do . Parsing [sent. 12689 len. 9]: So little did I know of the world !

Parsing [sent. 12707 len. 17]: says Richard , accompanying his last three words with three raps on his rock of trust .
Parsing [sent. 12708 len. 56]: `` Mr. C. , '' returns Vholes , immovable in attitude and never winking his hungry eyes , `` I should be wanting in my duty as your professional adviser , I should be departing from my fidelity to your interests , if I represented those interests as identical with the interests of Mr. Jarndyce .
Parsing [sent. 12709 len. 8]: They are no such thing , sir .
Parsing [sent. 12710 len. 19]: I never impute motives ; I both have and am a father , and I never impute motives .
Parsing [sent. 12711 len. 18]: But I must not shrink from a professional duty , even if it sows dissensions in families .
Parsing [sent. 12712 len. 14]: I understand you to be now consulting me professionally as to your interests ?
Parsing [sent. 12713 len. 4]: You are so ?
Parsing [sent. 12714 len. 16]: I reply , then , they are not identical with those of Mr. Jarndyce . ''
Parsing [sent. 12715 len. 8]: `` Of course they are not ! ''
Parsing [sent. 12716 len. 3]: cries Richard .
Parsing [sent. 12717 len. 9]: `` You found that out long ago . ''
Parsing [sent. 12718 len. 23]: `` Mr. C. , '' returns Vholes , `` I wish to say no more of any third party than is necessary .
Parsing [sent. 12719 len. 35]: I wish to leave my good name unsullied , together with any little property of which I may become possessed through industry and perseverance , to my daughters Emma , Jane , and Caroline .
Parsing [sent. 12720 len. 12]: I also desire to live in amity with my professional brethren .
Parsing [sent. 12721 len. 62]: When Mr. Skimpole did me the honour , sir -- I will not say the very high honour , for I never stoop to flattery -- of bringing us together in this room , I mentioned to you that I could offer no opinion or advice as to your interests while those interests were entrusted to another member of the profession .
Parsing [sent. 12722 len. 23]: And I spoke in such terms as I was bound to speak of Kenge and Carboy 's office , which stands high .
Parsing [sent. 12723 len. 21]: You , sir , thought fit to withdraw your interests from that keeping nevertheless and to offer them to me .
Parsing [sent. 12724 len. 17]: You brought them with clean hands , sir , and I accepted them with clean hands .
Parsing [sent. 12725 len. 9]: Those interests are now paramount in this office .
Parsing [sent. 12726 len. 39]: My digestive functions , as you may have heard me mention , are not in a good state , and rest might improve them ; but I shall not rest , sir , while I am your representative .
Parsing [sent. 12727 len. 11]: Whenever you want me , you will find me here .
Parsing [sent. 12728 len. 9]: Summon me anywhere , and I will come .
Parsing [sent. 12729 len. 132]: During the long vacation , sir , I shall devote my leisure to studying your interests more and more closely and to making arrangements for moving heaven and earth -LRB- including , of course , the Chancellor -RRB- after Michaelmas term ; and when I ultimately congratulate you , sir , '' says Mr. Vholes with the severity of a determined man , `` when I ultimately congratulate you , sir , with all my heart , on your accession to fortune -- which , but that I never give hopes , I might say something further about -- you will owe me nothing beyond whatever little balance may be then outstanding of the costs as between solicitor and client not included in the taxed costs allowed out of the estate .
Parsing [sent. 12730 len. 40]: I pretend to no claim upon you , Mr. C. , but for the zealous and active discharge -- not the languid and routine discharge , sir : that much credit I stipulate for -- of my professional duty .
Parsing [sent. 12731 len. 12]: My duty prosperously ended , all between us is ended . ''
Parsing [sent. 12732 len. 44]: Vholes finally adds , by way of rider to this declaration of his principles , that as Mr. Carstone is about to rejoin his regiment , perhaps Mr. C. will favour him with an order on his agent for twenty pounds on account .
Parsing [sent. 12733 len. 46]: `` For there have been many little consultations and attendances of late , sir , '' observes Vholes , turning over the leaves of his diary , `` and these things mount up , and I do n't profess to be a man of capital .
Parsing [sent. 12734 len. 59]: When we first entered on our present relations I stated to you openly -- it is a principle of mine that there never can be too much openness between solicitor and client -- that I was not a man of capital and that if capital was your object you had better leave your papers in Kenge 's office .
Parsing [sent. 12735 len. 20]: No , Mr. C. , you will find none of the advantages or disadvantages of capital here , sir .
Parsing [sent. 12736 len. 25]: This , '' Vholes gives the desk one hollow blow again , `` is your rock ; it pretends to be nothing more . ''
Parsing [sent. 12737 len. 45]: The client , with his dejection insensibly relieved and his vague hopes rekindled , takes pen and ink and writes the draft , not without perplexed consideration and calculation of the date it may bear , implying scant effects in the agent 's hands .
Parsing [sent. 12738 len. 18]: All the while , Vholes , buttoned up in body and mind , looks at him attentively .
Parsing [sent. 12739 len. 14]: All the while , Vholes 's official cat watches the mouse 's hole .
Parsing [sent. 12740 len. 36]: Lastly , the client , shaking hands , beseeches Mr. Vholes , for heaven 's sake and earth 's sake , to do his utmost to `` pull him through '' the Court of Chancery .
Parsing [sent. 12741 len. 28]: Mr. Vholes , who never gives hopes , lays his palm upon the client 's shoulder and answers with a smile , `` Always here , sir .
Parsing [sent. 12742 len. 23]: Personally , or by letter , you will always find me here , sir , with my shoulder to the wheel . ''
Parsing [sent. 12743 len. 35]: Thus they part , and Vholes , left alone , employs himself in carrying sundry little matters out of his diary into his draft bill book for the ultimate behoof of his three daughters .
Parsing [sent. 12744 len. 56]: So might an industrious fox or bear make up his account of chickens or stray travellers with an eye to his cubs , not to disparage by that word the three raw-visaged , lank , and buttoned-up maidens who dwell with the parent Vholes in an earthy cottage situated in a damp garden at Kennington .
Parsing [sent. 12745 len. 50]: Richard , emerging from the heavy shade of Symond 's Inn into the sunshine of Chancery Lane -- for there happens to be sunshine there to-day -- walks thoughtfully on , and turns into Lincoln 's Inn , and passes under the shadow of the Lincoln 's Inn trees .
Parsing [sent. 12746 len. 49]: On many such loungers have the speckled shadows of those trees often fallen ; on the like bent head , the bitten nail , the lowering eye , the lingering step , the purposeless and dreamy air , the good consuming and consumed , the life turned sour .
Parsing [sent. 12747 len. 12]: This lounger is not shabby yet , but that may come .
Parsing [sent. 12748 len. 27]: Chancery , which knows no wisdom but in precedent , is very rich in such precedents ; and why should one be different from ten thousand ?
Parsing [sent. 12749 len. 47]: Yet the time is so short since his depreciation began that as he saunters away , reluctant to leave the spot for some long months together , though he hates it , Richard himself may feel his own case as if it were a startling one .
Parsing [sent. 12750 len. 47]: While his heart is heavy with corroding care , suspense , distrust , and doubt , it may have room for some sorrowful wonder when he recalls how different his first visit there , how different he , how different all the colours of his mind .
Parsing [sent. 12751 len. 72]: But injustice breeds injustice ; the fighting with shadows and being defeated by them necessitates the setting up of substances to combat ; from the impalpable suit which no man alive can understand , the time for that being long gone by , it has become a gloomy relief to turn to the palpable figure of the friend who would have saved him from this ruin and make HIM his enemy .
Parsing [sent. 12752 len. 7]: Richard has told Vholes the truth .
Parsing [sent. 12753 len. 71]: Is he in a hardened or a softened mood , he still lays his injuries equally at that door ; he was thwarted , in that quarter , of a set purpose , and that purpose could only originate in the one subject that is resolving his existence into itself ; besides , it is a justification to him in his own eyes to have an embodied antagonist and oppressor .
Parsing [sent. 12754 len. 30]: Is Richard a monster in all this , or would Chancery be found rich in such precedents too if they could be got for citation from the Recording Angel ?

Parsing [sent. 12795 len. 81]: Regularly , every morning at eight , is the elder Mr. Smallweed brought down to the corner and carried in , accompanied by Mrs. Smallweed , Judy , and Bart ; and regularly , all day , do they all remain there until nine at night , solaced by gipsy dinners , not abundant in quantity , from the cook 's shop , rummaging and searching , digging , delving , and diving among the treasures of the late lamented .

Parsing [sent. 12897 len. 17]: Chapter XL -- National and Domestic England has been in a dreadful state for some weeks .
Parsing [sent. 12898 len. 37]: Lord Coodle would go out , Sir Thomas Doodle would n't come in , and there being nobody in Great Britain -LRB- to speak of -RRB- except Coodle and Doodle , there has been no government .
Parsing [sent. 12899 len. 74]: It is a mercy that the hostile meeting between those two great men , which at one time seemed inevitable , did not come off , because if both pistols had taken effect , and Coodle and Doodle had killed each other , it is to be presumed that England must have waited to be governed until young Coodle and young Doodle , now in frocks and long stockings , were grown up .
Parsing [sent. 12900 len. 103]: This stupendous national calamity , however , was averted by Lord Coodle 's making the timely discovery that if in the heat of debate he had said that he scorned and despised the whole ignoble career of Sir Thomas Doodle , he had merely meant to say that party differences should never induce him to withhold from it the tribute of his warmest admiration ; while it as opportunely turned out , on the other hand , that Sir Thomas Doodle had in his own bosom expressly booked Lord Coodle to go down to posterity as the mirror of virtue and honour .
Parsing [sent. 12901 len. 74]: Still England has been some weeks in the dismal strait of having no pilot -LRB- as was well observed by Sir Leicester Dedlock -RRB- to weather the storm ; and the marvellous part of the matter is that England has not appeared to care very much about it , but has gone on eating and drinking and marrying and giving in marriage as the old world did in the days before the flood .
Parsing [sent. 12902 len. 27]: But Coodle knew the danger , and Doodle knew the danger , and all their followers and hangers-on had the clearest possible perception of the danger .
Parsing [sent. 12903 len. 37]: At last Sir Thomas Doodle has not only condescended to come in , but has done it handsomely , bringing in with him all his nephews , all his male cousins , and all his brothers-in-law .
Parsing [sent. 12904 len. 10]: So there is hope for the old ship yet .
Parsing [sent. 12905 len. 21]: Doodle has found that he must throw himself upon the country , chiefly in the form of sovereigns and beer .
Parsing [sent. 12906 len. 28]: In this metamorphosed state he is available in a good many places simultaneously and can throw himself upon a considerable portion of the country at one time .
Parsing [sent. 12907 len. 69]: Britannia being much occupied in pocketing Doodle in the form of sovereigns , and swallowing Doodle in the form of beer , and in swearing herself black in the face that she does neither -- plainly to the advancement of her glory and morality -- the London season comes to a sudden end , through all the Doodleites and Coodleites dispersing to assist Britannia in those religious exercises .
Parsing [sent. 12908 len. 48]: Hence Mrs. Rouncewell , housekeeper at Chesney Wold , foresees , though no instructions have yet come down , that the family may shortly be expected , together with a pretty large accession of cousins and others who can in any way assist the great Constitutional work .
Parsing [sent. 12909 len. 79]: And hence the stately old dame , taking Time by the forelock , leads him up and down the staircases , and along the galleries and passages , and through the rooms , to witness before he grows any older that everything is ready , that floors are rubbed bright , carpets spread , curtains shaken out , beds puffed and patted , still-room and kitchen cleared for action -- all things prepared as beseems the Dedlock dignity .
Parsing [sent. 12910 len. 16]: This present summer evening , as the sun goes down , the preparations are complete .
Parsing [sent. 12911 len. 26]: Dreary and solemn the old house looks , with so many appliances of habitation and with no inhabitants except the pictured forms upon the walls .
Parsing [sent. 12912 len. 104]: So did these come and go , a Dedlock in possession might have ruminated passing along ; so did they see this gallery hushed and quiet , as I see it now ; so think , as I think , of the gap that they would make in this domain when they were gone ; so find it , as I find it , difficult to believe that it could be without them ; so pass from my world , as I pass from theirs , now closing the reverberating door ; so leave no blank to miss them , and so die .
Parsing [sent. 12913 len. 51]: Through some of the fiery windows beautiful from without , and set , at this sunset hour , not in dull-grey stone but in a glorious house of gold , the light excluded at other windows pours in rich , lavish , overflowing like the summer plenty in the land .

Parsing [sent. 12915 len. 14]: Strange movements come upon their features as the shadows of leaves play there .

Parsing [sent. 12918 len. 27]: Down into the bosom of a stony shepherdess there steals a fleck of light and warmth that would have done it good a hundred years ago .

Parsing [sent. 12921 len. 9]: But the fire of the sun is dying .
Parsing [sent. 12922 len. 23]: Even now the floor is dusky , and shadow slowly mounts the walls , bringing the Dedlocks down like age and death .
Parsing [sent. 12923 len. 53]: And now , upon my Lady 's picture over the great chimney-piece , a weird shade falls from some old tree , that turns it pale , and flutters it , and looks as if a great arm held a veil or hood , watching an opportunity to draw it over her .
Parsing [sent. 12924 len. 23]: Higher and darker rises shadow on the wall -- now a red gloom on the ceiling -- now the fire is out .
Parsing [sent. 12925 len. 42]: All that prospect , which from the terrace looked so near , has moved solemnly away and changed -- not the first nor the last of beautiful things that look so near and will so change -- into a distant phantom .
Parsing [sent. 12926 len. 23]: Light mists arise , and the dew falls , and all the sweet scents in the garden are heavv in the air .
Parsing [sent. 12927 len. 16]: Now the woods settle into great masses as if they were each one profound tree .
Parsing [sent. 12928 len. 38]: And now the moon rises to separate them , and to glimmer here and there in horizontal lines behind their stems , and to make the avenue a pavement of light among high cathedral arches fantastically broken .
Parsing [sent. 12929 len. 24]: Now the moon is high ; and the great house , needing habitation more than ever , is like a body without life .
Parsing [sent. 12930 len. 31]: Now it is even awful , stealing through it , to think of the live people who have slept in the solitary bedrooms , to say nothing of the dead .
Parsing [sent. 12931 len. 81]: Now is the time for shadow , when every corner is a cavern and every downward step a pit , when the stained glass is reflected in pale and faded hues upon the floors , when anything and everything can be made of the heavy staircase beams excepting their own proper shapes , when the armour has dull lights upon it not easily to be distinguished from stealthy movement , and when barred helmets are frightfully suggestive of heads inside .
Parsing [sent. 12932 len. 32]: But of all the shadows in Chesney Wold , the shadow in the long drawing-room upon my Lady 's picture is the first to come , the last to be disturbed .
Parsing [sent. 12933 len. 25]: At this hour and by this light it changes into threatening hands raised up and menacing the handsome face with every breath that stirs .
Parsing [sent. 12934 len. 18]: `` She is not well , ma'am , '' says a groom in Mrs. Rouncewell 's audience-chamber .
Parsing [sent. 12935 len. 6]: `` My Lady not well !
Parsing [sent. 12936 len. 6]: What 's the matter ? ''
Parsing [sent. 12937 len. 40]: `` Why , my Lady has been but poorly , ma'am , since she was last here -- I do n't mean with the family , ma'am , but when she was here as a bird of passage like .
Parsing [sent. 12938 len. 19]: My Lady has not been out much for her and has kept her room a good deal . ''
Parsing [sent. 12939 len. 21]: `` Chesney Wold , Thomas , '' rejoins the housekeeper with proud complacency , `` will set my Lady up !
Parsing [sent. 12940 len. 14]: There is no finer air and no healthier soil in the world ! ''
Parsing [sent. 12941 len. 54]: Thomas may have his own personal opinions on this subject , probably hints them in his manner of smoothing his sleek head from the nape of his neck to his temples , but he forbears to express them further and retires to the servants ' hall to regale on cold meat-pie and ale .
Parsing [sent. 12942 len. 10]: This groom is the pilot-fish before the nobler shark .
Parsing [sent. 12943 len. 30]: Next evening , down come Sir Leicester and my Lady with their largest retinue , and down come the cousins and others from all the points of the compass .
Parsing [sent. 12944 len. 54]: Thenceforth for some weeks backward and forward rush mysterious men with no names , who fly about all those particular parts of the country on which Doodle is at present throwing himself in an auriferous and malty shower , but who are merely persons of a restless disposition and never do anything anywhere .
Parsing [sent. 12945 len. 11]: On these national occasions Sir Leicester finds the cousins useful .
Parsing [sent. 12946 len. 21]: A better man than the Honourable Bob Stables to meet the Hunt at dinner , there could not possibly be .
Parsing [sent. 12947 len. 35]: Better got up gentlemen than the other cousins to ride over to polling-booths and hustings here and there , and show themselves on the side of England , it would be hard to find .
Parsing [sent. 12948 len. 64]: Volumnia is a little dim , but she is of the true descent ; and there are many who appreciate her sprightly conversation , her French conundrums so old as to have become in the cycles of time almost new again , the honour of taking the fair Dedlock in to dinner , or even the privilege of her hand in the dance .
Parsing [sent. 12949 len. 28]: On these national occasions dancing may be a patriotic service , and Volumnia is constantly seen hopping about for the good of an ungrateful and unpensioning country .
Parsing [sent. 12950 len. 25]: My Lady takes no great pains to entertain the numerous guests , and being still unwell , rarely appears until late in the day .
Parsing [sent. 12951 len. 25]: But at all the dismal dinners , leaden lunches , basilisk balls , and other melancholy pageants , her mere appearance is a relief .
Parsing [sent. 12952 len. 53]: As to Sir Leicester , he conceives it utterly impossible that anything can be wanting , in any direction , by any one who has the good fortune to be received under that roof ; and in a state of sublime satisfaction , he moves among the company , a magnificent refrigerator .
Parsing [sent. 12953 len. 50]: Daily the cousins trot through dust and canter over roadside turf , away to hustings and polling-booths -LRB- with leather gloves and hunting-whips for the counties and kid gloves and riding-canes for the boroughs -RRB- , and daily bring back reports on which Sir Leicester holds forth after dinner .
Parsing [sent. 12954 len. 18]: Daily the restless men who have no occupation in life present the appearance of being rather busy .
Parsing [sent. 12955 len. 38]: Daily Volumnia has a little cousinly talk with Sir Leicester on the state of the nation , from which Sir Leicester is disposed to conclude that Volumnia is a more reflecting woman than he had thought her .

Parsing [sent. 12957 len. 8]: says Miss Volumnia , clasping her hands .
