Parsing [sent. 13146 len. 37]: To say of a man so severely and strictly self-repressed that he is triumphant would be to do him as great an injustice as to suppose him troubled with love or sentiment or any romantic weakness .
Parsing [sent. 13147 len. 5]: He is sedately satisfied .
Parsing [sent. 13148 len. 36]: Perhaps there is a rather increased sense of power upon him as he loosely grasps one of his veinous wrists with his other hand and holding it behind his back walks noiselessly up and down .
Parsing [sent. 13149 len. 18]: There is a capacious writing-table in the room on which is a pretty large accumulation of papers .
Parsing [sent. 13150 len. 47]: The green lamp is lighted , his reading-glasses lie upon the desk , the easy-chair is wheeled up to it , and it would seem as though he had intended to bestow an hour or so upon these claims on his attention before going to bed .
Parsing [sent. 13151 len. 11]: But he happens not to be in a business mind .
Parsing [sent. 13152 len. 45]: After a glance at the documents awaiting his notice -- with his head bent low over the table , the old man 's sight for print or writing being defective at night -- he opens the French window and steps out upon the leads .
Parsing [sent. 13153 len. 35]: There he again walks slowly up and down in the same attitude , subsiding , if a man so cool may have any need to subside , from the story he has related downstairs .
Parsing [sent. 13154 len. 30]: The time was once when men as knowing as Mr. Tulkinghorn would walk on turret-tops in the starlight and look up into the sky to read their fortunes there .
Parsing [sent. 13155 len. 19]: Hosts of stars are visible to-night , though their brilliancy is eclipsed by the splendour of the moon .
Parsing [sent. 13156 len. 31]: If he be seeking his own star as he methodically turns and turns upon the leads , it should be but a pale one to be so rustily represented below .
Parsing [sent. 13157 len. 20]: If he be tracing out his destiny , that may be written in other characters nearer to his hand .
Parsing [sent. 13158 len. 39]: As he paces the leads with his eyes most probably as high above his thoughts as they are high above the earth , he is suddenly stopped in passing the window by two eyes that meet his own .
Parsing [sent. 13159 len. 27]: The ceiling of his room is rather low ; and the upper part of the door , which is opposite the window , is of glass .
Parsing [sent. 13160 len. 24]: There is an inner baize door , too , but the night being warm he did not close it when he came upstairs .
Parsing [sent. 13161 len. 17]: These eyes that meet his own are looking in through the glass from the corridor outside .
Parsing [sent. 13162 len. 5]: He knows them well .
Parsing [sent. 13163 len. 24]: The blood has not flushed into his face so suddenly and redly for many a long year as when he recognizes Lady Dedlock .
Parsing [sent. 13164 len. 19]: He steps into the room , and she comes in too , closing both the doors behind her .
Parsing [sent. 13165 len. 12]: There is a wild disturbance -- is it fear or anger ?
Parsing [sent. 13166 len. 5]: -- in her eyes .
Parsing [sent. 13167 len. 16]: In her carriage and all else she looks as she looked downstairs two hours ago .
Parsing [sent. 13168 len. 9]: Is it fear or is it anger now ?
Parsing [sent. 13169 len. 6]: He can not be sure .
Parsing [sent. 13170 len. 10]: Both might be as pale , both as intent .
Parsing [sent. 13171 len. 5]: `` Lady Dedlock ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13172 len. 21]: She does not speak at first , nor even when she has slowly dropped into the easy-chair by the table .
Parsing [sent. 13173 len. 10]: They look at each other , like two pictures .
Parsing [sent. 13174 len. 13]: `` Why have you told my story to so many persons ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13175 len. 18]: `` Lady Dedlock , it was necessary for me to inform you that I knew it . ''
Parsing [sent. 13176 len. 9]: `` How long have you known it ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13177 len. 17]: `` I have suspected it a long while -- fully known it a little while . ''
Parsing [sent. 13178 len. 4]: `` Months ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13179 len. 4]: `` Days . ''
Parsing [sent. 13180 len. 34]: He stands before her with one hand on a chair-back and the other in his old-fashioned waistcoat and shirt-frill , exactly as he has stood before her at any time since her marriage .
Parsing [sent. 13181 len. 37]: The same formal politeness , the same composed deference that might as well be defiance ; the whole man the same dark , cold object , at the same distance , which nothing has ever diminished .

Parsing [sent. 13183 len. 14]: He slightly inclines and advances his head as not quite understanding the question .

Parsing [sent. 13189 len. 2]: So !
Parsing [sent. 13190 len. 8]: Anger , and fear , and shame .
Parsing [sent. 13191 len. 4]: All three contending .
Parsing [sent. 13192 len. 12]: What power this woman has to keep these raging passions down !

Parsing [sent. 13194 len. 6]: `` No , Lady Dedlock .

Parsing [sent. 13316 len. 13]: Better for common sense , better for him , better for me .

Parsing [sent. 13318 len. 12]: She stands looking out at the same stars without a word .

Parsing [sent. 13351 len. 34]: Mr. Tulkinghorn opens both the doors exactly as he would have done yesterday , or as he would have done ten years ago , and makes his old-fashioned bow as she passes out .
Parsing [sent. 13352 len. 39]: It is not an ordinary look that he receives from the handsome face as it goes into the darkness , and it is not an ordinary movement , though a very slight one , that acknowledges his courtesy .
Parsing [sent. 13353 len. 21]: But as he reflects when he is left alone , the woman has been putting no common constraint upon herself .
Parsing [sent. 13354 len. 41]: He would know it all the better if he saw the woman pacing her own rooms with her hair wildly thrown from her flung-back face , her hands clasped behind her head , her figure twisted as if by pain .
Parsing [sent. 13355 len. 37]: He would think so all the more if he saw the woman thus hurrying up and down for hours , without fatigue , without intermission , followed by the faithful step upon the Ghost 's Walk .
Parsing [sent. 13356 len. 21]: But he shuts out the now chilled air , draws the window-curtain , goes to bed , and falls asleep .
Parsing [sent. 13357 len. 40]: And truly when the stars go out and the wan day peeps into the turret-chamber , finding him at his oldest , he looks as if the digger and the spade were both commissioned and would soon be digging .
Parsing [sent. 13358 len. 79]: The same wan day peeps in at Sir Leicester pardoning the repentant country in a majestically condescending dream ; and at the cousins entering on various public employments , principally receipt of salary ; and at the chaste Volumnia , bestowing a dower of fifty thousand pounds upon a hideous old general with a mouth of false teeth like a pianoforte too full of keys , long the admiration of Bath and the terror of every other commuuity .
Parsing [sent. 13359 len. 39]: Also into rooms high in the roof , and into offices in court-yards , and over stables , where humbler ambition dreams of bliss , in keepers ' lodges , and in holy matrimony with Will or Sally .
Parsing [sent. 13360 len. 71]: Up comes the bright sun , drawing everything up with it -- the Wills and Sallys , the latent vapour in the earth , the drooping leaves and flowers , the birds and beasts and creeping things , the gardeners to sweep the dewy turf and unfold emerald velvet where the roller passes , the smoke of the great kitchen fire wreathing itself straight and high into the lightsome air .
Parsing [sent. 13361 len. 36]: Lastly , up comes the flag over Mr. Tulkinghorn 's unconscious head cheerfully proclaiming that Sir Leicester and Lady Dedlock are in their happy home and that there is hospitality at the place in Lincolnshire .
Parsing [sent. 13362 len. 34]: Chapter XLII -- In Mr. Tulkinghorn 's Chambers From the verdant undulations and the spreading oaks of the Dedlock property , Mr. Tulkinghorn transfers himself to the stale heat and dust of London .
Parsing [sent. 13363 len. 16]: His manner of coming and going between the two places is one of his impenetrabilities .
Parsing [sent. 13364 len. 32]: He walks into Chesney Wold as if it were next door to his chambers and returns to his chambers as if he had never been out of Lincoln 's Inn Fields .
Parsing [sent. 13365 len. 14]: He neither changes his dress before the journey nor talks of it afterwards .
Parsing [sent. 13366 len. 25]: He melted out of his turret-room this morning , just as now , in the late twilight , he melts into his own square .
Parsing [sent. 13367 len. 88]: Like a dingy London bird among the birds at roost in these pleasant fields , where the sheep are all made into parchment , the goats into wigs , and the pasture into chaff , the lawyer , smoke-dried and faded , dwelling among mankind but not consorting with them , aged without experience of genial youth , and so long used to make his cramped nest in holes and corners of human nature that he has forgotten its broader and better range , comes sauntering home .
Parsing [sent. 13368 len. 35]: In the oven made by the hot pavements and hot buildings , he has baked himself dryer than usual ; and he has in his thirsty mind his mellowed port-wine half a century old .
Parsing [sent. 13369 len. 30]: The lamplighter is skipping up and down his ladder on Mr. Tulkinghorn 's side of the Fields when that high-priest of noble mysteries arrives at his own dull court-yard .
Parsing [sent. 13370 len. 27]: He ascends the door-steps and is gliding into the dusky hall when he encounters , on the top step , a bowing and propitiatory little man .
Parsing [sent. 13371 len. 6]: `` Is that Snagsby ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13372 len. 5]: `` Yes , sir .
Parsing [sent. 13373 len. 8]: I hope you are well , sir .
Parsing [sent. 13374 len. 14]: I was just giving you up , sir , and going home . ''
Parsing [sent. 13375 len. 3]: `` Aye ?
Parsing [sent. 13376 len. 4]: What is it ?
Parsing [sent. 13377 len. 8]: What do you want with me ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13378 len. 41]: `` Well , sir , '' says Mr. Snagsby , holding his hat at the side of his head in his deference towards his best customer , `` I was wishful to say a word to you , sir . ''
Parsing [sent. 13379 len. 8]: `` Can you say it here ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13380 len. 6]: `` Perfectly , sir . ''
Parsing [sent. 13381 len. 6]: `` Say it then . ''
Parsing [sent. 13382 len. 27]: The lawyer turns , leans his arms on the iron railing at the top of the steps , and looks at the lamplighter lighting the court-yard .
Parsing [sent. 13383 len. 37]: `` It is relating , '' says Mr. Snagsby in a mysterious low voice , `` it is relating -- not to put too fine a point upon it -- to the foreigner , sir ! ''
Parsing [sent. 13384 len. 8]: Mr. Tulkinghorn eyes him with some surprise .
Parsing [sent. 13385 len. 5]: `` What foreigner ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13386 len. 7]: `` The foreign female , sir .
Parsing [sent. 13387 len. 8]: French , if I do n't mistake ?
Parsing [sent. 13388 len. 28]: I am not acquainted with that language myself , but I should judge from her manners and appearance that she was French ; anyways , certainly foreign .
Parsing [sent. 13389 len. 26]: Her that was upstairs , sir , when Mr. Bucket and me had the honour of waiting upon you with the sweeping-boy that night . ''
Parsing [sent. 13390 len. 3]: `` Oh !
Parsing [sent. 13391 len. 4]: Yes , yes .
Parsing [sent. 13392 len. 4]: Mademoiselle Hortense . ''
Parsing [sent. 13393 len. 6]: `` Indeed , sir ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13394 len. 11]: Mr. Snagsby coughs his cough of submission behind his hat .
Parsing [sent. 13395 len. 25]: `` I am not acquainted myself with the names of foreigners in general , but I have no doubt it WOULD be that . ''
Parsing [sent. 13396 len. 28]: Mr. Snagsby appears to have set out in this reply with some desperate design of repeating the name , but on reflection coughs again to excuse himself .
Parsing [sent. 13397 len. 21]: `` And what can you have to say , Snagsby , '' demands Mr. Tulkinghorn , `` about her ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13398 len. 26]: `` Well , sir , '' returns the stationer , shading his communication with his hat , `` it falls a little hard upon me .
Parsing [sent. 13399 len. 33]: My domestic happiness is very great -- at least , it 's as great as can be expected , I 'm sure -- but my little woman is rather given to jealousy .
Parsing [sent. 13400 len. 18]: Not to put too fine a point upon it , she is very much given to jealousy .
Parsing [sent. 13401 len. 56]: And you see , a foreign female of that genteel appearance coming into the shop , and hovering -- I should be the last to make use of a strong expression if I could avoid it , but hovering , sir -- in the court -- you know it is -- now ai n't it ?
Parsing [sent. 13402 len. 9]: I only put it to yourself , sir .
Parsing [sent. 13403 len. 26]: Mr. Snagsby , having said this in a very plaintive manner , throws in a cough of general application to fill up all the blanks .
Parsing [sent. 13404 len. 9]: `` Why , what do you mean ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13405 len. 4]: asks Mr. Tulkinghorn .
Parsing [sent. 13406 len. 39]: `` Just so , sir , '' returns Mr. Snagsby ; `` I was sure you would feel it yourself and would excuse the reasonableness of MY feelings when coupled with the known excitableness of my little woman .
Parsing [sent. 13407 len. 49]: You see , the foreign female -- which you mentioned her name just now , with quite a native sound I am sure -- caught up the word Snagsby that night , being uncommon quick , and made inquiry , and got the direction and come at dinner-time .
Parsing [sent. 13408 len. 95]: Now Guster , our young woman , is timid and has fits , and she , taking fright at the foreigner 's looks -- which are fierce -- and at a grinding manner that she has of speaking -- which is calculated to alarm a weak mind -- gave way to it , instead of bearing up against it , and tumbled down the kitchen stairs out of one into another , such fits as I do sometimes think are never gone into , or come out of , in any house but ours .
Parsing [sent. 13409 len. 21]: Consequently there was by good fortune ample occupation for my little woman , and only me to answer the shop .
Parsing [sent. 13410 len. 54]: When she DID say that Mr. Tulkinghorn , being always denied to her by his employer -LRB- which I had no doubt at the time was a foreign mode of viewing a clerk -RRB- , she would do herself the pleasure of continually calling at my place until she was let in here .
Parsing [sent. 13411 len. 33]: Since then she has been , as I began by saying , hovering , hovering , sir '' -- Mr. Snagsby repeats the word with pathetic emphasis -- `` in the court .
Parsing [sent. 13412 len. 11]: The effects of which movement it is impossible to calculate .
Parsing [sent. 13413 len. 36]: I should n't wonder if it might have already given rise to the painfullest mistakes even in the neighbours ' minds , not mentioning -LRB- if such a thing was possible -RRB- my little woman .
Parsing [sent. 13414 len. 50]: Whereas , goodness knows , '' says Mr. Snagsby , shaking his head , `` I never had an idea of a foreign female , except as being formerly connected with a bunch of brooms and a baby , or at the present time with a tambourine and earrings .

Parsing [sent. 13567 len. 28]: Chapter XLIII -- Esther 's Narrative It matters little now how much I thought of my living mother who had told me evermore to consider her dead .
Parsing [sent. 13568 len. 39]: I could not venture to approach her or to communicate with her in writing , for my sense of the peril in which her life was passed was only to be equalled by my fears of increasing it .
Parsing [sent. 13569 len. 37]: Knowing that my mere existence as a living creature was an unforeseen danger in her way , I could not always conquer that terror of myself which had seized me when I first knew the secret .
Parsing [sent. 13570 len. 11]: At no time did I dare to utter her name .
Parsing [sent. 13571 len. 13]: I felt as if I did not even dare to hear it .
Parsing [sent. 13572 len. 43]: If the conversation anywhere , when I was present , took that direction , as it sometimes naturally did , I tried not to hear : I mentally counted , repeated something that I knew , or went out of the room .
Parsing [sent. 13573 len. 49]: I am conscious now that I often did these things when there can have been no danger of her being spoken of , but I did them in the dread I had of hearing anything that might lead to her betrayal , and to her betrayal through me .
Parsing [sent. 13574 len. 48]: It matters little now how often I recalled the tones of my mother 's voice , wondered whether I should ever hear it again as I so longed to do , and thought how strange and desolate it was that it should be so new to me .
Parsing [sent. 13575 len. 80]: It matters little that I watched for every public mention of my mother 's name ; that I passed and repassed the door of her house in town , loving it , but afraid to look at it ; that I once sat in the theatre when my mother was there and saw me , and when we were so wide asunder before the great company of all degrees that any link or confidence between us seemed a dream .
Parsing [sent. 13576 len. 7]: It is all , all over .
Parsing [sent. 13577 len. 25]: My lot has been so blest that I can relate little of myself which is not a story of goodness and generosity in others .
Parsing [sent. 13578 len. 10]: I may well pass that little and go on .
Parsing [sent. 13579 len. 24]: When we were settled at home again , Ada and I had many conversations with my guardian of which Richard was the theme .
Parsing [sent. 13580 len. 36]: My dear girl was deeply grieved that he should do their kind cousin so much wrong , but she was so faithful to Richard that she could not bear to blame him even for that .
Parsing [sent. 13581 len. 18]: My guardian was assured of it , and never coupled his name with a word of reproof .
Parsing [sent. 13582 len. 15]: `` Rick is mistaken , my dear , '' he would say to her .
Parsing [sent. 13583 len. 5]: `` Well , well !
Parsing [sent. 13584 len. 10]: We have all been mistaken over and over again .
Parsing [sent. 13585 len. 13]: We must trust to you and time to set him right . ''
Parsing [sent. 13586 len. 26]: We knew afterwards what we suspected then , that he did not trust to time until he had often tried to open Richard 's eyes .
Parsing [sent. 13587 len. 26]: That he had written to him , gone to him , talked with him , tried every gentle and persuasive art his kindness could devise .
Parsing [sent. 13588 len. 11]: Our poor devoted Richard was deaf and blind to all .
Parsing [sent. 13589 len. 16]: If he were wrong , he would make amends when the Chancery suit was over .
Parsing [sent. 13590 len. 31]: If he were groping in the dark , he could not do better than do his utmost to clear away those clouds in which so much was confused and obscured .
Parsing [sent. 13591 len. 10]: Suspicion and misunderstanding were the fault of the suit ?
Parsing [sent. 13592 len. 16]: Then let him work the suit out and come through it to his right mind .
Parsing [sent. 13593 len. 6]: This was his unvarying reply .
Parsing [sent. 13594 len. 46]: Jarndyce and Jarndyce had obtained such possession of his whole nature that it was impossible to place any consideration before him which he did not , with a distorted kind of reason , make a new argument in favour of his doing what he did .
Parsing [sent. 13595 len. 32]: `` So that it is even more mischievous , '' said my guardian once to me , `` to remonstrate with the poor dear fellow than to leave him alone . ''
Parsing [sent. 13596 len. 20]: I took one of these opportunities of mentioning my doubts of Mr. Skimpole as a good adviser for Richard .
Parsing [sent. 13597 len. 4]: `` Adviser ! ''
Parsing [sent. 13598 len. 17]: returned my guardian , laughing , `` My dear , who would advise with Skimpole ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13599 len. 17]: `` Encourager would perhaps have been a better word , '' said I. `` Encourager ! ''
Parsing [sent. 13600 len. 5]: returned my guardian again .
Parsing [sent. 13601 len. 9]: `` Who could be encouraged by Skimpole ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13602 len. 5]: `` Not Richard ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13603 len. 3]: I asked .
Parsing [sent. 13604 len. 7]: `` No , '' he replied .
Parsing [sent. 13605 len. 18]: `` Such an unworldly , uncalculating , gossamer creature is a relief to him and an amusement .
Parsing [sent. 13606 len. 32]: But as to advising or encouraging or occupying a serious station towards anybody or anything , it is simply not to be thought of in such a child as Skimpole . ''
Parsing [sent. 13607 len. 31]: `` Pray , cousin John , '' said Ada , who had just joined us and now looked over my shoulder , `` what made him such a child ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13608 len. 9]: `` What made him such a child ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13609 len. 14]: inquired my guardian , rubbing his head , a little at a loss .
Parsing [sent. 13610 len. 7]: `` Yes , cousin John . ''
Parsing [sent. 13611 len. 36]: `` Why , '' he slowly replied , roughening his head more and more , `` he is all sentiment , and -- and susceptibility , and -- and sensibility , and -- and imagination .
Parsing [sent. 13612 len. 11]: And these qualities are not regulated in him , somehow .
Parsing [sent. 13613 len. 40]: I suppose the people who admired him for them in his youth attached too much importance to them and too little to any training that would have balanced and adjusted them , and so he became what he is .
Parsing [sent. 13614 len. 3]: Hey ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13615 len. 12]: said my guardian , stopping short and looking at us hopefully .
Parsing [sent. 13616 len. 10]: `` What do you think , you two ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13617 len. 21]: Ada , glancing at me , said she thought it was a pity he should be an expense to Richard .
Parsing [sent. 13618 len. 15]: `` So it is , so it is , '' returned my guardian hurriedly .
Parsing [sent. 13619 len. 6]: `` That must not be .
Parsing [sent. 13620 len. 5]: We must arrange that .
Parsing [sent. 13621 len. 5]: I must prevent it .
Parsing [sent. 13622 len. 6]: That will never do . ''
Parsing [sent. 13623 len. 26]: And I said I thought it was to be regretted that he had ever introduced Richard to Mr. Vholes for a present of five pounds .
Parsing [sent. 13624 len. 5]: `` Did he ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13625 len. 13]: said my guardian with a passing shade of vexation on his face .
Parsing [sent. 13626 len. 8]: `` But there you have the man .
Parsing [sent. 13627 len. 6]: There you have the man !
Parsing [sent. 13628 len. 9]: There is nothing mercenary in that with him .
Parsing [sent. 13629 len. 10]: He has no idea of the value of money .
Parsing [sent. 13630 len. 20]: He introduces Rick , and then he is good friends with Mr. Vholes and borrows five pounds of him .
Parsing [sent. 13631 len. 11]: He means nothing by it and thinks nothing of it .
Parsing [sent. 13632 len. 14]: He told you himself , I 'll be bound , my dear ? ''
Parsing [sent. 13633 len. 6]: `` Oh , yes ! ''
Parsing [sent. 13634 len. 6]: said I. `` Exactly ! ''
Parsing [sent. 13635 len. 7]: cried my guardian , quite triumphant .
Parsing [sent. 13636 len. 7]: `` There you have the man !
Parsing [sent. 13637 len. 23]: If he had meant any harm by it or was conscious of any harm in it , he would n't tell it .
Parsing [sent. 13638 len. 11]: He tells it as he does it in mere simplicity .
Parsing [sent. 13639 len. 18]: But you shall see him in his own home , and then you 'll understand him better .

Parsing [sent. 14022 len. 59]: I began with my overshadowed childhood , and passed through those timid days to the heavy time when my aunt lay dead , with her resolute face so cold and set , and when I was more solitary with Mrs. Rachael than if I had had no one in the world to speak to or to look at .

Parsing [sent. 14025 len. 32]: I recalled the first bright gleam of welcome which had shone out of those very windows upon our expectant faces on that cold bright night , and which had never paled .
Parsing [sent. 14026 len. 54]: I lived my happy life there over again , I went through my illness and recovery , I thought of myself so altered and of those around me so unchanged ; and all this happiness shone like a light from one central figure , represented before me by the letter on the table .
Parsing [sent. 14027 len. 7]: I opened it and read it .
Parsing [sent. 14028 len. 44]: It was so impressive in its love for me , and in the unselfish caution it gave me , and the consideration it showed for me in every word , that my eyes were too often blinded to read much at a time .
Parsing [sent. 14029 len. 13]: But I read it through three times before I laid it down .
Parsing [sent. 14030 len. 14]: I had thought beforehand that I knew its purport , and I did .
Parsing [sent. 14031 len. 13]: It asked me , would I be the mistress of Bleak House .
Parsing [sent. 14032 len. 29]: It was not a love letter , though it expressed so much love , but was written just as he would at any time have spoken to me .
Parsing [sent. 14033 len. 23]: I saw his face , and heard his voice , and felt the influence of his kind protecting manner in every line .
Parsing [sent. 14034 len. 28]: It addressed me as if our places were reversed , as if all the good deeds had been mine and all the feelings they had awakened his .
Parsing [sent. 14035 len. 57]: It dwelt on my being young , and he past the prime of life ; on his having attained a ripe age , while I was a child ; on his writing to me with a silvered head , and knowing all this so well as to set it in full before me for mature deliberation .
Parsing [sent. 14036 len. 47]: It told me that I would gain nothing by such a marriage and lose nothing by rejecting it , for no new relation could enhance the tenderness in which he held me , and whatever my decision was , he was certain it would be right .
Parsing [sent. 14037 len. 45]: But he had considered this step anew since our late confidence and had decided on taking it , if it only served to show me through one poor instance that the whole world would readily unite to falsify the stern prediction of my childhood .
Parsing [sent. 14038 len. 45]: I was the last to know what happiness I could bestow upon him , but of that he said no more , for I was always to remember that I owed him nothing and that he was my debtor , and for very much .
Parsing [sent. 14039 len. 58]: He had often thought of our future , and foreseeing that the time must come , and fearing that it might come soon , when Ada -LRB- now very nearly of age -RRB- would leave us , and when our present mode of life must be broken up , had become accustomed to reflect on this proposal .
Parsing [sent. 14040 len. 5]: Thus he made it .
Parsing [sent. 14041 len. 80]: If I felt that I could ever give him the best right he could have to be my protector , and if I felt that I could happily and justly become the dear companion of his remaining life , superior to all lighter chances and changes than death , even then he could not have me bind myself irrevocably while this letter was yet so new to me , but even then I must have ample time for reconsideration .
Parsing [sent. 14042 len. 34]: In that case , or in the opposite case , let him be unchanged in his old relation , in his old manner , in the old name by which I called him .
Parsing [sent. 14043 len. 21]: And as to his bright Dame Durden and little housekeeper , she would ever be the same , he knew .
Parsing [sent. 14044 len. 42]: This was the substance of the letter , written throughout with a justice and a dignity as if he were indeed my responsible guardian impartially representing the proposal of a friend against whom in his integrity he stated the full case .
Parsing [sent. 14045 len. 29]: But he did not hint to me that when I had been better looking he had had this same proceeding in his thoughts and had refrained from it .
Parsing [sent. 14046 len. 29]: That when my old face was gone from me , and I had no attractions , he could love me just as well as in my fairer days .
Parsing [sent. 14047 len. 11]: That the discovery of my birth gave him no shock .
Parsing [sent. 14048 len. 13]: That his generosity rose above my disfigurement and my inheritance of shame .
Parsing [sent. 14049 len. 23]: That the more I stood in need of such fidelity , the more firmly I might trust in him to the last .
Parsing [sent. 14050 len. 11]: But I knew it , I knew it well now .
Parsing [sent. 14051 len. 28]: It came upon me as the close of the benignant history I had been pursuing , and I felt that I had but one thing to do .
Parsing [sent. 14052 len. 30]: To devote my life to his happiness was to thank him poorly , and what had I wished for the other night but some new means of thanking him ?
Parsing [sent. 14053 len. 58]: Still I cried very much , not only in the fullness of my heart after reading the letter , not only in the strangeness of the prospect -- for it was strange though I had expected the contents -- but as if something for which there was no name or distinct idea were indefinitely lost to me .
Parsing [sent. 14054 len. 17]: I was very happy , very thankful , very hopeful ; but I cried very much .
Parsing [sent. 14055 len. 10]: By and by I went to my old glass .

Parsing [sent. 14057 len. 30]: I am afraid the face in the glass was going to cry again at this reproach , but I held up my finger at it , and it stopped .
Parsing [sent. 14058 len. 25]: `` That is more like the composed look you comforted me with , my dear , when you showed me such a change ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14059 len. 10]: said I , beginning to let down my hair .
Parsing [sent. 14060 len. 19]: `` When you are mistress of Bleak House , you are to be as cheerful as a bird .
Parsing [sent. 14061 len. 21]: In fact , you are always to be cheerful ; so let us begin for once and for all . ''
Parsing [sent. 14062 len. 11]: I went on with my hair now , quite comfortably .

Parsing [sent. 14064 len. 14]: `` And so Esther , my dear , you are happy for life .

Parsing [sent. 14066 len. 29]: I thought , all at once , if my guardian had married some one else , how should I have felt , and what should I have done !
Parsing [sent. 14067 len. 8]: That would have been a change indeed .
Parsing [sent. 14068 len. 32]: It presented my life in such a new and blank form that I rang my housekeeping keys and gave them a kiss before I laid them down in their basket again .
Parsing [sent. 14069 len. 63]: Then I went on to think , as I dressed my hair before the glass , how often had I considered within myself that the deep traces of my illness and the circumstances of my birth were only new reasons why I should be busy , busy , busy -- useful , amiable , serviceable , in all honest , unpretending ways .
Parsing [sent. 14070 len. 17]: This was a good time , to be sure , to sit down morbidly and cry !

Parsing [sent. 14075 len. 10]: It would be better not to keep them now .

Parsing [sent. 14077 len. 26]: They were in a book , and it happened to be in the next room -- our sitting-room , dividing Ada 's chamber from mine .
Parsing [sent. 14078 len. 15]: I took a candle and went softly in to fetch it from its shelf .
Parsing [sent. 14079 len. 30]: After I had it in my hand , I saw my beautiful darling , through the open door , lying asleep , and I stole in to kiss her .
Parsing [sent. 14080 len. 34]: It was weak in me , I know , and I could have no reason for crying ; but I dropped a tear upon her dear face , and another , and another .
Parsing [sent. 14081 len. 20]: Weaker than that , I took the withered flowers out and put them for a moment to her lips .

Parsing [sent. 14415 len. 6]: Chapter XLVI -- Stop Him !
Parsing [sent. 14416 len. 10]: Darkness rests upon Tom -- All -- Alone 's .
Parsing [sent. 14417 len. 24]: Dilating and dilating since the sun went down last night , it has gradually swelled until it fills every void in the place .
Parsing [sent. 14418 len. 52]: For a time there were some dungeon lights burning , as the lamp of life hums in Tom-all -- Alone 's , heavily , heavily , in the nauseous air , and winking -- as that lamp , too , winks in Tom-all -- Alone 's -- at many horrible things .
Parsing [sent. 14419 len. 6]: But they are blotted out .
Parsing [sent. 14420 len. 40]: The moon has eyed Tom with a dull cold stare , as admitting some puny emulation of herself in his desert region unfit for life and blasted by volcanic fires ; but she has passed on and is gone .
Parsing [sent. 14421 len. 20]: The blackest nightmare in the infernal stables grazes on Tom-all -- Alone 's , and Tom is fast asleep .
Parsing [sent. 14422 len. 28]: Much mighty speech-making there has been , both in and out of Parliament , concerning Tom , and much wrathful disputation how Tom shall be got right .
Parsing [sent. 14423 len. 76]: Whether he shall be put into the main road by constables , or by beadles , or by bell-ringing , or by force of figures , or by correct principles of taste , or by high church , or by low church , or by no church ; whether he shall be set to splitting trusses of polemical straws with the crooked knife of his mind or whether he shall be put to stone-breaking instead .
Parsing [sent. 14424 len. 43]: In the midst of which dust and noise there is but one thing perfectly clear , to wit , that Tom only may and can , or shall and will , be reclaimed according to somebody 's theory but nobody 's practice .
Parsing [sent. 14425 len. 18]: And in the hopeful meantime , Tom goes to perdition head foremost in his old determined spirit .
Parsing [sent. 14426 len. 6]: But he has his revenge .
Parsing [sent. 14427 len. 17]: Even the winds are his messengers , and they serve him in these hours of darkness .
Parsing [sent. 14428 len. 17]: There is not a drop of Tom 's corrupted blood but propagates infection and contagion somewhere .
Parsing [sent. 14429 len. 43]: It shall pollute , this very night , the choice stream -LRB- in which chemists on analysis would find the genuine nobility -RRB- of a Norman house , and his Grace shall not be able to say nay to the infamous alliance .
Parsing [sent. 14430 len. 71]: There is not an atom of Tom 's slime , not a cubic inch of any pestilential gas in which he lives , not one obscenity or degradation about him , not an ignorance , not a wickedness , not a brutality of his committing , but shall work its retribution through every order of society up to the proudest of the proud and to the highest of the high .
Parsing [sent. 14431 len. 16]: Verily , what with tainting , plundering , and spoiling , Tom has his revenge .
Parsing [sent. 14432 len. 64]: It is a moot point whether Tom-all -- Alone 's be uglier by day or by night , but on the argument that the more that is seen of it the more shocking it must be , and that no part of it left to the imagination is at all likely to be made so bad as the reality , day carries it .
Parsing [sent. 14433 len. 43]: The day begins to break now ; and in truth it might be better for the national glory even that the sun should sometimes set upon the British dominions than that it should ever rise upon so vile a wonder as Tom .
Parsing [sent. 14434 len. 33]: A brown sunburnt gentleman , who appears in some inaptitude for sleep to be wandering abroad rather than counting the hours on a restless pillow , strolls hitherward at this quiet time .
Parsing [sent. 14435 len. 19]: Attracted by curiosity , he often pauses and looks about him , up and down the miserable by-ways .

Parsing [sent. 14517 len. 8]: cries the woman , almost breath less .
Parsing [sent. 14518 len. 7]: `` Stop him , sir ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14519 len. 42]: He darts across the road into the boy 's path , but the boy is quicker than he , makes a curve , ducks , dives under his hands , comes up half-a-dozen yards beyond him , and scours away again .
Parsing [sent. 14520 len. 18]: Still the woman follows , crying , `` Stop him , sir , pray stop him ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14521 len. 51]: Allan , not knowing but that he has just robbed her of her money , follows in chase and runs so hard that he runs the boy down a dozen times , but each time he repeats the curve , the duck , the dive , and scours away again .
Parsing [sent. 14522 len. 35]: To strike at him on any of these occasions would be to fell and disable him , but the pursuer can not resolve to do that , and so the grimly ridiculous pursuit continues .
Parsing [sent. 14523 len. 20]: At last the fugitive , hard-pressed , takes to a narrow passage and a court which has no thoroughfare .
Parsing [sent. 14524 len. 36]: Here , against a hoarding of decaying timber , he is brought to bay and tumbles down , lying gasping at his pursuer , who stands and gasps at him until the woman comes up .

Parsing [sent. 14531 len. 4]: To be sure !
Parsing [sent. 14532 len. 14]: I recollect this lad some time ago being brought before the coroner . ''
Parsing [sent. 14533 len. 16]: `` Yes , I see you once afore at the inkwhich , '' whimpers Jo .

Parsing [sent. 14536 len. 9]: A n't I unfortnet enough for you yet ?
Parsing [sent. 14537 len. 10]: How unfortnet do you want me fur to be ?
Parsing [sent. 14538 len. 28]: I 've been a-chivied and a-chivied , fust by one on you and nixt by another on you , till I 'm worritted to skins and bones .
Parsing [sent. 14539 len. 7]: The inkwhich war n't MY fault .
Parsing [sent. 14540 len. 4]: I done nothink .
Parsing [sent. 14541 len. 28]: He wos wery good to me , he wos ; he wos the only one I knowed to speak to , as ever come across my crossing .

Parsing [sent. 14543 len. 8]: I only wish I wos , myself .
Parsing [sent. 14544 len. 25]: I do n't know why I do n't go and make a hole in the water , I 'm sure I do n't . ''
Parsing [sent. 14545 len. 52]: He says it with such a pitiable air , and his grimy tears appear so real , and he lies in the corner up against the hoarding so like a growth of fungus or any unwholesome excrescence produced there in neglect and impurity , that Allan Woodcourt is softened towards him .
Parsing [sent. 14546 len. 16]: He says to the woman , `` Miserable creature , what has he done ? ''

Parsing [sent. 14548 len. 8]: I have found you at last ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14549 len. 7]: `` What has he done ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14550 len. 3]: says Allan .
Parsing [sent. 14551 len. 7]: `` Has he robbed you ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14552 len. 7]: `` No , sir , no .
Parsing [sent. 14553 len. 3]: Robbed me ?
Parsing [sent. 14554 len. 19]: He did nothing but what was kind-hearted by me , and that 's the wonder of it . ''
Parsing [sent. 14555 len. 25]: Allan looks from Jo to the woman , and from the woman to Jo , waiting for one of them to unravel the riddle .
Parsing [sent. 14556 len. 15]: `` But he was along with me , sir , '' says the woman .
Parsing [sent. 14557 len. 6]: `` Oh , you Jo !
Parsing [sent. 14558 len. 55]: He was along with me , sir , down at Saint Albans , ill , and a young lady , Lord bless her for a good friend to me , took pity on him when I durst n't , and took him home -- '' Allan shrinks back from him with a sudden horror .
Parsing [sent. 14559 len. 7]: `` Yes , sir , yes .
Parsing [sent. 14560 len. 38]: Took him home , and made him comfortable , and like a thankless monster he ran away in the night and never has been seen or heard of since till I set eyes on him just now .
Parsing [sent. 14561 len. 50]: And that young lady that was such a pretty dear caught his illness , lost her beautiful looks , and would n't hardly be known for the same young lady now if it was n't for her angel temper , and her pretty shape , and her sweet voice .
Parsing [sent. 14562 len. 5]: Do you know it ?
Parsing [sent. 14563 len. 22]: You ungrateful wretch , do you know that this is all along of you and of her goodness to you ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14564 len. 19]: demands the woman , beginning to rage at him as she recalls it and breaking into passionate tears .
Parsing [sent. 14565 len. 47]: The boy , in rough sort stunned by what he hears , falls to smearing his dirty forehead with his dirty palm , and to staring at the ground , and to shaking from head to foot until the crazy hoarding against which he leans rattles .
Parsing [sent. 14566 len. 14]: Allan restrains the woman , merely by a quiet gesture , but effectually .
Parsing [sent. 14567 len. 9]: `` Richard told me -- '' He falters .
Parsing [sent. 14568 len. 24]: `` I mean , I have heard of this -- do n't mind me for a moment , I will speak presently . ''
Parsing [sent. 14569 len. 15]: He turns away and stands for a while looking out at the covered passage .
Parsing [sent. 14570 len. 35]: When he comes back , he has recovered his composure , except that he contends against an avoidance of the boy , which is so very remarkable that it absorbs the woman 's attention .
Parsing [sent. 14571 len. 7]: `` You hear what she says .
Parsing [sent. 14572 len. 8]: But get up , get up ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14573 len. 51]: Jo , shaking and chattering , slowly rises and stands , after the manner of his tribe in a difficulty , sideways against the hoarding , resting one of his high shoulders against it and covertly rubbing his right hand over his left and his left foot over his right .
Parsing [sent. 14574 len. 14]: `` You hear what she says , and I know it 's true .
Parsing [sent. 14575 len. 8]: Have you been here ever since ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14576 len. 19]: `` Wishermaydie if I seen Tom-all -- Alone 's till this blessed morning , '' replies Jo hoarsely .
Parsing [sent. 14577 len. 9]: `` Why have you come here now ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14578 len. 41]: Jo looks all round the confined court , looks at his questioner no higher than the knees , and finally answers , `` I do n't know how to do nothink , and I ca n't get nothink to do .
Parsing [sent. 14579 len. 47]: I 'm wery poor and ill , and I thought I 'd come back here when there war n't nobody about , and lay down and hide somewheres as I knows on till arter dark , and then go and beg a trifle of Mr. Snagsby .
Parsing [sent. 14580 len. 27]: He wos allus willin fur to give me somethink he wos , though Mrs. Snagsby she was allus a-chivying on me -- like everybody everywheres . ''
Parsing [sent. 14581 len. 8]: `` Where have you come from ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14582 len. 31]: Jo looks all round the court again , looks at his questioner 's knees again , and concludes by laying his profile against the hoarding in a sort of resignation .
Parsing [sent. 14583 len. 14]: `` Did you hear me ask you where you have come from ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14584 len. 8]: `` Tramp then , '' says Jo .
Parsing [sent. 14585 len. 65]: `` Now tell me , '' proceeds Allan , making a strong effort to overcome his repugnance , going very near to him , and leaning over him with an expression of confidence , `` tell me how it came about that you left that house when the good young lady had been so unfortunate as to pity you and take you home . ''
Parsing [sent. 14586 len. 79]: Jo suddenly comes out of his resignation and excitedly declares , addressing the woman , that he never known about the young lady , that he never heern about it , that he never went fur to hurt her , that he would sooner have hurt his own self , that he 'd sooner have had his unfortnet ed chopped off than ever gone a-nigh her , and that she wos wery good to him , she wos .
Parsing [sent. 14587 len. 23]: Conducting himself throughout as if in his poor fashion he really meant it , and winding up with some very miserable sobs .
Parsing [sent. 14588 len. 10]: Allan Woodcourt sees that this is not a sham .
Parsing [sent. 14589 len. 7]: He constrains himself to touch him .
Parsing [sent. 14590 len. 5]: `` Come , Jo .
Parsing [sent. 14591 len. 4]: Tell me . ''
Parsing [sent. 14592 len. 3]: `` No .
Parsing [sent. 14593 len. 14]: I dust n't , '' says Jo , relapsing into the profile state .
Parsing [sent. 14594 len. 10]: `` I dust n't , or I would . ''
Parsing [sent. 14595 len. 16]: `` But I must know , '' returns the other , `` all the same .
Parsing [sent. 14596 len. 5]: Come , Jo . ''
Parsing [sent. 14597 len. 36]: After two or three such adjurations , Jo lifts up his head again , looks round the court again , and says in a low voice , `` Well , I 'll tell you something .
Parsing [sent. 14598 len. 5]: I was took away .
Parsing [sent. 14599 len. 3]: There ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14600 len. 4]: `` Took away ?
Parsing [sent. 14601 len. 5]: In the night ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14602 len. 4]: `` Ah ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14603 len. 46]: Very apprehensive of being overheard , Jo looks about him and even glances up some ten feet at the top of the hoarding and through the cracks in it lest the object of his distrust should be looking over or hidden on the other side .
Parsing [sent. 14604 len. 7]: `` Who took you away ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14605 len. 11]: `` I dust n't name him , '' says Jo .
Parsing [sent. 14606 len. 9]: `` I dust n't do it , sir .
Parsing [sent. 14607 len. 15]: `` But I want , in the young lady 's name , to know .
Parsing [sent. 14608 len. 5]: You may trust me .
Parsing [sent. 14609 len. 7]: No one else shall hear . ''
Parsing [sent. 14610 len. 26]: `` Ah , but I do n't know , '' replies Jo , shaking his head fearfulty , `` as he DO N'T hear . ''
Parsing [sent. 14611 len. 11]: `` Why , he is not in this place . ''
Parsing [sent. 14612 len. 9]: `` Oh , ai n't he though ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14613 len. 3]: says Jo .
Parsing [sent. 14614 len. 14]: `` He 's in all manner of places , all at wanst . ''
Parsing [sent. 14615 len. 23]: Allan looks at him in perplexity , but discovers some real meaning and good faith at the bottom of this bewildering reply .
Parsing [sent. 14616 len. 30]: He patiently awaits an explicit answer ; and Jo , more baffled by his patience than by anything else , at last desperately whispers a name in his ear .
Parsing [sent. 14617 len. 4]: `` Aye ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14618 len. 3]: says Allan .
Parsing [sent. 14619 len. 10]: `` Why , what had you been doing ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14620 len. 5]: `` Nothink , sir .
Parsing [sent. 14621 len. 20]: Never done nothink to get myself into no trouble , ` sept in not moving on and the inkwhich .
Parsing [sent. 14622 len. 7]: But I 'm a-moving on now .
Parsing [sent. 14623 len. 20]: I 'm a-moving on to the berryin ground -- that 's the move as I 'm up to . ''
Parsing [sent. 14624 len. 12]: `` No , no , we will try to prevent that .
Parsing [sent. 14625 len. 9]: But what did he do with you ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14626 len. 41]: `` Put me in a horsepittle , '' replied Jo , whispering , `` till I was discharged , then giv me a little money -- four half-bulls , wot you may call half-crowns -- and ses ` Hook it !
Parsing [sent. 14627 len. 9]: Nobody wants you here , ' he ses .
Parsing [sent. 14628 len. 5]: ` You hook it .
Parsing [sent. 14629 len. 9]: You go and tramp , ' he ses .
Parsing [sent. 14630 len. 9]: ` You move on , ' he ses .
Parsing [sent. 14631 len. 22]: ` Do n't let me ever see you nowheres within forty mile of London , or you 'll repent it . '
Parsing [sent. 14632 len. 35]: So I shall , if ever he doos see me , and he 'll see me if I 'm above ground , '' concludes Jo , nervously repeating all his former precautions and investigations .
Parsing [sent. 14633 len. 30]: Allan considers a little , then remarks , turning to the woman but keeping an encouraging eye on Jo , `` He is not so ungrateful as you supposed .
Parsing [sent. 14634 len. 16]: He had a reason for going away , though it was an insufficient one . ''
Parsing [sent. 14635 len. 8]: `` Thankee , sir , thankee ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14636 len. 3]: exclaims Jo .
Parsing [sent. 14637 len. 4]: `` There now !
Parsing [sent. 14638 len. 8]: See how hard you wos upon me .
Parsing [sent. 14639 len. 18]: But ony you tell the young lady wot the genlmn ses , and it 's all right .
Parsing [sent. 14640 len. 15]: For YOU wos wery good to me too , and I knows it . ''
Parsing [sent. 14641 len. 36]: `` Now , Jo , '' says Allan , keeping his eye upon him , `` come with me and I will find you a better place than this to lie down and hide in .
Parsing [sent. 14642 len. 35]: If I take one side of the way and you the other to avoid observation , you will not run away , I know very well , if you make me a promise . ''
Parsing [sent. 14643 len. 17]: `` I wo n't , not unless I wos to see HIM a-coming , sir . ''
Parsing [sent. 14644 len. 4]: `` Very well .
Parsing [sent. 14645 len. 5]: I take your word .
Parsing [sent. 14646 len. 22]: Half the town is getting up by this time , and the whole town will be broad awake in another hour .
Parsing [sent. 14647 len. 3]: Come along .
Parsing [sent. 14648 len. 9]: Good day again , my good woman . ''
Parsing [sent. 14649 len. 17]: `` Good day again , sir , and I thank you kindly many times again . ''
Parsing [sent. 14650 len. 19]: She has been sitting on her bag , deeply attentive , and now rises and takes it up .
Parsing [sent. 14651 len. 26]: Jo , repeating , `` Ony you tell the young lady as I never went fur to hurt her and wot the genlmn ses ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14652 len. 45]: nods and shambles and shivers , and smears and blinks , and half laughs and half cries , a farewell to her , and takes his creeping way along after Allan Woodcourt , close to the houses on the opposite side of the street .
Parsing [sent. 14653 len. 26]: In this order , the two come up out of Tom-all -- Alone 's into the broad rays of the sunlight and the purer air .
Parsing [sent. 14654 len. 55]: Chapter XLVII -- Jo 's Will As Allan Woodcourt and Jo proceed along the streets where the high church spires and the distances are so near and clear in the morning light that the city itself seems renewed by rest , Allan revolves in his mind how and where he shall bestow his companion .
Parsing [sent. 14655 len. 39]: `` It surely is a strange fact , '' he considers , `` that in the heart of a civilized world this creature in human form should be more difficult to dispose of than an unowned dog . ''
Parsing [sent. 14656 len. 18]: But it is none the less a fact because of its strangeness , and the difficulty remains .
Parsing [sent. 14657 len. 17]: At first he looks behind him often to assure himself that Jo is still really following .
Parsing [sent. 14658 len. 47]: But look where he will , he still beholds him close to the opposite houses , making his way with his wary hand from brick to brick and from door to door , and often , as he creeps along , glancing over at him watchfully .
Parsing [sent. 14659 len. 31]: Soon satisfied that the last thing in his thoughts is to give him the slip , Allan goes on , considering with a less divided attention what he shall do .
Parsing [sent. 14660 len. 13]: A breakfast-stall at a street-corner suggests the first thing to be done .
Parsing [sent. 14661 len. 11]: He stops there , looks round , and beckons Jo .
Parsing [sent. 14662 len. 37]: Jo crosses and comes halting and shuffling up , slowly scooping the knuckles of his right hand round and round in the hollowed palm of his left , kneading dirt with a natural pestle and mortar .
Parsing [sent. 14663 len. 46]: What is a dainty repast to Jo is then set before him , and he begins to gulp the coffee and to gnaw the bread and butter , looking anxiously about him in all directions as he eats and drinks , like a scared animal .
Parsing [sent. 14664 len. 14]: But he is so sick and miserable that even hunger has abandoned him .
Parsing [sent. 14665 len. 32]: `` I thought I was amost a-starvin , sir , '' says Jo , soon putting down his food , `` but I do n't know nothink -- not even that .
Parsing [sent. 14666 len. 15]: I do n't care for eating wittles nor yet for drinking on 'em . ''
Parsing [sent. 14667 len. 11]: And Jo stands shivering and looking at the breakfast wonderingly .
Parsing [sent. 14668 len. 13]: Allan Woodcourt lays his hand upon his pulse and on his chest .
Parsing [sent. 14669 len. 7]: `` Draw breath , Jo ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14670 len. 16]: `` It draws , '' says Jo , `` as heavy as a cart . ''
Parsing [sent. 14671 len. 27]: He might add , `` And rattles like it , '' but he only mutters , `` I 'm a -- moving on , sir . ''
Parsing [sent. 14672 len. 9]: Allan looks about for an apothecary 's shop .
Parsing [sent. 14673 len. 15]: There is none at hand , but a tavern does as well or better .
Parsing [sent. 14674 len. 18]: He obtains a little measure of wine and gives the lad a portion of it very carefully .
Parsing [sent. 14675 len. 13]: He begins to revive almost as soon as it passes his lips .
Parsing [sent. 14676 len. 20]: `` We may repeat that dose , Jo , '' observes Allan after watching him with his attentive face .
Parsing [sent. 14677 len. 3]: `` So !
Parsing [sent. 14678 len. 16]: Now we will take five minutes ' rest , and then go on again . ''
Parsing [sent. 14679 len. 42]: Leaving the boy sitting on the bench of the breakfast-stall , with his back against an iron railing , Allan Woodcourt paces up and down in the early sunshine , casting an occasional look towards him without appearing to watch him .
Parsing [sent. 14680 len. 13]: It requires no discernment to perceive that he is warmed and refreshed .
Parsing [sent. 14681 len. 31]: If a face so shaded can brighten , his face brightens somewhat ; and by little and little he eats the slice of bread he had so hopelessly laid down .
Parsing [sent. 14682 len. 33]: Observant of these signs of improvement , Allan engages him in conversation and elicits to his no small wonder the adventure of the lady in the veil , with all its consequences .
Parsing [sent. 14683 len. 9]: Jo slowly munches as he slowly tells it .
Parsing [sent. 14684 len. 15]: When he has finished his story and his bread , they go on again .
Parsing [sent. 14685 len. 39]: Intending to refer his difficulty in finding a temporary place of refuge for the boy to his old patient , zealous little Miss Flite , Allan leads the way to the court where he and Jo first foregathered .
Parsing [sent. 14686 len. 58]: But all is changed at the rag and bottle shop ; Miss Flite no longer lodges there ; it is shut up ; and a hard-featured female , much obscured by dust , whose age is a problem , but who is indeed no other than the interesting Judy , is tart and spare in her replies .
Parsing [sent. 14687 len. 70]: These sufficing , however , to inform the visitor that Miss Flite and her birds are domiciled with a Mrs. Blinder , in Bell Yard , he repairs to that neighbouring place , where Miss Flite -LRB- who rises early that she may be punctual at the divan of justice held by her excellent friend the Chancellor -RRB- comes running downstairs with tears of welcome and with open arms .
Parsing [sent. 14688 len. 6]: `` My dear physician ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14689 len. 4]: cries Miss Flite .
Parsing [sent. 14690 len. 10]: `` My meritorious , distinguished , honourable officer ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14691 len. 27]: She uses some odd expressions , but is as cordial and full of heart as sanity itself can be -- more so than it often is .
Parsing [sent. 14692 len. 35]: Allan , very patient with her , waits until she has no more raptures to express , then points out Jo , trembling in a doorway , and tells her how he comes there .
Parsing [sent. 14693 len. 11]: `` Where can I lodge him hereabouts for the present ?
Parsing [sent. 14694 len. 16]: Now , you have a fund of knowledge and good sense and can advise me .
Parsing [sent. 14695 len. 26]: Miss Flite , mighty proud of the compliment , sets herself to consider ; but it is long before a bright thought occurs to her .
Parsing [sent. 14696 len. 15]: Mrs. Blinder is entirely let , and she herself occupies poor Gridley 's room .
Parsing [sent. 14697 len. 4]: `` Gridley ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14698 len. 15]: exclaims Miss Flite , clapping her hands after a twentieth repetition of this remark .
Parsing [sent. 14699 len. 3]: `` Gridley !
Parsing [sent. 14700 len. 4]: To be sure !
Parsing [sent. 14701 len. 3]: Of course !
Parsing [sent. 14702 len. 4]: My dear physician !
Parsing [sent. 14703 len. 8]: General George will help us out . ''
Parsing [sent. 14704 len. 45]: It is hopeless to ask for any information about General George , and would be , though Miss Flite had not akeady run upstairs to put on her pinched bonnet and her poor little shawl and to arm herself with her reticule of documents .
Parsing [sent. 14705 len. 56]: But as she informs her physician in her disjointed manner on coming down in full array that General George , whom she often calls upon , knows her dear Fitz Jarndyce and takes a great interest in all connected with her , Allan is induced to think that they may be in the right way .
Parsing [sent. 14706 len. 27]: So he tells Jo , for his encouragement , that this walking about will soon be over now ; and they repair to the general 's .
Parsing [sent. 14707 len. 6]: Fortunately it is not far .
Parsing [sent. 14708 len. 26]: From the exterior of George 's Shooting Gallery , and the long entry , and the bare perspective beyond it , Allan Woodcourt augurs well .
Parsing [sent. 14709 len. 49]: He also descries promise in the figure of Mr. George himself , striding towards them in his mornmg exercise with his pipe in his mouth , no stock on , and his muscular arms , developed by broadsword and dumbbell , weightily asserting themselves through his light shirt-sleeves .
Parsing [sent. 14710 len. 15]: `` Your servant , sir , '' says Mr. George with a military salute .
Parsing [sent. 14711 len. 39]: Good-humouredly smiling all over his broad forehead up into his crisp hair , he then defers to Miss Flite , as , with great stateliness , and at some length , she performs the courtly ceremony of presentation .
Parsing [sent. 14712 len. 13]: He winds it up with another `` Your servant , sir ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14713 len. 4]: and another salute .
Parsing [sent. 14714 len. 6]: `` Excuse me , sir .
Parsing [sent. 14715 len. 7]: A sailor , I believe ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14716 len. 4]: says Mr. George .
Parsing [sent. 14717 len. 27]: `` I am proud to find I have the air of one , '' returns Allan ; `` but I am only a sea-going doctor . ''
Parsing [sent. 14718 len. 5]: `` Indeed , sir !
Parsing [sent. 14719 len. 12]: I should have thought you was a regular blue-jacket myself . ''
Parsing [sent. 14720 len. 40]: Allan hopes Mr. George will forgive his intrusion the more readily on that account , and particularly that he will not lay aside his pipe , which , in his politeness , he has testifled some intention of doing .
Parsing [sent. 14721 len. 13]: `` You are very good , sir , '' returns the trooper .
Parsing [sent. 14722 len. 37]: `` As I know by experience that it 's not disagreeable to Miss Flite , and since it 's equally agreeable to yourself -- '' and finishes the sentence by putting it between his lips again .
Parsing [sent. 14723 len. 21]: Allan proceeds to tell him all he knows about Jo , unto which the trooper listens with a grave face .
Parsing [sent. 14724 len. 13]: `` And that 's the lad , sir , is it ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14725 len. 30]: he inquires , looking along the entry to where Jo stands staring up at the great letters on the whitewashed front , which have no meaning in his eyes .
Parsing [sent. 14726 len. 9]: `` That 's he , '' says Allan .
Parsing [sent. 14727 len. 14]: `` And , Mr. George , I am in this difficulty about him .
Parsing [sent. 14728 len. 40]: I am unwilling to place him in a hospital , even if I could procure him immediate admission , because I foresee that he would not stay there many hours if he could be so much as got there .
Parsing [sent. 14729 len. 47]: The same objection applies to a workhouse , supposing I had the patience to be evaded and shirked , and handed about from post to pillar in trying to get him into one , which is a system that I do n't take kindly to . ''
Parsing [sent. 14730 len. 12]: `` No man does , sir , '' returns Mr. George .
Parsing [sent. 14731 len. 52]: `` I am convinced that he would not remain in either place , because he is possessed by an extraordinary terror of this person who ordered him to keep out of the way ; in his ignorance , he believes this person to be everywhere , and cognizant of everything . ''
Parsing [sent. 14732 len. 13]: `` I ask your pardon , sir , '' says Mr. George .
Parsing [sent. 14733 len. 11]: `` But you have not mentioned that party 's name .
Parsing [sent. 14734 len. 8]: Is it a secret , sir ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14735 len. 7]: `` The boy makes it one .
Parsing [sent. 14736 len. 7]: But his name is Bucket . ''
Parsing [sent. 14737 len. 8]: `` Bucket the detective , sir ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14738 len. 6]: `` The same man . ''
Parsing [sent. 14739 len. 44]: `` The man is known to me , sir , '' returns the trooper after blowing out a cloud of smoke and squaring his chest , `` and the boy is so far correct that he undoubtedly is a -- rum customer . ''
Parsing [sent. 14740 len. 16]: Mr. George smokes with a profound meaning after this and surveys Miss Flite in silence .
Parsing [sent. 14741 len. 47]: `` Now , I wish Mr. Jarndyce and Miss Summerson at least to know that this Jo , who tells so strange a story , has reappeared , and to have it in their power to speak with him if they should desire to do so .
Parsing [sent. 14742 len. 26]: Therefore I want to get him , for the present moment , into any poor lodging kept by decent people where he would be admitted .
Parsing [sent. 14743 len. 35]: Decent people and Jo , Mr. George , '' says Allan , following the direction of the trooper 's eyes along the entry , `` have not been much acquainted , as you see .
Parsing [sent. 14744 len. 4]: Hence the difficulty .
Parsing [sent. 14745 len. 25]: Do you happen to know any one in this neighbourhood who would receive him for a while on my paying for him beforehand ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14746 len. 38]: As he puts the question , he becomes aware of a dirty-faced little man standing at the trooper 's elbow and looking up , with an oddly twisted figure and countenance , into the trooper 's face .
Parsing [sent. 14747 len. 29]: After a few more puffs at his pipe , the trooper looks down askant at the little man , and the little man winks up at the trooper .
Parsing [sent. 14748 len. 56]: `` Well , sir , '' says Mr. George , `` I can assure you that I would willingiy be knocked on the head at any time if it would be at all agreeable to Miss Summerson , and consequently I esteem it a privilege to do that young lady any service , however small .
Parsing [sent. 14749 len. 16]: We are naturally in the vagabond way here , sir , both myself and Phil .
Parsing [sent. 14750 len. 7]: You see what the place is .
Parsing [sent. 14751 len. 20]: You are welcome to a quiet corner of it for the boy if the same would meet your views .
Parsing [sent. 14752 len. 8]: No charge made , except for rations .
Parsing [sent. 14753 len. 13]: We are not in a flourishing state of circumstances here , sir .
Parsing [sent. 14754 len. 16]: We are liable to be tumbled out neck and crop at a moment 's notice .
Parsing [sent. 14755 len. 25]: However , sir , such as the place is , and so long as it lasts , here it is at your service . ''
Parsing [sent. 14756 len. 20]: With a comprehensive wave of his pipe , Mr. George places the whole building at his visitor 's disposal .
Parsing [sent. 14757 len. 34]: `` I take it for granted , sir , '' he adds , `` you being one of the medical staff , that there is no present infection about this unfortunate subject ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14758 len. 7]: Allan is quite sure of it .
Parsing [sent. 14759 len. 24]: `` Because , sir , '' says Mr. George , shaking his head sorrowfully , `` we have had enough of that . ''
Parsing [sent. 14760 len. 12]: His tone is no less sorrowfully echoed by his new acquaintance .
Parsing [sent. 14761 len. 48]: ` Still I am bound to tell you , '' observes Allan after repeating his former assurance , `` that the boy is deplorably low and reduced and that he may be -- I do not say that he is -- too far gone to recover . ''
Parsing [sent. 14762 len. 12]: `` Do you consider him in present danger , sir ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14763 len. 4]: inquires the trooper .
Parsing [sent. 14764 len. 8]: `` Yes , I fear so . ''
Parsing [sent. 14765 len. 41]: `` Then , sir , '' returns the trooper in a decisive manner , `` it appears to me -- being naturally in the vagabond way myself -- that the sooner he comes out of the street , the better .
Parsing [sent. 14766 len. 4]: You , Phil !
Parsing [sent. 14767 len. 5]: Bring him in ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14768 len. 30]: Mr. Squod tacks out , all on one side , to execute the word of command ; and the trooper , having smoked his pipe , lays it by .
Parsing [sent. 14769 len. 5]: Jo is brought in .
Parsing [sent. 14770 len. 53]: He is not one of Mrs. Pardiggle 's Tockahoopo Indians ; he is not one of Mrs. Jellyby 's lambs , being wholly unconnected with Borrioboola -- Gha ; he is not softened by distance and unfamiliarity ; he is not a genuine foreign-grown savage ; he is the ordinary home-made article .
Parsing [sent. 14771 len. 26]: Dirty , ugly , disagreeable to all the senses , in body a common creature of the common streets , only in soul a heathen .
Parsing [sent. 14772 len. 44]: Homely filth begrimes him , homely parasites devour him , homely sores are in him , homely rags are on him ; native ignorance , the growth of English soil and climate , sinks his immortal nature lower than the beasts that perish .
Parsing [sent. 14773 len. 9]: Stand forth , Jo , in uncompromising colours !
Parsing [sent. 14774 len. 20]: From the sole of thy foot to the crown of thy head , there is nothing interesting about thee .
Parsing [sent. 14775 len. 22]: He shuffles slowly into Mr. George 's gallery and stands huddled together in a bundle , looking all about the floor .
Parsing [sent. 14776 len. 27]: He seems to know that they have an inclination to shrink from him , partly for what he is and partly for what he has caused .
Parsing [sent. 14777 len. 8]: He , too , shrinks from them .
Parsing [sent. 14778 len. 18]: He is not of the same order of things , not of the same place in creation .
Parsing [sent. 14779 len. 17]: He is of no order and no place , neither of the beasts nor of humanity .
Parsing [sent. 14780 len. 7]: `` Look here , Jo ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14781 len. 3]: says Allan .
Parsing [sent. 14782 len. 7]: `` This is Mr. George . ''
Parsing [sent. 14783 len. 21]: Jo searches the floor for some time longer , then looks up for a moment , and then down again .
Parsing [sent. 14784 len. 21]: `` He is a kind friend to you , for he is going to give you lodging room here . ''
Parsing [sent. 14785 len. 16]: Jo makes a scoop with one hand , which is supposed to be a bow .
Parsing [sent. 14786 len. 28]: After a little more consideration and some backing and changing of the foot on which he rests , he mutters that he is `` wery thankful . ''
Parsing [sent. 14787 len. 7]: `` You are quite safe here .
Parsing [sent. 14788 len. 16]: All you have to do at present is to be obedient and to get strong .
Parsing [sent. 14789 len. 16]: And mind you tell us the truth here , whatever you do , Jo . ''
Parsing [sent. 14790 len. 19]: `` Wishermaydie if I do n't , sir , '' says Jo , reverting to his favourite declaration .
Parsing [sent. 14791 len. 20]: `` I never done nothink yit , but wot you knows on , to get myself into no trouble .
Parsing [sent. 14792 len. 22]: I never was in no other trouble at all , sir , ` sept not knowin ' nothink and starwation . ''
Parsing [sent. 14793 len. 11]: `` I believe it , now attend to Mr. George .
Parsing [sent. 14794 len. 11]: I see he is going to speak to you . ''
Parsing [sent. 14795 len. 38]: `` My intention merely was , sir , '' observes Mr. George , amazingly broad and upright , `` to point out to him where he can lie down and get a thorough good dose of sleep .
Parsing [sent. 14796 len. 6]: Now , look here . ''
Parsing [sent. 14797 len. 23]: As the trooper speaks , he conducts them to the other end of the gallery and opens one of the little cabins .
Parsing [sent. 14798 len. 8]: `` There you are , you see !

Parsing [sent. 14800 len. 22]: Do n't you be alarmed if you hear shots ; they 'll be aimed at the target , and not you .
Parsing [sent. 14801 len. 22]: Now , there 's another thing I would recommend , sir , '' says the trooper , turning to his visitor .
Parsing [sent. 14802 len. 7]: `` Phil , come here ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14803 len. 11]: Phil bears down upon them according to his usual tactics .
Parsing [sent. 14804 len. 20]: `` Here is a man , sir , who was found , when a baby , in the gutter .
Parsing [sent. 14805 len. 18]: Consequently , it is to be expected that he takes a natural interest in this poor creature .
Parsing [sent. 14806 len. 10]: You do , do n't you , Phil ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14807 len. 17]: `` Certainly and surely I do , guv ` ner , '' is Phil 's reply .
Parsing [sent. 14808 len. 94]: `` Now I was thinking , sir , '' says Mr. George in a martial sort of confidence , as if he were giving his opinion in a council of war at a drum-head , `` that if this man was to take him to a bath and was to lay out a few shillings in getting him one or two coarse articles -- '' `` Mr. George , my considerate friend , '' returns Allan , taking out his purse , `` it is the very favour I would have asked . ''
Parsing [sent. 14809 len. 14]: Phil Squod and Jo are sent out immediately on this work of improvement .
Parsing [sent. 14810 len. 72]: Miss Flite , quite enraptured by her success , makes the best of her way to court , having great fears that otherwise her friend the Chancellor may be uneasy about her or may give the judgment she has so long expected in her absence , and observing `` which you know , my dear physician , and general , after so many years , would be too absurdly unfortunate ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14811 len. 43]: Allan takes the opportunity of going out to procure some restorative medicines , and obtaining them near at hand , soon returns to find the trooper walking up and down the gallery , and to fall into step and walk with him .
Parsing [sent. 14812 len. 22]: `` I take it , sir , '' says Mr. George , `` that you know Miss Summerson pretty well ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14813 len. 5]: Yes , it appears .
Parsing [sent. 14814 len. 9]: `` Not related to her , sir ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14815 len. 5]: No , it appears .
Parsing [sent. 14816 len. 11]: `` Excuse the apparent curiosity , '' says Mr. George .

Parsing [sent. 14818 len. 12]: 'T is MY case , sir , I assure you . ''
Parsing [sent. 14819 len. 8]: `` And mine , Mr. George . ''
Parsing [sent. 14820 len. 28]: The trooper looks sideways at Allan 's sunburnt cheek and bright dark eye , rapidly measures his height and build , and seems to approve of him .
Parsing [sent. 14821 len. 36]: `` Since you have been out , sir , I have been thinking that I unquestionably know the rooms in Lincoln 's Inn Fields , where Bucket took the lad , according to his account .
Parsing [sent. 14822 len. 16]: Though he is not acquainted with the name , I can help you to it .
Parsing [sent. 14823 len. 4]: It 's Tulkinghorn .
Parsing [sent. 14824 len. 7]: That 's what it is . ''

Parsing [sent. 14827 len. 7]: That 's the name , sir .
Parsing [sent. 14828 len. 27]: I know the man , and know him to have been in communication with Bucket before , respecting a deceased person who had given him offence .
Parsing [sent. 14829 len. 7]: I know the man , sir .
Parsing [sent. 14830 len. 5]: To my sorrow . ''
Parsing [sent. 14831 len. 10]: Allan naturally asks what kind of man he is .
Parsing [sent. 14832 len. 6]: `` What kind of man !
Parsing [sent. 14833 len. 8]: Do you mean to look at ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14834 len. 10]: `` I think I know that much of him .
Parsing [sent. 14835 len. 6]: I mean to deal with .
Parsing [sent. 14836 len. 8]: Generally , what kind of man ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14837 len. 47]: `` Why , then I 'll tell you , sir , '' returns the trooper , stopping short and folding his arms on his square chest so angrily that his face fires and flushes all over ; `` he is a confoundedly bad kind of man .
Parsing [sent. 14838 len. 8]: He is a slow-torturing kind of man .
Parsing [sent. 14839 len. 15]: He is no more like flesh and blood than a rusty old carbine is .
Parsing [sent. 14840 len. 10]: He is a kind of man -- by George !
Parsing [sent. 14841 len. 24]: -- that has caused me more restlessness , and more uneasiness , and more dissatisfaction with myself than all other men put together .
Parsing [sent. 14842 len. 11]: That 's the kind of man Mr. Tulkinghorn is ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14843 len. 19]: `` I am sorry , '' says Allan , `` to have touched so sore a place . ''
Parsing [sent. 14844 len. 4]: `` Sore ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14845 len. 25]: The trooper plants his legs wider apart , wets the palm of his broad right hand , and lays it on the imaginary moustache .
Parsing [sent. 14846 len. 15]: `` It 's no fault of yours , sir ; but you shall judge .
Parsing [sent. 14847 len. 8]: He has got a power over me .
Parsing [sent. 14848 len. 23]: He is the man I spoke of just now as being able to tumble me out of this place neck and crop .
Parsing [sent. 14849 len. 8]: He keeps me on a constant see-saw .
Parsing [sent. 14850 len. 13]: He wo n't hold off , and he wo n't come on .
Parsing [sent. 14851 len. 79]: If I have a payment to make him , or time to ask him for , or anything to go to him about , he do n't see me , do n't hear me -- passes me on to Melchisedech 's in Clifford 's Inn , Melchisedech 's in Clifford 's Inn passes me back again to him -- he keeps me prowling and dangling about him as if I was made of the same stone as himself .
Parsing [sent. 14852 len. 19]: Why , I spend half my life now , pretty well , loitering and dodging about his door .
Parsing [sent. 14853 len. 5]: What does he care ?
Parsing [sent. 14854 len. 2]: Nothing .
Parsing [sent. 14855 len. 14]: Just as much as the rusty old carbine I have compared him to .
