Parsing [sent. 14857 len. 2]: Nonsense !
Parsing [sent. 14858 len. 5]: I am forgetting myself .
Parsing [sent. 14859 len. 47]: Mr. Woodcourt , '' the trooper resumes his march , `` all I say is , he is an old man ; but I am glad I shall never have the chance of setting spurs to my horse and riding at him in a fair field .
Parsing [sent. 14860 len. 25]: For if I had that chance , in one of the humours he drives me into -- he 'd go down , sir ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14861 len. 19]: Mr. George has been so excited that he finds it necessary to wipe his forehead on his shirt-sleeve .
Parsing [sent. 14862 len. 59]: Even while he whistles his impetuosity away with the national anthem , some involuntary shakings of his head and heavings of his chest still linger behind , not to mention an occasional hasty adjustment with both hands of his open shirt-collar , as if it were scarcely open enough to prevent his being troubled by a choking sensation .
Parsing [sent. 14863 len. 22]: In short , Allan Woodcourt has not much doubt about the going down of Mr. Tulkinghorn on the field referred to .
Parsing [sent. 14864 len. 40]: Jo and his conductor presently return , and Jo is assisted to his mattress by the careful Phil , to whom , after due administration of medicine by his own hands , Allan confides all needful means and instructions .
Parsing [sent. 14865 len. 10]: The morning is by this time getting on apace .
Parsing [sent. 14866 len. 27]: He repairs to his lodgings to dress and breakfast , and then , without seeking rest , goes away to Mr. Jarndyce to communicate his discovery .
Parsing [sent. 14867 len. 29]: With him Mr. Jarndyce returns alone , confidentially telling him that there are reasons for keeping this matter very quiet indeed and showing a serious interest in it .
Parsing [sent. 14868 len. 20]: To Mr. Jarndyce , Jo repeats in substance what he said in the morning , without any material variation .
Parsing [sent. 14869 len. 17]: Only that cart of his is heavier to draw , and draws with a hollower sound .
Parsing [sent. 14870 len. 66]: `` Let me lay here quiet and not be chivied no more , '' falters Jo , `` and be so kind any person as is a-passin nigh where I used fur to sleep , as jist to say to Mr. Sangsby that Jo , wot he known once , is a-moving on right forards with his duty , and I 'll be wery thankful .
Parsing [sent. 14871 len. 23]: I 'd be more thankful than I am aready if it wos any ways possible for an unfortnet to be it . ''
Parsing [sent. 14872 len. 48]: He makes so many of these references to the law-stationer in the course of a day or two that Allan , after conferring with Mr. Jarndyce , good-naturedly resolves to call in Cook 's Court , the rather , as the cart seems to be breaking down .
Parsing [sent. 14873 len. 10]: To Cook 's Court , therefore , he repairs .
Parsing [sent. 14874 len. 60]: Mr. Snagsby is behind his counter in his grey coat and sleeves , inspecting an indenture of several skins which has just come in from the engrosser 's , an immense desert of law-hand and parchment , with here and there a resting-place of a few large letters to break the awful monotony and save the traveller from despair .
Parsing [sent. 14875 len. 23]: Mr Snagsby puts up at one of these inky wells and greets the stranger with his cough of general preparation for business .
Parsing [sent. 14876 len. 11]: `` You do n't remember me , Mr. Snagsby ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14877 len. 17]: The stationer 's heart begins to thump heavily , for his old apprehensions have never abated .
Parsing [sent. 14878 len. 23]: It is as much as he can do to answer , `` No , sir , I ca n't say I do .
Parsing [sent. 14879 len. 25]: I should have considered -- not to put too fine a point upon it -- that I never saw you before , sir . ''
Parsing [sent. 14880 len. 9]: `` Twice before , '' says Allan Woodcourt .
Parsing [sent. 14881 len. 19]: `` Once at a poor bedside , and once -- '' `` It 's come at last ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14882 len. 11]: thinks the afflicted stationer , as recollection breaks upon him .
Parsing [sent. 14883 len. 15]: `` It 's got to a head now and is going to burst ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14884 len. 21]: But he has sufficient presence of mind to conduct his visitor into the little counting-house and to shut the door .
Parsing [sent. 14885 len. 10]: `` Are you a married man , sir ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14886 len. 8]: `` No , I am not . ''
Parsing [sent. 14887 len. 28]: `` Would you make the attempt , though single , '' says Mr. Snagsby in a melancholy whisper , `` to speak as low as you can ?
Parsing [sent. 14888 len. 20]: For my little woman is a-listening somewheres , or I 'll forfeit the business and five hundred pound ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14889 len. 32]: In deep dejection Mr. Snagsby sits down on his stool , with his back against his desk , protesting , `` I never had a secret of my own , sir .
Parsing [sent. 14890 len. 26]: I ca n't charge my memory with ever having once attempted to deceive my little woman on my own account since she named the day .
Parsing [sent. 14891 len. 9]: I would n't have done it , sir .
Parsing [sent. 14892 len. 24]: Not to put too fine a point upon it , I could n't have done it , I durs n't have done it .
Parsing [sent. 14893 len. 25]: Whereas , and nevertheless , I find myself wrapped round with secrecy and mystery , till my life is a burden to me . ''
Parsing [sent. 14894 len. 16]: His visitor professes his regret to bear it and asks him does he remember Jo .
Parsing [sent. 14895 len. 14]: Mr. Snagsby answers with a suppressed groan , oh , do n't he !
Parsing [sent. 14896 len. 31]: `` You could n't name an individual human being -- except myself -- that my little woman is more set and determined against than Jo , '' says Mr. Snagsby .
Parsing [sent. 14897 len. 4]: Allan asks why .
Parsing [sent. 14898 len. 4]: `` Why ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14899 len. 21]: repeats Mr. Snagsby , in his desperation clutching at the clump of hair at the back of his bald head .
Parsing [sent. 14900 len. 7]: `` How should 1 know why ?
Parsing [sent. 14901 len. 25]: But you are a single person , sir , and may you long be spared to ask a married person such a question ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14902 len. 25]: With this beneficent wish , Mr. Snagsby coughs a cough of dismal resignation and submits himself to hear what the visitor has to communicate .
Parsing [sent. 14903 len. 5]: `` There again ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14904 len. 25]: says Mr. Snagsby , who , between the earnestness of his feelings and the suppressed tones of his voice is discoloured in the face .
Parsing [sent. 14905 len. 10]: `` At it again , in a new direction !
Parsing [sent. 14906 len. 25]: A certain person charges me , in the solemnest way , not to talk of Jo to any one , even my little woman .

Parsing [sent. 14908 len. 8]: Why , this is a private asylum !
Parsing [sent. 14909 len. 19]: Why , not to put too fine a point upon it , this is Bedlam , sir ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14910 len. 4]: says Mr. Snagsby .
Parsing [sent. 14911 len. 29]: But it is better than he expected after all , being no explosion of the mine below him or deepening of the pit into which he has fallen .
Parsing [sent. 14912 len. 35]: And being tender-hearted and affected by the account he hears of Jo 's condition , he readily engages to `` look round '' as early in the evening as he can manage it quietly .
Parsing [sent. 14913 len. 26]: He looks round very quietly when the evening comes , but it may turn out that Mrs. Snagsby is as quiet a manager as he .
Parsing [sent. 14914 len. 42]: Jo is very glad to see his old friend and says , when they are left alone , that he takes it uncommon kind as Mr. Sangsby should come so far out of his way on accounts of sich as him .
Parsing [sent. 14915 len. 30]: Mr. Snagsby , touched by the spectacle before him , immediately lays upon the table half a crown , that magic balsam of his for all kinds of wounds .
Parsing [sent. 14916 len. 13]: `` And how do you find yourself , my poor lad ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14917 len. 9]: inquires the stationer with his cough of sympathy .
Parsing [sent. 14918 len. 24]: `` I am in luck , Mr. Sangsby , I am , '' returns Jo , `` and do n't want for nothink .
Parsing [sent. 14919 len. 10]: I 'm more cumfbler nor you ca n't think .
Parsing [sent. 14920 len. 3]: Mr. Sangsby !
Parsing [sent. 14921 len. 22]: I 'm wery sorry that I done it , but I did n't go fur to do it , sir . ''
Parsing [sent. 14922 len. 21]: The stationer softly lays down another half-crown and asks him what it is that he is sorry for having done .
Parsing [sent. 14923 len. 60]: `` Mr. Sangsby , '' says Jo , `` I went and giv a illness to the lady as wos and yit as war n't the t ` other lady , and none of 'em never says nothink to me for having done it , on accounts of their being ser good and my having been s ` unfortnet .

Parsing [sent. 14927 len. 3]: she ses .

Parsing [sent. 14931 len. 10]: The softened stationer deposits another half-crown on the table .
Parsing [sent. 14932 len. 14]: Nothing less than a repetition of that infallible remedy will relieve his feelings .
Parsing [sent. 14933 len. 31]: `` Wot I was a-thinkin on , Mr. Sangsby , '' proceeds Jo , `` wos , as you wos able to write wery large , p ` raps ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14934 len. 13]: `` Yes , Jo , please God , '' returns the stationer .
Parsing [sent. 14935 len. 10]: `` Uncommon precious large , p ` raps ? ''
Parsing [sent. 14936 len. 5]: says Jo with eagerness .
Parsing [sent. 14937 len. 8]: `` Yes , my poor boy . ''
Parsing [sent. 14938 len. 5]: Jo laughs with pleasure .
Parsing [sent. 14939 len. 124]: `` Wot I wos a-thinking on then , Mr. Sangsby , wos , that when I wos moved on as fur as ever I could go and could n't he moved no furder , whether you might be so good p ` raps as to write out , wery large so that any one could see it anywheres , as that I wos wery truly hearty sorry that I done it and that I never went fur to do it , and that though I did n't know nothink at all , I knowd as Mr. Woodcot once cried over it and wos allus grieved over it , and that I hoped as he 'd be able to forgive me in his mind .
Parsing [sent. 14940 len. 16]: If the writin could be made to say it wery large , he might . ''
Parsing [sent. 14941 len. 8]: `` It shall say it , Jo .

Parsing [sent. 14943 len. 4]: Jo laughs again .
Parsing [sent. 14944 len. 6]: `` Thankee , Mr. Sangsby .
Parsing [sent. 14945 len. 21]: It 's wery kind of you , sir , and it makes me more cumfbler nor I was afore . ''
Parsing [sent. 14946 len. 37]: The meek little stationer , with a broken and unfinished cough , slips down his fourth half-crown -- he has never been so close to a case requiring so many -- and is fain to depart .
Parsing [sent. 14947 len. 15]: And Jo and he , upon this little earth , shall meet no more .
Parsing [sent. 14948 len. 3]: No more .
Parsing [sent. 14949 len. 19]: For the cart so hard to draw is near its journey 's end and drags over stony ground .
Parsing [sent. 14950 len. 15]: All round the clock it labours up the broken steps , shattered and worn .
Parsing [sent. 14951 len. 16]: Not many times can the sun rise and behold it still upon its weary road .
Parsing [sent. 14952 len. 54]: Phil Squod , with his smoky gunpowder visage , at once acts as nurse and works as armourer at his little table in a corner , often looking round and saying with a nod of his green-baize cap and an encouraging elevation of his one eyebrow , `` Hold up , my boy !
Parsing [sent. 14953 len. 4]: Hold up ! ''
Parsing [sent. 14954 len. 38]: There , too , is Mr. Jarndyce many a time , and Allan Woodcourt almost always , both thinking , much , how strangely fate has entangled this rough outcast in the web of very different lives .
Parsing [sent. 14955 len. 51]: There , too , the trooper is a frequent visitor , filling the doorway with his athletic figure and , from his superfluity of life and strength , seeming to shed down temporary vigour upon Jo , who never fails to speak more robustly in answer to his cheerful words .
Parsing [sent. 14956 len. 29]: Jo is in a sleep or in a stupor to-day , and Allan Woodcourt , newly arrived , stands by him , looking down upon his wasted form .

Parsing [sent. 14962 len. 18]: When the little hammer is next used , there will be a speck of rust upon it .
Parsing [sent. 14963 len. 5]: `` Well , Jo !
Parsing [sent. 14964 len. 5]: What is the matter ?
Parsing [sent. 14965 len. 6]: Do n't be frightened . ''

Parsing [sent. 14977 len. 5]: `` No , sir .

Parsing [sent. 14980 len. 15]: He prayed a lot , but I could n't make out nothink on it .

Parsing [sent. 14991 len. 21]: `` Where they laid him as wos wery good to me , wery good to me indeed , he wos .

Parsing [sent. 14993 len. 9]: I wants to go there and be berried .

Parsing [sent. 15004 len. 23]: They 'll have to get the key of the gate afore they can take me in , for it 's allus locked .
Parsing [sent. 15005 len. 17]: And there 's a step there , as I used for to clean with my broom .
Parsing [sent. 15006 len. 8]: It 's turned wery dark , sir .

Parsing [sent. 15024 len. 5]: Dead , your Majesty .
Parsing [sent. 15025 len. 7]: Dead , my lords and gentlemen .
Parsing [sent. 15026 len. 11]: Dead , right reverends and wrong reverends of every order .
Parsing [sent. 15027 len. 14]: Dead , men and women , born with heavenly compassion in your hearts .
Parsing [sent. 15028 len. 8]: And dying thus around us every day .
Parsing [sent. 15029 len. 24]: Chapter XLVIII -- Closing in The place in Lincolnshire has shut its many eyes again , and the house in town is awake .
Parsing [sent. 15030 len. 29]: In Lincolnshire the Dedlocks of the past doze in their picture-frames , and the low wind murmurs through the long drawing-room as if they were breathing pretty regularly .
Parsing [sent. 15031 len. 53]: In town the Dedlocks of the present rattle in their fire-eyed carriages through the darkness of the night , and the Dedlock Mercuries , with ashes -LRB- or hair-powder -RRB- on their heads , symptomatic of their great humility , loll away the drowsy mornings in the little windows of the hall .
Parsing [sent. 15032 len. 28]: The fashionable world -- tremendous orb , nearly five miles round -- is in full swing , and the solar system works respectfully at its appointed distances .
Parsing [sent. 15033 len. 30]: Where the throng is thickest , where the lights are brightest , where all the senses are ministered to with the greatest delicacy and refinement , Lady Dedlock is .
Parsing [sent. 15034 len. 15]: From the shining heights she has scaled and taken , she is never absent .
Parsing [sent. 15035 len. 63]: Though the belief she of old reposed in herself as one able to reserve whatsoever she would under her mantle of pride is beaten down , though she has no assurance that what she is to those around her she will remain another day , it is not in her nature when envious eyes are looking on to yield or to droop .
Parsing [sent. 15036 len. 15]: They say of her that she has lately grown more handsome and more haughty .

Parsing [sent. 15040 len. 20]: Of all men he is still the last who might be supposed to have any influence upon my Lady .

Parsing [sent. 15044 len. 15]: It is morning in the great world , afternoon according to the little sun .

Parsing [sent. 15364 len. 21]: Clear of the room he looks at his watch but is inclined to doubt it by a minute or thereabouts .
Parsing [sent. 15365 len. 22]: There is a splendid clock upon the staircase , famous , as splendid clocks not often are , for its accuracy .

Parsing [sent. 15374 len. 21]: What a watch to return good for evil if it ticked in answer , `` Do n't go home ! ''
Parsing [sent. 15375 len. 49]: He passes out into the streets and walks on , with his hands behind him , under the shadow of the lofty houses , many of whose mysteries , difficulties , mortgages , delicate affairs of all kinds , are treasured up within his old black satin waistcoat .

''

Parsing [sent. 15381 len. 26]: It is a moonlight night , but the moon , being past the full , is only now rising over the great wilderness of London .

Parsing [sent. 15394 len. 15]: A fine night , and a bright large moon , and multitudes of stars .

Parsing [sent. 15396 len. 22]: He looks up casually , thinking what a fine night , what a bright large moon , what multitudes of stars !
Parsing [sent. 15397 len. 6]: A quiet night , too .
Parsing [sent. 15398 len. 5]: A very quiet night .
Parsing [sent. 15399 len. 25]: When the moon shines very brilliantly , a solitude and stillness seem to proceed from her that influence even crowded places full of life .
Parsing [sent. 15400 len. 225]: Not only is it a still night on dusty high roads and on hill-summits , whence a wide expanse of country may be seen in repose , quieter and quieter as it spreads away into a fringe of trees against the sky with the grey ghost of a bloom upon them ; not only is it a still night in gardens and in woods , and on the river where the water-meadows are fresh and green , and the stream sparkles on among pleasant islands , murmuring weirs , and whispering rushes ; not only does the stillness attend it as it flows where houses cluster thick , where many bridges are reflected in it , where wharves and shipping make it black and awful , where it winds from these disfigurements through marshes whose grim beacons stand like skeletons washed ashore , where it expands through the bolder region of rising grounds , rich in cornfield wind-mill and steeple , and where it mingles with the ever-heaving sea ; not only is it a still night on the deep , and on the shore where the watcher stands to see the ship with her spread wings cross the path of light that appears to be presented to only him ; but even on this stranger 's wilderness of London there is some rest .
Parsing [sent. 15401 len. 48]: Its steeples and towers and its one great dome grow more ethereal ; its smoky house-tops lose their grossness in the pale effulgence ; the noises that arise from the streets are fewer and are softened , and the footsteps on the pavements pass more tranquilly away .
Parsing [sent. 15402 len. 67]: In these fields of Mr. Tulkinghorn 's inhabiting , where the shepherds play on Chancery pipes that have no stop , and keep their sheep in the fold by hook and by crook until they have shorn them exceeding close , every noise is merged , this moonlight night , into a distant ringing hum , as if the city were a vast glass , vibrating .

Parsing [sent. 15423 len. 14]: It is not likely that he has any new meaning in him to-night .
Parsing [sent. 15424 len. 19]: Once pointing , always pointing -- like any Roman , or even Briton , with a single idea .

Parsing [sent. 15428 len. 16]: But a little after the coming of the day come people to clean the rooms .

Parsing [sent. 15430 len. 25]: The others , looking in as the first one looked , shriek and fly too , and there is an alarm in the street .

Parsing [sent. 15432 len. 33]: No light is admitted into the darkened chamber , and people unaccustomed to it enter , and treading softly but heavily , carry a weight into the bedroom and lay it down .

Parsing [sent. 15437 len. 8]: These objects lie directly within his range .
Parsing [sent. 15438 len. 59]: An excited imagination might suppose that there was something in them so terrific as to drive the rest of the composition , not only the attendant big-legged boys , but the clouds and flowers and pillars too -- in short , the very body and soul of Allegory , and all the brains it has -- stark mad .
Parsing [sent. 15439 len. 44]: It happens surely that every one who comes into the darkened room and looks at these things looks up at the Roman and that he is invested in all eyes with mystery and awe , as if he were a paralysed dumb witness .
Parsing [sent. 15440 len. 81]: So it shall happen surely , through many years to come , that ghostly stories shall be told of the stain upon the floor , so easy to be covered , so hard to be got out , and that the Roman , pointing from the ceiling shall point , so long as dust and damp and spiders spare him , with far greater significance than he ever had in Mr. Tulkinghorn 's time , and with a deadly meaning .
Parsing [sent. 15441 len. 46]: For Mr. Tulkinghorn 's time is over for evermore , and the Roman pointed at the murderous hand uplifted against his life , and pointed helplessly at him , from night to morning , lying face downward on the floor , shot through the heart .
Parsing [sent. 15442 len. 29]: Chapter XLIX -- Dutiful Friendship A great annual occasion has come round in the establishment of Mr. Matthew Bagnet , otherwise Lignum Vitae , ex-artilleryman and present bassoon-player .
Parsing [sent. 15443 len. 7]: An occasion of feasting and festival .
Parsing [sent. 15444 len. 9]: The celebration of a birthday in the family .
Parsing [sent. 15445 len. 8]: It is not Mr. Bagnet 's birthday .
Parsing [sent. 15446 len. 62]: Mr. Bagnet merely distinguishes that epoch in the musical instrument business by kissing the children with an extra smack before breakfast , smoking an additional pipe after dinner , and wondering towards evening what his poor old mother is thinking about it -- a subject of infinite speculation , and rendered so by his mother having departed this life twenty years .
Parsing [sent. 15447 len. 33]: Some men rarely revert to their father , but seem , in the bank-books of their remembrance , to have transferred all the stock of filial affection into their mother 's name .

''

Parsing [sent. 15454 len. 27]: but there failing in the exact precision of his memory and substituting for number three the question `` And how do you like that name ? ''

Parsing [sent. 15458 len. 20]: The auspicious event is always commemorated according to certain forms settled and prescribed by Mr. Bagnet some years since .
Parsing [sent. 15459 len. 68]: Mr. Bagnet , being deeply convinced that to have a pair of fowls for dinner is to attain the highest pitch of imperial luxury , invariably goes forth himself very early in the morning of this day to buy a pair ; he is , as invariably , taken in by the vendor and installed in the possession of the oldest inhabitants of any coop in Europe .

Parsing [sent. 15462 len. 30]: He further requires that the old girl shall do nothing all day long but sit in her very best gown and be served by himself and the young people .

Parsing [sent. 15464 len. 13]: On this present birthday , Mr. Bagnet has accomplished the usual preliminaries .
Parsing [sent. 15465 len. 83]: He has bought two specimens of poultry , which , if there be any truth in adages , were certainly not caught with chaff , to be prepared for the spit ; he has amazed and rejoiced the family by their unlooked-for production ; he is himself directing the roasting of the poultry ; and Mrs. Bagnet , with her wholesome brown fingers itching to prevent what she sees going wrong , sits in her gown of ceremony , an honoured guest .

Parsing [sent. 15469 len. 4]: Says Mr. Bagnet .

Parsing [sent. 15471 len. 6]: They 'll be done . ''

Parsing [sent. 15509 len. 8]: Who would put the devil out . ''

Parsing [sent. 15511 len. 65]: Further conversation is prevented , for the time , by the necessity under which Mr. Bagnet finds himself of directing the whole force of his mind to the dinner , which is a little endangered by the dry humour of the fowls in not yielding any gravy , and also by the made gravy acquiring no flavour and turning out of a flaxen complexion .
Parsing [sent. 15512 len. 32]: With a similar perverseness , the potatoes crumble off forks in the process of peeling , upheaving from their centres in every direction , as if they were subject to earthquakes .
Parsing [sent. 15513 len. 19]: The legs of the fowls , too , are longer than could be desired , and extremely scaly .
Parsing [sent. 15514 len. 34]: Overcoming these disadvantages to the best of his ability , Mr. Bagnet at last dishes and they sit down at table , Mrs. Bagnet occupying the guest 's place at his right hand .
Parsing [sent. 15515 len. 27]: It is well for the old girl that she has but one birthday in a year , for two such indulgences in poultry might be injurious .
Parsing [sent. 15516 len. 28]: Every kind of finer tendon and ligament that is in the nature of poultry to possess is developed in these specimens in the singular form of guitar-strings .
Parsing [sent. 15517 len. 22]: Their limbs appear to have struck roots into their breasts and bodies , as aged trees strike roots into the earth .
Parsing [sent. 15518 len. 33]: Their legs are so hard as to encourage the idea that they must have devoted the greater part of their long and arduous lives to pedestrian exercises and the walking of matches .
Parsing [sent. 15519 len. 63]: But Mr. Bagnet , unconscious of these little defects , sets his heart on Mrs. Bagnet eating a most severe quantity of the delicacies before her ; and as that good old girl would not cause him a moment 's disappointment on any day , least of all on such a day , for any consideration , she imperils her digestion fearfully .
Parsing [sent. 15520 len. 22]: How young Woolwich cleans the drum-sticks without being of ostrich descent , his anxious mother is at a loss to understand .
Parsing [sent. 15521 len. 39]: The old girl has another trial to undergo after the conclusion of the repast in sitting in state to see the room cleared , the hearth swept , and the dinner-service washed up and polished in the backyard .
Parsing [sent. 15522 len. 52]: The great delight and energy with which the two young ladies apply themselves to these duties , turning up their skirts in imitation of their mother and skating in and out on little scaffolds of pattens , inspire the highest hopes for the future , but some anxiety for the present .
Parsing [sent. 15523 len. 63]: The same causes lead to confusion of tongues , a clattering of crockery , a rattling of tin mugs , a whisking of brooms , and an expenditure of water , all in excess , while the saturation of the young ladies themselves is almost too moving a spectacle for Mrs. Bagnet to look upon with the calmness proper to her position .
Parsing [sent. 15524 len. 57]: At last the various cleansing processes are triumphantly completed ; Quebec and Malta appear in fresh attire , smiling and dry ; pipes , tobacco , and something to drink are placed upon the table ; and the old girl enjoys the first peace of mind she ever knows on the day of this delightful entertainment .

Parsing [sent. 15837 len. 69]: Chapter L -- Esther 's Narrative It happened that when I came home from Deal I found a note from Caddy Jellyby -LRB- as we always continued to call her -RRB- , informing me that her health , which had been for some time very delicate , was worse and that she would be more glad than she could tell me if I would go to see her .
Parsing [sent. 15838 len. 37]: It was a note of a few lines , written from the couch on which she lay and enclosed to me in another from her husband , in which he seconded her entreaty with much solicitude .
Parsing [sent. 15839 len. 50]: Caddy was now the mother , and I the godmother , of such a poor little baby -- such a tiny old-faced mite , with a countenance that seemed to be scarcely anything but cap-border , and a little lean , long-fingered hand , always clenched under its chin .
Parsing [sent. 15840 len. 35]: It would lie in this attitude all day , with its bright specks of eyes open , wondering -LRB- as I used to imagine -RRB- how it came to be so small and weak .
Parsing [sent. 15841 len. 32]: Whenever it was moved it cried , but at all other times it was so patient that the sole desire of its life appeared to be to lie quiet and think .
Parsing [sent. 15842 len. 47]: It had curious little dark veins in its face and curious little dark marks under its eyes like faint remembrances of poor Caddy 's inky days , and altogether , to those who were not used to it , it was quite a piteous little sight .
Parsing [sent. 15843 len. 13]: But it was enough for Caddy that SHE was used to it .
Parsing [sent. 15844 len. 75]: The projects with which she beguiled her illness , for little Esther 's education , and little Esther 's marriage , and even for her own old age as the grandmother of little Esther 's little Esthers , was so prettily expressive of devotion to this pride of her life that I should be tempted to recall some of them but for the timely remembrance that I am getting on irregularly as it is .
Parsing [sent. 15845 len. 6]: To return to the letter .
Parsing [sent. 15846 len. 31]: Caddy had a superstition about me which had been strengthening in her mind ever since that night long ago when she had lain asleep with her head in my lap .
Parsing [sent. 15847 len. 22]: She almost -- I think I must say quite -- believed that I did her good whenever I was near her .
Parsing [sent. 15848 len. 37]: Now although this was such a fancy of the affectionate girl 's that I am almost ashamed to mention it , still it might have all the force of a fact when she was really ill .
Parsing [sent. 15849 len. 32]: Therefore I set off to Caddy , with my guardian 's consent , post-haste ; and she and Prince made so much of me that there never was anything like it .
Parsing [sent. 15850 len. 17]: Next day I went again to sit with her , and next day I went again .
Parsing [sent. 15851 len. 34]: It was a very easy journey , for I had only to rise a little earlier in the morning , and keep my accounts , and attend to housekeeping matters before leaving home .
Parsing [sent. 15852 len. 35]: But when I had made these three visits , my guardian said to me , on my return at night , `` Now , little woman , little woman , this will never do .

Parsing [sent. 15854 len. 17]: We will go to London for a while and take possession of our old lodgings . ''
Parsing [sent. 15855 len. 25]: `` Not for me , dear guardian , '' said I , `` for I never feel tired , '' which was strictly true .
Parsing [sent. 15856 len. 11]: I was only too happy to be in such request .
Parsing [sent. 15857 len. 21]: `` For me then , '' returned my guardian , `` or for Ada , or for both of us .
Parsing [sent. 15858 len. 11]: It is somebody 's birthday to-morrow , I think . ''
Parsing [sent. 15859 len. 21]: `` Truly I think it is , '' said I , kissing my darling , who would be twenty-one to-morrow .

Parsing [sent. 15885 len. 51]: This caused me to feel that I ought to tell her , and Caddy too , that I was going to be the mistress of Bleak House and that if I avoided that disclosure any longer I might become less worthy in my own eyes of its master 's love .
Parsing [sent. 15886 len. 75]: Therefore , when we went upstairs and had waited listening until the clock struck twelve in order that only I might be the first to wish my darling all good wishes on her birthday and to take her to my heart , I set before her , just as I had set before myself , the goodness and honour of her cousin John and the happy life that was in store for for me .
Parsing [sent. 15887 len. 27]: If ever my darling were fonder of me at one time than another in all our intercourse , she was surely fondest of me that night .

Parsing [sent. 15889 len. 28]: I had scarcely thought it a reservation a few hours ago , but now that it was gone I felt as if I understood its nature better .

Parsing [sent. 15893 len. 53]: After that day I was for some weeks -- eight or nine as I remember -- very much with Caddy , and thus it fell out that I saw less of Ada at this time than any other since we had first come together , except the time of my own illness .

Parsing [sent. 15896 len. 27]: With her husband and her poor little mite of a baby to love and their home to strive for , what a good creature Caddy was !
Parsing [sent. 15897 len. 50]: So self-denying , so uncomplaining , so anxious to get well on their account , so afraid of giving trouble , and so thoughtful of the unassisted labours of her husband and the comforts of old Mr. Turveydrop ; I had never known the best of her until now .
Parsing [sent. 15898 len. 57]: And it seemed so curious that her pale face and helpless figure should be lying there day after day where dancing was the business of life , where the kit and the apprentices began early every morning in the ball-room , and where the untidy little boy waltzed by himself in the kitchen all the afternoon .
Parsing [sent. 15899 len. 77]: At Caddy 's request I took the supreme direction of her apartment , trimmed it up , and pushed her , couch and all , into a lighter and more airy and more cheerful corner than she had yet occupied ; then , every day , when we were in our neatest array , I used to lay my small small namesake in her arms and sit down to chat or work or read to her .

Parsing [sent. 15903 len. 33]: Whatever Caddy 's condition really was , she never failed to declare to Prince that she was all but well -- which I , heaven forgive me , never failed to confirm .
Parsing [sent. 15904 len. 51]: This would put Prince in such good spirits that he would sometimes take the kit from his pocket and play a chord or two to astonish the baby , which I never knew it to do in the least degree , for my tiny namesake never noticed it at all .
Parsing [sent. 15905 len. 6]: Then there was Mrs. Jellyby .

Parsing [sent. 15907 len. 31]: As bright-eyed as ever , as serene , and as untidy , she would say , `` Well , Caddy , child , and how do you do to-day ? ''

Parsing [sent. 15912 len. 20]: If the fire wanted stirring in the night , it was surreptitiously done lest his rest should be broken .

Parsing [sent. 15942 len. 53]: But even this disinterestedness was attended with no inconsiderable cost , to my knowledge , for before Peepy was sufficiently decorated to walk hand in hand with the professor of deportment , he had to be newly dressed , at the expense of Caddy and her husband , from top to toe .

Parsing [sent. 15956 len. 46]: Her tenderness for me was as loving and true as ever ; I did not for a moment doubt that ; but there was a quiet sorrow about her which she did not confide to me , and in which I traced some hidden regret .
Parsing [sent. 15957 len. 32]: Now , I could not understand this , and I was so anxious for the happiness of my own pet that it caused me some uneasiness and set me thinking often .

Parsing [sent. 15966 len. 68]: However , as Caddy 's illness had certainly interfered , more or less , with my home duties -- though I had always been there in the morning to make my guardian 's breakfast , and he had a hundred times laughed and said there must be two little women , for his little woman was never missing -- I resolved to be doubly diligent and gay .
Parsing [sent. 15967 len. 37]: So I went about the house humming all the tunes I knew , and I sat working and working in a desperate manner , and I talked and talked , morning , noon , and night .

Parsing [sent. 16327 len. 51]: Chapter LII -- Obstinacy But one other day had intervened when , early in the morning as we were going to breakfast , Mr. Woodcourt came in haste with the astounding news that a terrible murder had been committed for which Mr. George had been apprehended and was in custody .

Parsing [sent. 16447 len. 4]: It HAS happened .
Parsing [sent. 16448 len. 40]: Then comes the question how to meet it '' He rubbed his swarthy forehead for a moment with a good-humoured look and said apologetically , `` I am such a short-winded talker that I must think a bit . ''

Parsing [sent. 16602 len. 20]: Chapter LIII -- The Track Mr. Bucket and his fat forefinger are much in consultation together under existing circumstances .
Parsing [sent. 16603 len. 29]: When Mr. Bucket has a matter of this pressing interest under his consideration , the fat forefinger seems to rise , to the dignity of a familiar demon .
Parsing [sent. 16604 len. 55]: He puts it to his ears , and it whispers information ; he puts it to his lips , and it enjoins him to secrecy ; he rubs it over his nose , and it sharpens his scent ; he shakes it before a guilty man , and it charms him to his destruction .
Parsing [sent. 16605 len. 30]: The Augurs of the Detective Temple invariably predict that when Mr. Bucket and that finger are in much conference , a terrible avenger will be heard of before long .
Parsing [sent. 16606 len. 54]: Otherwise mildly studious in his observation of human nature , on the whole a benignant philosopher not disposed to be severe upon the follies of mankind , Mr. Bucket pervades a vast number of houses and strolls about an infinity of streets , to outward appearance rather languishing for want of an object .
Parsing [sent. 16607 len. 17]: He is in the friendliest condition towards his species and will drink with most of them .
Parsing [sent. 16608 len. 32]: He is free with his money , affable in his manners , innocent in his conversation -- but through the placid stream of his life there glides an under-current of forefinger .
Parsing [sent. 16609 len. 9]: Time and place can not bind Mr. Bucket .
Parsing [sent. 16610 len. 29]: Like man in the abstract , he is here to-day and gone to-morrow -- but , very unlike man indeed , he is here again the next day .
Parsing [sent. 16611 len. 52]: This evening he will be casually looking into the iron extinguishers at the door of Sir Leicester Dedlock 's house in town ; and to-morrow morning he will be walking on the leads at Chesney Wold , where erst the old man walked whose ghost is propitiated with a hundred guineas .
Parsing [sent. 16612 len. 16]: Drawers , desks , pockets , all things belonging to him , Mr. Bucket examines .
Parsing [sent. 16613 len. 16]: A few hours afterwards , he and the Roman will be alone together comparing forefingers .
Parsing [sent. 16614 len. 26]: It is likely that these occupations are irreconcilable with home enjoyment , but it is certain that Mr. Bucket at present does not go home .
Parsing [sent. 16615 len. 57]: Though in general he highly appreciates the society of Mrs. Bucket -- a lady of a natural detective genius , which if it had been improved by professional exercise , might have done great things , but which has paused at the level of a clever amateur -- he holds himself aloof from that dear solace .
Parsing [sent. 16616 len. 24]: Mrs. Bucket is dependent on their lodger -LRB- fortunately an amiable lady in whom she takes an interest -RRB- for companionship and conversation .

Parsing [sent. 16662 len. 59]: Having leisurely helped himself from a canister borrowed from somebody downstairs for the purpose , and having made a considerable show of tasting it , first with one side of his nose and then with the other , Mr. Bucket , with much deliberation , pronounces it of the right sort and goes on , letter in hand .
Parsing [sent. 16663 len. 41]: Now although Mr. Bucket walks upstairs to the little library within the larger one with the face of a man who receives some scores of letters every day , it happens that much correspondence is not incidental to his life .
Parsing [sent. 16664 len. 44]: He is no great scribe , rather handling his pen like the pocket-staff he carries about with him always convenient to his grasp , and discourages correspondence with himself in others as being too artless and direct a way of doing delicate business .
Parsing [sent. 16665 len. 25]: Further , he often sees damaging letters produced in evidence and has occasion to reflect that it was a green thing to write them .
Parsing [sent. 16666 len. 18]: For these reasons he has very little to do with letters , either as sender or receiver .

Parsing [sent. 16673 len. 40]: Having put the letters in his book of fate and girdled it up again , he unlocks the door just in time to admit his dinner , which is brought upon a goodly tray with a decanter of sherry .
Parsing [sent. 16674 len. 35]: Mr. Bucket frequently observes , in friendly circles where there is no restraint , that he likes a toothful of your fine old brown East Inder sherry better than anything you can offer him .
Parsing [sent. 16675 len. 26]: Consequently he fills and empties his glass with a smack of his lips and is proceeding with his refreshment when an idea enters his mind .

Parsing [sent. 16705 len. 10]: It is not likely ever to recover its tone .
Parsing [sent. 16706 len. 30]: But it is full of indignation to-night after undergoing the ordeal of consigning to the tomb the remains of a faithful , a zealous , a devoted adherent . ''
Parsing [sent. 16707 len. 14]: Sir Leicester 's voice trembles and his grey hair stirs upon his head .
Parsing [sent. 16708 len. 15]: Tears are in his eyes ; the best part of his nature is aroused .
Parsing [sent. 16709 len. 41]: `` I declare , '' he says , `` I solemnly declare that until this crime is discovered and , in the course of justice , punished , I almost feel as if there were a stain upon my name .
Parsing [sent. 16710 len. 64]: A gentleman who has devoted a large portion of his life to me , a gentleman who has devoted the last day of his life to me , a gentleman who has constantly sat at my table and slept under my roof , goes from my house to his own , and is struck down within an hour of his leaving my house .
Parsing [sent. 16711 len. 54]: I can not say but that he may have been followed from my house , watched at my house , even first marked because of his association with my house -- which may have suggested his possessing greater wealth and being altogether of greater importance than his own retiring demeanour would have indicated .
Parsing [sent. 16712 len. 50]: If I can not with my means and influence and my position bring all the perpetrators of such a crime to light , I fail in the assertion of my respect for that gentleman 's memory and of my fidelity towards one who was ever faithful to me . ''
Parsing [sent. 16713 len. 51]: While he makes this protestation with great emotion and earnestness , looking round the room as if he were addressing an assembly , Mr. Bucket glances at him with an observant gravity in which there might be , but for the audacity of the thought , a touch of compassion .

Parsing [sent. 16883 len. 23]: Chapter LIV -- Springing a Mine Refreshed by sleep , Mr. Bucket rises betimes in the morning and prepares for a field-day .

Parsing [sent. 16911 len. 67]: `` Now , Sir Leicester Dedlock , Baronet , '' Mr. Bucket begins , standing over him with one hand spread out on the library-table and the forefinger of the other in impressive use , `` it 's my duty to prepare you for a train of circumstances that may , and I go so far as to say that will , give you a shock .
Parsing [sent. 16912 len. 27]: But Sir Leicester Dedlock , Baronet , you are a gentleman , and I know what a gentleman is and what a gentleman is capable of .
Parsing [sent. 16913 len. 15]: A gentleman can bear a shock when it must come , boldly and steadily .
Parsing [sent. 16914 len. 15]: A gentleman can make up his mind to stand up against almost any blow .
Parsing [sent. 16915 len. 11]: Why , take yourself , Sir Leicester Dedlock , Baronet .
Parsing [sent. 16916 len. 18]: If there 's a blow to be inflicted on you , you naturally think of your family .
Parsing [sent. 16917 len. 58]: You ask yourself , how would all them ancestors of yours , away to Julius Caesar -- not to go beyond him at present -- have borne that blow ; you remember scores of them that would have borne it well ; and you bear it well on their accounts , and to maintain the family credit .

Parsing [sent. 17120 len. 25]: `` My friend the law-stationer 's good lady , over there , '' says Mr. Bucket , luring Mrs. Snagsby forward with the finger .
Parsing [sent. 17121 len. 10]: `` What may YOUR game be , ma'am ? ''
Parsing [sent. 17122 len. 111]: Mrs. Snagsby is at first prevented , by tears and lamentations , from stating the nature of her game , but by degrees it confusedly comes to light that she is a woman overwhelmed with injuries and wrongs , whom Mr. Snagsby has habitually deceived , abandoned , and sought to keep in darkness , and whose chief comfort , under her afflictions , has been the sympathy of the late Mr. Tulkinghorn , who showed so much commiseration for her on one occasion of his calling in Cook 's Court in the absence of her perjured husband that she has of late habitually carried to him all her woes .
Parsing [sent. 17123 len. 17]: Everybody it appears , the present company excepted , has plotted against Mrs. Snagsby 's peace .
Parsing [sent. 17124 len. 48]: There is Mr. Guppy , clerk to Kenge and Carboy , who was at first as open as the sun at noon , but who suddenly shut up as close as midnight , under the influence -- no doubt -- of Mr. Snagsby 's suborning and tampering .
Parsing [sent. 17125 len. 24]: There is Mr. Weevle , friend of Mr. Guppy , who lived mysteriously up a court , owing to the like coherent causes .
Parsing [sent. 17126 len. 28]: There was Krook , deceased ; there was Nimrod , deceased ; and there was Jo , deceased ; and they were `` all in it . ''
Parsing [sent. 17127 len. 62]: In what , Mrs. Snagsby does not with particularity express , but she knows that Jo was Mr. Snagsby 's son , `` as well as if a trumpet had spoken it , '' and she followed Mr. Snagsby when he went on his last visit to the boy , and if he was not his son why did he go ?
Parsing [sent. 17128 len. 66]: The one occupation of her life has been , for some time back , to follow Mr. Snagsby to and fro , and up and down , and to piece suspicious circumstances together -- and every circumstance that has happened has been most suspicious ; and in this way she has pursued her object of detecting and confounding her false husband , night and day .
Parsing [sent. 17129 len. 73]: Thus did it come to pass that she brought the Chadbands and Mr. Tulkinghorn together , and conferred with Mr. Tulkinghorn on the change in Mr. Guppy , and helped to turn up the circumstances in which the present company are interested , casually , by the wayside , being still and ever on the great high road that is to terminate in Mr. Snagsby 's full exposure and a matrimonial separation .
Parsing [sent. 17130 len. 95]: All this , Mrs. Snagsby , as an injured woman , and the friend of Mrs. Chadband , and the follower of Mr. Chadband , and the mourner of the late Mr. Tulkinghorn , is here to certify under the seal of confidence , with every possible confusion and involvement possible and impossible , having no pecuniary motive whatever , no scheme or project but the one mentioned , and bringing here , and taking everywhere , her own dense atmosphere of dust , arising from the ceaseless working of her mill of jealousy .
Parsing [sent. 17131 len. 48]: While this exordium is in hand -- and it takes some time -- Mr. Bucket , who has seen through the transparency of Mrs. Snagsby 's vinegar at a glance , confers with his familiar demon and bestows his shrewd attention on the Chadbands and Mr. Smallweed .

Parsing [sent. 17133 len. 9]: `` Very good , '' says Mr. Bucket .

Parsing [sent. 17326 len. 100]: I watched this young woman yesterday without her knowledge when she was looking at the funeral , in company with my wife , who planned to take her there ; and I had so much to convict her , and I saw such an expression in her face , and my mind so rose against her malice towards her ladyship , and the time was altogether such a time for bringing down what you may call retribution upon her , that if I had been a younger hand with less experience , I should have taken her , certain .

Parsing [sent. 17390 len. 25]: Sir Leicester , left alone , remains in the same attitude , as though he were still listening and his attention were still occupied .
Parsing [sent. 17391 len. 37]: At length he gazes round the empty room , and finding it deserted , rises unsteadily to his feet , pushes back his chair , and walks a few steps , supporting himself by the table .
Parsing [sent. 17392 len. 23]: Then he stops , and with more of those inarticulate sounds , lifts up his eyes and seems to stare at something .
Parsing [sent. 17393 len. 6]: Heaven knows what he sees .
Parsing [sent. 17394 len. 47]: The green , green woods of Chesney Wold , the noble house , the pictures of his forefathers , strangers defacing them , officers of police coarsely handling his most precious heirlooms , thousands of fingers pointing at him , thousands of faces sneering at him .
Parsing [sent. 17395 len. 43]: But if such shadows flit before him to his bewilderment , there is one other shadow which he can name with something like distinctness even yet and to which alone he addresses his tearing of his white hair and his extended arms .
Parsing [sent. 17396 len. 35]: It is she in association with whom , saving that she has been for years a main fibre of the root of his dignity and pride , he has never had a selfish thought .
Parsing [sent. 17397 len. 21]: It is she whom he has loved , admired , honoured , and set up for the world to respect .
Parsing [sent. 17398 len. 43]: It is she who , at the core of all the constrained formalities and conventionalities of his life , has been a stock of living tenderness and love , susceptible as nothing else is of being struck with the agony he feels .
Parsing [sent. 17399 len. 31]: He sees her , almost to the exclusion of himself , and can not bear to look upon her cast down from the high place she has graced so well .
Parsing [sent. 17400 len. 47]: And even to the point of his sinking on the ground , oblivious of his suffering , he can yet pronounce her name with something like distinctness in the midst of those intrusive sounds , and in a tone of mourning and compassion rather than reproach .
Parsing [sent. 17401 len. 59]: Chapter LV -- Flight Inspector Bucket of the Detective has not yet struck his great blow , as just now chronicled , but is yet refreshing himself with sleep preparatory to his field-day , when through the night and along the freezing wintry roads a chaise and pair comes out of Lincolnshire , making its way towards London .
Parsing [sent. 17402 len. 50]: Railroads shall soon traverse all this country , and with a rattle and a glare the engine and train shall shoot like a meteor over the wide night-landscape , turning the moon paler ; but as yet such things are non-existent in these parts , though not wholly unexpected .
Parsing [sent. 17403 len. 13]: Preparations are afoot , measurements are made , ground is staked out .
Parsing [sent. 17404 len. 76]: Bridges are begun , and their not yet united piers desolately look at one another over roads and streams like brick and mortar couples with an obstacle to their union ; fragments of embankments are thrown up and left as precipices with torrents of rusty carts and barrows tumbling over them ; tripods of tall poles appear on hilltops , where there are rumours of tunnels ; everything looks chaotic and abandoned in full hopelessness .
Parsing [sent. 17405 len. 22]: Along the freezing roads , and through the night , the post-chaise makes its way without a railroad on its mind .
Parsing [sent. 17406 len. 30]: Mrs. Rouncewell , so many years housekeeper at Chesney Wold , sits within the chaise ; and by her side sits Mrs. Bagnet with her grey cloak and umbrella .
Parsing [sent. 17407 len. 48]: The old girl would prefer the bar in front , as being exposed to the weather and a primitive sort of perch more in accordance with her usual course of travelling , but Mrs. Rouncewell is too thoughtful of her comfort to admit of her proposing it .
Parsing [sent. 17408 len. 12]: The old lady can not make enough of the old girl .
Parsing [sent. 17409 len. 25]: She sits , in her stately manner , holding her hand , and regardless of its roughness , puts it often to her lips .
Parsing [sent. 17410 len. 27]: `` You are a mother , my dear soul , '' says she many times , `` and you found out my George 's mother ! ''
Parsing [sent. 17411 len. 96]: `` Why , George , '' returns Mrs. Bagnet , `` was always free with me , ma'am , and when he said at our house to my Woolwich that of all the things my Woolwich could have to think of when he grew to be a man , the comfortablest would be that he had never brought a sorrowful line into his mother 's face or turned a hair of her head grey , then I felt sure , from his way , that something fresh had brought his own mother into his mind .
Parsing [sent. 17412 len. 22]: I had often known him say to me , in past times , that he had behaved bad to her . ''
Parsing [sent. 17413 len. 7]: `` Never , my dear ! ''
Parsing [sent. 17414 len. 8]: returns Mrs. Rouncewell , bursting into tears .
Parsing [sent. 17415 len. 8]: `` My blessing on him , never !
Parsing [sent. 17416 len. 16]: He was always fond of me , and loving to me , was my George !
Parsing [sent. 17417 len. 19]: But he had a bold spirit , and he ran a little wild and went for a soldier .
Parsing [sent. 17418 len. 48]: And I know he waited at first , in letting us know about himself , till he should rise to be an officer ; and when he did n't rise , I know he considered himself beneath us , and would n't be a disgrace to us .
Parsing [sent. 17419 len. 17]: For he had a lion heart , had my George , always from a baby ! ''
Parsing [sent. 17420 len. 92]: The old lady 's hands stray about her as of yore , while she recalls , all in a tremble , what a likely lad , what a fine lad , what a gay good-humoured clever lad he was ; how they all took to him down at Chesney Wold ; how Sir Leicester took to him when he was a young gentleman ; how the dogs took to him ; how even the people who had been angry with him forgave him the moment he was gone , poor boy .
Parsing [sent. 17421 len. 14]: And now to see him after all , and in a prison too !
Parsing [sent. 17422 len. 20]: And the broad stomacher heaves , and the quaint upright old-fashioned figure bends under its load of affectionate distress .
Parsing [sent. 17423 len. 87]: Mrs. Bagnet , with the instinctive skill of a good warm heart , leaves the old housekeeper to her emotions for a little while -- not without passing the back of her hand across her own motherly eyes -- and presently chirps up in her cheery manner , `` So I says to George when I goes to call him in to tea -LRB- he pretended to be smoking his pipe outside -RRB- , ` What ails you this afternoon , George , for gracious sake ?

Parsing [sent. 17430 len. 50]: Now , ma'am , when George says to me that it 's best not tried to be undone now , I have my thoughts as I have often had before , and I draw it out of George how he comes to have such things on him that afternoon .
Parsing [sent. 17431 len. 60]: Then George tells me that he has seen by chance , at the lawyer 's office , a fine old lady that has brought his mother plain before him , and he runs on about that old lady till he quite forgets himself and paints her picture to me as she used to be , years upon years back .
Parsing [sent. 17432 len. 19]: So I says to George when he has done , who is this old lady he has seen ?
Parsing [sent. 17433 len. 27]: And George tells me it 's Mrs. Rouncewell , housekeeper for more than half a century to the Dedlock family down at Chesney Wold in Lincolnshire .

Parsing [sent. 17452 len. 29]: The frosty night wears away , and the dawn breaks , and the post-chaise comes rolling on through the early mist like the ghost of a chaise departed .
Parsing [sent. 17453 len. 24]: It has plenty of spectral company in ghosts of trees and hedges , slowly vanishing and giving place to the realities of day .
Parsing [sent. 17454 len. 60]: London reached , the travellers alight , the old housekeeper in great tribulation and confusion , Mrs. Bagnet quite fresh and collected -- as she would be if her next point , with no new equipage and outfit , were the Cape of Good Hope , the Island of Ascension , Hong Kong , or any other military station .
Parsing [sent. 17455 len. 40]: But when they set out for the prison where the trooper is confined , the old lady has managed to draw about her , with her lavender-coloured dress , much of the staid calmness which is its usual accompaniment .
Parsing [sent. 17456 len. 41]: A wonderfully grave , precise , and handsome piece of old china she looks , though her heart beats fast and her stomacher is ruffled more than even the remembrance of this wayward son has ruffled it these many years .

Parsing [sent. 17459 len. 26]: So George , who is writing at his table , supposing himself to be alone , does not raise his eyes , but remains absorbed .

Parsing [sent. 17464 len. 5]: Mrs. Bagnet understands them .
Parsing [sent. 17465 len. 72]: They speak of gratitude , of joy , of grief , of hope ; of inextinguishable affection , cherished with no return since this stalwart man was a stripling ; of a better son loved less , and this son loved so fondly and so proudly ; and they speak in such touching language that Mrs. Bagnet 's eyes brim up with tears and they run glistening down her sun-brown face .
Parsing [sent. 17466 len. 4]: `` George Rouncewell !
Parsing [sent. 17467 len. 13]: Oh , my dear child , turn and look at me ! ''

Parsing [sent. 17485 len. 44]: The trooper has dried his eyes and put away his handkerchief , but there is an extraordinary contrast between his habitual manner of expressing himself and carrying himself and the softened tone in which he speaks , interrupted occasionally by a half-stifled sob .
Parsing [sent. 17486 len. 31]: `` So I wrote a line home , mother , as you too well know , to say I had ` listed under another name , and I went abroad .
Parsing [sent. 17487 len. 61]: Abroad , at one time I thought I would write home next year , when I might be better off ; and when that year was out , I thought I would write home next year , when I might be better off ; and when that year was out again , perhaps I did n't think much about it .
Parsing [sent. 17488 len. 33]: So on , from year to year , through a service of ten years , till I began to get older , and to ask myself why should I ever write . ''
Parsing [sent. 17489 len. 19]: `` I do n't find any fault , child -- but not to ease my mind , George ?
Parsing [sent. 17490 len. 15]: Not a word to your loving mother , who was growing older too ? ''
Parsing [sent. 17491 len. 24]: This almost overturns the trooper afresh , but he sets himself up with a great , rough , sounding clearance of his throat .

Parsing [sent. 17494 len. 24]: There was my brother , as I read in chance North Country papers now and then , rising to be prosperous and famous .
Parsing [sent. 17495 len. 47]: There was I a dragoon , roving , unsettled , not self-made like him , but self-unmade -- all my earlier advantages thrown away , all my little learning unlearnt , nothing picked up but what unfitted me for most things that I could think of .

Parsing [sent. 17504 len. 60]: You would have sought me out ; you would have purchased my discharge ; you would have taken me down to Chesney Wold ; you would have brought me and my brother and my brother 's family together ; you would all have considered anxiously how to do something for me and set me up as a respectable civilian .
Parsing [sent. 17505 len. 22]: But how could any of you feel sure of me when I could n't so much as feel sure of myself ?

Parsing [sent. 17517 len. 9]: To which Mrs. Bagnet responds with two pokes .
Parsing [sent. 17518 len. 126]: And now the old lady impresses upon her son George , her own dear recovered boy , her joy and pride , the light of her eyes , the happy close of her life , and every fond name she can think of , that he must be governed by the best advice obtainable by money and influence , that he must yield up his case to the greatest lawyers that can be got , that he must act in this serious plight as he shall be advised to act and must not be self-willed , however right , but must promise to think only of his poor old mother 's anxiety and suffering until he is released , or he will break her heart .
Parsing [sent. 17519 len. 41]: `` Mother , 't is little enough to consent to , '' returns the trooper , stopping her with a kiss ; `` tell me what I shall do , and I 'll make a late beginning and do it .

Parsing [sent. 17521 len. 11]: A very hard poke from the old girl 's umbrella .

Parsing [sent. 17538 len. 57]: If it 's ever broke to him that his rip of a brother has turned up , I could wish , '' says the trooper , shaking his head very doubtfully , `` to break it myself and be governed as to advancing or retreating by the way in which he seems to take it . ''
Parsing [sent. 17539 len. 36]: As he evidently has a rooted feeling on this point , and as the depth of it is recognized in Mrs. Bagnet 's face , his mother yields her implicit assent to what he asks .
Parsing [sent. 17540 len. 7]: For this he thanks her kindly .
Parsing [sent. 17541 len. 31]: `` In all other respects , my dear mother , I 'll be as tractable and obedient as you can wish ; on this one alone , I stand out .

Parsing [sent. 17543 len. 39]: I have been drawing up , '' he glances at his writing on the table , `` an exact account of what I knew of the deceased and how I came to be involved in this unfortunate affair .
Parsing [sent. 17544 len. 25]: It 's entered , plain and regular , like an orderly-book ; not a word in it but what 's wanted for the facts .
Parsing [sent. 17545 len. 23]: I did intend to read it , straight on end , whensoever I was called upon to say anything in my defence .
Parsing [sent. 17546 len. 42]: I hope I may be let to do it still ; but I have no longer a will of my own in this case , and whatever is said or done , I give my promise not to have any . ''
Parsing [sent. 17547 len. 23]: Matters being brought to this so far satisfactory pass , and time being on the wane , Mrs. Bagnet proposes a departure .
Parsing [sent. 17548 len. 26]: Again and again the old lady hangs upon her son 's neck , and again and again the trooper holds her to his broad chest .

Parsing [sent. 17553 len. 8]: But of course I know you will .
Parsing [sent. 17554 len. 7]: Why should I ask it ! ''
Parsing [sent. 17555 len. 10]: Why indeed , Mrs. Bagnet expresses with the umbrella .

Parsing [sent. 17558 len. 26]: So saying , the trooper puts his lips to the old girl 's tanned forehead , and the door shuts upon him in his cell .

Parsing [sent. 17561 len. 52]: My Lady is in that room in which she held her last conference with the murdered man , and is sitting where she sat that night , and is looking at the spot where he stood upon the hearth studying her so leisurely , when a tap comes at the door .

Parsing [sent. 17567 len. 14]: Oh , my Lady , may I beg a word with you ? ''

Parsing [sent. 17571 len. 8]: Sit down and take your breath . ''

Parsing [sent. 17596 len. 25]: Night after night , as it has fallen dark , the sound has echoed through your rooms , but last night it was awfullest .

Parsing [sent. 17600 len. 3]: Hush ! ''
Parsing [sent. 17601 len. 53]: The housekeeper looks round and answers in a frightened whisper , `` My Lady , I have not breathed a word of it , I do n't believe what 's written in it , I know it ca n't be true , I am sure and certain that it is not true .

Parsing [sent. 17603 len. 58]: If you know of anything that is not known to others , if you have any suspicion , if you have any clue at all , and any reason for keeping it in your own breast , oh , my dear Lady , think of me , and conquer that reason , and let it be known !
Parsing [sent. 17604 len. 8]: This is the most I consider possible .
Parsing [sent. 17605 len. 61]: I know you are not a hard lady , but you go your own way always without help , and you are not familiar with your friends ; and all who admire you -- and all do -- as a beautiful and elegant lady , know you to be one far away from themselves who ca n't be approached close .
Parsing [sent. 17606 len. 58]: My Lady , you may have some proud or angry reasons for disdaining to utter something that you know ; if so , pray , oh , pray , think of a faithful servant whose whole life has been passed in this family which she dearly loves , and relent , and help to clear my son !
Parsing [sent. 17607 len. 86]: My Lady , my good Lady , '' the old housekeeper pleads with genuine simplicity , `` I am so humble in my place and you are by nature so high and distant that you may not think what I feel for my child , but I feel so much that I have come here to make so bold as to beg and pray you not to be scornful of us if you can do us any right or justice at this fearful time ! ''

Parsing [sent. 17615 len. 12]: The old housekeeper leaves her with the letter in her hand .
Parsing [sent. 17616 len. 37]: In truth she is not a hard lady naturally , and the time has been when the sight of the venerable figure suing to her with such strong earnestness would have moved her to great compassion .
Parsing [sent. 17617 len. 70]: But so long accustomed to suppress emotion and keep down reality , so long schooled for her own purposes in that destructive school which shuts up the natural feelings of the heart like flies in amber and spreads one uniform and dreary gloss over the good and bad , the feeling and the unfeeling , the sensible and the senseless , she had subdued even her wonder until now .
Parsing [sent. 17618 len. 5]: She opens the letter .
Parsing [sent. 17619 len. 45]: Spread out upon the paper is a printed account of the discovery of the body as it lay face downward on the floor , shot through the heart ; and underneath is written her own name , with the word `` murderess '' attached .
Parsing [sent. 17620 len. 7]: It falls out of her hand .
Parsing [sent. 17621 len. 35]: How long it may have lain upon the ground she knows not , but it lies where it fell when a servant stands before her announcing the young man of the name of Guppy .
Parsing [sent. 17622 len. 23]: The words have probably been repeated several times , for they are ringing in her head before she begins to understand them .
Parsing [sent. 17623 len. 7]: `` Let him come in ! ''
Parsing [sent. 17624 len. 4]: He comes in .
Parsing [sent. 17625 len. 22]: Holding the letter in her hand , which she has taken from the floor , she tries to collect her thoughts .
Parsing [sent. 17626 len. 23]: In the eyes of Mr. Guppy she is the same Lady Dedlock , holding the same prepared , proud , chilling state .
Parsing [sent. 17627 len. 81]: `` Your ladyship may not be at first disposed to excuse this visit from one who has never been welcome to your ladyship '' -- which he do n't complain of , for he is bound to confess that there never has been any particular reason on the face of things why he should be -- `` but I hope when I mention my motives to your ladyship you will not find fault with me , '' says Mr. Guppy .
Parsing [sent. 17628 len. 5]: `` Do so . ''
Parsing [sent. 17629 len. 5]: `` Thank your ladyship .
Parsing [sent. 17630 len. 104]: I ought first to explain to your ladyship , '' Mr. Guppy sits on the edge of a chair and puts his hat on the carpet at his feet , `` that Miss Summerson , whose image , as I formerly mentioned to your ladyship , was at one period of my life imprinted on my ` eart until erased by circumstances over which I had no control , communicated to me , after I had the pleasure of waiting on your ladyship last , that she particularly wished me to take no steps whatever in any manner at all relating to her .
Parsing [sent. 17631 len. 41]: And Miss Summerson 's wishes being to me a law -LRB- except as connected with circumstances over which I have no control -RRB- , I consequently never expected to have the distinguished honour of waiting on your ladyship again . ''
Parsing [sent. 17632 len. 13]: And yet he is here now , Lady Dedlock moodily reminds him .

Parsing [sent. 17634 len. 22]: `` My object being to communicate to your ladyship , under the seal of confidence , why I am here . ''
Parsing [sent. 17635 len. 16]: He can not do so , she tells him , too plainly or too briefly .

Parsing [sent. 17637 len. 14]: I have no interested views of my own to serve in coming here .
Parsing [sent. 17638 len. 41]: If it was not for my promise to Miss Summerson and my keeping of it sacred -- I , in point of fact , should n't have darkened these doors again , but should have seen 'em further first . ''
Parsing [sent. 17639 len. 16]: Mr. Guppy considers this a favourable moment for sticking up his hair with both hands .
Parsing [sent. 17640 len. 33]: `` Your ladyship will remember when I mention it that the last time I was here I run against a party very eminent in our profession and whose loss we all deplore .
Parsing [sent. 17641 len. 58]: That party certainly did from that time apply himself to cutting in against me in a way that I will call sharp practice , and did make it , at every turn and point , extremely difficult for me to be sure that I had n't inadvertently led up to something contrary to Miss Summerson 's wishes .
Parsing [sent. 17642 len. 24]: Self-praise is no recommendation , but I may say for myself that I am not so bad a man of business neither . ''
Parsing [sent. 17643 len. 9]: Lady Dedlock looks at him in stern inquiry .
Parsing [sent. 17644 len. 14]: Mr. Guppy immediately withdraws his eyes from her face and looks anywhere else .
Parsing [sent. 17645 len. 66]: `` Indeed , it has been made so hard , '' he goes on , `` to have any idea what that party was up to in combination with others that until the loss which we all deplore I was gravelled -- an expression which your ladyship , moving in the higher circles , will be so good as to consider tantamount to knocked over .
Parsing [sent. 17646 len. 49]: Small likewise -- a name by which I refer to another party , a friend of mine that your ladyship is not acquainted with -- got to be so close and double-faced that at times it was n't easy to keep one 's hands off his ` ead .
Parsing [sent. 17647 len. 69]: However , what with the exertion of my humble abilities , and what with the help of a mutual friend by the name of Mr. Tony Weevle -LRB- who is of a high aristocratic turn and has your ladyship 's portrait always hanging up in his room -RRB- , I have now reasons for an apprehension as to which I come to put your ladyship upon your guard .

Parsing [sent. 17667 len. 45]: In case I should be taking a liberty in putting your ladyship on your guard when there 's no necessity for it , you will endeavour , I should hope , to outlive my presumption , and I shall endeavour to outlive your disapprobation .
