Parsing [sent. 17674 len. 16]: Mercury proceeds to a description of them , which has been anticipated by Mr. Guppy .
Parsing [sent. 17675 len. 6]: Enough ; he may go .
Parsing [sent. 17676 len. 2]: So !
Parsing [sent. 17677 len. 5]: All is broken down .
Parsing [sent. 17678 len. 60]: Her name is in these many mouths , her husband knows his wrongs , her shame will be published -- may be spreading while she thinks about it -- and in addition to the thunderbolt so long foreseen by her , so unforeseen by him , she is denounced by an invisible accuser as the murderess of her enemy .
Parsing [sent. 17679 len. 17]: Her enemy he was , and she has often , often , often wished him dead .
Parsing [sent. 17680 len. 10]: Her enemy he is , even in his grave .
Parsing [sent. 17681 len. 15]: This dreadful accusation comes upon her like a new torment at his lifeless hand .
Parsing [sent. 17682 len. 50]: And when she recalls how she was secretly at his door that night , and how she may be represented to have sent her favourite girl away so soon before merely to release herself from observation , she shudders as if the hangman 's hands were at her neck .
Parsing [sent. 17683 len. 26]: She has thrown herself upon the floor and lies with her hair all wildly scattered and her face buried in the cushions of a couch .
Parsing [sent. 17684 len. 19]: She rises up , hurries to and fro , flings herself down again , and rocks and moans .
Parsing [sent. 17685 len. 9]: The horror that is upon her is unutterable .
Parsing [sent. 17686 len. 19]: If she really were the murderess , it could hardly be , for the moment , more intense .
Parsing [sent. 17687 len. 118]: For as her murderous perspective , before the doing of the deed , however subtle the precautions for its commission , would have been closed up by a gigantic dilatation of the hateful figure , preventing her from seeing any consequences beyond it ; and as those consequences would have rushed in , in an unimagined flood , the moment the figure was laid low -- which always happens when a murder is done ; so , now she sees that when he used to be on the watch before her , and she used to think , `` if some mortal stroke would but fall on this old man and take him from my way ! ''
Parsing [sent. 17688 len. 25]: it was but wishing that all he held against her in his hand might be flung to the winds and chance-sown in many places .
Parsing [sent. 17689 len. 15]: So , too , with the wicked relief she has felt in his death .
Parsing [sent. 17690 len. 31]: What was his death but the key-stone of a gloomy arch removed , and now the arch begins to fall in a thousand fragments , each crushing and mangling piecemeal !
Parsing [sent. 17691 len. 47]: Thus , a terrible impression steals upon and overshadows her that from this pursuer , living or dead -- obdurate and imperturbable before her in his well-remembered shape , or not more obdurate and imperturbable in his coffin-bed -- there is no escape but in death .
Parsing [sent. 17692 len. 5]: Hunted , she flies .
Parsing [sent. 17693 len. 39]: The complication of her shame , her dread , remorse , and misery , overwhelms her at its height ; and even her strength of self-reliance is overturned and whirled away like a leaf before a mighty wind .
Parsing [sent. 17694 len. 38]: She hurriedly addresses these lines to her husband , seals , and leaves them on her table : If I am sought for , or accused of , his murder , believe that I am wholly innocent .
Parsing [sent. 17695 len. 28]: Believe no other good of me , for I am innocent of nothing else that you have heard , or will hear , laid to my charge .
Parsing [sent. 17696 len. 18]: He prepared me , on that fatal night , for his disclosure of my guilt to you .
Parsing [sent. 17697 len. 62]: After he had left me , I went out on pretence of walking in the garden where I sometimes walk , but really to follow him and make one last petition that he would not protract the dreadful suspense on which I have been racked by him , you do not know how long , but would mercifully strike next morning .
Parsing [sent. 17698 len. 8]: I found his house dark and silent .
Parsing [sent. 17699 len. 18]: I rang twice at his door , but there was no reply , and I came home .
Parsing [sent. 17700 len. 6]: I have no home left .
Parsing [sent. 17701 len. 7]: I will encumber you no more .
Parsing [sent. 17702 len. 49]: May you , in your just resentment , be able to forget the unworthy woman on whom you have wasted a most generous devotion -- who avoids you only with a deeper shame than that with which she hurries from herself -- and who writes this last adieu .
Parsing [sent. 17703 len. 42]: She veils and dresses quickly , leaves all her jewels and her money , listens , goes downstairs at a moment when the hall is empty , opens and shuts the great door , flutters away in the shrill frosty wind .
Parsing [sent. 17704 len. 38]: Chapter LVI -- Pursuit Impassive , as behoves its high breeding , the Dedlock town house stares at the other houses in the street of dismal grandeur and gives no outward sign of anything going wrong within .
Parsing [sent. 17705 len. 53]: Carriages rattle , doors are battered at , the world exchanges calls ; ancient charmers with skeleton throats and peachy cheeks that have a rather ghastly bloom upon them seen by daylight , when indeed these fascinating creatures look like Death and the Lady fused together , dazzle the eyes of men .
Parsing [sent. 17706 len. 45]: Forth from the frigid mews come easily swinging carriages guided by short-legged coachmen in flaxen wigs , deep sunk into downy hammercloths , and up behind mount luscious Mercuries bearing sticks of state and wearing cocked hats broadwise , a spectacle for the angels .
Parsing [sent. 17707 len. 19]: The Dedlock town house changes not externally , and hours pass before its exalted dullness is disturbed within .
Parsing [sent. 17708 len. 37]: But Volumnia the fair , being subject to the prevalent complaint of boredom and finding that disorder attacking her spirits with some virulence , ventures at length to repair to the library for change of scene .
Parsing [sent. 17709 len. 25]: Her gentle tapping at the door producing no response , she opens it and peeps in ; seeing no one there , takes possession .
Parsing [sent. 17710 len. 50]: The sprightly Dedlock is reputed , in that grass-grown city of the ancients , Bath , to be stimulated by an urgent curiosity which impels her on all convenient and inconvenient occasions to sidle about with a golden glass at her eye , peering into objects of every description .
Parsing [sent. 17711 len. 64]: Certain it is that she avails herself of the present opportunity of hovering over her kinsman 's letters and papers like a bird , taking a short peck at this document and a blink with her head on one side at that document , and hopping about from table to table with her glass at her eye in an inquisitive and restless manner .
Parsing [sent. 17712 len. 31]: In the course of these researches she stumbles over something , and turning her glass in that direction , sees her kinsman lying on the ground like a felled tree .
Parsing [sent. 17713 len. 23]: Volumnia 's pet little scream acquires a considerable augmentation of reality from this surprise , and the house is quickly in commotion .
Parsing [sent. 17714 len. 30]: Servants tear up and down stairs , bells are violently rung , doctors are sent for , and Lady Dedlock is sought in all directions , but not found .
Parsing [sent. 17715 len. 13]: Nobody has seen or heard her since she last rang her bell .
Parsing [sent. 17716 len. 49]: Her letter to Sir Leicester is discovered on her table , but it is doubtful yet whether he has not received another missive from another world requiring to be personally answered , and all the living languages , and all the dead , are as one to him .
Parsing [sent. 17717 len. 31]: They lay him down upon his bed , and chafe , and rub , and fan , and put ice to his head , and try every means of restoration .
Parsing [sent. 17718 len. 37]: Howbeit , the day has ebbed away , and it is night in his room before his stertorous breathing lulls or his fixed eyes show any consciousness of the candle that is occasionally passed before them .
Parsing [sent. 17719 len. 32]: But when this change begins , it goes on ; and by and by he nods or moves his eyes or even his hand in token that he hears and comprehends .
Parsing [sent. 17720 len. 27]: He fell down , this morning , a handsome stately gentleman , somewhat infirm , but of a fine presence , and with a well-filled face .
Parsing [sent. 17721 len. 19]: He lies upon his bed , an aged man with sunken cheeks , the decrepit shadow of himself .
Parsing [sent. 17722 len. 42]: His voice was rich and mellow and he had so long been thoroughly persuaded of the weight and import to mankind of any word he said that his words really had come to sound as if there were something in them .
Parsing [sent. 17723 len. 22]: But now he can only whisper , and what he whispers sounds like what it is -- mere jumble and jargon .
Parsing [sent. 17724 len. 10]: His favourite and faithful housekeeper stands at his bedside .
Parsing [sent. 17725 len. 16]: It is the first act he notices , and he clearly derives pleasure from it .
Parsing [sent. 17726 len. 17]: After vainly trying to make himself understood in speech , he makes signs for a pencil .
Parsing [sent. 17727 len. 28]: So inexpressively that they can not at first understand him ; it is his old housekeeper who makes out what he wants and brings in a slate .
Parsing [sent. 17728 len. 24]: After pausing for some time , he slowly scrawls upon it in a hand that is not his , `` Chesney Wold ? ''
Parsing [sent. 17729 len. 11]: No , she tells him ; he is in London .
Parsing [sent. 17730 len. 10]: He was taken ill in the library this morning .
Parsing [sent. 17731 len. 19]: Right thankful she is that she happened to come to London and is able to attend upon him .
Parsing [sent. 17732 len. 14]: `` It is not an illness of any serious consequence , Sir Leicester .

Parsing [sent. 17734 len. 7]: All the gentlemen say so . ''
Parsing [sent. 17735 len. 12]: This , with the tears coursing down her fair old face .

Parsing [sent. 17738 len. 13]: He points again , in great agitation , at the two words .

Parsing [sent. 17744 len. 13]: She opens it for him and puts it out for his perusal .

Parsing [sent. 17747 len. 21]: The doctors know that he is best with her , and when not actively engaged about him , stand aloof .

Parsing [sent. 17755 len. 5]: That 's his meaning .

Parsing [sent. 17757 len. 5]: Shall he come up ?

Parsing [sent. 17759 len. 10]: It is speedily done , and Mr. Bucket appears .

Parsing [sent. 17771 len. 8]: Not a minute must be lost . ''
Parsing [sent. 17772 len. 21]: With the quickness of thought , he follows Sir Leicester Dedlock 's look towards a little box upon a table .
Parsing [sent. 17773 len. 11]: `` Bring it here , Sir Leicester Dedlock , Baronet ?
Parsing [sent. 17774 len. 2]: Certainly .
Parsing [sent. 17775 len. 9]: Open it with one of these here keys ?
Parsing [sent. 17776 len. 2]: Certainly .
Parsing [sent. 17777 len. 4]: The littlest key ?
Parsing [sent. 17778 len. 4]: TO be sure .
Parsing [sent. 17779 len. 5]: Take the notes out ?
Parsing [sent. 17780 len. 4]: So I will .
Parsing [sent. 17781 len. 3]: Count 'em ?
Parsing [sent. 17782 len. 5]: That 's soon done .
Parsing [sent. 17783 len. 23]: Twenty and thirty 's fifty , and twenty 's seventy , and fifty 's one twenty , and forty 's one sixty .
Parsing [sent. 17784 len. 5]: Take 'em for expenses ?
Parsing [sent. 17785 len. 12]: That I 'll do , and render an account of course .
Parsing [sent. 17786 len. 5]: Do n't spare money ?
Parsing [sent. 17787 len. 6]: No I wo n't . ''
Parsing [sent. 17788 len. 19]: The velocity and certainty of Mr. Bucket 's interpretation on all these heads is little short of miraculous .
Parsing [sent. 17789 len. 28]: Mrs. Rouncewell , who holds the light , is giddy with the swiftness of his eyes and hands as he starts up , furnished for his journey .
Parsing [sent. 17790 len. 21]: `` You 're George 's mother , old lady ; that 's about what you are , I believe ? ''
Parsing [sent. 17791 len. 15]: says Mr. Bucket aside , with his hat already on and buttoning his coat .
Parsing [sent. 17792 len. 12]: `` Yes , sir , I am his distressed mother . ''
Parsing [sent. 17793 len. 15]: `` So I thought , according to what he mentioned to me just now .
Parsing [sent. 17794 len. 10]: Well , then , I 'll tell you something .
Parsing [sent. 17795 len. 8]: You need n't be distressed no more .
Parsing [sent. 17796 len. 6]: Your son 's all right .
Parsing [sent. 17797 len. 35]: Now , do n't you begin a-crying , because what you 've got to do is to take care of Sir Leicester Dedlock , Baronet , and you wo n't do that by crying .
Parsing [sent. 17798 len. 28]: As to your son , he 's all right , I tell you ; and he sends his loving duty , and hoping you 're the same .
Parsing [sent. 17799 len. 38]: He 's discharged honourable ; that 's about what HE is ; with no more imputation on his character than there is on yours , and yours is a tidy one , I 'LL bet a pound .
Parsing [sent. 17800 len. 11]: You may trust me , for I took your son .
Parsing [sent. 17801 len. 52]: He conducted himself in a game way , too , on that occasion ; and he 's a fine-made man , and you 're a fine-made old lady , and you 're a mother and son , the pair of you , as might be showed for models in a caravan .
Parsing [sent. 17802 len. 18]: Sir Leicester Dedlock , Baronet , what you 've trusted to me I 'll go through with .
Parsing [sent. 17803 len. 40]: Do n't you be afraid of my turing out of my way , right or left , or taking a sleep , or a wash , or a shave till I have found what I go in search of .
Parsing [sent. 17804 len. 11]: Say everything as is kind and forgiving on your part ?
Parsing [sent. 17805 len. 9]: Sir Leicester Dedlock , Baronet , I will .
Parsing [sent. 17806 len. 37]: And I wish you better , and these family affairs smoothed over -- as , Lord , many other family affairs equally has been , and equally wlll be , to the end of time . ''
Parsing [sent. 17807 len. 32]: With this peroration , Mr. Bucket , buttoned up , goes quietly out , looking steadily before him as if he were already piercing the night in quest of the fugitive .
Parsing [sent. 17808 len. 26]: His first step is to take himself to Lady Dedlock 's rooms and look all over them for any trifling indication that may help him .
Parsing [sent. 17809 len. 63]: The rooms are in darkness now ; and to see Mr. Bucket with a wax-light in his hand , holding it above his head and taking a sharp mental inventory of the many delicate objects so curiously at variance with himself , would be to see a sight -- which nobody DOES see , as he is particular to lock himself in .

Parsing [sent. 17830 len. 54]: Mr. Bucket does not claim to be a scientific judge of horses , but he lays out a little money on the principal events in that line , and generally sums up his knowledge of the subject in the remark that when he sees a horse as can go , he knows him .
Parsing [sent. 17831 len. 11]: His knowledge is not at fault in the present instance .
Parsing [sent. 17832 len. 108]: Clattering over the stones at a dangerous pace , yet thoughtfully bringing his keen eyes to bear on every slinking creature whom he passes in the midnight streets , and even on the lights in upper windows where people are going or gone to bed , and on all the turnings that he rattles by , and alike on the heavy sky , and on the earth where the snow lies thin -- for something may present itself to assist him , anywhere -- he dashes to his destination at such a speed that when he stops the horse half smothers him in a cloud of steam .

Parsing [sent. 17844 len. 40]: Mr. Jarndyce , the only person up in the house , is just going to bed , rises from his book on hearing the rapid ringing at the bell , and comes down to the door in his dressing-gown .

Parsing [sent. 17852 len. 6]: Matter of life or death .

Parsing [sent. 17859 len. 6]: Run your eye over it .

Parsing [sent. 17864 len. 18]: Anyways , there 's more and more danger , every minute , of its drawing to that .

Parsing [sent. 17870 len. 44]: `` Now , Mr. Jarndyce '' -- Mr. Bucket has read his face with the greatest attention all along -- `` I speak to you as a gentleman of a humane heart , and under such pressing circumstances as do n't often happen .
Parsing [sent. 17871 len. 29]: If ever delay was dangerous , it 's dangerous now ; and if ever you could n't afterwards forgive yourself for causing it , this is the time .
Parsing [sent. 17872 len. 27]: Eight or ten hours , worth , as I tell you , a hundred pound apiece at least , have been lost since Lady Dedlock disappeared .
Parsing [sent. 17873 len. 7]: I am charged to find her .
Parsing [sent. 17874 len. 5]: I am Inspector Bucket .
Parsing [sent. 17875 len. 23]: Besides all the rest that 's heavy on her , she has upon her , as she believes , suspicion of murder .
Parsing [sent. 17876 len. 30]: If I follow her alone , she , being in ignorance of what Sir Leicester Dedlock , Baronet , has communicated to me , may be driven to desperation .
Parsing [sent. 17877 len. 49]: But if I follow her in company with a young lady , answering to the description of a young lady that she has a tenderness for -- I ask no question , and I say no more than that -- she will give me credit for being friendly .
Parsing [sent. 17878 len. 38]: Let me come up with her and be able to have the hold upon her of putting that young lady for ` ard , and I 'll save her and prevail with her if she is alive .
Parsing [sent. 17879 len. 31]: Let me come up with her alone -- a hard matter -- and I 'll do my best , but I do n't answer for what the best may be .
Parsing [sent. 17880 len. 11]: Time flies ; it 's getting on for one o'clock .
Parsing [sent. 17881 len. 24]: When one strikes , there 's another hour gone , and it 's worth a thousand pound now instead of a hundred . ''
Parsing [sent. 17882 len. 17]: This is all true , and the pressing nature of the case can not be questioned .
Parsing [sent. 17883 len. 14]: Mr. Jarndyce begs him to remain there while he speaks to Miss Summerson .
Parsing [sent. 17884 len. 28]: Mr. Bucket says he will , but acting on his usual principle , does no such thing , following upstairs instead and keeping his man in sight .
Parsing [sent. 17885 len. 18]: So he remains , dodging and lurking about in the gloom of the staircase while they confer .
Parsing [sent. 17886 len. 32]: In a very little time Mr. Jarndyce comes down and tells him that Miss Summerson will join him directly and place herself under his protection to accompany him where he pleases .
Parsing [sent. 17887 len. 16]: Mr. Bucket , satisfied , expresses high approval and awaits her coming at the door .
Parsing [sent. 17888 len. 16]: There he mounts a high tower in his mind and looks out far and wide .
Parsing [sent. 17889 len. 25]: Many solitary figures he perceives creeping through the streets ; many solitary figures out on heaths , and roads , and lying under haystacks .
Parsing [sent. 17890 len. 11]: But the figure that he seeks is not among them .
Parsing [sent. 17891 len. 51]: Other solitaries he perceives , in nooks of bridges , looking over ; and in shadowed places down by the river 's level ; and a dark , dark , shapeless object drifting with the tide , more solitary than all , clings with a drowning hold on his attention .
Parsing [sent. 17892 len. 4]: Where is she ?
Parsing [sent. 17893 len. 8]: Living or dead , where is she ?
Parsing [sent. 17894 len. 49]: If , as he folds the handkerchief and carefully puts it up , it were able with an enchanted power to bring before him the place where she found it and the night-landscape near the cottage where it covered the little child , would he descry her there ?
Parsing [sent. 17895 len. 103]: On the waste where the brick-kilns are burning with a pale blue flare , where the straw-roofs of the wretched huts in which the bricks are made are being scattered by the wind , where the clay and water are hard frozen and the mill in which the gaunt blind horse goes round all day looks like an instrument of human torture -- traversing this deserted , blighted spot there is a lonely figure with the sad world to itself , pelted by the snow and driven by the wind , and cast out , it would seem , from all companionship .
Parsing [sent. 17896 len. 36]: It is the figure of a woman , too ; but it is miserably dressed , and no such clothes ever came through the hall and out at the great door of the Dedlock mansion .
Parsing [sent. 17897 len. 32]: Chapter LVII -- Esther 's Narrative I had gone to bed and fallen asleep when my guardian knocked at the door of my room and begged me to get up directly .
Parsing [sent. 17898 len. 37]: On my hurrying to speak to him and learn what had happened , he told me , after a word or two of preparation , that there had been a discovery at Sir Leicester Dedlock 's .
Parsing [sent. 17899 len. 59]: That my mother had fled , that a person was now at our door who was empowered to convey to her the fullest assurances of affectionate protection and forgiveness if he could possibly find her , and that I was sought for to accompany him in the hope that my entreaties might prevail upon her if his failed .
Parsing [sent. 17900 len. 58]: Something to this general purpose I made out , but I was thrown into such a tumult of alarm , and hurry and distress , that in spite of every effort I could make to subdue my agitation , I did not seem , to myself , fully to recover my right mind until hours had passed .
Parsing [sent. 17901 len. 29]: But I dressed and wrapped up expeditiously without waking Charley or any one and went down to Mr. Bucket , who was the person entrusted with the secret .
Parsing [sent. 17902 len. 26]: In taking me to him my guardian told me this , and also explained how it was that he had come to think of me .
Parsing [sent. 17903 len. 57]: Mr. Bucket , in a low voice , by the light of my guardian 's candle , read to me in the hall a letter that my mother had left upon her table ; and I suppose within ten minutes of my having been aroused I was sitting beside him , rolling swiftly through the streets .
Parsing [sent. 17904 len. 40]: His manner was very keen , and yet considerate when he explained to me that a great deal might depend on my being able to answer , without confusion , a few questions that he wished to ask me .
Parsing [sent. 17905 len. 45]: These were , chiefly , whether I had had much communication with my mother -LRB- to whom he only referred as Lady Dedlock -RRB- , when and where I had spoken with her last , and how she had become possessed of my handkerchief .
Parsing [sent. 17906 len. 51]: When I had satisfied him on these points , he asked me particularly to consider -- taking time to think -- whether within my knowledge there was any one , no matter where , in whom she might be at all likely to confide under circumstances of the last necessity .
Parsing [sent. 17907 len. 10]: I could think of no one but my guardian .
Parsing [sent. 17908 len. 9]: But by and by I mentioned Mr. Boythorn .
Parsing [sent. 17909 len. 41]: He came into my mind as connected with his old chivalrous manner of mentioning my mother 's name and with what my guardian had informed me of his engagement to her sister and his unconscious connexion with her unhappy story .
Parsing [sent. 17910 len. 21]: My companion had stopped the driver while we held this conversation , that we might the better hear each other .
Parsing [sent. 17911 len. 33]: He now told him to go on again and said to me , after considering within himself for a few moments , that he had made up his mind how to proceed .
Parsing [sent. 17912 len. 23]: He was quite willing to tell me what his plan was , but I did not feel clear enough to understand it .
Parsing [sent. 17913 len. 24]: We had not driven very far from our lodgings when we stopped in a by-street at a public-looking place lighted up with gas .
Parsing [sent. 17914 len. 16]: Mr. Bucket took me in and sat me in an armchair by a bright fire .
Parsing [sent. 17915 len. 16]: It was now past one , as I saw by the clock against the wall .
Parsing [sent. 17916 len. 55]: Two police officers , looking in their perfectly neat uniform not at all like people who were up all night , were quietly writing at a desk ; and the place seemed very quiet altogether , except for some beating and calling out at distant doors underground , to which nobody paid any attention .
Parsing [sent. 17917 len. 38]: A third man in uniform , whom Mr. Bucket called and to whom he whispered his instructions , went out ; and then the two others advised together while one wrote from Mr. Bucket 's subdued dictation .
Parsing [sent. 17918 len. 31]: It was a description of my mother that they were busy with , for Mr. Bucket brought it to me when it was done and read it in a whisper .
Parsing [sent. 17919 len. 6]: It was very accurate indeed .
Parsing [sent. 17920 len. 42]: The second officer , who had attended to it closely , then copied it out and called in another man in uniform -LRB- there were several in an outer room -RRB- , who took it up and went away with it .
Parsing [sent. 17921 len. 23]: All this was done with the greatest dispatch and without the waste of a moment ; yet nobody was at all hurried .
Parsing [sent. 17922 len. 27]: As soon as the paper was sent out upon its travels , the two officers resumed their former quiet work of writing with neatness and care .
Parsing [sent. 17923 len. 23]: Mr. Bucket thoughtfully came and warmed the soles of his boots , first one and then the other , at the fire .
Parsing [sent. 17924 len. 11]: `` Are you well wrapped up , Miss Summerson ? ''
Parsing [sent. 17925 len. 9]: he asked me as his eyes met mine .
Parsing [sent. 17926 len. 17]: `` It 's a desperate sharp night for a young lady to be out in . ''
Parsing [sent. 17927 len. 13]: I told him I cared for no weather and was warmly clothed .
Parsing [sent. 17928 len. 26]: `` It may be a long job , '' he observed ; `` but so that it ends well , never mind , miss . ''
Parsing [sent. 17929 len. 11]: `` I pray to heaven it may end well ! ''
Parsing [sent. 17930 len. 3]: said I .
Parsing [sent. 17931 len. 4]: He nodded comfortingly .
Parsing [sent. 17932 len. 16]: `` You see , whatever you do , do n't you go and fret yourself .
Parsing [sent. 17933 len. 43]: You keep yourself cool and equal for anything that may happen , and it 'll be the better for you , the better for me , the better for Lady Dedlock , and the better for Sir Leicester Dedlock , Baronet . ''
Parsing [sent. 17934 len. 37]: He was really very kind and gentle , and as he stood before the fire warming his boots and rubbing his face with his forefinger , I felt a confidence in his sagacity which reassured me .
Parsing [sent. 17935 len. 18]: It was not yet a quarter to two when I heard horses ' feet and wheels outside .
Parsing [sent. 17936 len. 20]: `` Now , Miss Summerson , '' said he , `` we are off , if you please ! ''
Parsing [sent. 17937 len. 32]: He gave me his arm , and the two officers courteously bowed me out , and we found at the door a phaeton or barouche with a postilion and post horses .
Parsing [sent. 17938 len. 14]: Mr. Bucket handed me in and took his own seat on the box .
Parsing [sent. 17939 len. 39]: The man in uniform whom he had sent to fetch this equipage then handed him up a dark lantern at his request , and when he had given a few directions to the driver , we rattled away .
Parsing [sent. 17940 len. 13]: I was far from sure that I was not in a dream .
Parsing [sent. 17941 len. 65]: We rattled with great rapidity through such a labyrinth of streets that I soon lost all idea where we were , except that we had crossed and re-crossed the river , and still seemed to be traversing a low-lying , waterside , dense neighbourhood of narrow thoroughfares chequered by docks and basins , high piles of warehouses , swing-bridges , and masts of ships .
Parsing [sent. 17942 len. 56]: At length we stopped at the corner of a little slimy turning , which the wind from the river , rushing up it , did not purify ; and I saw my companion , by the light of his lantern , in conference with several men who looked like a mixture of police and sailors .
Parsing [sent. 17943 len. 49]: Against the mouldering wall by which they stood , there was a bill , on which I could discern the words , `` Found Drowned '' ; and this and an inscription about drags possessed me with the awful suspicion shadowed forth in our visit to that place .
Parsing [sent. 17944 len. 39]: I had no need to remind myself that I was not there by the indulgence of any feeling of mine to increase the difficulties of the search , or to lessen its hopes , or enhance its delays .
Parsing [sent. 17945 len. 17]: I remained quiet , but what I suffered in that dreadful spot I never can forget .
Parsing [sent. 17946 len. 11]: And still it was like the horror of a dream .
Parsing [sent. 17947 len. 53]: A man yet dark and muddy , in long swollen sodden boots and a hat like them , was called out of a boat and whispered with Mr. Bucket , who went away with him down some slippery steps -- as if to look at something secret that he had to show .
Parsing [sent. 17948 len. 27]: They came back , wiping their hands upon their coats , after turning over something wet ; but thank God it was not what I feared !
Parsing [sent. 17949 len. 46]: After some further conference , Mr. Bucket -LRB- whom everybody seemed to know and defer to -RRB- went in with the others at a door and left me in the carriage , while the driver walked up and down by his horses to warm himself .
Parsing [sent. 17950 len. 34]: The tide was coming in , as I judged from the sound it made , and I could hear it break at the end of the alley with a little rush towards me .
Parsing [sent. 17951 len. 53]: It never did so -- and I thought it did so , hundreds of times , in what can have been at the most a quarter of an hour , and probably was less -- but the thought shuddered through me that it would cast my mother at the horses ' feet .
Parsing [sent. 17952 len. 24]: Mr. Bucket came out again , exhorting the others to be vigilant , darkened his lantern , and once more took his seat .
Parsing [sent. 17953 len. 26]: `` Do n't you be alarmed , Miss Summerson , on account of our coming down here , '' he said , turning to me .
Parsing [sent. 17954 len. 23]: `` I only want to have everything in train and to know that it is in train by looking after it myself .
Parsing [sent. 17955 len. 7]: Get on , my lad ! ''
Parsing [sent. 17956 len. 10]: We appeared to retrace the way we had come .
Parsing [sent. 17957 len. 27]: Not that I had taken note of any particular objects in my perturbed state of mind , but judging from the general character of the streets .
Parsing [sent. 17958 len. 16]: We called at another office or station for a minute and crossed the river again .
Parsing [sent. 17959 len. 52]: During the whole of this time , and during the whole search , my companion , wrapped up on the box , never relaxed in his vigilance a single moment ; but when we crossed the bridge he seemed , if possible , to be more on the alert than before .
Parsing [sent. 17960 len. 45]: He stood up to look over the parapet , he alighted and went back after a shadowy female figure that flitted past us , and he gazed into the profound black pit of water with a face that made my heart die within me .
Parsing [sent. 17961 len. 43]: The river had a fearful look , so overcast and secret , creeping away so fast between the low flat lines of shore -- so heavy with indistinct and awful shapes , both of substance and shadow ; so death-like and mysterious .
Parsing [sent. 17962 len. 25]: I have seen it many times since then , by sunlight and by moonlight , but never free from the impressions of that journey .
Parsing [sent. 17963 len. 56]: In my memory the lights upon the bridge are always burning dim , the cutting wind is eddying round the homeless woman whom we pass , the monotonous wheels are whirling on , and the light of the carriage-lamps reflected back looks palely in upon me -- a face rising out of the dreaded water .
Parsing [sent. 17964 len. 29]: Clattering and clattering through the empty streets , we came at length from the pavement on to dark smooth roads and began to leave the houses behind us .
Parsing [sent. 17965 len. 12]: After a while I recognized the familiar way to Saint Albans .
Parsing [sent. 17966 len. 16]: At Barnet fresh horses were ready for us , and we changed and went on .
Parsing [sent. 17967 len. 21]: It was very cold indeed , and the open country was white with snow , though none was falling then .
Parsing [sent. 17968 len. 19]: `` An old acquaintance of yours , this road , Miss Summerson , '' said Mr. Bucket cheerfully .
Parsing [sent. 17969 len. 7]: `` Yes , '' I returned .
Parsing [sent. 17970 len. 8]: `` Have you gathered any intelligence ? ''
Parsing [sent. 17971 len. 25]: `` None that can be quite depended on as yet , '' he answered , `` but it 's early times as yet . ''
Parsing [sent. 17972 len. 43]: He had gone into every late or early public-house where there was a light -LRB- they were not a few at that time , the road being then much frequented by drovers -RRB- and had got down to talk to the turnpike-keepers .
Parsing [sent. 17973 len. 59]: I had heard him ordering drink , and chinking money , and making himself agreeable and merry everywhere ; but whenever he took his seat upon the box again , his face resumed its watchful steady look , and he always said to the driver in the same business tone , `` Get on , my lad ! ''
Parsing [sent. 17974 len. 41]: With all these stoppages , it was between five and six o'clock and we were yet a few miles short of Saint Albans when he came out of one of these houses and handed me in a cup of tea .
Parsing [sent. 17975 len. 13]: `` Drink it , Miss Summerson , it 'll do you good .
Parsing [sent. 17976 len. 14]: You 're beginning to get more yourself now , ai n't you ? ''
Parsing [sent. 17977 len. 9]: I thanked him and said I hoped so .
Parsing [sent. 17978 len. 22]: `` You was what you may call stunned at first , '' he returned ; `` and Lord , no wonder !
Parsing [sent. 17979 len. 8]: Do n't speak loud , my dear .
Parsing [sent. 17980 len. 5]: It 's all right .
Parsing [sent. 17981 len. 6]: She 's on ahead . ''
Parsing [sent. 17982 len. 26]: I do n't know what joyful exclamation I made or was going to make , but he put up his finger and I stopped myself .
Parsing [sent. 17983 len. 13]: `` Passed through here on foot this evening about eight or nine .

Parsing [sent. 18227 len. 7]: Such roads I had never seen .
Parsing [sent. 18228 len. 18]: I sometimes feared we had missed the way and got into the ploughed grounds or the marshes .
Parsing [sent. 18229 len. 46]: If I ever thought of the time I had been out , it presented itself as an indefinite period of great duration , and I seemed , in a strange way , never to have been free from the anxiety under which I then laboured .
Parsing [sent. 18230 len. 15]: As we advanced , I began to feel misgivings that my companion lost confidence .
Parsing [sent. 18231 len. 25]: He was the same as before with all the roadside people , but he looked graver when he sat by himself on the box .
Parsing [sent. 18232 len. 20]: I saw his finger uneasily going across and across his mouth during the whole of one long weary stage .
Parsing [sent. 18233 len. 32]: I overheard that he began to ask the drivers of coaches and other vehicles coming towards us what passengers they had seen in other coaches and vehicles that were in advance .
Parsing [sent. 18234 len. 7]: Their replies did not encourage him .
Parsing [sent. 18235 len. 40]: He always gave me a reassuring beck of his finger and lift of his eyelid as he got upon the box again , but he seemed perplexed now when he said , `` Get on , my lad ! ''
Parsing [sent. 18236 len. 29]: At last , when we were changing , he told me that he had lost the track of the dress so long that he began to be surprised .
Parsing [sent. 18237 len. 48]: It was nothing , he said , to lose such a track for one while , and to take it up for another while , and so on ; but it had disappeared here in an unaccountable manner , and we had not come upon it since .
Parsing [sent. 18238 len. 38]: This corroborated the apprehensions I had formed , when he began to look at direction-posts , and to leave the carriage at cross roads for a quarter of an hour at a time while he explored them .
Parsing [sent. 18239 len. 29]: But I was not to be down-hearted , he told me , for it was as likely as not that the next stage might set us right again .
Parsing [sent. 18240 len. 18]: The next stage , however , ended as that one ended ; we had no new clue .
Parsing [sent. 18241 len. 64]: There was a spacious inn here , solitary , but a comfortable substantial building , and as we drove in under a large gateway before I knew it , where a landlady and her pretty daughters came to the carriage-door , entreating me to alight and refresh myself while the horses were making ready , I thought it would be uncharitable to refuse .
Parsing [sent. 18242 len. 13]: They took me upstairs to a warm room and left me there .
Parsing [sent. 18243 len. 16]: It was at the corner of the house , I remember , looking two ways .
Parsing [sent. 18244 len. 53]: On one side to a stable-yard open to a by-road , where the ostlers were unharnessing the splashed and tired horses from the muddy carriage , and beyond that to the by-road itself , across which the sign was heavily swinging ; on the other side to a wood of dark pine-trees .
Parsing [sent. 18245 len. 22]: Their branches were encumbered with snow , and it silently dropped off in wet heaps while I stood at the window .
Parsing [sent. 18246 len. 24]: Night was setting in , and its bleakness was enhanced by the contrast of the pictured fire glowing and gleaming in the window-pane .
Parsing [sent. 18247 len. 58]: As I looked among the stems of the trees and followed the discoloured marks in the snow where the thaw was sinking into it and undermining it , I thought of the motherly face brightly set off by daughters that had just now welcomed me and of MY mother lying down in such a wood to die .
Parsing [sent. 18248 len. 34]: I was frightened when I found them all about me , but I remembered that before I fainted I tried very hard not to do it ; and that was some little comfort .
Parsing [sent. 18249 len. 33]: They cushioned me up on a large sofa by the fire , and then the comely landlady told me that I must travel no further to-night , but must go to bed .
Parsing [sent. 18250 len. 30]: But this put me into such a tremble lest they should detain me there that she soon recalled her words and compromised for a rest of half an hour .
Parsing [sent. 18251 len. 7]: A good endearing creature she was .
Parsing [sent. 18252 len. 13]: She and her three fair girls , all so busy about me .
Parsing [sent. 18253 len. 46]: I was to take hot soup and broiled fowl , while Mr. Bucket dried himself and dined elsewhere ; but I could not do it when a snug round table was presently spread by the fireside , though I was very unwilling to disappoint them .
Parsing [sent. 18254 len. 25]: However , I could take some toast and some hot negus , and as I really enjoyed that refreshment , it made some recompense .
Parsing [sent. 18255 len. 45]: Punctual to the time , at the half-hour 's end the carriage came rumbling under the gateway , and they took me down , warmed , refreshed , comforted by kindness , and safe -LRB- I assured them -RRB- not to faint any more .
Parsing [sent. 18256 len. 51]: After I had got in and had taken a grateful leave of them all , the youngest daughter -- a blooming girl of nineteen , who was to be the first married , they had told me -- got upon the carriage step , reached in , and kissed me .
Parsing [sent. 18257 len. 22]: I have never seen her , from that hour , but I think of her to this hour as my friend .
Parsing [sent. 18258 len. 37]: The transparent windows with the fire and light , looking so bright and warm from the cold darkness out of doors , were soon gone , and again we were crushing and churning the loose snow .
Parsing [sent. 18259 len. 28]: We went on with toil enough , but the dismal roads were not much worse than they had been , and the stage was only nine miles .
Parsing [sent. 18260 len. 60]: My companion smoking on the box -- I had thought at the last inn of begging him to do so when I saw him standing at a great fire in a comfortable cloud of tobacco -- was as vigilant as ever and as quickly down and up again when we came to any human abode or any human creature .
Parsing [sent. 18261 len. 43]: He had lighted his little dark lantern , which seemed to be a favourite with him , for we had lamps to the carriage ; and every now and then he turned it upon me to see that I was doing well .
Parsing [sent. 18262 len. 22]: There was a folding-window to the carriage-head , but I never closed it , for it seemed like shutting out hope .

Parsing [sent. 18324 len. 31]: Chapter LVIII -- A Wintry Day and Night Still impassive , as behoves its breeding , the Dedlock town house carries itself as usual towards the street of dismal grandeur .
Parsing [sent. 18325 len. 54]: There are powdered heads from time to time in the little windows of the hall , looking out at the untaxed powder falling all day from the sky ; and in the same conservatory there is peach blossom turning itself exotically to the great hall fire from the nipping weather out of doors .
Parsing [sent. 18326 len. 20]: It is given out that my Lady has gone down into Lincolnshire , but is expected to return presently .
Parsing [sent. 18327 len. 14]: Rumour , busy overmuch , however , will not go down into Lincolnshire .
Parsing [sent. 18328 len. 9]: It persists in flitting and chattering about town .
Parsing [sent. 18329 len. 16]: It knows that that poor unfortunate man , Sir Leicester , has been sadly used .
Parsing [sent. 18330 len. 13]: It hears , my dear child , all sorts of shocking things .
Parsing [sent. 18331 len. 11]: It makes the world of five miles round quite merry .
Parsing [sent. 18332 len. 18]: Not to know that there is something wrong at the Dedlocks ' is to augur yourself unknown .
Parsing [sent. 18333 len. 35]: One of the peachy-cheeked charmers with the skeleton throats is already apprised of all the principal circumstances that will come out before the Lords on Sir Leicester 's application for a bill of divorce .
Parsing [sent. 18334 len. 36]: At Blaze and Sparkle 's the jewellers and at Sheen and Gloss 's the mercers , it is and will be for several hours the topic of the age , the feature of the century .
Parsing [sent. 18335 len. 41]: The patronesses of those establishments , albeit so loftily inscrutable , being as nicely weighed and measured there as any other article of the stock-in-trade , are perfectly understood in this new fashion by the rawest hand behind the counter .
Parsing [sent. 18336 len. 33]: `` Our people , Mr. Jones , '' said Blaze and Sparkle to the hand in question on engaging him , `` our people , sir , are sheep -- mere sheep .
Parsing [sent. 18337 len. 13]: Where two or three marked ones go , all the rest follow .
Parsing [sent. 18338 len. 19]: Keep those two or three in your eye , Mr. Jones , and you have the flock . ''
Parsing [sent. 18339 len. 36]: So , likewise , Sheen and Gloss to THEIR Jones , in reference to knowing where to have the fashionable people and how to bring what they -LRB- Sheen and Gloss -RRB- choose into fashion .
Parsing [sent. 18340 len. 48]: On similar unerring principles , Mr. Sladdery the librarian , and indeed the great farmer of gorgeous sheep , admits this very day , `` Why yes , sir , there certainly ARE reports concerning Lady Dedlock , very current indeed among my high connexion , sir .
Parsing [sent. 18341 len. 40]: You see , my high connexion must talk about something , sir ; and it 's only to get a subject into vogue with one or two ladies I could name to make it go down with the whole .
Parsing [sent. 18342 len. 52]: Just what I should have done with those ladies , sir , in the case of any novelty you had left to me to bring in , they have done of themselves in this case through knowing Lady Dedlock and being perhaps a little innocently jealous of her too , sir .
Parsing [sent. 18343 len. 18]: You 'll find , sir , that this topic will be very popular among my high connexion .
Parsing [sent. 18344 len. 15]: If it had been a speculation , sir , it would have brought money .
Parsing [sent. 18345 len. 43]: And when I say so , you may trust to my being right , sir , for I have made it my business to study my high connexion and to be able to wind it up like a clock , sir . ''
Parsing [sent. 18346 len. 15]: Thus rumour thrives in the capital , and will not go down into Lincolnshire .
Parsing [sent. 18347 len. 45]: By half-past five , post meridian , Horse Guards ' time , it has even elicited a new remark from the Honourable Mr. Stables , which bids fair to outshine the old one , on which he has so long rested his colloquial reputation .
Parsing [sent. 18348 len. 30]: This sparkling sally is to the effect that although he always knew she was the best-groomed woman in the stud , he had no idea she was a bolter .
Parsing [sent. 18349 len. 7]: It is immensely received in turf-circles .
Parsing [sent. 18350 len. 28]: At feasts and festivals also , in firmaments she has often graced , and among constellations she outshone but yesterday , she is still the prevalent subject .
Parsing [sent. 18351 len. 4]: What is it ?

Parsing [sent. 18356 len. 38]: She is discussed by her dear friends with all the genteelest slang in vogue , with the last new word , the last new manner , the last new drawl , and the perfection of polite indifference .
Parsing [sent. 18357 len. 32]: A remarkable feature of the theme is that it is found to be so inspiring that several people come out upon it who never came out before -- positively say things !
Parsing [sent. 18358 len. 73]: William Buffy carries one of these smartnesses from the place where he dines down to the House , where the Whip for his party hands it about with his snuff-box to keep men together who want to be off , with such effect that the Speaker -LRB- who has had it privately insinuated into his own ear under the corner of his wig -RRB- cries , `` Order at the bar ! ''
Parsing [sent. 18359 len. 7]: three times without making an impression .
Parsing [sent. 18360 len. 108]: And not the least amazing circumstance connected with her being vaguely the town talk is that people hovering on the confines of Mr. Sladdery 's high connexion , people who know nothing and ever did know nothing about her , think it essential to their reputation to pretend that she is their topic too , and to retail her at second-hand with the last new word and the last new manner , and the last new drawl , and the last new polite indifference , and all the rest of it , all at second-hand but considered equal to new in inferior systems and to fainter stars .
Parsing [sent. 18361 len. 31]: If there be any man of letters , art , or science among these little dealers , how noble in him to support the feeble sisters on such majestic crutches !
Parsing [sent. 18362 len. 10]: So goes the wintry day outside the Dedlock mansion .
Parsing [sent. 18363 len. 4]: How within it ?
Parsing [sent. 18364 len. 19]: Sir Leicester , lying in his bed , can speak a little , though with difficulty and indistinctness .

Parsing [sent. 18366 len. 17]: He is never asleep , though sometimes he seems to fall into a dull waking doze .

Parsing [sent. 18374 len. 13]: He began to look at them as soon as it was light .

Parsing [sent. 18402 len. 44]: Rooms get an awful look about them when they are fitted up , like these , for one person you are used to see in them , and that person is away under any shadow , let alone being God knows where . ''
Parsing [sent. 18403 len. 6]: He is not far out .
Parsing [sent. 18404 len. 33]: As all partings foreshadow the great final one , so , empty rooms , bereft of a familiar presence , mournfully whisper what your room and what mine must one day be .
Parsing [sent. 18405 len. 61]: My Lady 's state has a hollow look , thus gloomy and abandoned ; and in the inner apartment , where Mr. Bucket last night made his secret perquisition , the traces of her dresses and her ornaments , even the mirrors accustomed to reflect them when they were a portion of herself , have a desolate and vacant air .
Parsing [sent. 18406 len. 77]: Dark and cold as the wintry day is , it is darker and colder in these deserted chambers than in many a hut that will barely exclude the weather ; and though the servants heap fires in the grates and set the couches and the chairs within the warm glass screens that let their ruddy light shoot through to the furthest corners , there is a heavy cloud upon the rooms which no light will dispel .
Parsing [sent. 18407 len. 19]: The old housekeeper and her son remain until the preparations are complete , and then she returns upstairs .
Parsing [sent. 18408 len. 35]: Volumnia has taken Mrs. Rouncewell 's place in the meantime , though pearl necklaces and rouge pots , however calculated to embellish Bath , are but indifferent comforts to the invalid under present circumstances .
Parsing [sent. 18409 len. 68]: Volumnia , not being supposed to know -LRB- and indeed not knowing -RRB- what is the matter , has found it a ticklish task to offer appropriate observations and consequently has supplied their place with distracting smoothings of the bed-linen , elaborate locomotion on tiptoe , vigilant peeping at her kinsman 's eyes , and one exasperating whisper to herself of , `` He is asleep . ''
Parsing [sent. 18410 len. 21]: In disproof of which superfluous remark Sir Leicester has indignantly written on the slate , `` I am not . ''
Parsing [sent. 18411 len. 27]: Yielding , therefore , the chair at the bedside to the quaint old housekeeper , Volumnia sits at a table a little removed , sympathetically sighing .
Parsing [sent. 18412 len. 17]: Sir Leicester watches the sleet and snow and listens for the returning steps that he expects .
Parsing [sent. 18413 len. 46]: In the ears of his old servant , looking as if she had stepped out of an old picture-frame to attend a summoned Dedlock to another world , the silence is fraught with echoes of her own words , `` who will tell him ! ''
Parsing [sent. 18414 len. 26]: He has been under his valet 's hands this morning to be made presentable and is as well got up as the circumstances will allow .
Parsing [sent. 18415 len. 33]: He is propped with pillows , his grey hair is brushed in its usual manner , his linen is arranged to a nicety , and he is wrapped in a responsible dressing-gown .
Parsing [sent. 18416 len. 11]: His eye-glass and his watch are ready to his hand .
Parsing [sent. 18417 len. 32]: It is necessary -- less to his own dignity now perhaps than for her sake -- that he should be seen as little disturbed and as much himself as may be .
Parsing [sent. 18418 len. 16]: Women will talk , and Volumnia , though a Dedlock , is no exceptional case .
Parsing [sent. 18419 len. 17]: He keeps her here , there is little doubt , to prevent her talking somewhere else .
Parsing [sent. 18420 len. 20]: He is very ill , but he makes his present stand against distress of mind and body most courageously .
Parsing [sent. 18421 len. 40]: The fair Volumnia , being one of those sprightly girls who can not long continue silent without imminent peril of seizure by the dragon Boredom , soon indicates the approach of that monster with a series of undisguisable yawns .
Parsing [sent. 18422 len. 74]: Finding it impossible to suppress those yawns by any other process than conversation , she compliments Mrs. Rouncewell on her son , declaring that he positively is one of the finest figures she ever saw and as soldierly a looking person , she should think , as what 's his name , her favourite Life Guardsman -- the man she dotes on , the dearest of creatures -- who was killed at Waterloo .
Parsing [sent. 18423 len. 27]: Sir Leicester hears this tribute with so much surprise and stares about him in such a confused way that Mrs. Rouncewell feels it necesary to explain .
Parsing [sent. 18424 len. 18]: `` Miss Dedlock do n't speak of my eldest son , Sir Leicester , but my youngest .
Parsing [sent. 18425 len. 5]: I have found him .
Parsing [sent. 18426 len. 6]: He has come home . ''
Parsing [sent. 18427 len. 9]: Sir Leicester breaks silence with a harsh cry .

Parsing [sent. 18430 len. 7]: The old housekeeper wipes her eyes .

Parsing [sent. 18432 len. 6]: Yes , Sir Leicester . ''
Parsing [sent. 18433 len. 28]: Does this discovery of some one lost , this return of some one so long gone , come upon him as a strong confirmation of his hopes ?
Parsing [sent. 18434 len. 36]: Does he think , `` Shall I not , with the aid I have , recall her safely after this , there being fewer hours in her case than there are years in his ? ''
Parsing [sent. 18435 len. 19]: It is of no use entreating him ; he is determined to speak now , and he does .
