Parsing [sent. 18439 len. 33]: Besides , the giddy Volumnia now remembers with her little scream that nobody was to have known of his being Mrs. Rouncewell 's son and that she was not to have told .
Parsing [sent. 18440 len. 29]: But Mrs. Rouncewell protests , with warmth enough to swell the stomacher , that of course she would have told Sir Leicester as soon as he got better .
Parsing [sent. 18441 len. 11]: `` Where is your son George , Mrs. Rouncewell ? ''
Parsing [sent. 18442 len. 25]: asks Sir Leicester , Mrs. Rouncewell , not a little alarmed by his disregard of the doctor 's injunctions , replies , in London .
Parsing [sent. 18443 len. 6]: `` Where in London ? ''
Parsing [sent. 18444 len. 13]: Mrs. Rouncewell is constrained to admit that he is in the house .
Parsing [sent. 18445 len. 8]: `` Bring him here to my room .
Parsing [sent. 18446 len. 5]: Bring him directly . ''
Parsing [sent. 18447 len. 13]: The old lady can do nothing but go in search of him .
Parsing [sent. 18448 len. 20]: Sir Leicester , with such power of movement as he has , arranges himself a little to receive him .
Parsing [sent. 18449 len. 24]: When he has done so , he looks out again at the falling sleet and snow and listens again for the returning steps .
Parsing [sent. 18450 len. 31]: A quantity of straw has been tumbled down in the street to deaden the noises there , and she might be driven to the door perhaps without his hearing wheels .
Parsing [sent. 18451 len. 25]: He is lying thus , apparently forgetful of his newer and minor surprise , when the housekeeper returns , accompanied by her trooper son .
Parsing [sent. 18452 len. 30]: Mr. George approaches softly to the bedside , makes his bow , squares his chest , and stands , with his face flushed , very heartily ashamed of himself .
Parsing [sent. 18453 len. 12]: `` Good heaven , and it is really George Rouncewell ! ''
Parsing [sent. 18454 len. 4]: exclaims Sir Leicester .
Parsing [sent. 18455 len. 9]: `` Do you remember me , George ? ''
Parsing [sent. 18456 len. 60]: The trooper needs to look at him and to separate this sound from that sound before he knows what he has said , but doing this and being a little helped by his mother , he replies , `` I must have a very bad memory , indeed , Sir Leicester , if I failed to remember you . ''
Parsing [sent. 18457 len. 36]: `` When I look at you , George Rouncewell , '' Sir Leicester observes with difficulty , `` I see something of a boy at Chesney Wold -- I remember well -- very well . ''
Parsing [sent. 18458 len. 23]: He looks at the trooper until tears come into his eyes , and then he looks at the sleet and snow again .
Parsing [sent. 18459 len. 27]: `` I ask your pardon , Sir Leicester , '' says the trooper , `` but would you accept of my arms to raise you up ?
Parsing [sent. 18460 len. 18]: You would lie easier , Sir Leicester , if you would allow me to move you . ''
Parsing [sent. 18461 len. 16]: `` If you please , George Rouncewell ; if you will be so good . ''
Parsing [sent. 18462 len. 26]: The trooper takes him in his arms like a child , lightly raises him , and turns him with his face more towards the window .
Parsing [sent. 18463 len. 4]: `` Thank you .
Parsing [sent. 18464 len. 18]: You have your mother 's gentleness , '' returns Sir Leicester , `` and your own strength .
Parsing [sent. 18465 len. 4]: Thank you . ''
Parsing [sent. 18466 len. 12]: He signs to him with his hand not to go away .
Parsing [sent. 18467 len. 13]: George quietly remains at the bedside , waiting to be spoken to .
Parsing [sent. 18468 len. 9]: `` Why did you wish for secrecy ? ''
Parsing [sent. 18469 len. 10]: It takes Sir Leicester some time to ask this .
Parsing [sent. 18470 len. 55]: `` Truly I am not much to boast of , Sir Leicester , and I -- I should still , Sir Leicester , if you was not so indisposed -- which I hope you will not be long -- I should still hope for the favour of being allowed to remain unknown in general .
Parsing [sent. 18471 len. 24]: That involves explanations not very hard to be guessed at , not very well timed here , and not very creditable to myself .
Parsing [sent. 18472 len. 32]: However opinions may differ on a variety of subjects , I should think it would be universally agreed , Sir Leicester , that I am not much to boast of . ''
Parsing [sent. 18473 len. 19]: `` You have been a soldier , '' observes Sir Leicester , `` and a faithful one . ''
Parsing [sent. 18474 len. 6]: George makes his military how .
Parsing [sent. 18475 len. 28]: `` As far as that goes , Sir Leicester , I have done my duty under discipline , and it was the least I could do . ''
Parsing [sent. 18476 len. 27]: `` You find me , '' says Sir Leicester , whose eyes are much attracted towards him , `` far from well , George Rouncewell . ''
Parsing [sent. 18477 len. 18]: `` I am very sorry both to hear it and to see it , Sir Leicester . ''
Parsing [sent. 18478 len. 7]: `` I am sure you are .
Parsing [sent. 18479 len. 2]: No .
Parsing [sent. 18480 len. 16]: In addition to my older malady , I have had a sudden and bad attack .
Parsing [sent. 18481 len. 25]: Something that deadens , '' making an endeavour to pass one hand down one side , `` and confuses , '' touching his lips .
Parsing [sent. 18482 len. 14]: George , with a look of assent and sympathy , makes another bow .
Parsing [sent. 18483 len. 36]: The different times when they were both young men -LRB- the trooper much the younger of the two -RRB- and looked at one another down at Chesney Wold arise before them both and soften both .
Parsing [sent. 18484 len. 38]: Sir Leicester , evidently with a great determination to say , in his own manner , something that is on his mind before relapsing into silence , tries to raise himself among his pillows a little more .
Parsing [sent. 18485 len. 22]: George , observant of the action , takes him in his arms again and places him as he desires to be .
Parsing [sent. 18486 len. 6]: `` Thank you , George .
Parsing [sent. 18487 len. 7]: You are another self to me .
Parsing [sent. 18488 len. 13]: You have often carried my spare gun at Chesney Wold , George .
Parsing [sent. 18489 len. 14]: You are familiar to me in these strange circumstances , very familiar . ''
Parsing [sent. 18490 len. 32]: He has put Sir Leicester 's sounder arm over his shoulder in lifting him up , and Sir Leicester is slow in drawing it away again as he says these words .
Parsing [sent. 18491 len. 39]: `` I was about to add , '' he presently goes on , `` I was about to add , respecting this attack , that it was unfortunately simultaneous with a slight misunderstanding between my Lady and myself .
Parsing [sent. 18492 len. 48]: I do not mean that there was any difference between us -LRB- for there has been none -RRB- , but that there was a misunderstanding of certain circumstances important only to ourselves , which deprives me , for a little while , of my Lady 's society .
Parsing [sent. 18493 len. 16]: She has found it necessary to make a journey -- I trust will shortly return .
Parsing [sent. 18494 len. 8]: Volumnia , do I make myself intelligible ?
Parsing [sent. 18495 len. 16]: The words are not quite under my command in the manner of pronouncing them . ''
Parsing [sent. 18496 len. 25]: Volumnia understands him perfectly , and in truth be delivers himself with far greater plainness than could have been supposed possible a minute ago .
Parsing [sent. 18497 len. 19]: The effort by which he does so is written in the anxious and labouring expression of his face .
Parsing [sent. 18498 len. 13]: Nothing but the strength of his purpose enables him to make it .
Parsing [sent. 18499 len. 136]: `` Therefore , Volumnia , I desire to say in your presence -- and in the presence of my old retainer and friend , Mrs. Rouncewell , whose truth and fidelity no one can question , and in the presence of her son George , who comes back like a familiar recollection of my youth in the home of my ancestors at Chesney Wold -- in case I should relapse , in case I should not recover , in case I should lose both my speech and the power of writing , though I hope for better things -- '' The old housekeeper weeping silently ; Volumnia in the greatest agitation , with the freshest bloom on her cheeks ; the trooper with his arms folded and his head a little bent , respectfully attentive .
Parsing [sent. 18500 len. 35]: `` Therefore I desire to say , and to call you all to witness -- beginning , Volumnia , with yourself , most solemnly -- that I am on unaltered terms with Lady Dedlock .
Parsing [sent. 18501 len. 11]: That I assert no cause whatever of complaint against her .
Parsing [sent. 18502 len. 18]: That I have ever had the strongest affection for her , and that I retain it undiminished .
Parsing [sent. 18503 len. 10]: Say this to herself , and to every one .
Parsing [sent. 18504 len. 19]: If you ever say less than this , you will be guilty of deliberate falsehood to me . ''
Parsing [sent. 18505 len. 13]: Volumnia tremblingly protests that she will observe his injunctions to the letter .
Parsing [sent. 18506 len. 43]: `` My Lady is too high in position , too handsome , too accomplished , too superior in most respects to the best of those by whom she is surrounded , not to have her enemies and traducers , I dare say .
Parsing [sent. 18507 len. 37]: Let it be known to them , as I make it known to you , that being of sound mind , memory , and understanding , I revoke no disposition I have made in her favour .
Parsing [sent. 18508 len. 10]: I abridge nothing I have ever bestowed upon her .
Parsing [sent. 18509 len. 41]: I am on unaltered terms with her , and I recall -- having the full power to do it if I were so disposed , as you see -- no act I have done for her advantage and happiness . ''
Parsing [sent. 18510 len. 33]: His formal array of words might have at any other time , as it has often had , something ludicrous in it , but at this time it is serious and affecting .
Parsing [sent. 18511 len. 37]: His noble earnestness , his fidelity , his gallant shielding of her , his generous conquest of his own wrong and his own pride for her sake , are simply honourable , manly , and true .
Parsing [sent. 18512 len. 28]: Nothing less worthy can be seen through the lustre of such qualities in the commonest mechanic , nothing less worthy can be seen in the best-born gentleman .
Parsing [sent. 18513 len. 20]: In such a light both aspire alike , both rise alike , both children of the dust shine equally .
Parsing [sent. 18514 len. 41]: Overpowered by his exertions , he lays his head back on his pillows and closes his eyes for not more than a minute , when he again resumes his watching of the weather and his attention to the muffled sounds .
Parsing [sent. 18515 len. 26]: In the rendering of those little services , and in the manner of their acceptance , the trooper has become installed as necessary to him .
Parsing [sent. 18516 len. 11]: Nothing has been said , but it is quite understood .
Parsing [sent. 18517 len. 23]: He falls a step or two backward to be out of sight and mounts guard a little behind his mother 's chair .
Parsing [sent. 18518 len. 8]: The day is now beginning to decline .
Parsing [sent. 18519 len. 31]: The mist and the sleet into which the snow has all resolved itself are darker , and the blaze begins to tell more vividly upon the room walls and furniture .
Parsing [sent. 18520 len. 49]: The gloom augments ; the bright gas springs up in the streets ; and the pertinacious oil lamps which yet hold their ground there , with their source of life half frozen and half thawed , twinkle gaspingly like fiery fish out of water -- as they are .
Parsing [sent. 18521 len. 49]: The world , which has been rumbling over the straw and pulling at the bell , `` to inquire , '' begins to go home , begins to dress , to dine , to discuss its dear friend with all the last new modes , as already mentioned .
Parsing [sent. 18522 len. 16]: Now does Sir Leicester become worse , restless , uneasy , and in great pain .
Parsing [sent. 18523 len. 32]: Volumnia , lighting a candle -LRB- with a predestined aptitude for doing something objectionable -RRB- , is bidden to put it out again , for it is not yet dark enough .
Parsing [sent. 18524 len. 16]: Yet it is very dark too , as dark as it will be all night .
Parsing [sent. 18525 len. 7]: By and by she tries again .
Parsing [sent. 18526 len. 2]: No !
Parsing [sent. 18527 len. 4]: Put it out .
Parsing [sent. 18528 len. 7]: It is not dark enough yet .
Parsing [sent. 18529 len. 25]: His old housekeeper is the first to understand that he is striving to uphold the fiction with himself that it is not growing late .
Parsing [sent. 18530 len. 53]: `` Dear Sir Leicester , my honoured master , '' she softly whispers , `` I must , for your own good , and my duty , take the freedom of begging and praying that you will not lie here in the lone darkness watching and waiting and dragging through the time .
Parsing [sent. 18531 len. 19]: Let me draw the curtains , and light the candles , and make things more comfortable about you .
Parsing [sent. 18532 len. 23]: The church-clocks will strike the hours just the same , Sir Leicester , and the night will pass away just the same .
Parsing [sent. 18533 len. 11]: My Lady will come back , just the same . ''
Parsing [sent. 18534 len. 22]: `` I know it , Mrs. Rouncewell , but I am weak -- and he has been so long gone . ''
Parsing [sent. 18535 len. 9]: `` Not so very long , Sir Leicester .
Parsing [sent. 18536 len. 6]: Not twenty-four hours yet . ''
Parsing [sent. 18537 len. 8]: `` But that is a long time .
Parsing [sent. 18538 len. 9]: Oh , it is a long time ! ''
Parsing [sent. 18539 len. 11]: He says it with a groan that wrings her heart .
Parsing [sent. 18540 len. 30]: She knows that this is not a period for bringing the rough light upon him ; she thinks his tears too sacred to be seen , even by her .
Parsing [sent. 18541 len. 34]: Therefore she sits in the darkness for a while without a word , then gently begins to move about , now stirring the fire , now standing at the dark window looking out .
Parsing [sent. 18542 len. 25]: Finally he tells her , with recovered self-command , `` As you say , Mrs. Rouncewell , it is no worse for being confessed .
Parsing [sent. 18543 len. 11]: It is getting late , and they are not come .
Parsing [sent. 18544 len. 5]: Light the room ! ''
Parsing [sent. 18545 len. 19]: When it is lighted and the weather shut out , it is only left to him to listen .
Parsing [sent. 18546 len. 38]: But they find that however dejected and ill he is , he brightens when a quiet pretence is made of looking at the fires in her rooms and being sure that everything is ready to receive her .
Parsing [sent. 18547 len. 18]: Poor pretence as it is , these allusions to her being expected keep up hope within him .
Parsing [sent. 18548 len. 10]: Midnight comes , and with it the same blank .
Parsing [sent. 18549 len. 41]: The carriages in the streets are few , and other late sounds in that neighbourhood there are none , unless a man so very nomadically drunk as to stray into the frigid zone goes brawling and bellowing along the pavement .
Parsing [sent. 18550 len. 21]: Upon this wintry night it is so still that listening to the intense silence is like looking at intense darkness .
Parsing [sent. 18551 len. 29]: If any distant sound be audible in this case , it departs through the gloom like a feeble light in that , and all is heavier than before .
Parsing [sent. 18552 len. 37]: The corporation of servants are dismissed to bed -LRB- not unwilling to go , for they were up all last night -RRB- , and only Mrs. Rouncewell and George keep watch in Sir Leicester 's room .
Parsing [sent. 18553 len. 44]: As the night lags tardily on -- or rather when it seems to stop altogether , at between two and three o'clock -- they find a restless craving on him to know more about the weather , now he can not see it .
Parsing [sent. 18554 len. 56]: Hence George , patrolling regularly every half-hour to the rooms so carefully looked after , extends his march to the hall-door , looks about him , and brings back the best report he can make of the worst of nights , the sleet still falling and even the stone footways lying ankle-deep in icy sludge .
Parsing [sent. 18555 len. 71]: Volumnia , in her room up a retired landing on the stair-case -- the second turning past the end of the carving and gilding , a cousinly room containing a fearful abortion of a portrait of Sir Leicester banished for its crimes , and commanding in the day a solemn yard planted with dried-up shrubs like antediluvian specimens of black tea -- is a prey to horrors of many kinds .
Parsing [sent. 18556 len. 37]: Not last nor least among them , possibly , is a horror of what may befall her little income in the event , as she expresses it , `` of anything happening '' to Sir Leicester .
Parsing [sent. 18557 len. 30]: Anything , in this sense , meaning one thing only ; and that the last thing that can happen to the consciousness of any baronet in the known world .
Parsing [sent. 18558 len. 79]: An effect of these horrors is that Volumnia finds she can not go to bed in her own room or sit by the fire in her own room , but must come forth with her fair head tied up in a profusion of shawl , and her fair form enrobed in drapery , and parade the mansion like a ghost , particularly haunting the rooms , warm and luxurious , prepared for one who still does not return .
Parsing [sent. 18559 len. 75]: Solitude under such circumstances being not to be thought of , Volumnia is attended by her maid , who , impressed from her own bed for that purpose , extremely cold , very sleepy , and generally an injured maid as condemned by circumstances to take office with a cousin , when she had resolved to be maid to nothing less than ten thousand a year , has not a sweet expression of countenance .
Parsing [sent. 18560 len. 44]: The periodical visits of the trooper to these rooms , however , in the course of his patrolling is an assurance of protection and company both to mistress and maid , which renders them very acceptable in the small hours of the night .
Parsing [sent. 18561 len. 74]: Whenever he is heard advancing , they both make some little decorative preparation to receive him ; at other times they divide their watches into short scraps of oblivion and dialogues not wholly free from acerbity , as to whether Miss Dedlock , sitting with her feet upon the fender , was or was not falling into the fire when rescued -LRB- to her great displeasure -RRB- by her guardian genius the maid .
Parsing [sent. 18562 len. 11]: `` How is Sir Leicester now , Mr. George ? ''
Parsing [sent. 18563 len. 10]: inquires Volumnia , adjusting her cowl over her head .
Parsing [sent. 18564 len. 12]: `` Why , Sir Leicester is much the same , miss .
Parsing [sent. 18565 len. 16]: He is very low and ill , and he even wanders a little sometimes . ''
Parsing [sent. 18566 len. 8]: `` Has he asked for me ? ''
Parsing [sent. 18567 len. 4]: inquires Volumnia tenderly .
Parsing [sent. 18568 len. 14]: `` Why , no , I ca n't say he has , miss .
Parsing [sent. 18569 len. 11]: Not within my hearing , that is to say . ''
Parsing [sent. 18570 len. 12]: `` This is a truly sad time , Mr. George . ''
Parsing [sent. 18571 len. 7]: `` It is indeed , miss .
Parsing [sent. 18572 len. 9]: Had n't you better go to bed ? ''
Parsing [sent. 18573 len. 19]: `` You had a deal better go to bed , Miss Dedlock , '' quoth the maid sharply .
Parsing [sent. 18574 len. 5]: But Volumnia answers No !
Parsing [sent. 18575 len. 2]: No !
Parsing [sent. 18576 len. 16]: She may be asked for , she may be wanted at a moment 's notice .
Parsing [sent. 18577 len. 20]: She never should forgive herself `` if anything was to happen '' and she was not on the spot .
Parsing [sent. 18578 len. 47]: She declines to enter on the question , mooted by the maid , how the spot comes to be there , and not in her room -LRB- which is nearer to Sir Leicester 's -RRB- , but staunchly declares that on the spot she will remain .
Parsing [sent. 18579 len. 41]: Volumnia further makes a merit of not having `` closed an eye '' -- as if she had twenty or thirty -- though it is hard to reconcile this statement with her having most indisputably opened two within five minutes .
Parsing [sent. 18580 len. 84]: But when it comes to four o'clock , and still the same blank , Volumnia 's constancy begins to fail her , or rather it begins to strengthen , for she now considers that it is her duty to be ready for the morrow , when much may be expected of her , that , in fact , howsoever anxious to remain upon the spot , it may be required of her , as an act of self-devotion , to desert the spot .
Parsing [sent. 18581 len. 20]: So when the trooper reappears with his , `` Had n't you better go to bed , miss ? ''
Parsing [sent. 18582 len. 25]: and when the maid protests , more sharply than before , `` You had a deal better go to bed , Miss Dedlock ! ''
Parsing [sent. 18583 len. 16]: she meekly rises and says , `` Do with me what you think best ! ''
Parsing [sent. 18584 len. 38]: Mr. George undoubtedly thinks it best to escort her on his arm to the door of her cousinly chamber , and the maid as undoubtedly thinks it best to hustle her into bed with mighty little ceremony .
Parsing [sent. 18585 len. 22]: Accordingly , these steps are taken ; and now the trooper , in his rounds , has the house to himself .
Parsing [sent. 18586 len. 8]: There is no improvement in the weather .
Parsing [sent. 18587 len. 25]: From the portico , from the eaves , from the parapet , from every ledge and post and pillar , drips the thawed snow .
Parsing [sent. 18588 len. 41]: It has crept , as if for shelter , into the lintels of the great door -- under it , into the corners of the windows , into every chink and crevice of retreat , and there wastes and dies .
Parsing [sent. 18589 len. 40]: It is falling still ; upon the roof , upon the skylight , even through the skylight , and drip , drip , drip , with the regularity of the Ghost 's Walk , on the stone floor below .
Parsing [sent. 18590 len. 44]: The trooper , his old recollections awakened by the solitary grandeur of a great house -- no novelty to him once at Chesney Wold -- goes up the stairs and through the chief rooms , holding up his light at arm 's length .
Parsing [sent. 18591 len. 90]: Thinking of his varied fortunes within the last few weeks , and of his rustic boyhood , and of the two periods of his life so strangely brought together across the wide intermediate space ; thinking of the murdered man whose image is fresh in his mind ; thinking of the lady who has disappeared from these very rooms and the tokens of whose recent presence are all here ; thinking of the master of the house upstairs and of the foreboding , `` Who will tell him ! ''
Parsing [sent. 18592 len. 39]: he looks here and looks there , and reflects how he MIGHT see something now , which it would tax his boldness to walk up to , lay his hand upon , and prove to be a fancy .
Parsing [sent. 18593 len. 29]: But it is all blank , blank as the darkness above and below , while he goes up the great staircase again , blank as the oppressive silence .
Parsing [sent. 18594 len. 11]: `` All is still in readiness , George Rouncewell ? ''
Parsing [sent. 18595 len. 10]: `` Quite orderly and right , Sir Leicester . ''
Parsing [sent. 18596 len. 8]: `` No word of any kind ? ''
Parsing [sent. 18597 len. 6]: The trooper shakes his head .
Parsing [sent. 18598 len. 11]: `` No letter that can possibly have been overlooked ? ''
Parsing [sent. 18599 len. 21]: But he knows there is no such hope as that and lays his head down without looking for an answer .
Parsing [sent. 18600 len. 53]: Very familiar to him , as he said himself some hours ago , George Rouncewell lifts him into easier positions through the long remainder of the blank wintry night , and equally familiar with his unexpressed wish , extinguishes the light and undraws the curtains at the first late break of day .
Parsing [sent. 18601 len. 7]: The day comes like a phantom .
Parsing [sent. 18602 len. 36]: Cold , colourless , and vague , it sends a warning streak before it of a deathlike hue , as if it cried out , `` Look what I am bringing you who watch there !
Parsing [sent. 18603 len. 6]: Who will tell him ! ''
Parsing [sent. 18604 len. 34]: Chapter LIX -- Esther 's Narrative It was three o'clock in the morning when the houses outside London did at last begin to exclude the country and to close us in with streets .
Parsing [sent. 18605 len. 41]: We had made our way along roads in a far worse condition than when we had traversed them by daylight , both the fall and the thaw having lasted ever since ; but the energy of my companion never slackened .
Parsing [sent. 18606 len. 27]: It had only been , as I thought , of less assistance than the horses in getting us on , and it had often aided them .
Parsing [sent. 18607 len. 66]: They had stopped exhausted halfway up hills , they had been driven through streams of turbulent water , they had slipped down and become entangled with the harness ; but he and his little lantern had been always ready , and when the mishap was set right , I had never heard any variation in his cool , `` Get on , my lads ! ''
Parsing [sent. 18608 len. 18]: The steadiness and confidence with which he had directed our journey back I could not account for .
Parsing [sent. 18609 len. 21]: Never wavering , he never even stopped to make an inquiry until we were within a few miles of London .
Parsing [sent. 18610 len. 33]: A very few words , here and there , were then enough for him ; and thus we came , at between three and four o'clock in the morning , into Islington .
Parsing [sent. 18611 len. 29]: I will not dwell on the suspense and anxiety with which I reflected all this time that we were leaving my mother farther and farther behind every minute .
Parsing [sent. 18612 len. 41]: I think I had some strong hope that he must be right and could not fail to have a satisfactory object in following this woman , but I tormented myself with questioning it and discussing it during the whole journey .
Parsing [sent. 18613 len. 43]: What was to ensue when we found her and what could compensate us for this loss of time were questions also that I could not possibly dismiss ; my mind was quite tortured by long dwelling on such reflections when we stopped .
Parsing [sent. 18614 len. 11]: We stopped in a high-street where there was a coach-stand .
Parsing [sent. 18615 len. 55]: My companion paid our two drivers , who were as completely covered with splashes as if they had been dragged along the roads like the carriage itself , and giving them some brief direction where to take it , lifted me out of it and into a hackney-coach he had chosen from the rest .
Parsing [sent. 18616 len. 7]: `` Why , my dear ! ''
Parsing [sent. 18617 len. 7]: he said as he did this .
Parsing [sent. 18618 len. 7]: `` How wet you are ! ''
Parsing [sent. 18619 len. 8]: I had not been conscious of it .
Parsing [sent. 18620 len. 42]: But the melted snow had found its way into the carriage , and I had got out two or three times when a fallen horse was plunging and had to be got up , and the wet had penetrated my dress .
Parsing [sent. 18621 len. 41]: I assured him it was no matter , but the driver , who knew him , would not be dissuaded by me from running down the street to his stable , whence he brought an armful of clean dry straw .
Parsing [sent. 18622 len. 19]: They shook it out and strewed it well about me , and I found it warm and comfortable .
Parsing [sent. 18623 len. 24]: `` Now , my dear , '' said Mr. Bucket , with his head in at the window after I was shut up .
Parsing [sent. 18624 len. 10]: `` We 're a-going to mark this person down .
Parsing [sent. 18625 len. 14]: It may take a little time , but you do n't mind that .
Parsing [sent. 18626 len. 11]: You 're pretty sure that I 've got a motive .
Parsing [sent. 18627 len. 5]: Ai n't you ? ''
Parsing [sent. 18628 len. 31]: I little thought what it was , little thought in how short a time I should understand it better , but I assured him that I had confidence in him .
Parsing [sent. 18629 len. 13]: `` So you may have , my dear , '' he returned .
Parsing [sent. 18630 len. 7]: `` And I tell you what !
Parsing [sent. 18631 len. 27]: If you only repose half as much confidence in me as I repose in you after what I 've experienced of you , that 'll do .
Parsing [sent. 18632 len. 2]: Lord !
Parsing [sent. 18633 len. 7]: You 're no trouble at all .
Parsing [sent. 18634 len. 37]: I never see a young woman in any station of society -- and I 've seen many elevated ones too -- conduct herself like you have conducted yourself since you was called out of your bed .
Parsing [sent. 18635 len. 27]: You 're a pattern , you know , that 's what you are , '' said Mr. Bucket warmly ; `` you 're a pattern . ''
Parsing [sent. 18636 len. 31]: I told him I was very glad , as indeed I was , to have been no hindrance to him , and that I hoped I should be none now .
Parsing [sent. 18637 len. 41]: `` My dear , '' he returned , `` when a young lady is as mild as she 's game , and as game as she 's mild , that 's all I ask , and more than I expect .
Parsing [sent. 18638 len. 16]: She then becomes a queen , and that 's about what you are yourself . ''
Parsing [sent. 18639 len. 31]: With these encouraging words -- they really were encouraging to me under those lonely and anxious circumstances -- he got upon the box , and we once more drove away .
Parsing [sent. 18640 len. 27]: Where we drove I neither knew then nor have ever known since , but we appeared to seek out the narrowest and worst streets in London .
Parsing [sent. 18641 len. 30]: Whenever I saw him directing the driver , I was prepared for our descending into a deeper complication of such streets , and we never failed to do so .
Parsing [sent. 18642 len. 20]: Sometimes we emerged upon a wider thoroughfare or came to a larger building than the generality , well lighted .
Parsing [sent. 18643 len. 25]: Then we stopped at offices like those we had visited when we began our journey , and I saw him in consultation with others .
Parsing [sent. 18644 len. 23]: Sometimes he would get down by an archway or at a street corner and mysteriously show the light of his little lantern .
Parsing [sent. 18645 len. 23]: This would attract similar lights from various dark quarters , like so many insects , and a fresh consultation would be held .
Parsing [sent. 18646 len. 14]: By degrees we appeared to contract our search within narrower and easier limits .
Parsing [sent. 18647 len. 22]: Single police-officers on duty could now tell Mr. Bucket what he wanted to know and point to him where to go .
Parsing [sent. 18648 len. 33]: At last we stopped for a rather long conversation between him and one of these men , which I supposed to be satisfactory from his manner of nodding from time to time .
Parsing [sent. 18649 len. 15]: When it was finished he came to me looking very busy and very attentive .

Parsing [sent. 18888 len. 24]: and Mr. Bucket added , `` You 'll be better with us , we may want you ; do n't lose time ! ''
Parsing [sent. 18889 len. 10]: I have the most confused impressions of that walk .
Parsing [sent. 18890 len. 39]: I recollect that it was neither night nor day , that morning was dawning but the street-lamps were not yet put out , that the sleet was still falling and that all the ways were deep with it .
Parsing [sent. 18891 len. 11]: I recollect a few chilled people passing in the streets .
Parsing [sent. 18892 len. 36]: I recollect the wet house-tops , the clogged and bursting gutters and water-spouts , the mounds of blackened ice and snow over which we passed , the narrowness of the courts by which we went .
Parsing [sent. 18893 len. 76]: At the same time I remember that the poor girl seemed to be yet telling her story audibly and plainly in my hearing , that I could feel her resting on my arm , that the stained house-fronts put on human shapes and looked at me , that great water-gates seemed to be opening and closing in my head or in the air , and that the unreal things were more substantial than the real .
Parsing [sent. 18894 len. 29]: At last we stood under a dark and miserable covered way , where one lamp was burning over an iron gate and where the morning faintly struggled in .
Parsing [sent. 18895 len. 5]: The gate was closed .
Parsing [sent. 18896 len. 58]: Beyond it was a burial ground -- a dreadful spot in which the night was very slowly stirring , but where I could dimly see heaps of dishonoured graves and stones , hemmed in by filthy houses with a few dull lights in their windows and on whose walls a thick humidity broke out like a disease .
Parsing [sent. 18897 len. 48]: On the step at the gate , drenched in the fearful wet of such a place , which oozed and splashed down everywhere , I saw , with a cry of pity and horror , a woman lying -- Jenny , the mother of the dead child .

Parsing [sent. 19350 len. 2]: Yes .
Parsing [sent. 19351 len. 4]: Skimpole perceives them .
Parsing [sent. 19352 len. 4]: What are they ?
Parsing [sent. 19353 len. 66]: Skimpole reasons with himself , this is a tamed lynx , an active police-officer , an intelligent man , a person of a peculiarly directed energy and great subtlety both of conception and execution , who discovers our friends and enemies for us when they run away , recovers our property for us when we are robbed , avenges us comfortably when we are murdered .
Parsing [sent. 19354 len. 39]: This active police-officer and intelligent man has acquired , in the exercise of his art , a strong faith in money ; he finds it very useful to him , and he makes it very useful to society .
